More than a millennium ago, during the Tang Dynasty in China, someone had the bright idea to take fermented milk and ground rice, stir in dragon brain fragments — a k a camphor — and submerge the mixture in a pool of ice. The mothball-scented confection apparently pleased the emperor.

You can’t make grilled pomegranate-glazed chicken without a grill. But you can still make excellent pomegranate-glazed chicken thighs in your oven. They won’t benefit from the smokiness of charcoal, but will still have plenty of tangy, complex, fruity flavor from the glaze. It’s a dish worth making. To do so, preheat your oven to 450 degrees and spread the chicken thighs on a baking pan. Roast, turning once, until brown, crisp-skinned and cooked through, 25 to 35 minutes. Then follow the rest of the recipe from that point and dig in.
Having already suffered years of war, many Somalians are now fleeing the most severe drought the region has known in 60 years.

Into the summer squall of new phone plans, add Virgin Mobile (is owned by Sprint), which is changing the price of its no-contract plans. The change raises the prices of two tiers of service but lowers the cost for the unlimited voice plan. Data remains unlimited in all of the plans.

By midnight Friday, the New York City Campaign Finance Board will post the latest six-month fundraising figures for candidates considering a run in 2013. And already, the leading contenders to succeed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg have trumpeted their numbers, topped by the City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who pulled in $1.3 million, and the city’s comptroller, John C. Liu, who had $1 million.

The world’s forests are magnificent palaces of biodiversity, teeming with wacky and wonderful creatures and plants that seem otherworldly. But they’re also something far more mundane although useful: they’re giant sponges, soaking up vast amounts of carbon dioxide.

If you haven’t thought about cooking with sage since Thanksgiving, now is a good time to think again. Fresh sage is great in a lot of summer dishes, from pastas to vegetables. You can get it at the farmers’ market, or in the supermarket in those annoying little plastic clamshells. Or ask your friend with the garden for a little bunch. But a little pot of sage wouldn’t go amiss on a sunny city kitchen windowsill, along with a thyme plant and a pot of rosemary. For a small investment you’ll have the sprig or two you need when you need it, ready to snip.
SANDWICH, England — If things continue the way they’ve been going the first two days of the British Open for Phil Mickelson, he might be able to market a recipe for a golf memory cleanser.

Among the challenges for Tim Pawlenty as he runs for president has been building a national network of donors that goes beyond the core of supporters he developed and nurtured as governor of Minnesota.
The European bank stress test results are out, and we are told that all but eight — or is it nine? — banks passed.

The hacking scandal that has roiled Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation reached his American media empire for the first time on Friday, claiming the publisher of The Wall Street Journal, who has resigned.

The Greek dip skordalia is most easily described as eggless mayonnaise, but it’s so much better than that. Unlike “real” mayonnaise — an emulsion of egg (or just yolk), vinegar and lots of oil — skordalia consists mainly of nuts, with just a little oil and moistened bread, or potato, as a binder. Purée these ingredients with garlic and stock or milk (the latter is creamier, obviously), and you end up with a thick, silky and, most importantly, intensely flavorful sauce that’s terrific with crudités.
Mark Bittman pairs a flavorful Greek dip with cold cooked chicken, one of his favorite recipes from the Minimalist archives.
Five months after the armed uprising erupted in Libya, a fresh round of the weapons have been slipping from storage bunkers captured by rebels.

The Belgian designer Raf Simons named his three-day mini-festival “Transmission” to convey how the participants convert the dynamic contradictions and contagious energy of Berlin’s creative scene into art. “Transmission” is the first installment of “The Avant-Garde Diaries,” a series of Mercedes-Benz sponsored cultural events to be curated by Simons that the car company will host in cities all over the world. For Berlin, Simons selected a group of artists who are inspired by the city but who are not necessarily based here, including the graphic designer Peter Saville, the industrial designer Konstantin Grcic, the Scottish dancer and choreographer Michael Clark, the British writer Jo-Ann Furniss, These New Puritans (a band from Southend-on-Sea), the Belgian artist Peter de Potter and New York’s very own Fischerspooner. “Transmission” also features a sampling of Simons’s favorite horror films. The show is physically situated in the Berlin Congress Center, with events running from noon to midnight. Theavantgardediaries.com, a digital magazine, will broadcast the key events for non-Berliners and introduce readers to the artists involved. Simons sat down with The Moment just hours before the opening to discuss Berlin’s significance as a contemporary creative hub.Q.How many cities will be involved in this project?

Two more members of the board of New York City Opera have resigned in the wake of the company’s departure from Lincoln Center and artistic changes. Jonathan Sheffer, a conductor and composer who had been a trustee for two years, said on Friday he stepped down 10 days ago, but not because of the move. “I really felt at odds with the company’s artistic direction,” he said, adding that it had “broken faith with the audience.” The general and artistic director, George Steel, has been criticized by some for neglecting more traditional productions in favor of the offbeat.

There’s major turnover on the manga list this week with eight new additions. Only Naruto, a regular of the list, and Vampire Knight, about an academy whose evening students are creatures of the night, remain from the previous week. I’ve had difficulty reading manga: the traditional right-to-left layouts often confuse me and many series that are at Volume 50 or higher make me feel late to the party. Of the new books this week, Dengeki Daisy has a “Ghost” or “Sixth Sense” vibe to it. The series is about Teru Kurebayashi, who after the death of her brother has been receiving comforting messages from the mysterious Daisy, who communicates through her brother’s cell phone. Spooky! Volume 5 enters our list at No. 8 this week.

Commercial theater producers seeking to make money off Shakespeare usually stick to tried-and-true audience draws like “Hamlet” or “Macbeth,” but even those can be financially risky without a celebrity in the title role. (Last season’s critically acclaimed “Merchant of Venice,” starring Al Pacino, narrowly turned a profit.) Next month, however, a group of commercial producers will try to make a go of “Cymbeline,” one of Shakespeare’s trickier tragic romances — though with a staging that received strong notices from critics this winter.

In 1972 the Los Angeles Dodgers bucked seven decades of baseball precedent and added a fifth starting pitcher to their rotation. The quintet of Don Sutton, Claude Osteen, Al Downing, Tommy John and Bill Singer portended the future, and by the end of the decade the once revolutionary five-man rotation was adopted leaguewide.

The third installment of Sean Hanratty’s summer playlist is brought to you by the Los Angeles producers (and former violinists) Daniel Pineda and Asma Maroof, a k a Nguzunguzu. The group, which takes its name from a traditional Solomon Island figurehead used to protect against supernatural forces during canoe trips, offers a unique blend of R&B, house, cumbia and tribal music. They are known for improvising with, well, really weird sounds achieved through electronic instruments and a room full of synthesizers, as well as for an energy that Hanratty says is “incredible.” Pineda and Maroof, who have worked closely with the Sri Lankan songstress M.I.A., recently kicked off a tour with Gang Gang Dance and Total Freedom, and will be at Santos Party House on Thursday, July 21. (They are rumored to be playing the Capsule after-party on Monday, July 18!?)

Very soon, the military will signal that it has prepared itself for the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy. This policy, in effect since the early days of the Clinton administration, allows gays and lesbians to serve as long as they do not identify themselves as such in public. Before signing the repeal into law, President Obama asked the military to take a reasonable amount of time to teach and train its soldiers about the policy changes. The military responded with a goal of training all currently serving soldiers by July 15. So far, that training has been delivered to nearly 95 percent of the military. Repeal could be final by the fall.

This Sunday marks the first of the New Amsterdam “market specials,” an occasional series that will bring chefs and food purveyors to New York’s original market district,  located at the Old Fulton Fish Market on South Street and Peck Slip in Lower Manhattan.  From 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. at the market, Russ & Daughters will sell the short-seasoned Hollandse Nieuwe, or New Catch Holland Herring, with traditional garnishes: chopped raw onion and cornichons ($8). P&H Soda Company will sell house-made soft drinks ($3) to accompany the herring, and for dessert, Marja Samson is making poffertjes ($5), a traditional Dutch street food. Starting at noon, Pasanella and Son (115 South Street, across the street from the market) will pour small, complimentary shots of aquavit.

One of the pleasures (and pains) of going to the theater for many years is watching actors get older and grow up -– or not, as the case may be. Take Rupert Everett. The rakish, indignantly handsome Mr. Everett made his mark in theater 30 years ago in his early 20’s in Julian Mitchell’s “Another Country,” portraying a rebellious child of privilege with an aristocratic profile and a smoldering case of the sulks. As time passed, whenever Mr. Everett (who became a minor film star) returned to the theater, he continued to portray much the same person, but in a state of arrested development, like the drug-addicted, mother-fixated son in Noël Coward’s “Vortex” (1989) or a debonaire middle-aged but boyish Charles Condomine in Coward’s “Blithe Spirit,” on Broadway two years ago.

All too often, the jewelry that we see at fashion shows makes it only to the end of the runway and back. Thankfully, the owl pin designed by Alexis Bittar for Jason Wu — the one that adorned Wu’s fall peacoats and blazers — is very much real and ours for the buying, arriving in stores on Friday. Fans will recognize the owl, a k a Miss Wu, the designer’s muse and logo (“perhaps because of too many late nights sketching,” Wu says), and also appreciate Bittar’s gutsy take on it. Inspired by the photographer Robert Polidori’s book on the restoration of Versailles, “Parcours Museologique Reviste” (Steidl), the two fell hard for the contrast between grand décor and raw metals. “I love the juxtaposition,” says Wu, who calls his fall collection Baroque Sportswear. “The piece combines opulence with early ’90s grunge,” Bittar says. “And a sense of raw romanticism,” Wu adds. “A perfect complement to the clothes.”

The Travel Almanac, the newest of a growing crop of compact niche magazines (see: Apartamento, Boat and Afterzine), looks at the art of travel through the perspectives of artists, musicians, writers and filmmakers who are well, well-traveled. The journal was founded two years ago by Paul Kominek, a musician and sometime D.J. from Germany, with the help of his friend John Roberts, an American musician who, like Kominek, lives in Berlin. “By using the topic of traveling as an overarching theme, it gave us an amazing excuse to ask high-profile artists or cultural icons questions that avoid the obligatory ‘What do you do?’ and ‘How did you get started?’ and instead ask about different aspects of their lives that we personally find more interesting,” says Kominek. The first volume, on Japan, debuted this spring. The cover is printed on textured German cardstock, the interior pages on creamy Swedish drawing paper. It features tips from the likes of David Lynch, James Murphy and Javier Peres, as well as some handsome photographs of traditional Japanese inns, called “ryokans.” T turned the tables on Kominek and asked for his own travel preferences, and his Berlin mainstays.

The French famously take jazz very seriously, and have for decades warmly welcomed American musicians to their country. So it comes as no surprise that a tribute to one of the greatest of them all, Miles Davis, will take place at the Olympia Theater (28, boulevard des Capucines; 33-892-683-368) on Monday, July 18. Three of his band’s most famous alumni, the pianist and composer Herbie Hancock, the bassist Marcus Miller and the saxophonist Wayne Shorter will be on hand to celebrate him.

LYONS--Donald, 73, died July 12 at home in New York City. His friends will remember his brilliant wit, divers talents, colossal erudition, and love of hoi polloi. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

Mexican soldiers on patrol Tuesday found 300 acres of eight-feet-tall marijuana plants growing in the desert in Baja California State, about 220 miles south of Tijuana. Gen. Alfonso Duarte said the plantation was being tended by dozens of men, most of whom fled. Six suspects were later arrested at a military checkpoint.

''Go through the park,'' Dudley Moore slurs to his chauffeur in the 1981 film ''Arthur,'' his character giddy and drunk and in need of simple and profound pleasure. ''You know how I love the park.'' I've always felt the same way: Driving through Central Park is one of the true guilty pleasures of living and driving in New York City.

WANDERMAN--Alice, 81, of Boca Raton, FL died on July 13, after a 3-year battle with esophageal cancer. Wed 60 years, her husband Bob, daughters Karen and Wendy, son Mark, daughter-in-law Kris, grandsons Nathan, Max and Jack, and sisters Elaine and Naomi survive her. She graduated from NYU, raised her children, began a doll business with Bob, got an MBA at Adelphi, and became an administrator at the New School for Social Research. She marched against the Vietnam War, was an outspoken liberal, an active member of the Democratic Party and above all a supporter of Israel. She loved tennis, hiking, travel, theatre, ballet, film, art museums, classical music, playing bridge, chatting with friends and reading the NY Times. No words are adequate to express how much she will be missed by all who knew her. Donations made to Jewish Federation of South Palm Beach County are welcome.

SANDWICH, England -- When Jerry Kelly learned that he would be hitting the opening tee shot in the British Open on Thursday at 6:30 a.m. local time, he was amused. After all, eight years should be long enough for the pain to subside from the not-so-funny episode that happened here in 2003. That was when, on the first hole, Kelly drove the ball into the rough, slashed his way to an 11, wound up hurting his shoulder, shot 86 and withdrew after one round.
9:16 p.m. | Updated BHP Billiton said Thursday that it would buy Petrohawk Energy for about $12.1 billion in cash, as the mining giant continues its quest for shale natural gas assets.

An architecture review and two picture captions on Wednesday about the CCTV building in Beijing, the headquarters of China Central Television, omitted one of the architects. Besides Rem Koolhaas, Ole Scheeren also designed the building.

LOS ANGELES -- California will become the first state to require public schools to teach gay and lesbian history. As expected, Gov. Jerry Brown signed a bill on Thursday that mandates that the contributions of gays and lesbians in the state and the country be included in social science instruction and in textbooks. School districts will have until next January to begin implementing the new law, which was also promoted in part as a way to combat bullying of gay and lesbian students.

The Books of The Times review last Friday, about ''Reasonable Doubt: The Fashion Writer, Cape Cod, and The Trial of Chris McCowen,'' by Peter Manso, erroneously attributed to Mr. Manso comments about the district attorney who was the prosecutor when Mr. McCowen was tried for the murder of the fashion writer Christa Worthington. While Mr. Manso wrote that the district attorney came to be perceived as a ''wacko'' and ''the DA who couldn't keep his zipper shut,'' he did not call him those things himself.

SHERMAN--Diane N. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express profound sorrow at the loss of a beloved longtime friend, Diane Sherman of Chicago and Rancho Mirage, Calif. Together with her husband Leonard, a former ATS national president, Mrs. Sherman was a steadfast supporter of the Technion and Israel, and a Technion Guardian, a distinction reserved for those who have reached the highest level of commitment to the university. Among the significant Technion projects the Shermans funded are the Leonard and Diane Sherman Interdisciplinary Graduate School Fellowships, the Leonard and Diane Sherman Environmental Engineering Center, the Leonard and Diane Sherman Center for Research in Biomaterials, and the Leonard and Diane Sherman Dormitory. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Leonard, son David Sherman and daughter Mimi Sherman Timins, and the entire Sherman family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Joel S. Rothman, President Joan Seidel, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

An article on Thursday about the fiscal record of the presidential candidate Tim Pawlenty, a former governor of Minnesota, misidentified the branch of the state Legislature in which a lawmaker, Patrick Garofalo, serves. Mr. Garofalo, who said Mr. Pawlenty had outfoxed Democrats in 2009 in maneuvering over the state budget, is a member of the state House of Representatives, not a state senator.

SANDWICH, England -- The knock on Rory McIlroy, back when there were any knocks on him, was that he did not deal well with adversity, that he would sometimes quit on a bad round or would try so hard to bring it around that it was almost as bad. There was a time Thursday at the British Open when McIlroy had ample opportunity to do either. But he did neither. After he bogeyed two of the first three holes, missing an 8-foot comebacker at No. 1 and pushing a 4-footer at No. 3, it was cold, blowing about 25 miles per hour and threatening rain.

Kip Tiernan was dumbfounded when she saw women disguising themselves as men to get a meal at a men-only homeless shelter in Boston nearly 40 years ago -- so much so that she went ahead and founded the nation's first homeless shelter for women. Ms. Tiernan died at 85 at her home in Boston on July 2. The cause was cancer, said Sue Marsh, the executive director of Rosie's Place, the shelter Ms. Tiernan started in 1974.

An article on Thursday about two studies that found that a daily pill could prevent H.I.V. infections in heterosexuals described incorrectly an earlier study, known as iPrEx, that found similar effects in gay men. Although some of the iPrEx participants were in San Francisco, where the research was based, the study also enrolled participants in other American cities and five other countries; the iPrEx study was not ''conducted among gay men in San Francisco.''

RULON-MILLER--Sumner III, age 73, a man passionately committed to serving his community, died on July 11th in the Bar Harbor Hospital after a quiet battle with prostate cancer. He received an early education at Princeton Country Day, went on to graduate at Proctor Academy in 1957 and Princeton University in 1961. He set up his own insurance business, Rulon Miller Inc. in 1962. His experience at Proctor Academy fostered a lasting interest in education. He is the past chairman of the boards of Proctor Academy and the American School of Tangier. In each case, he led them through challenging times. He is a trustee of the Princeton Club of New York and the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture. He also serves on many boards and is a member of the Racquet & Tennis Club. Recently his passion has been an involvement with the Town of Mount Desert, Maine where he just began serving as a selectman. He is survived by his daughter, Tanya Rulon-Miller Schlemmer of London, England, two grandchildren, Jackson and Lucy and two brothers, Patrick Rulon-Miller of Kingston, NJ and Harry Rulon-Miller of Pennington, NJ. He is also survived by his stepchildren, Daria VanVacas, Irina Redwine, Joshua Prentice and god-children Madeline and Carlo Keep. By his wishes, there is to be a graveside service for the immediate family. Memorial contributions can be sent to the Marion Hatt Scholarship, Proctor Academy, PO Box 389, Andover, N.H. 03216 or the Sumner Scholarship Foundation Inc. c/o Rulon Miller Inc., 531 East 72nd Street, New York, NY 10021.

Alfonso Duarte said the plantation was being tended by dozens of men, most of whom fled. Six suspects were later arrested at a military checkpoint.

In a shake-up of New York's close-knit world of organists and sacred music directors, Kent Tritle is leaving his longtime position as director of music ministries at St. Ignatius Loyola Church to become organist and director of music at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, officials said on Thursday. Mr. Tritle, who is also organist of the New York Philharmonic, has been at St. Ignatius for 22 years, building it into a major center of sacred music in New York. He ran its professional choir, oversaw a parish choir and led more than 400 services a year. He starts at St. John's on Sept. 1. Mr. Tritle replaces Bruce Neswick, who left to teach at Indiana University's Jacobs School of Music.

REISER--Max, on July 13, 2011. Beloved husband of the late Estelle, father of Debra and the late Laurie, uncle and great-uncle. Services today, 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

9:30 P.M. (13) RIGOLETTO FROM MANTUA Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' was filmed on Sept. 4 and 5 in Mantua, Italy, in the locations and at the times specified in the opera's libretto. Plácido Domingo, above, performs the title role of the court jester, who, after publicly ridiculing a nobleman, is punished by courtiers for his insolence. Julia Novikova is his innocent daughter, Gilda; Vittorio Grigolo is the womanizing Duke of Mantua; and Ruggero Raimondi is the assassin Sparafucile. Zubin Mehta conducts the RAI National Symphony Orchestra. Directed by Marco Bellocchio, this ''Great Performances'' presentation is the third of the producer Andrea Andermann's ''Live Films.'' ''Rigoletto,'' Mr. Domingo has said, is the first opera he ever heard. The production was shot at the Palazzo Te, a 16th-century villa built by Giulio Romano for Federico II Gonzaga; the Palazzo Ducale, the main residence of the Gonzagas; and the Fortress of Sparafucile, a former military garrison known as the Rock of Rigoletto. 8 P.M. (NBC) FRIDAY NIGHT LIGHTS This series finale brings decisions that could forever change the lives of Coach Taylor (Kyle Chandler) and his wife, Tami (Connie Britton). Meanwhile the Lions prepare for the Texas high school football championship.

An obituary on June 28 about Norma Lyon, who made butter sculptures of cows at the Iowa State Fair, misstated the time frame during which she began making sculptures of other subjects, and the year she made one of the singer Garth Brooks. Ms. Lyon began expanding her repertory beyond cows in the late 1970s and made a butter sculpture of Mr. Brooks, her first of a living person, in 1994; she did not begin expanding her repertory in 1984 with a sculpture of Mr. Brooks.

ROBINSON--Henrietta Truesdell, passed away on June 27, 2011, after a short illness at the age of 95. Born in New York City on September 20, 1915, she was the daughter of Dr. Edward Delavan Truesdell, a surgeon, and the former Henrietta Norton. Mrs. Robinson graduated from Brearley School and Smith College. In 1941 she married Horace Brookes Blackwell Robinson, former partner at the law firm of Dewey Ballantine. She is survived by three children, Edward T. Robinson, Dr. Thomas D. Robinson, and J. Howland Robinson, and six grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Brick Church, Park Ave. at 91st St., at 3pm on Friday, July 29, 2011. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Brick Church, 62 E. 92nd St., New York, NY 10128, or US English Foundation, Inc., 1747 Pennsylvania Ave, NW, Suite 1050, Washington, DC 20006.

FRIEDLAND--Melvin. With great sadness we mourn the passing of Mel. He was a warm and generous best friend, whose presence at our Shabbat dinners, holiday meals and weekends in Sagaponack added a special dimension to our enjoyment and to our lives. A heavily corrected unfinished draft of an early Jane Austen manuscript sold at auction at Sotheby's in London on Thursday for almost 1 million pounds ($1.6 million), three times the estimated presale price, The Associated Press reported. The draft of ''The Watsons'' went to an unidentified buyer; Sotheby's said it is the only major manuscript by Austen still in private hands. Austen wrote ''The Watsons,'' an unfinished and unpublished novel, in 1804. It is the story of a poverty-stricken young woman whose only friend is her ailing clergyman father. A Sotheby's book specialist, Gabriel Heaton, said the draft ''has afforded an extremely broad audience an insight into the author's process and reworkings.''

WADA--Steve Shigeo, 93, passed away on July 5, 2011. Born in Loomis, California, Steve was raised in Hiroshima, Japan, and served in the U.S. Army in World War II. He studied art on the G.I. Bill of Rights, at the Chicago Art Institute, the Art Students League of New York, and the Atelier Fernand Leger in Paris. In addition to being recognized as one of the finest dental ceramists in the country, he was an artist in media including drawing, painting, calligraphy, graphic art, and photography, and showed his work in one-person and group shows. He was a member of the Art Students League of New York, Artists Equity of New York, Japanese Artists Association of New York, and the Sumi-E Society of America. He was beloved by his extended family and a wide circle of friends for his artistry, his warmth and cheerfulness, and his zest for living. He is survived by his wife, Takako, daughters Stephanie and Jennifer, and grandchildren Esther and Christopher, who love him and miss him very much. A gathering for family and friends will be held on Saturday, July 30, at the Japanese American United Church, 255 Seventh Avenue (24-25 Sts.), 2:00-4:00pm.

'Play Dead' Matinees When is scary too scary? This question often haunts those considering certain entertainment for their children, including thrill rides, movies and TV shows. And it certainly applies to the theater production ''Play Dead,'' which posts a warning in the lobby that ''children should not attend without the knowledge and permission of their parents.'' Nevertheless, ''Play Dead'' has recently devised a familyfriendly matinee. So how friendly is it? If your child is under 12, afraid of the dark or prone to nightmares, don't even think about it. But if you have a jaded middle school or high school student who sneers at the very idea of a magic show, then get thee to the phone, Web or box office immediately: ''Play Dead'' closes on July 24. The show comes across like a séance conducted by a charming and mellifluously voiced psychopath. He is Todd Robbins, who wrote the piece with its director, Teller (of Penn & Teller). Mr. Robbins, above, who warms up his audience by noisily eating a light bulb, performs on a stage holding many cardboard file boxes and one large, coffin-shaped vat, which will at one point contain a theatergoer. He promises ''an afternoon of spooky amusement,'' and boy, does he deliver. Each box, he notes, is a kind of coffin, containing not mortal remains but memorabilia related to real dead people. With the exception of an unfortunate friend of Mr. Robbins's, they make up a most unpleasant lot, including unscrupulous psychics and a murderer of children. (As I said, don't take little ones.)

Two sweeping new HBO dramas, ''Boardwalk Empire'' and ''Game of Thrones,'' will challenge AMC's three-time winner ''Mad Men'' for the title of best drama in the 63rd annual Primetime Emmy Awards this year. For the last three seasons, the Red Sox, the Yankees and the Rays have jockeyed among themselves for the American League East title and the A.L.'s wild-card berth, with each team missing the playoffs once. In 2011, these three teams are again atop the East, with the Red Sox leading at the All-Star Game break and the Rays having the most ground to make up. With the trading deadline just a little over two weeks away, playoff contenders will most likely start making moves to upgrade their rosters. To better understand what moves they need to make, I look to how teams have performed batting, pitching and on defense. A variety of techniques are used to quantify these performances, but all are denoted in runs and all are compared with the major league average.

SANDWICH, England - In his 34th British Open, Tom Watson finally got to play with a namesake, and the namesake beat him - at least on Thursday - by seven strokes. ''Tom Lewis, how about that?'' Watson said. ''He could be my grandson.'' Lewis, the 20-year-old British amateur who has a share of the lead with Thomas Bjorn, is 41 years younger than Watson. He showed him plenty of deference before, during and after the first round. ''To play with Tom, no matter what I shot, was going to be excellent,'' Lewis said. ''I was more not wanting to embarrass myself in front of him.'' Lewis accomplished that and much more with his stunning 65. ''He's quite a refined player at age 20,'' Watson said. ''We certainly have a new young breed out here, don't we? We've got the McIlroys and the Ishikawas and the Lewises. We have a lot of young players playing very good golf.'' Unlike Rory McIlroy, the 22-year-old from Northern Ireland, and Ryo Ishikawa, the 19-year-old Japanese star, Lewis is not yet a professional, although he has been a full-time golfer since age 16.

An article on May 17 about the initial denial of bail to Dominique Strauss-Kahn after his arrest on sexual assault charges misstated the nature of a diplomatic arrangement between the United States and France. The two countries have an extradition treaty, though it does not require France to extradite its nationals to the United States; it is not the case that there is no such treaty between the countries. The error was repeated on July 3 in an Op-Ed column about the Strauss-Kahn case. After a reader pointed out the error in that column, editors discovered the error in the earlier news article.

Calling the rising cost of city pensions ''unsustainable,'' Deputy Mayor Robert K. Steel said Thursday that New York City should move swiftly to overhaul its benefit system, including by investing more funds in overseas markets. Mr. Steel, who oversees economic development for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, said moving retiree investments out of American stock markets and into international equities could bring higher returns, helping alleviate some pressure on the city's budget.

The American culture war, that combustible, stupefying cocktail of religion, sex, politics and everything else that gets people hot and bothered, represents a rich vein of satiric and dramatic potential. George Ratliff's ''Salvation Boulevard,'' adapted from a novel by Larry Beinhart (''Wag the Dog''), suggests that it may sometimes be too rich. The movie, set in and around a Sun Belt megachurch with a charismatic pastor, is a console full of jammed and disconnected hot buttons. The exceptional cast does what it can to keep things jumping and grounded, as the tone wobbles from intrigue to farce and back. Pierce Brosnan, as Pastor Dan, who is trying to leverage his spiritual juice into lucrative real estate, has a hearty, sly allure that steers almost entirely clear of caricature. And the best thing about ''Salvation Boulevard'' is its avoidance of condescending stereotypes. Mr. Ratliff, whose earlier films include the documentary ''Hell House,'' is happy to let his fish swim free of their barrel.

Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about an interview with Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo misstated the date of the first day that same sex marriages will be allowed in New York. It is Sunday, July 24 -- not this Sunday, July 17.

STERN--Herman, on July 8, 2011 at almost 96 years of age. Herman (Hank) Stern was a CPA for over 60 years. He served in World War II as 1st Lieutenant in the 2nd Infantry Division, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. His wife of 51 years, Selma, predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by brother Harold and wife Francis, son Robert, daughter Beverly, grandchildren Elizabeth and Michael, and great-grandson Elliott. He had a passion for sports and was an active participant in baseball, racquetball, tennis, bowling, pool, and especially golf. He had a keen mind, doing the Sunday Times puzzle into his 90's, and continuing to do puzzles in his local paper up to the day he passed. He will be sorely missed by family, friends, and associates, all of whom appreciated his intellectual sharpness, sense of humor, kindness and generosity. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to National Brain Tumor Foundation.

Get me to my car, stat. Windows down. Sun roof back. Radio blaring, damaging the already tender speakers. It's where music sounds best, where a new song jumping out of the radio can be enough to put nearby drivers at risk. Two a.m., F.D.R. Drive, ''Make It Rain'' bouncing off the car frame -- that's when things make sense. I grew up in the outer precincts of Brooklyn, and knew how to get places by car long before I got comfortable on the subway. These days I'll take any excuse to drive. There are the long trips out to the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater in Wantagh, N.Y., or the PNC Bank Arts Center in Holmdel, N.J. -- summer tour sheds where critics have to go to criticize. But also quick, unnecessary jaunts up to Patsy's in East Harlem for a midnight pizza, or getting pulled, vacuumlike, into the Midtown Tunnel on the way out to Queens, or on Belt Parkway drives out to Sheepshead Bay and Mill Basin, the neighborhoods I grew up in. Hearing a song in a car is more than listening, it's sound inside body inside sound, impossible to untether (except by a flick of the dial, of course).

Nathan Lane will play one of the stage's great dramatic characters -- the doomed salesman Theodore (Hickey) Hickman -- in the Goodman Theater's revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh'' in spring 2012, the Chicago-based theater announced on Thursday. In an interview, Mr. Lane said that he had never been in a O'Neill play before but that he had long been fascinated by ''Iceman'' and the self-deluding Hickey. In addition, after 30 years of performing on New York stages, he said he was eager for some time away - and had fallen in love with Chicago during the pre-Broadway tryouts there of ''The Producers'' and ''The Addams Family.''

A German billionaire has paid more than 50 million euros ($70 million) to buy an oil painting of the Madonna by Hans Holbein the Younger, Bloomberg News reported. Reinhold Wuerth, a manufacturer of screws and other industrial hardware, bought the painting from the heirs of the princes and landgraves of the state of Hesse, according to an e-mailed statement sent Thursday by Britta Fischer Public Relations on behalf of the Wuerth Collection, Bloomberg reported. The Staedel Museum, where the painting has been displayed since 2003 on long-term loan, said in a statement that it had tried to buy the work itself, but that its offer of 40 million euros ($57 million) was rejected. Christoph Graf Douglas, the art dealer who handled the sale, would not give the final purchase price but said it was more than 50 million euros. The painting, ''The Madonna With the Family of Mayor Meyer,'' from 1525-28, depicts the mayor of Basel's family--to whom it belonged for nearly 100 years--at the feet of the Madonna. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

It has been more than two decades since rock fans could pick up a copy of Creem magazine at a newsstand and submerse themselves in the fabled publication where critics like Lester Bangs and Dave Marsh helped define a generation of popular musicians. But there are plans afoot to resurrect the printed magazine this fall, The Associated Press reported this week. -Jason Turner, the chairman of Creem Enterprises Inc., said the team that has been operating a music Web site under the Creem trademark since 2001 plans to begin publishing a quarterly edition of the magazine sometime in late September.

An article on Saturday about efforts by the European Union to unify laws on consumer protection misstated the history of the Uniform Commercial Code in the United States. The model code was initially published in 1952 and was later adopted with various amendments by each state, a majority doing so in the 1960s; it has not been used by all 50 states since 1952.

My Sunday column is a despairing bleat at the cutbacks in education budgets around the country — including my old school, Yamhill-Carlton High School, here in Yamhill, Oregon. In years of writing about poverty, I’ve come to believe firmly that there are no perfect solutions either in America or abroad — but the closest thing to a silver bullet is an excellent education system. And it is so frustrating that that’s still what’s missing in so many communities.

SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE — If you watch a lot of television, there comes a point in most series where the entertainment level drops precipitously, and that is the point where the show is said to have “jumped the shark.” It might be a case of a specific character doing something that just strains viewers’ credulity, or the entire storyline might just lose its oomph. Either way, it’s a clear signal to everyone involved that it might be time to re-tool the show or pack up their toys and go home.

Regents Canal was built in the early 19th century to carry coal and other goods across northern London. Although its commercial days are long over, it has found a new life as a popular site for boat trips and other leisure activities — among them the Shoreditch Festival, which will run in London’s East End from today to July 24. The festival puts on a colorful — and free — program of entertainment, including theater, dance and musical performances, as well as exploration of East London’s waterways.

There are few series I can think of whose conclusions occasion feelings of sorrow. “The Sopranos” ended amid confusion and awe. We may miss the narrative and the ingeniously black comedy of it all, if not the actual characters, none of whom you really want tucking you into bed at night. The same can be said of “Big Love,” another of the greatest family dramas ever on television. Though we may miss its intelligent social commentary, we do not necessarily pine for the people in it to re-enter our lives. HBO renders characters ambiguously; we are not supposed to fall in love with each and every one of them.

St. Ignatius Loyola, the Roman Catholic church, rests nobly at Park Avenue and 84th Street amid the wealth and power of the Upper East Side. Its music program is equally imposing, an important part of the city's concert scene. Kent Tritle, the organist and choral conductor, has overseen the church's lyrical side for 22 years. It's an established, comfortable perch. But Mr. Tritle is giving it up for roomier, less plush and decidedly non-Catholic confines on the dowdier Upper West Side. He is becoming music director of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, starting on Sept. 1.

With all the chatter about making potential changes to Social Security, many people are probably thinking that they should start collecting benefits as soon as they can. But that would be unwise, at least for many people. And a new calculator from AARP attempts to illustrate why you should wait -- if you can afford to, of course. Figuring out the optimal time to collect benefits is impossible because nobody can predict how long they'll live. Most people follow the bird in the hand philosophy and begin collecting as soon as they're eligible.

An article on the DealBook page on Friday about managed futures funds, which bet on the ups and downs of stocks, bonds, commodities and currencies, misstated the recent performance of one such fund, Altis Partners. The fund's performance -- not its assets -- is down more than 20 percent so far in 2011.

The economy is still suffering from the worst financial crisis since the Depression, and widespread anger persists that financial institutions that caused it received bailouts of billions of taxpayer dollars and haven't been held accountable for any wrongdoing. Yet the House Appropriations Committee has responded by starving the agency responsible for bringing financial wrongdoers to justice -- while putting over $200 million that could otherwise have been spent on investigations and enforcement actions back into the pockets of Wall Street. A few weeks ago, the Republican-controlled appropriations committee cut the Securities and Exchange Commission's fiscal 2012 budget request by $222.5 million, to $1.19 billion (the same as this year's), even though the S.E.C.'s responsibilities were vastly expanded under the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. Charged with protecting investors and policing markets, the S.E.C. is the nation's front-line defense against financial fraud. The committee's accompanying report referred to the agency's ''troubled past'' and ''lack of ability to manage funds,'' and said the committee ''remains concerned with the S.E.C.'s track record in dealing with Ponzi schemes.'' The report stressed, ''With the federal debt exceeding $14 trillion, the committee is committed to reducing the cost and size of government.''

Commercial theater producers seeking to make money off Shakespeare usually stick to tried-and-true audience draws like ''Hamlet'' or ''Macbeth,'' but even those can be financially risky without a celebrity in the title role. (Last season's critically acclaimed ''Merchant of Venice,'' starring Al Pacino, narrowly turned a profit.) Next month, however, a group of commercial producers will try to make a go of ''Cymbeline,'' one of Shakespeare's trickier tragic romances - though with a staging that received strong notices from critics this winter. Fiasco Theater's highly inventive production, featuring six actors in 14 roles and an imaginative set that relied on just two crates, a sheet and a trunk serving many purposes, will begin an 18-week run on Aug. 27 at the Barrow Street Theater. The nonprofit Theater for a New Audience, which presented the earlier, noncommercial production of ''Cymbeline,'' is now undertaking the first commercial run of a Shakespeare play in an Off Broadway house in its 32-year history.

An article on July 8 about the promise and pitfalls of using genetics to detect and treat cancer overstated the legal action taken by relatives of patients who received treatment in a research study at Duke University. The relatives, including Walter Jacobs, whose wife died a few months after treatment, have retained lawyers, but they have not sued Duke.

I am pressing against a secure wall, not daring to step away. The wind is whipping against me -- or is it howling? My feet feel rubbery on the narrow walkway. I think of those balconies on the upper floors of colonial homes in old ports, where pacing wives would gaze out to sea, seeking the long-overdue ships of sailor husbands: widows' walks. If this particular walk were open to an anxiously pacing public, I can only imagine how many new widows and widowers would be left behind. But I look out, and the vision is literally breathtaking, the Hudson shimmering in the west, and a patch of green off to the north -- Central Park -- lying just beyond some half-hearted high-rises. I am standing a floor above the highest observation deck of the Empire State Building just outside a room with cables and communications equipment. The walkway circles around the building's narrow spire, which, in 1930, was envisioned as a mooring mast for dirigibles; as it turned out, only King Kong ever reliably used it for support.

He leaves his parents, Caitlin and David, sister Hannah, and grandparents Alice Daniels, Jim Daniels, Adele and Howard Israel. Funeral services at Larchmont Temple. Sunday, 12pm. Donations to Leo Israel Memorial Fund, 8 Shadow Lane, Larchmont NY 10538 to create a magical playground at his nursery school in his honor.

A theater entry in the Listings pages in some editions on Friday about the Off Broadway musical ''The Magdalene'' was outdated. After the section had gone to press publicists for the show announced that it closed on Wednesday.

Sam Troughton, the actor playing Romeo who was injured on Tuesday during the Royal Shakespeare Company's performance of ''Romeo and Juliet'' at the Park Avenue Armory, has undergone arthroscopic surgery on his knee, according to Nada Zakula, a spokeswoman for the company. She said she did not know if he would be able to return to the role on Sunday, when the next performance is scheduled. The play is being presented as part of the Lincoln Center Festival. When Mr. Troughton was hurt during the Tuesday matinee, the show went on, after a brief delay, with Dyfan Dwyfor filling in as Mr. Troughton went to a hospital. Mr. Dwyfor also played the role Tuesday night. In a statement, Mr. Troughton said: ''My time in New York so far has been brilliant, and performing at the armory for such generous and enthusiastic audiences a thrill, so it is extremely disappointing to have suffered this injury. I'd like to wish Dyfan all the best and thank everyone for their support and good wishes including the fantastic medical team, with whose continued care I intend to defy the stars and return to the stage as soon as possible.''

8:03 p.m. | Updated The billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn sought to put Clorox on the auction block on Friday, offering to buy the households goods maker in a deal that would value it at $10.2 billion, while at the same time encouraging the company to actively seek higher bids.

An article on Page 24 this weekend about the film director Miranda July reverses, in one instance, the first two words in the title of one of her movies. It is ''Me and You and Everyone We Know,'' not ''You and Me.''

Two more members of the board of New York City Opera have resigned in the wake of the company's departure from Lincoln Center and artistic changes. Jonathan Sheffer, a conductor and composer who had been a trustee for two years, said on Friday he stepped down 10 days ago, but not because of the move. ''I really felt at odds with the company's artistic direction,'' he said, adding that it had ''broken faith with the audience.'' The general and artistic director, George Steel, has been criticized by some for neglecting more traditional productions in favor of the offbeat. Mr. Sheffer, the former music director of the Eos Orchestra in New York and a group in Cleveland known as Red 3/5an orchestra 4/5, said he still had ''enormous respect and admiration for Mr. Steel.'' Roy L. Furman, an investment banker and theater producer, has also resigned, Mr. Sheffer said. Mr. Furman did not immediately return messages; nor did a City Opera spokeswoman. The soprano Joyce Castle stepped down last month, citing opposition to the move.

8 P.M. (TCM) THE ESSENTIALS: CLARK GABLE IN COLOR Robert Osborne and Alec Baldwin explain why this lineup is required viewing, beginning with ''The Misfits'' (1961), which stars Marilyn Monroe (below, with Clark Gable) as Roslyn Taber, a freshly divorced showgirl, and Gable as Gay Langland, a ruggedly independent cowboy intent on joining an auto mechanic (Eli Wallach) and a rodeo performer (Montgomery Clift) in a plan to rope mustangs -- known as misfits, because they're too small for riding -- in the Nevada desert and sell them for dog food. Directed by John Huston and written by Arthur Miller, the film is considered a pioneer in the evolution of the American western, with its more contemporary, bleaker outlook. ''Westerns and the West have always been built on a morally balanced world where evil has a recognizable tab -- the black hats -- and evil always loses out in the end,'' Miller wrote. ''This is that same world, but it's been dragged out of the 19th century into today, when the good guy is also part of the problem.'' Among the movie's memorable lines: Gay's declaration that ''the man who's too afraid to die is too afraid to live.'' (Gable died just weeks after completing the film.) The evening continues into the wee hours with Gable as a big-game hunter in Kenya in ''Mogambo'' (1953), at 10:15; a slave owner in ''Band of Angels'' (1957), at 12:15 a.m.; a Dutch intelligence officer in ''Betrayed'' (1954), at 2:30; and a con man who seduces widows in ''The King and Four Queens'' (1956), at 4:30. NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND Bill Moyers discusses his latest book, ''Bill Moyers Journal: The Conversation Continues,'' and opens up about President Lyndon B. Johnson, whom he served as press secretary.

THE best birthday present I ever received came from my wife. She gave me a baseball from the 2009 World Series signed by Derek Jeter, the New York Yankees shortstop. I treasure it because he's my favorite player but also because my newborn daughter slept in my arms while I watched the Yankees win that World Series. Like many Yankees' fans, I spent last Saturday watching the coverage of Jeter getting his 3,000th hit over and over. And then, I thought of all the memorabilia that was coming -- all the balls, bats, jerseys, photos and anything you could imagine signed by Jeter.

Jaroslav Jirik, a Czech hockey star who played a role in his national team's emotional victory over the Soviets in 1969 after the Soviet invasion of his homeland and who later became the first Eastern-bloc player to appear in the National Hockey League, died Monday when the small plane he was piloting crashed in the Czech Republic near Brno. He was 71. The cause of the accident was not known, said Jan Brskovsky, the president of the Light Aircraft Association of the Czech Republic. Jirik was the only person aboard. As a member of the Czech national team, Jirik scored 83 goals in 134 games, winning a bronze medal at the 1964 Olympics and a silver in 1968.

The Books of The Times review on July 8, about ''Reasonable Doubt: The Fashion Writer, Cape Cod, and The Trial of Chris McCowen,'' by Peter Manso, erroneously attributed to Mr. Manso comments about the district attorney who had jurisdiction over the case when Mr. McCowen was tried for the murder of the fashion writer Christa Worthington. While Mr. Manso wrote that the district attorney came to be perceived as a ''wacko'' and ''the DA who couldn't keep his zipper shut,'' he did not call him those things himself. And a correction in this space on Friday referred incorrectly to the district attorney's role in the trial. While his office handled the case, the trial prosecutor was an assistant district attorney, not the district attorney.

The big names on the invitation for a book party at the St. Regis New York hotel were all dead. Salvador Dalí, Alfred Hitchcock and Diana Vreeland had once lived or lived it up here on East 55th Street, we were told. Had they been among the guests on Wednesday at a party for the release of ''It Happened Here'' by Lesley M. M. Blume, a book chronicling the St. Regis's creative history, they would no doubt have reveled again. Models with feather headdresses and backless dresses reclined face down on settees in the Jacob Astor library. Their backs served as canvases for a Dalí look-alike with a protrusion of wiry chest hair, who painted phrases like ''There is no frigate like a book to take us lands away'' (Emily Dickinson) on their bare skin. Apparently Dalí had pulled a similar party trick when he lived here with his wife and pet ocelot.

Nathan Lane will play one of the stage's great dramatic characters -- the doomed salesman Theodore (Hickey) Hickman -- in the Goodman Theater's revival of Eugene O'Neill's ''Iceman Cometh'' in spring 2012, the Chicago-based theater announced on Thursday. In an interview, Mr. Lane said that he had never been in a O'Neill play before but that he had long been fascinated by ''Iceman'' and the self-deluding Hickey. In addition, after 30 years of performing on New York stages, he said he was eager for some time away - and had fallen in love with Chicago during the pre-Broadway tryouts there of ''The Producers'' and ''The Addams Family.''

A man in a white chapeau passed three cancan dancers changing in a dim hallway. They were adjusting corsets, fluffing feathers, pulling up fishnet stockings. He told them something - something in French - and a dancer turned her head, puzzled. ''Oh,'' he said. ''You don't speak!''
A headline on Friday with a film review of ''Salvation Boulevard'' referred incorrectly to an incident in the film. The shooting of an outspoken atheist professor is an accident, not a murder.

Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com. At least four things make up what I like to call our personal human capital: money, time, skill and energy. But when it comes to investing, we almost always focus on money and ignore the other three.
Speak, father, speak to your little boy. Or I shall be lost forever. TOMMY DONAHUE, reciting a childhood poem he wrote about his father, an innocent victim of Boston's mob wars. [A14]

The Newark Museum has received a $1 million grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation to support initiatives related to its African art collection. The grant will allow the museum to hire a new assistant curator, doubling the size of its African art department, and to engage additional scholars for research, the museum's director, Mary Sue Sweeney Price, said in a telephone interview. The museum is also planning an expansion and reinstallation of its African art galleries, which will open in 2015. It received a $500,000 challenge grant toward that project from the National Endowment for the Humanities, which requires the museum to raise an additional $1.5 million from private sources. Ms. Price said the museum was making progress toward that goal and would announce some major gifts in the next few months.

SANDWICH, England —Greg Norman is not normally a source of good karma that players turn to when it comes to major championships.

The undercurrent running through the entire Women’s World Cup for Japan was their hope that they could play well enough and long enough to bring joy and pride to their countrymen in the wake of this spring’s devastating earthquake and resulting nuclear disaster. As the Times reported last week:

SANDWICH, England — It was not as impolitic as his downplaying the Ryder Cup as an “exhibition”: a point of view that Rory McIlroy has since revised. But McIlroy did not exactly embrace the traditional challenge of the British Open after finishing 12 shots off the lead with a seven-over total of 287. Among his indignities on Sunday was the penalty stroke he was given after his ball moved on the seventh green in the strong winds after he had grounded his putter behind it.

Brazil followed its biggest rival Argentina, down the exit ramp at the Copa America on Sunday, losing to plucky Paraguay on penalty kicks after the teams played a scoreless tie in La Plata, Argentina.
Darren Clarke captured his first major title with a steady final round at the British Open.
Japan won its first Women’s World Cup on Sunday, lifting a stricken country and somehow winning a match that the United States frequently dominated but could never control.

On July 18, 1861, the 12th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry left Fort Warren, in Boston Harbor, and marched through the city for an official review on the Boston Common. Leading the way was the regiment’s colonel, Fletcher Webster, the eldest son of Daniel Webster. The regiment’s association with such an eminent personage endeared it to Boston’s most respectable citizens, who lined the streets and cheered as the men trooped by. On the Common, Edward Everett, representing the “ladies of Boston,” presented the regiment with an ornate flag — and then with an equally ornate celebratory address.
With plans to revitalize the Boardwalk next year, this summer is the last for seven longtime Coney Island businesses.
LOS ANGELES — “We used to have petroglyphs,” said Ray Halbritter, the nation representative of the Oneida Indian Nation and the chief executive of its Nation Enterprises.
While many were transfixed by the women’s World Cup final on Sunday afternoon, Greenhill & Company was doing something different: releasing its latest quarterly earnings.

CHICAGO — All weekend, the anti-domestic violence organization Between Friends has been onsite here, handing out fans to festivalgoers that read “Cool It. Don’t Be A Fan Of Violence.” The move was a protest against the presence on the bill of the foulmouthed, spiteful and fantastic Los Angeles rap collective Odd Future, whose appearance on this festival bill largely full of tasteful indie rock became a flashpoint for debates about violent and hateful imagery and messages in music. Rumors of a protest during the group’s performance swirled.

As expected:
Hertz Global Holdings agreed on Sunday to buy the Donlen Corporation, a vehicle leasing and management company, for $250 million in cash. Hertz will also assume Donlen’s $680 million of debt.

MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I realize that some of you solve the puzzle when it comes out the day before, but for the sake of making my point, let’s pretend that it’s Monday morning and you are settling in to solve with your first cup of coffee. You’ve spent the weekend wrestling with the tough Friday and Saturday grids, and you’ve devoted most of your Sunday to finishing the big puzzle and the variety. A challenge is a wonderful thing, but now you need something to ease you into your week.

Human Rights are all the rage. They have become, currently, a very popular arena for both political activism and rampant discourse. Human rights, as we all know, are the rights humans are due simply by virtue of being human. But there is nothing simple here, since both “human” and “rights” are concepts in need of investigation.

Some readers like to see portraits of authors they admire, study their personal histories or hear them read aloud. I like to know whether an author can spell. Nabokov spelled beautifully. Fitzgerald was crummy at spelling, bedeviled by entry-level traps like “definate.” Bad spellers, of course, can be sublime writers and good spellers punctilious duds. But it’s still intriguing that Fitzgerald, for all his gifts, didn’t perceive the word “finite” in definite, the way good spellers automatically do. Did this oversight color his impression of infinity? Infinaty?

Zahi Hawass, Egypt’s antiquities minister, who has been under fire for his ties to the Mubarak regime, will lose his job in a cabinet reshuffle intended to appease the protesters in Tahrir Square, he confirmed to The New York Times by text message on Sunday. The summertime appeal of ice pops (as they're properly called -- ''Popsicle'' is a trademarked word that's become a default name) is easy to understand. They're sweet, colorful, lickable and a manageably small snack in an age of gargantuan portions. They recall a simpler time, before the era of artisanal-gelato shops. And they're cold.

The cover article on June 19 about a married couple's return to Provence 40 years after their honeymoon misidentified the owner of the cottage in Opio where the newlyweds had lived for a year. A family with the surname Spencer owns the cottage -- not Earl Spencer, brother of the late Princess Diana. And a correction in this space on July 3 clarifying that point erroneously referred to Mr. Spencer as the ''Earl of Spencer.''

DELACORTE--Valerie Pascal, (1919 2011) passed away on July 14th at her home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL. Valerie was the devoted wife of the late George T. Delacorte, founder of Dell Publishing Company and a well known New York and Florida philanthropist. Valerie was born in Budapest, Hungary and educated at the Ursuline Convent. Graced with stunning beauty, intellect and elegant style, Valerie became a stage and film actress in Hungary under the name Hidveghy Valeria. Valerie's earlier marriage was to Gabriel Pascal, Hollywood's renowned film producer of George Bernard Shaw's plays, including "Major Barbara", "Caesar" and "Cleopatra" and it was Pascal's idea to turn "Pygmalion" into a musical which became a reality as "My Fair Lady" after Pascal's death in 1954. Valerie authored a memoir entitled, "The Disciple and His Devil," to reveal an extraordinarily close view of Shaw and Pascal, and their charged, creative success. Valerie's glamorous, high-profile love and heartache with Pascal, included socializing with the legendary figures Vivien Leigh and Rex Harrison. McGraw Hill published Valerie's memoir in 1970; Michael Joseph re-published the book in England in 1972; IUniverse re-issued it in 2004; and, in 2008 the book was translated and published in Hungary. Valerie donated the voluminous Shaw-Pascal correspondence to Boston University. Valerie and George greatly enjoyed their life together in New York, Florida and Connecticut, traveling, collecting art, and taking pride in the many gifts George gave to New York City, in particular, the Delacorte Musical Clock, Alice in Wonderland Statue and the Delacorte Shakespeare Amphitheatre, all in Central Park. George was a major benefactor of Columbia University, and established the Delacorte Center for Magazine Journalism. Following George's death in 1991, Valerie served as a Trustee of the Center until 2001. In honor of her beloved husband, George, Valerie contributed their vast art collection of Old Masters to the Norton Museum of Art in Florida. Valerie was a devout Catholic, and her faith defined her journey through life, and inspired her friendships and charitable commitments to the poor and homeless and to other philanthropies. The Funeral Service and Christian Mass will be offered at 10am on Monday, August 8th at St. Ignatius Loyola, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street, followed by her burial to rest in eternal peace in the Delacorte Mausoleum at Woodlawn Cemetery, Webster Avenue & East 233rd Street, Bronx, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations in Valerie Delacorte's memory may be made to: Broadway Housing Communities, 583 Riverside Dr., NY, NY 10031; www.broadwayhousing.org Orbis International, Inc., 520 Eighth Avenue, 11th Floor, NY, NY 10018, www.orbis.org. St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, 262 Danny Thomas Place, Memphis, TN 38105 www.stjude.org

IN old Hong Kong, around the intersection of Queen's Road and Hollywood Road, the Sheung Wan neighborhood has found new life with a bumper crop of restaurants, galleries and night-life spots. The revival has been described by locals as akin to that of New York's meatpacking district: gritty, winding back lanes and low-rise heritage buildings are newly buzzing with trendy establishments. And in Sheung Wan, the newcomers are packed in alongside the bric-a-brac curio shops, apothecaries and herbalists that are the mainstays of the district. BONNIE TSUI

This weekend, Los Angeles residents face a 53-hour closing of the 405 freeway, the primary north-south highway through the city's West Side, as road crews take a sledgehammer to the Mulholland Drive bridge. The planned work threatens to clog surface streets near the Interstate, leading many Angelenos to call the impending amalgam of bottlenecks, honked horns and frayed nerves Carmageddon. But while Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa has urged citizens to stay home and barbecue, many residents intend to maintain forward momentum at any cost.

9 P.M. (13, 49) ZEN Rufus Sewell, above, stars as Detective Aurelio Zen, an honest cop in modern-day Italy whose superiors are on the side of the lawbreakers in this ''Masterpiece Mystery!'' adaptation of the novels by Michael Dibdin. In ''Vendetta,'' the first of three installments, a frazzled Zen, 40 years old, separated from his wife and living with his mother, finds himself ducking a killer on a rampage against those he believed wrongly imprisoned him, while grappling with a politically charged murder -- never mind the affections of his office mate Tania Moretti (Caterina Murino). ''There is nothing of the morose in this trilogy, which makes it a welcome antidote to the craze for the grimness and melancholy of the unstoppably popular Scandinavian crime genre,'' Ginia Bellafante wrote of the series in The New York Times. ''The films deploy a light comic sensibility and graphics that suggest a '60s caper. They situate us in a Rome where the weather always seems heavenly, blouses are always unbuttoned suggestively, and no lunch transpires without multiple courses and repeated instances of sexual innuendo. Risotto is eaten; cigarettes are smoked; espresso is consumed; public displays of lust are evident. There is little resistance to cliché in all this, but the cliché is so visually appealing that you'll feel like a spoiled child if you complain. And you're given such a treat that you'll also feel like one, begging for more.'' 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Senator Jon Kyl, Republican of Arizona, discusses the debate over the deficit and raising the debt ceiling. Chicago's literary heritage and reputation for design meet in the new Poetry Foundation center (poetryfoundation.org). Opened on June 25, the 22,000-square-foot center aims to fulfill the foundation's mission of engaging new audiences in poetry, principally with a library and a reading series. The 30,000-volume nonlending library, including a children's collection and two listening rooms where visitors can hear recordings of poets reciting their work, is open to the public.

''I WANTED to make easy pieces that are practical yet chic,'' said the model Claudia Schiffer, as she showed off examples from a new namesake cashmere line in her airy, art-filled Notting Hill, London, living room. ''You know, simple but well-cut dresses and tops that you can throw on with leggings and boots for the school run, and pair with a great pair of earrings or a cool cuff for dinner.'' Comprising chunky-knit jackets, dresses and buttery boyfriend sweaters, the collection (created in collaboration with the German knitwear label Iris von Arnim) ranges from about $400 to $1,600 and makes its debut later this month at net-a-porter.com. SENDAI, Japan -- It took minutes for the tsunami that hit the coast of Japan in March to destroy entire cities. It will take years to clean up the mess that was left behind. Last week, I visited several garbage dumps in Sendai where debris created on that day was being collected, sorted and destroyed. These were filled with the detritus of people's lives that were upended violently and involuntarily.

LUSTIG--Gerald I. Mr. Gerald I. Lustig, a WWII veteran and retired attorney recently passed away at age 87 after a short illness. He was born in Brooklyn, where he graduated from Boys High in 1941. After entering City College, Mr. Lustig enlisted, at age 18 in the Army during WWII. He received a degree in Electrical Engineering from Purdue University and then served for two years in the South Pacific and Japan. He was the recipient of multiple medals of commendation. After the war Mr. Lustig decided to switch gears completing a law degree at Brooklyn College and later, a specialty degree in taxation at NYU law school. He worked as a lawyer in Manhattan for over 50 years, and at one point argued a case before the Supreme Court in Washington, D.C. Mr. Lustig spent his retirement years in Florida with his wife of almost 60 years. He is survived by his beloved wife, Mrs. Rosalind Lustig, and his adored children, Dr. Alan Lustig and Mrs. Teresa Lustig of St. Petersburg, FL and Dr. James Dolin and Dr. Marnie Lustig Dolin of Woodbury, NY. He was the proud grandfather of Alyssa, Peyton, Justin and Parker. He was the dear brother of the late Neil Lustig. Mr. Lustig was known for his astute mind, warmth, joie de vivre, and philanthropy. He will forever remain in the hearts of his cherished family, friends and clients. Private services have been held, any contributions may be sent to The Anti-Defamation League.

FULLERTON--John S. (Bud), 94, of Southbury, CT passed quietly on July 8, 2011. He leaves his loving wife of 54 years, Jean, sons Bruce and John, daughters-in-law Antonina and Susan, and grandchildren Ali, Emma, Grace and Jack. Bud graduated from Hamilton College and served as a Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy in WWII in both the European and Asian theatres. He was at Omaha Beach on D-day, June 6, 1944. Bud spent his career in advertising and public relations and was one of the original organizers of the Operation Sail celebrations held in New York Harbor. He had belonged to the New York Yacht Club and Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. Bud Fullerton was a man loved by many and trusted by all. Services are being held privately.

TWENTY years after the breakup of the Soviet Union, the wave of nostalgia for the good old days of Communism peaks with the opening of ''Ostalgia,'' an exhibition at the New Museum curated by Massimilliano Gioni. Among the artists represented in the show is Nikolay Bakharev, who was born in Siberia in 1946 and worked as a photographer for the Communal Services Factory in Novokuznetsk. On the side, he took photographs of ordinary folks on the beach (one of the few places they could bare their bodies beyond the watchful gaze of Big Brother) and offered the pictures for sale to the subjects. For Mr. Bakharev, it was an exercise that tested the limits of private, and creative, enterprise under a regime that frowned upon both. In his intimate and casually charming portraits, photographer and subject are complicit in this small taste of freedom -- and clearly relishing it. ALIX BROWNE

SANDWICH, ENGLAND - An amateur who shoots a 65 in his first British Open round, makes the cut with ease and draws praise from none other than Tom Watson should be a lock for the silver medal awarded to the tournament's leading amateur. Not so fast. Tom Lewis, the 20-year-old Englishman in question, followed up that 65 with a 74 and a 76, and he is now just two shots in front of the American Peter Uihlein, the only other amateur still in the tournament. Lewis is at five-over par with one round to play; Uihlein, the reigning United States amateur champion, is at seven over after following two 71s with a third-round 75 to sit tied for 41st. Uihlein, like Lewis, has strong family connections to golf. Lewis's father is a golf professional. Uihlein's father, Wally, is the chairman and chief executive of the Acushnet Company, which includes the golf brands Titleist and FootJoy. ''Well, Peter is a great player, so no matter what happens tomorrow, hopefully I can play well, and if I don't win, then I don't win,'' Lewis said. ''He deserves whatever he gets. Hopefully I can win some bigger trophies in my career.'' Uihlein, a 21-year-old all-American golfer from Oklahoma State, missed the cut at the Masters and the United States Open this year, but he is playing on the weekend at this major. The conversation has shifted quickly here at Royal St. George's. On Thursday, it seemed like the early results were confirmation of Europe's increased domination of the game and Lewis's glittering 65 a big hint that the good times would keep right on rolling. But the Americans have struck back and now have 10 players in the top 16 heading into Sunday, and Uihlein now has a chance to snatch the silver medal for the United States, too.

THE work of Carl Andre, one of the only Minimalists to accept the term, is often as barely there as sculpture can get. In the first book to survey his ascetic half-century career, a maximalist doorstop published this month by Phaidon, the art historian Alistair Rider relates the story of a German artist who enthusiastically sought out Mr. Andre's work at a gallery in 1967, only to become confused when he couldn't find it. This was because the work, 100 square plates of hot-rolled steel arranged in a rectangle almost completely covering the gallery entryway, was directly beneath his feet. He had mistaken it for the flooring, a mistake that comes with the territory in Andre country, where art -- as Mr. Andre has said -- gets perilously ''close to zero,'' meant to be experienced as much with the body as with the eyes and mind. For more than two decades Mr. Andre, who turns 76 this year, has been almost as spectral a presence in the art world as his most inconspicuous floor pieces. He has shown regularly, at the Paula Cooper Gallery in New York and around the world, but he rarely appears in public and speaks for the record even less than he did when he was young, which was not a lot. So it was disconcerting to meet him one recent afternoon in the hallway outside his Greenwich Village apartment, where he was waiting on the other side of the elevator door; he smiled, stuck out his hand and said, ''Hi, I'm Carl Andre,'' pronouncing his last name with a flat ''a,'' in contrast to the broad ''a'' (''bahthtub,'' ''auhnt'') he carries conspicuously from his youth in Quincy, Mass.

Shortly after Candace Keshwar immigrated from Trinidad to Boston in 2002, her life took a difficult turn. Her dream had been to go to college and have a career where she could help others. But her first daughter was born with cerebral palsy and Keshwar spent the next seven years caring for her at home. She grew isolated. Her husband worked in construction, but jobs were sporadic, and the family relied on government assistance. ''It was a real dark space for me,'' Keshwar said. ''I kept thinking, 'This cannot be my life. I know I have the potential to do so much more.''' A turning point came when Keshwar was asked to join a group of families who had self-organized as part of an initiative that helps people in low-income communities achieve their goals. Called the Family Independence Initiative (FII), its approach is radically different from the American social service model. Although it is still quite small - working with a few hundred families - its results are so striking that the White House has taken notice. What FII does is create a structure for families that encourages the sense of control, desire for self-determination, and mutual support that have characterized the collective rise out of poverty for countless communities in American history.FII is not a ''program'' in a traditional sense. It doesn't seek to implement changes, but to elicit them from others. It was launched as a research project by Maurice Lim Miller in Oakland in 2001. Lim Miller, whose mother was an immigrant from Mexico who worked multiple jobs to support her children, had previously spent 22 years building Asian Neighborhood Design, a youth development and job training program, for which he was honored by President Clinton during the 1999 State of the Union address.

Until this season, the profile of a 190-strikeout batter was predictable: a hulking cleanup hitter with lots of home runs, lots of walks and not many stolen bases. Drew Stubbs of the Cincinnati Reds appears poised to change that. Batting leadoff, Stubbs isleading the major leagues in strikeouts but is not following in the powerful footsteps of his predecessors. A comparison of his 2011 season with the season averages of players who have struck out 190 times in a season. Averages are for 190-strikeout seasons.

ZIMET--Sidney, former attorney, died 15 July 2011 in Brooklyn at the age of 102. He is survived by his three children, seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be on Tuesday, 19 July at 1pm at Weinstein Garlick Kirschenbaum Chapels, 1153 Coney Island Ave., Brooklyn.

UNGER--Lynn. On July 9, 2011 at age 77. A passionate artist, world traveler, reader and nature lover, Lynn attended Music and Art High School, then graduated from Queens College Phi Beta Kappa with a degree in Mathematics in 1955. After earning her M.S. in 1970, she taught Math at Baldwin High School from 1973-1993. With her warmth and creativity, commitment and professionalism, she made math fun and logical for countless students, coaching winning Varsity Mathlete Teams, promoting Family Math Days, and continuing to receive commendations for her presentations at conferences and service to NCMTA long after her retirement. She will be greatly missed by her daughters, granddaughters, and many friends and relatives. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck on Sunday, August 28.
FRIEDMAN--Edwin. 90, urban planner and WWII veteran died July 8. Survivors are his wife Edith, two children and two grandchildren.
