CIESINSKI--Roman Anthony. 1921-2011. Delaware Sports Hall of Famer, Roman Anthony Ciesinski of Hockessin, Delaware, the only Track and Field Coach so honored, died Friday, June 10, 2011 at home, of heart failure following a long illness. Five days before his passing, the United States Veterans Administration awarded him the Order of the Purple Heart with Oak Clusters, the Prisoner of War Medal, and the Bronze Star for services rendered in World War II, 67 years earlier. He was 89. A Detroit native who worked in the Timken Axel Defense Plant before joining the Army, he was captured in France on Thanksgiving Day 1944 after his company engaged in a brief gun battle, during which he sustained wounds he would later have to treat himself. His internment at Mulhberg lasted until June of 1945. Forced labor and lack of food pulled 100 pounds off his 6'3" athletic frame, the physical hardship tempered by the kindness of a German sergeant who recognized a Polish last name and saw to it that regular food rations, as well as shoes, did not disappear. Transferred to Rehabilitation Camp Lucky Strike in France following liberation, he returned to the US, wounds not properly documented, and thus, placing him at a loss for points for discharge. Fortunately, his post rehab Camp Upton (Yaphank, NY) assignment to life guard a swimming pool still under construction left time for USO dances, at one of which he met Katherine Elizabeth Hansen of Long Island, the woman who would become his wife for 48 years. Later, as a defensive tackle for the University of Delaware's national champion team he was on the squad that won the 1947 Cigar Bowl and after graduation in 1948, his 32 year career as track and field coach at Newark High School followed. From 1949 to 1981 he assembled a 401-139 record, took three state championship and 16 Blue Hen Conference titles; a sports conference of which he was one of the founding fathers. Ciesinski was inducted into the Delaware Track and Field Hall of Fame in 2002 and the Delaware Sports Hall of Fame in 2003. His direct approach, integrity, unaffected communication, innate leadership and uncanny ability to assemble effective training regimes benefitted his program's alumni long after their schooling, among them Olympic high jumper Chris Dunn, Houston Oiler Conway Hayman, his brother Buffalo Bills and Seattle Seahawk running back Gary Hayman, Delaware football wide receiver and career coach for Newark High School Pat Walker, and Olympic hurdler Carol Thompson. He is preceded in death by his ten sisters and brothers, all children of August and Frances Bydlowski Ciesinski of Detroit, his wife Katherine and survived by three children; Katherine Ciesinski, professor of voice at the Eastman School of Music, Kristine Ciesinski, assistant professor of voice at Florida State University, Raymond Ciesinski, a senior software sales executive at Symantec Corporation; two grandchildren; and by his companion of 13 years, Nellie Ray Mackie of Hockessin.

Selinger '75, a 2011 recipient of the University's Alumni Medal for distinguished service. Neil's biography, "A Sloan Product: A Memoir of a Lost Boy," was published this year. Most mornings when he is in Washington, the House majority whip, Kevin McCarthy, wakes up at 6 a.m. on his office sofa -- which is a slight improvement over the air mattress he once slept on, and probably better than the houseboat that a fellow Republican congressman, Lynn Westmoreland, has half-jokingly tried to convince him to share. McCarthy pulls on some ratty gym clothes, descends three flights of stairs and exits the building, where, when the weather is agreeable, he meets up with about a half-dozen other G.O.P. members on their mountain bikes. Together they cruise along the Mall, past the Lincoln Memorial, across a bridge and along the Potomac River. An hour later, McCarthy will shower in the House gym, head off to breakfast with some other gaggle of Republicans, attend the morning management meeting with Speaker John Boehner and Eric Cantor, the majority leader, huddle throughout the day with his whip staff and committee chairmen and conservative advocacy groups and random needy or disgruntled members until it's finally evening and time to round up a bunch of other Republican colleagues for a dinner that can go on for several hours because McCarthy takes it upon himself to draw the others out from their professional shells with questions like, ''What's the most embarrassing thing that happened to you at college?'' or ''What was the first concert you went to?'' By 11 at night, he is back on his office couch with his BlackBerry and the next day's briefings, some 2,300 miles from his wife and son and daughter in Bakersfield, Calif. -- and then asleep, in a federal building, by 1 a.m. One of McCarthy's morning cycling mates is Sean Duffy, a 39-year-old freshman and Tea Party sensation from Wisconsin who was once a county prosecutor and, before that, a professional lumberjack and star in MTV's reality series ''The Real World.'' Several of the freshmen live in their House offices so as to pronounce themselves detached from the culture of Washington. Duffy also does so because he has six young children and thousands of dollars of debt accumulated during the seven months he spent without a salary before being elected to Congress.
Art Randy Kennedy

TIBBETTS--Gunhild Margareta, Age 81 (29 and holding!), longtime resident of Greenwich, CT, passed away peacefully on July 11, 2011, at her daughter's home in Manhattan Beach, CA, after a long illness. She was the widow of Hubert M. Tibbetts, former President and CEO of Thomas J. Lipton, Inc. Gunhild was born Kerstin Gunhild Margareta on October 12, 1929, in Malmo, Sweden, to Harry and Margareta Wetterhorn. She moved to the United States in 1951, first living in Florida where she attended junior college and was crowned in the Miss St. Petersburg beauty pageant. A lovely Swedish blonde with piercing blue eyes and flawless skin, her looks could have taken her to Hollywood. Always stunningly put together, she had an impeccable eye for fashion and design. After moving to New York City in the mid 1950s, she worked as a buyer for the Cotton Shop on Madison Avenue. It was love at first sight when she met Hubert Tibbetts in New York in 1954. Although multi-talented and creatively gifted, her main goals in life were to have a successful marriage and to provide a loving home for her children. She was happily married to Hubert for 46 years, before he passed away in 2002. Over the years, she played many roles in addition to wife, mother and homemaker: chicken farmer, taxi dispatcher, gardener, chef, and real estate agent. In her spare time, she enjoyed knitting and needlework, and vacationing on the beach in the Cayman Islands. Although beautiful beyond compare, it was her inner beauty that shone brightest. Always there with a friendly smile, she was exceptionally kind-hearted and extremely generous. Your happiness was always the greatest gift to her. A proud U.S. citizen and staunch Republican, she lived her life with no regrets. Family came first for her, and she focused much of the last 15 years spending time with her grandchildren, Serena and Marisa, whom she adored. She is survived by her sister Inger Wetterhorn; brother Richard Wetterhorn; son Lance Tibbetts; daughter and son-in-law Kerstin and Ron Kripalani; and granddaughters Serena and Marisa Kripalani. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, July 22, at 11am at The Second Congregational Church located at 139 Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, CT. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to; UCLA Department of OB/GYN, 10833 Le Conte Ave., Room 27-139, CHS Los Angeles, CA 90095. Checks should be written out to: Regents of the U.C. In the memo portion, please specify that the donation is for Dr. Robin Farias-Eisner's Research. A note can also be included if the donor wishes specifying above.

SIMKIN--Carol F.,died of cancer on July 9, at her summer home in East Dennis, Massachusetts. Carol grew up in Great Neck, Long Island, and graduated in 1970 from Brandeis University and in 1973 from New York University Law School. She was for many years a leading lawyer in the trademark and copyright fields. She was a partner first in the law firm of Cowan Liebowitz & Latman and then in the firm of Fross Zelnick Lehrman & Zissu, and also served as a mediator, privately and for Federal and State courts in New York. Carol was gifted with exceptional intelligence and possessed character and common sense to an uncommon degree. She was a brilliant legal counselor and litigation strategist, and a generous source of advice and support for her family, friends and colleagues. Although she lived and worked in Manhattan, she loved Cape Cod and especially her home and gardens overlooking Cape Cod Bay. She is survived by her husband, Ron Lehrman, her daughter, Lauren Simkin Berke, her brother, Steven Simkin, her father, Dr. Maxwell Simkin, and her nephews Alexander and Zachary Simkin. Family members and friends will be invited to gather on a date to be announced. No flowers or donations, please.

CHRISTCHURCH, NEW ZEALAND -- The once bustling central business district resembles a wasteland. Office furniture can be seen sitting inside partially collapsed buildings. Piles of bricks and steel lie along the closed, empty streets. ''Welcome to Limboland,'' declares a sign attached to the fencing that still marks off a large section of the inner city. ''When is the recovery starting?'' asks another sign.

At some point, perhaps soon, the N.F.L. and its players will reach a new labor agreement, and the great free-agent gold rush of 2011 will begin. But for now, for as many as 500 free agents, there is no blueprint, no courting or being courted, only anticipation for what comes next and more labor pains induced in the form of unemployment. Whenever this period of free agency begins, it will be condensed and frenzied. But the fine print, the rules governing the period, are still to be determined. Players drafted in 2006 or later will pay particular attention to whether four years of service (as expected) or six result in unrestricted free-agent status. Additionally, teams could receive some sort of right-of-first-refusal tag, allowing them to match offers for even unrestricted free agents, if only for this season.

STERN--Herman, on July 8, 2011 at almost 96 years of age. Herman (Hank) Stern was a CPA for over 60 years. He served in World War II as 1st Lieutenant in the 2nd Infantry Division, and fought in the Battle of the Bulge. His wife of 51 years, Selma, predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by brother Harold and wife Francis, son Robert, daughter Beverly, grandchildren Elizabeth and Michael, and great-grandson Elliott. He had a passion for sports and was an active participant in baseball, racquetball, tennis, bowling, pool, and especially golf. He had a keen mind, doing the Sunday Times puzzle into his 90's, and continuing to do puzzles in his local paper up to the day he passed. He will be sorely missed by family, friends, and associates, all of whom appreciated his intellectual sharpness, sense of humor, kindness and generosity. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to National Brain Tumor Foundation.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Routine Ruse in Men's Soccer Tumbles Into Women's World Cup,'' July 12: A friend proposed an interesting solution to faking injuries. If a player is taken off on a stretcher, which wastes the most time, then the referee should delay acknowledging the player's readmission for one to five minutes. If the player requires sideline medical attention or the coach sends in a replacement, that time would be waived.

When he was in his late 40s, Korchnoi, now 80, played for the championship twice.

At Yosemite National Park, campers are battling more than pesky mosquitoes. They also have to contend with scalpers trying to make a fast buck by reselling campsites and wilderness permits online. Reservations for some of the park's 900 campsites have lately been fetching $100 or more per night, many times the $20 the national park service charges on its Web site, recreation.gov. Scalpers have also been reselling permits to climb Half Dome, where a newly imposed limit of 400 hikers a day has made the $1.50 permits a hot commodity.

CAN'T get there from here? This summer's issue of Colors, the magazine published by Benetton, asks us to imagine the day when the planet's oil supply finally runs out. It offers alternatives that are largely grass-roots and low-tech, like the boat made of Styrofoam and plastic bottles or the tricked-out bicycle taxis from Kenya or the three-wheeled Indian motorcycle carts known as chakdas (helpfully illustrated with instructions) that can carry up to 15 passengers. But there is also a solar-powered car designed by an inventor in China. Never mind that it looks like a tin can covered with solar panels; when the inventor took it out for its first test drive in 2008, he passed a line of cars a mile long waiting for gas. PILAR VILADAS

With the military's ban on openly gay troops expected to end this fall, advocates for gay and lesbian service members are already looking ahead to the next battle: winning equal benefits for same-sex married couples. Under current law, particularly the Defense of Marriage Act, the Pentagon is prohibited from giving federally financed benefits to same-sex married couples. In the military, those benefits include base housing and allowances for off-base housing, health insurance, certain death benefits, legal counseling and access to base commissaries and other stores.

My brother is giving us Marriott/Starwood points to stay in hotels, and we're hoping to stay for $2,000 or less per person (exclusive of airfare). What suggestions do you have? Valerie Glassman, Durham, N.C.

DANNY HESS of San Francisco loves riding the waves, but he hates that many surfboards are made of nonrecyclable materials and must constantly be replaced. Mr. Hess, who has built boards since he was a teenager, left his job as a building contractor to devote himself to creating environmentally friendly and long-lasting surfboards. His materials include reclaimed and sustainably harvested wood, recycled cork, and nontoxic and recyclable foam. ''The search for a better surfboard'' -- and that means one that also performs well -- ''still remains a constant pursuit for me,'' he says. ''I'm always searching for new materials and better material sources.''

When the Yankees sent Tyler Clippard to the Washington Nationals at the winter meetings in December 2007, Clippard had never heard of the pitcher he was traded for. It was Jonathan Albaladejo, a reliever who made 49 appearances the next three seasons and now plays in Japan. Clippard, meanwhile, is the latest former Yankees pitching prospect to flourish elsewhere.

TORONTO - Manager Joe Girardi's frustration with his team's poor play in the first two games here seemed to boil over Saturday morning when he all but accused the Blue Jays of using off-the-field means to steal the Yankees' signs. The day after applauding their resourcefulness in divining Russell Martin's signals from second base, Girardi turned testy when asked why he told Martin on Friday night to use complicated signs even with no one on base. ''Sometimes we have inclinations that things might be happening in certain ballparks, and we're aware of it, and we try to protect our signs,'' Girardi said. ''The last thing you want is a hitter to know what's coming. And if you wanted to let him know, you could say it's a simulated batting practice, but we're not doing that. So we're going to protect our signs. And I told the guys, it's one of the things that you have to do in certain ballparks.''

LEVY--Gloria Cutler on July 10, 2011, of Heritage Hills, Somers, NY. Born February 13, 1921. Gloria is predeceased by her husband of 56 years, Israel (Lee) Levy and her son, Daniel Phillip Levy. She leaves behind a trove of artwork from her long career as both a commercial and fine artist. We'll celebrate her life and work on Sunday, July 24, contact Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, 914-232-3033. At Vinoteca, a wine bar in the U Street corridor of Washington, D.C.’s, the District’s popular bocce ball scene meets open-air snacking. Vinoteca itself is a perfectly fine wine bar, if a bit hushed and dimly lit, but the real action is happening around back: a clustered courtside next to a mock-rustic bocce ball lane made of tile and crushed oyster shells. Bocce — a game that can be described as shuffleboard with balls, or curling sans ice — is enjoying something of a youthful renaissance these days in Washington, spearheaded by the DC Bocce League, an organization with teams across the D.C. area and a membership roll that includes staffers, interns, pollsters, wonks and all manner of Washingtonian young professionals. They play mostly in outdoor parks and on lawns, but these sites have nothing on the backyard at Vinoteca, which could be a miniaturized village square in Torre del Greco, were it not for the condo developments towering above or the Rite Aid across the street. Such open-air surroundings are best accompanied by offerings from the outdoor grill: fresh barbecued monkfish in romesco, warmed olives and almonds, a bluefish tuna sandwich on rustic bread and assorted Mediterranean sausages. Perhaps best of all is the playful by-the-glass wine list, including a dry assyrtiko from Santorini, Greece, and a viognier from nearby Rappahannock Cellars, in Virginia.

I was only peripherally aware of Miranda July before Katrina Onstad wrote about her for this Sunday’s magazine. Netflix occasionally suggests I stream her 2005 film “Me and You and Everyone We Know,” probably because I have viewed other so-called indie films. After a few maddening minutes, it hit me: She’s the one who did “The Arky Girl.”

Several people were reported injured when a stage collapsed Sunday evening during a performance by Cheap Trick during the Ottawa Bluesfest, though the band members were said to be unharmed, according to The Associated Press. Canadian weather services had predicted a thunderstorm in Ottawa on Sunday night, which struck while Cheap Trick was performing on the festival’s main stage. This YouTube video posted by a user named gastorch997 shows the stage coming down in a matter of seconds as stunned onlookers scream. A concertgoer named Meghan Hurley wrote in The Ottawa Citizen that she “heard a loud bang,” after which “a frightened woman” told her “almost in tears that the stage had collapsed.” Ms. Hurley added, “I glanced over to where we had sat only moments before and all that remained was a heap of chairs that looked like a windswept pile of kindling for a bonfire.”

Gordon Parks (1912-2006) is celebrated as a photographer, filmmaker, memoirist and breaker of color barriers. Before he was famous, however; before he was Gordon Parks, he had a one-year fellowship as a photographer at the Farm Security Administration. There, under the tutelage of Roy Stryker, he honed his skills.

The cheerful, childlike doggerel of ''Hello Goodbye'' -- ''I don't know why you say goodbye/I say hello'' -- struck an unexpected note as Paul McCartney sang it on Friday night to start his two-night stand at Yankee Stadium. ''Who is this Derek Jeter guy?'' Mr. McCartney asked. ''Somebody said he's got more hits than me.'' At 69, Mr. McCartney is not saying goodbye but touring stadiums and playing marathon concerts. Friday's set ran two and a half hours, with Mr. McCartney constantly onstage, and it had 35 songs, not counting a few additional excerpts. He played half a dozen instruments (though he didn't show off his drumming), sang with only a few scrapes in the voice that's familiar worldwide, and looked as if he was having a boyish romp as he navigated what endure as some of rock's oddest hits. His hair grew more tousled with every song.

ZERNIKE--Frits, died July 12, 2011, at 80. Born and educated in Groningen, the Netherlands. A physicist with Perkin-Elmer Corp., Silicon Valley Group and Carl Zeiss, and first manager for Dept. of Energy's Extreme Ultraviolet Lithography Program. Survived by his wife of 49 years, Barbara Backus Zernike, children Frits III, Harry, and Kate, daughter- and son-in-law Jennifer Wu and Jonathan Schwartz, and three grandchildren: Frits and Nicolaas Schwartz and Anders Zernike. Memorial service will be 3pm Thursday, July 28, at Essex Yacht Club, Novelty Lane, Essex, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to Dance for Parkinson's, c/o NMS, 100 Audubon St, New Haven, CT 06510, or Community Music School, P.O. Box 387, Centerbrook, CT 06409.

Waiting for Amazon to sell a full-fledged tablet feels like waiting for the grass to grow: we know it's going to happen, but it's taking an awfully long time. As we have reported over the last year, Amazon has been readying a color screen tablet that will run the Google Android operating system. Jeff Bezos, Amazon's chief executive, has even acknowledged that a tablet project is in the works, saying earlier this year that the company was actively working on a ''multipurpose tablet device.''

TOKYO - Fans here spilled into the streets here at 6:45 a.m., hugging and cheering after Japan defeated the United States in the Women's World Cup final to lift the spirits of a country still reeling from the earthquake and tsunami that struck on March 11. ''Japan won because we played with 12 players - 11 and the goal post,'' said Takahiro Inagawa, referring to a number of American scoring opportunities that hit the goal posts in Frankfurt.

LOS ANGELES -- If Louis B. Mayer haunts the Irving Thalberg Building, once his seat of power at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, he may recognize more than the walnut walls. The building is now the home of Sony Pictures Entertainment, and there are signs that Mayer's old studio system is being revived. As Hollywood has backed away from movie stars as too expensive and too unreliable, Sony has embraced its favorites. On Friday, the studio will open ''Friends With Benefits,'' a romantic comedy with Justin Timberlake in a leading role. It is Sony's third film with Mr. Timberlake in less than 10 months, and comes on the heels of his performances in ''The Social Network'' last October and in ''Bad Teacher,'' which opened just over three weeks ago.

VMware made a handful of product announcements on Tuesday that add up to the company's bid to become the Microsoft of cloud computing. VMware, of course, is the leader in data center job-juggling technology called virtualization. This software not only makes data center computing more efficient -- less hardware, lower energy costs -- but it is a vital building block in the plumbing behind cloud computing.
GLICKSMAN--Albert. Aly - dearest husband, missing you every moment since July 18th, 2005, but still sharing my life with you. Love, Fran

Zahi Hawass, Egypt's antiquities minister, who has been under fire for his ties to the Mubarak regime, will lose his job in a cabinet reshuffle intended to appease the protesters in Tahrir Square, he confirmed to The New York Times by text message on Sunday. The full details of the cabinet changes have not yet been confirmed. Mr. Hawass's pending departure was reported by an Egyptian newspaper, Youm7, and Mr. Hawass confirmed the report's accuracy. Youm7 quoted him as saying that protesters outside his office tried to beat him as he left on Sunday. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Because of an editing error, a report in the Sports Briefing column last Monday about the golfer Luke Donald's victory in the Scottish Open -- it was shortened because of rain to three rounds -- misstated his final score. It was 197, not 269.
SCHARFF--Shirley. July 18, 1929 - Jan 22, 2010. Life is not Forever, but Love lasts an Eternity. Happy Birthday My Angel from All of Your Loved Ones. Always, Your Cliff

The Advertising column on Tuesday, about nostalgic marketing campaigns for Colorforms toys and the game Uno, erroneously attributed a distinction to part of Colorforms' campaign. The brand used television ads in the 1950s and '60s; this year's commercials are not its first. (The TV ads are the first under the ownership of University Games, which bought the brand in 1998.)

GOLDSTEIN--Doris Fischer, died after a long and brave battle with Parkinson's disease. Widow of adored husband Walter C. Goldstein. Beloved mother of Marjorie Van Dercook (Charles) and Carol Levin. Stepmother of Laurie Druker (Washington), Steven Colter (Lee) and Bruce Goldstein. Grandmother of George, Charlotte, Becky, Gina, Archie, Zach (Lisa), David, Michael, Tina and Rachel. A devoted native New Yorker, gifted writer, world traveler and unique spirit. Private burial. Family will be receiving at the home of Mrs. Goldstein on July 18 from 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to Temple Emanu-El, 1 East 65 Street, NY, NY 10065

Is the Internet due for a ''Magna Carta moment?'' That is a question being posed by Rebecca MacKinnon, an Internet scholar at the New America Foundation, who argues that private corporations are exerting excessive power over the Internet and should have that power checked. Just as the English barons crafted the original Magna Carta in 1215 to constrain the power of the unpopular King John, she says, Internet users should organize and push back against the companies.

An article on Friday about California's becoming the first state to require gay history in schools erroneously attributed a distinction to Mark Leon. While he is the first openly gay man to serve as a state senator, he is not California's first gay state senator. Former Senator Sheila Kuehl holds that distinction.
HERMAN--Diana Miriam. Beloved mother, grandmother. Singer, Patelson's clerk, music aficionado.

STEIN--Joel Maier, 67, passed away on July 17 after a brief illness at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital. Born January 9, 1944 in Queens, NY to the late Samuel and Helen Stein, raised in Shaker Heights, OH, and a die-hard New Yorker. Irreverent and loving older brother of David Stein (Josselin, France), beloved uncle of Mikhal (Bouganim), Maya and Adam Stein, devoted surrogate uncle of Peter, David and Sam Beller, and mentor, teacher and tutor of countless others. He was a raconteur, Egyptologist, student of entomology, collector of robots, gourmand and chef who retired from the Federal Reserve Bank of New York after decades of service. His humor, generosity and enormous heart will always be with us. Memorial at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St., New York City on Monday, July 18 at 12 noon.
An obituary on Saturday about the songwriter and record producer Jerry Ragovoy misspelled, in some editions, the given name of a fellow songwriter. She is Carole King, not Carol.

BERGER--Phyllis Belous. Died peacefully in her sleep July 16, 2011 surrounded by children Marsha and Peter, their spouses Jonathan and Nina, and grandchildren Danny, Theo, Laura and Lisa, shortly before her 87th birthday. Preceded in death by husband Alex in 2005. Proud to have helped break down barriers for future generations of woman by having been the 1st female mechanical engineer to graduate from Cooper Union and to share a state board of engineers (NY) and a Engineering Dept. in CUNY history. She was a founding member of the Society of Women Engineers. Passionate about reading and improving the lives of those less fortunate, Phyllis will be missed by all who knew her.

GOMPRECHT--Irvin. On July 17, 2011, Irvin Gomprecht of Jupiter, FL and Baltimore, MD died at home after a brief illness, surrounded by his loving family. He was the devoted and beloved husband of Ginger Harteveldt Gomprecht; loving father of Ellen Oppenheim (Bill) of New Canaan, CT, Tom Gomprecht (Kate) of Baltimore, MD, Henry Harteveldt, III, of San Francisco, CA, Robert Harteveldt (Kristy) of Greenwich, CT, and the late Gerry Gomprecht; dedicated grandfather of Jocelyn Oppenheim, Willy Oppenheim, Jaymie Oppenheim, Annie Oppenheim, Rosey Oppenheim, Charlotte Gomprecht, Sophie Gomprecht, Henry Michael Harteveldt, Ryan Harteveldt and Lauren Harteveldt. During his lifetime he was an adored friend to many and an avid supporter of the Wilmer Eye Institute and the Cardiology Department at Johns Hopkins Hospital, the Associated Jewish Charities, and The Friends School of Baltimore. Contributions in Irv's memory may be sent to The Johns Hopkins Hospital Development Office, 600 N. Wolfe St., Baltimore, MD 21287.

GENSER--Ruth and Sidney. Happy 63rd! After 13 years, I still wish for one more day. Love & miss you, Barbara

LOBEL--Francine, long time resident of the Bronx, passed away peacefully at home. FISH--Marcus. Beloved husband of the late Celia died peacefully on July 16, 2011. Popi was a devoted father to Carol and David Zolondek, adoring grandfather of Stacey (Scott) Ginesin and Lauren (Dan) Furstenberg and proudest great-grandfather of Gabriel, Ezra and Celia. The relationship between Twitter and the outside developers that build its apps is a little like the one between sharks and the small fish that latch onto their backs -- beneficial for both, until it isn't. Lately it has hit rough waters. The Federal Trade Commission is investigating Twitter's relationship with the developers, and although neither Twitter nor the agency would comment, two people briefed on the inquiry said that it questioned whether Twitter had been anticompetitive when it bought or regulated some apps.

An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about America's ties with France, incorrectly described the size of General Rochambeau's forces during the siege of Yorktown in 1781. While the combined forces of the French outnumbered those of Washington, Rochambeau himself commanded fewer soldiers than Washington, not more.

In a City Room post accompanying his article about the rise in weekend subway ridership, Michael M. Grynbaum asked readers to recount their memories of the city subway system of the 1970s and 1980s, when riders had plenty of leg room on weekends, but had to contend with plenty of problems, too. Below, some of the more interesting reader responses, edited for style and space. I have a vivid memory of running full speed back and forth on the ''GG'' train with my cousin. We'd swing wildly from pole to pole and pull ourselves up on the old metal straps. We were always filthy by the end of the ride, but it is definitely a fond place to revisit whenever I'm on a weekend sardine can.- BrooklynBoy426

8 P.M. (Lifetime) MAGIC BEYOND WORDS: THE J. K. ROWLING STORY (2011) Just as ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2,'' the final installment in the movie series, storms theaters, Poppy Montgomery, above, channels Ms. Rowling, the creator of ''Harry Potter'' and a single mother on government assistance in Britain who became one of the world's wealthiest women after a publisher finally took a chance on her first novel. The result: more than 400 million books sold, a billion-dollar film franchise and a place in history as the mastermind behind some of the most beloved characters in children's literature. 8 P.M. (Style) GIULIANA & BILL In the Season 4 premiere of this show about their marriage, Giuliana and Bill Rancic are trying to close the gap in their relationship by moving to the same city. And that in itself is a challenge.
GOLDSTEIN--Doris Fischer. It is with sorrow we mourn the death of our cherished and long time member and express our sincere condolences to her family. Congregation Emanu-El Of the City of New York

J. Terrence Lanni, a gambling company executive who helped turn a single casino into the industry giant now known as MGM Resorts International, died on Thursday night at his home in Pasadena, Calif. He was 68. The cause was cancer, said Alan Feldman, a company spokesman.

Irvina Booker makes a most unlikely criminal. She lives in constant pain, disabled by multiple sclerosis and arthritis, a grandmother whose limited mobility depends on her walker, her daughter and marijuana. ''I never smoked it before I got sick, and I don't smoke it for fun,'' said Ms. Booker, 59, who lives in Englewood, N.J. She would not divulge how she obtains her marijuana, but said, ''I don't want to be sneaking around, afraid someone is going to get arrested getting it for me.''

UNGER--Lynn. On July 9, 2011 at age 77. A passionate artist, world traveler, reader and nature lover, Lynn attended Music and Art High School, then graduated from Queens College Phi Beta Kappa with a degree in Mathematics in 1955. After earning her M.S. in 1970, she taught Math at Baldwin High School from 1973-1993. With her warmth and creativity, commitment and professionalism, she made math fun and logical for countless students, coaching winning Varsity Mathlete Teams, promoting Family Math Days, and continuing to receive commendations for her presentations at conferences and service to NCMTA long after her retirement. She will be greatly missed by her daughters, granddaughters, and many friends and relatives. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Chapel in Great Neck on Sunday, August 28.

Overall album sales, driven by some successful female artists, are up one percentage point so far this year, compared with the first of half of 2010. Adele, above, leads all artists with 2.5 million albums sold of ''21.'' Lady Gaga has helped the electronic music category grow, with ''Born This Way'' (1.6 million) and ''Fame'' (276,000).

SCHWARTZ--Miriam (nee Golding), at the age of 93, on July 15, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Sanford. Sister of the late David Golding. Devoted mother of Barbara (Alex) Sobel and Richard Schwartz. Loving grandmother of Lauren (Marc) Shapiro and Lara Sobel (Tim Faryniarz). Cherished great-grandmother of Aliza, Yael, Danielle, Julia, Joshua, Elahna and Jacob. An article on the DealBook page on Tuesday about recent thriller novels with financial industry themes reversed the publishers of two books. ''The Fund,'' by H. T. Narea, is published by Forge Books and ''The Gods of Greenwich,'' by Norb Vonnegut, by Minotaur Books.

EPSTEIN--Gayola Goldman, (born April 21, 1919) passed away on July 10 in Skillman, New Jersey. She was the daughter of Alice and Rabbi Solomon Goldman, wife of the late Joseph Epstein, mother of Deborah Nord and the late Jeremy Epstein, grandmother of Joshua Epstein, Joseph Nord, Abigail Epstein Schumer, and David Nord, and mother-in-law of Amy Epstein and Philip Nord. She spent most of her life in Chicago, where her father was the leader of the Anshe Emet Synagogue. For many years she was a book reviewer and current events commentator for women's groups. In 2005 she moved to Stonebridge, near Princeton, where she made many wonderful friends. She was an intelligent, loquacious, elegant, and feisty woman, who relished the pleasures of life even amidst loss and leaves a sad silence in the lives of all those close to her. Please direct contributions in her memory to Temple Micah, 2829 Wisconsin Ave. NW, Washington DC 20007 (www.templemicah.org) or The Polycystic Kidney Disease Foundation, 8330 Ward Parkway, Suite 510, Kansas City, Missouri 64114-2000 (www.pkdcure.org).

The Sports of The Times column last Monday, about the muted opposition to Major League Baseball's decision to keep its All-Star Game in Phoenix after the passage of Arizona's immigration law, misstated the date that the executive director of the players union, Michael Weiner, issued a statement expressing opposition to the law but not calling for a player boycott of the event. The statement that was quoted was made on April 30 -- not on July 8, when a similar statement was also issued, noting that portions of the immigration law had been judged unlawful.

WEISSBLUTH--Jack. Caring and loving husband to Sonia. Beloved husband of the late Edith. Devoted and loving father to Jill, Jay and Joy. Cherished grandfather to Casey, Randall, Kevin and Eyan. His love for life will be with us forever.

LOS ANGELES - ''We used to have petroglyphs,'' said Ray Halbritter, the nation representative of the Oneida Indian Nation and the chief executive of its Nation Enterprises. In a telephone interview on Friday, Mr. Halbritter was explaining his nation's reasons for dabbling in the movie business by agreeing to finance a planned picture about the Oneidas, their long-ago chief Han Yerry, and their alliance with American colonists during the Revolutionary War, even when others in the Iroquois Confederacy backed the British.

KAHN--Frank, J of New York City and Saltaire, Fire Island peacefully passed away on July 16th, 2011 surrounded by his family. He was 89 years old. Born in Frankfurt, Germany, he left for America one week before Kristallnacht arriving in New York City on Thanksgiving Day in 1938. In 1942 he joined the US Army and rose to the rank of Captain in the Counter Intelligence Corp. First as the Commanding Officer of the Interrogation of Prisoners of War Team and later as Chief of the Counter Intelligence Branch. He had under direct supervision 15 Counter-Intelligence teams in Holland, Belgium, France and Luxembourg and supervised all German prisoner of war interrogation teams for Holland, Belgium and France. For his service he received the French Medaille De La Reconnaissance and the Belgium Reconnaissance Des Services Medaille. In civilian life Frank became President of Start Pilot Corp. working with the aerospace industry and later founder and President of Motive Power Corp. After retiring he found great pleasure traveling and spending time at his home on Fire Island. He is survived by his loving wife of 48 years, Joyce, their son Paul of New York City, his sister-in-law and brother- in-law Grace and John Dick, niece Erica Carroll, nephew Jon Dick, all from Ft. Lauderdale, FL and his cousin Arnold Simmel. He will always be remembered for his vibrant personality, zest for life and great sense of humor. Visitation will be at Riverside Memorial in New York City on Tuesday, July 19 from 2:00-4:30pm and 6:30-9:30pm. A private funeral service will be held on Wednesday.

MCCARTNEY--Dorothy T.,58, of Manhattan, NY, on July 15, 2011. Beloved daughter of the late Dr. John and Dorothy McCartney of Manhasset. Loving sister of the Rev. John J. McCartney. Devoted niece of Patricia Fidgeon. Graduate of Smith College (1975). Former Research Director for William F. Buckley Jr., and lifelong employee of National Review Magazine. Reposing at Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, on Sunday and Monday, 3-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass at 10am Tuesday at St. Mary's RC Church in Manhasset. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Life, St. Paul's Convent, 586 McLean Ave., Yonkers, NY 10705

We don't think in trillions. We think in hundreds and maybe thousands once in a while. So, sorry if all this hullaballoo sounds a little unreal to us. SHARON CHEEK, of Clovis, Calif., on the contentious negotiations in Washington over raising the debt ceiling. [A11]

Guitars, guitars, guitars. They droned and scrabbled, pinged and screeched, buzzed and pealed through Saturday afternoon at the Village Voice/4Knots Music Festival, a free indie-rock concert at Pier 17 at South Street Seaport on Saturday afternoon. With just one stage and six bands, it was the pared-down successor to 10 years of the Siren Music Festival that The Voice used to present at Coney Island. The lineup -- The Black Angels, Titus Andronicus, Davila 666, Oberhofer, Eleanor Friedberger and Mr. Dream -- was purist in a way, clinging to hand-played instruments while steering clear of the electronic dance beats and hip-hop elements that other indie rock has embraced. (Those sorts of music were played in DJ sets -- by Dan Deacon, Yeasayer and others -- two blocks from the pier at the festival's Indoor Lounge, overrun with sponsors.) The bands performing Saturday chose an era, or scrambled together a few of them, and personalized their favorite parts of the rock timeline. By and large they did it well; the references were obvious, but so were the individual passions.

MARINE--Edward, of Buffalo, NY, on July 11, 2011. Devoted husband of Judy and beloved father of Joseph, Deborah, and Tricia. A memorial service will be held at the Buffalo Club on July 19 at 2pm. Memorials to Doctors Without Borders.

If you are not solving in a way that enables you to see it, the Notepad says: “When this puzzle is done, you will find that the ends of the answers to the five starred clues, when in the 15-/67-Across, comprise a 1-/71-Across.” That’s a fairly cryptic clue, so let’s get solving and see what he means.

On Friday, I reported on the Family Independence Initiative (F.I.I.), an organization that encourages low-income families to define their own goals and work towards them in mutual support groups, while carefully documenting their successes. So far, the few hundred families that F.I.I. has worked with have demonstrated impressive gains in areas like income and savings, debt reduction, skills training, and improvements in children’s grades and health care.

In May, I went to Iowa, primarily to learn more about so-called conventional agriculture, those thousand-acre farms growing corn and soybeans, planted, tended and harvested largely by machine. (We have plenty of the other type — what’s variously called traditional, or alternative, or non-conventional — in the Northeast.) But thanks to an auspicious combination of topsoil, climate, topography and weather, Iowa is among the best locales for farming in North America, and I saw a wide range of practices.

Finally, some not-dispiriting news from Washington: President Obama has given his qualified support to a new plan to reduce the deficit, remarking that it “is broadly consistent with what we’ve been working on at the White House.” And who put forward this proposal that could help stave off economic catastrophe? A bipartisan group of seven senators called the Gang of Six. (Congress has never been good with numbers.) Earlier this year, Bill Keller wrote a column for the magazine praising the gang’s efforts, which he said proved that the word “politician” need not be a synonym for “craven,” and it’s certainly worth rereading now.

We saw it first on the spring runways at Valentino and Chloé — models wearing delicate gold anklets with the daintiest flats. Then, for resort, the Row collaborated with the jewelry designer Ileana Makri on charmy versions of the accessory. And earlier this week the blogger Garance Doré confessed her love for the delicate adornment. It’s official: The anklet is de rigueur again. “I made one for myself last summer, and I absolutely love it,” the jewelry designer Irene Neuwirth says. “I don’t wear it every day, but I do find that once I put it on I don’t take it off.” Can’t wait until the Row’s resort version hits stores? Doré recommends doing it yourself. “I love the simple ones — tiny gold or silver bracelets will do, small beads I put on a string, or even just a piece of colored cord,” she says. “It’s charming when it feels easy.”

Remember the epic battle between CSX, the big railroad company, and the Children’s Investment Fund Management, a British hedge fund? If you do not, you are not alone. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit appears to have forgotten it as well. It took the federal court two years to give out its opinion deciding the litigation fight between the parties, in a ruling that came down on Monday that left some issues unsettled long after the battle subsided.

No amount of coverage of the lives of the Beatles could make us say it’s all too much, and the cable networks are surely relieved to hear it. Following an announcement by HBO that it had acquired a documentary about George Harrison, Showtime said on Tuesday that it would broadcast a nonfiction feature about Paul McCartney and his experiences in New York after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. The film, “The Love We Make,” will chronicle Mr. McCartney’s journey from Sept. 11, 2001, when his plane was grounded on a New York tarmac, through his planning for and performance at the “Concert for New York City” at Madison Square Garden the next month. “The Love We Make” will feature footage from that concert as well as appearances by Mr. McCartney’s friends and colleagues, including David Bowie, Eric Clapton, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Pete Townshend, as well as his daughter Stella. It is directed by Bradley Kaplan and Albert Maysles, the venerated co-director of “Grey Gardens” and “Gimme Shelter,” as well as the 1964 documentary “What’s Happening! The Beatles in the U.S.A.”

LONDON — My favorite part of “Being Shakespeare,” Simon Callow’s one-man show about guess who, was the intermission. This is no dis to Mr. Callow, a gracious and well-spoken docent in the eternal museum that is the life and works of William Shakespeare. But it was at the interval (as Londoners call the rest period between acts, when the audience provides the dialogue) that I felt that the old glovemaker-turned-playwright was most truly alive.

Rembrandt van Rijn and Edgar Degas don’t make for the most obvious pairing in art: the 17th-century Dutch painter is more associated with dark, somber portraits and landscapes, while the French Impressionist is best-known for his romantic pastel-hued scenes from ballet. But the Rijksmuseum (Jan Luijkenstraat 1; www.rijksmuseum.nl) is ingeniously devoting one show each year to the influence of great Dutch painters on those of other periods and nationalities, providing insight into relatively unexplored links between famous artists. Last year, Jan Steen was paired with Joan Miró. This year, through Oct. 23, the museum presents “Two Young Artists,” featuring more than 20 self-portraits of Rembrandt and Degas as they were beginning their early careers.

While all those associated with the ''Harry Potter'' film franchise presumably spent the weekend rolling around in their portions of the money minted by the record-breaking opening of ''Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2,'' a longstanding plagiarism case against the ''Harry Potter'' author J. K. Rowling has come to an end because of a shortage of funds. On Monday, Reuters reported, representatives for the estate of Adrian Jacobs said that their plagiarism case against Ms. Rowling ''was dead'' after they failed to meet a Friday deadline to pay the first portion of a $2.6 million security fund mandated by a British court if the case should go to trial.

The Stratford Shakespeare Festival's hit revival of ''Jesus Christ Superstar,'' the 1971 rock opera by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice about the last days of Jesus' life, will transfer to La Jolla Playhouse in San Diego in late fall for six weeks of performances that may serve as a prelude for a move to Broadway. La Jolla executives announced on Monday that ''Superstar,'' which is at the Ontario festival through October, will replace the musical ''Finding Neverland'' in its 2011-12 season and run from Nov. 18 to Dec. 31. A spokeswoman for ''Finding Neverland,'' which is based on the 2004 film starring Johnny Depp as J.M. Barrie, said on Monday that the project would instead have a private workshop in New York in the future.

Despite a 13-month absence after an excruciatingly tense Season 3 cliffhanger, ''Breaking Bad'' set a ratings record in its return to AMC on Sunday night. According to Nielsen, an estimated 2.6 million people tuned in to witness the further misadventures of the meth dealers Walter White (Bryan Cranston) and Jesse Pinkman (Aaron Paul) and to learn whether Jesse actually killed a fellow meth cooker. That number was 32 percent greater than the viewership for last season's premiere, and was the highest total in the series' history. Elsewhere, CBS won the night for the broadcast networks, with a double bill of ''60 Minutes'' (8.5 million total viewers) and ''Big Brother'' (6.89 million) leading the way. On Friday night, the 90-minute series finale of ''Friday Night Lights'' on NBC played the underdog to the end, drawing a mere 3.48 million viewers. That episode, which ran earlier on DirecTV, last week earned an Emmy nomination for outstanding writing for a television drama, along with the three other nominations (for outstanding drama, actor and actress).

DAVIS--Gertrude "Trudi", 95, died May 20th, 2011. Trudi's generosity and warmth were an inspiration. Ms. Davis is survived by her three children, Rina Okonkwo, Laura Davis, and Charles Davis and their spouses, six grandchildren, and 11 great grandchildren.

In order to cancel games, the N.B.A. first has to schedule them. So Tuesday, the league will announce the dates, times and matchups for a season that may never happen -- or at least, not on those dates and times. With the lockout now in its third week, the N.B.A. will engage in the awkward ritual of announcing its 2011-12 schedule, with a special on NBA TV (at 2 p.m.) and more content at NBA.com, where player likenesses are currently prohibited. As a practical matter, the N.B.A. has to book arenas and give its teams time to plan, even if N.B.A. and union officials all seem to doubt that the season will start on time.
THE FACTS Allergies are generally considered more of a nuisance than a blessing. But for some people there may be a silver lining.

LINKEDIN DOWNGRADE The rally in LinkedIn's stock price took a bit of a hit from an unlikely source: one of the underwriters for its initial public offering. The social network's shares fell 6.9 percent on Monday, to $102.44, after an analyst at JPMorgan Chase downgraded the company to neutral from overweight. Not that JPMorgan, which co-led the I.P.O. with Morgan Stanley and Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch, has fallen out of love with LinkedIn. ''Our move to neutral here is based on valuation rather than fundamental concerns,'' the analyst, Douglas Anmuth, wrote in a note to JPMorgan clients.

Marketa Kimbrell, an actress and co-founder of a theater company that brought stage productions to audiences for whom they were rarely available, among them prison inmates, died on July 6 in Sykesville, Md. She was 82. The cause was Alzheimer's disease, her son Andrew said.

SIMON--Francine. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Francine Simon and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

9 P.M. (Sundance) LUDO BITES AMERICA Ludo Lefebvre, above right, catapulted to stardom at L'Orangerie and Bastide in Los Angeles, where he became the city's only chef to receive the Mobil Travel Guide Five Star Award at two restaurants. Now he is on a mission to apply his culinary talents to everyday cuisine. In this new series he and his business partner and wife, Krissy, cross the country in an effort to reinvent comfort food. They start in Santa Fe, N.M., where they open their pop-up restaurant, LudoBites, outside a favorite local haunt, Tecolote Café. The Lefebvres discover a community of spice-craving food lovers, but the inexperience of Katie Adkins, the owner of Tecolote, and the Lefebvres' ambitious menu threaten to undermine the project. 8 P.M. (NBC) IT'S WORTH WHAT? Cedric the Entertainer hosts this new game show, in which contestants must discern the price of collectibles, oddities and treasures like a life-size model of the White House or William Shatner's kidney stone. Those who guess correctly through a succession of progressively more difficult rounds can win up to $1 million.

A vaccine meant to help people quit smoking has failed to work in a large, late-stage clinical trial, dealing a setback to efforts to harness the immune system to help people fight addictions. Some 11 percent of the people who received the vaccine, called NicVax, had quit smoking after a year, virtually the same as the percentage for those getting a placebo.

TRENNER--Edgar M.,89, July 16, 2011 in Florence, MA after a brief illness. Survived by his wife of 58 years Noreen nee Karsh, sons Daniel in Florence, MA, Donald in Nashville, TN and twin sister Estelle M. Linz in Cortlandt Manor, NY. Ed served in WWII as a much decorated B24 Bomber Pilot, who flew 47 missions with the same crew and plane. An eagle scout, Ed was a life long camp director and owner. He owned Kamp Kohut in Maine and was active in the American Camping Association.

Frank Langella, who has memorably played Richard Nixon on stage and screen in ''Frost/Nixon'' (and of course Count Dracula in the film ''Dracula''), will write of his up-close-and-personal encounters with Elizabeth Taylor, Laurence Olivier, William Styron, Marilyn Monroe, Arthur Miller and Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, among others, in a memoir to be released next year, his publisher said on Monday. HarperCollins acquired the rights to ''Dropped Names,'' Mr. Langella's first book, said Jonathan Burnham, the publisher of the Harper imprint. ''Mr. Langella is a razor sharp writer with a brilliantly perceptive eye and a remarkable gift for the telling detail,'' Mr. Burnham said in a statement. Mr. Langella, whose long career has included films like ''Dave,'' ''Starting Out in the Evening'' and ''The Ninth Gate,'' is set to return to Broadway this fall in the Terence Rattigan drama ''Man and Boy.'' This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
SCHARFF--Shirley. July 18, 1929 - Jan 22, 2010. Life is not Forever, but Love lasts an Eternity. Happy Birthday My Angel from All of Your Loved Ones. Always, Your Cliff

SIMON--Francine Iny died on July 17, 2011. Widow of the recently deceased Abdallah H. Simon, known as Ab, Francine was mother to Jamil and Michael and loving grandmother to Lucy. Married for 58 years, she and Ab had a life long love. They were beloved "Aunty and Uncle" to younger generations of the Sassoon, Simon, and Iny families; their open-hearted hospitality made their home a center for family and friends. Francine will be remembered for her deep love for family, especially children; her unwavering loyalty and many acts of quiet kindness; and her unquenchable thirst for learning. With her optimism, generous spirit and vitality, she made many dear friendships. She was a beloved docent at the Jewish Museum for 15 years. And, she and Ab focused much of their charitable giving on building kindergartens in Tel Aviv through the Tel Aviv Foundation. Funeral services will be on Tuesday, July 19, at 10am at the Riverside Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

LEAKE--Jane W.,of Bryn Mawr, PA, formerly of Villanova, PA, on July 14, 2011, age 89. Widow of John B. Leake. Survived by two daughters, Alexandra Leake and Joan Leake, three grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Also survived by her brother Frederick W. Whitridge, of Orcas Island, WA, and many nieces and nephews. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, September 24 at 11am at St. Christopher's Church, Gladwynne, PA.

An article on July 11 about the golfer Rory McIlroy of Northern Ireland and his cross-community appeal in his home country misidentified one of the colors in the Republic of Ireland flag. Besides green and white, it also has a stripe of orange -- not gold. (The flag's colors are sometimes referred to as green, white and gold.)

Schapiro of the Securities and Exchange Commission and Gary Gensler of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. An article last Tuesday about new federal rules on reporting the sale of multiple guns along the Southwest border misidentified the opponents of the regulations. Gun-rights advocates, not gun-control advocates, have strongly contested the rules.

Most doctors view pain as a symptom of an underlying problem -- treat the disease or the injury, and the pain goes away. But for large numbers of patients, the pain never goes away. In a sweeping review issued last month, the Institute of Medicine -- the medical branch of the National Academy of Sciences -- estimated that chronic pain afflicts 116 million Americans, far more than previously believed.

The board of the News Corporation might as well be named ''Friends of Rupert.'' The independent directors - who have a fiduciary responsibility to the company's shareholders - have remained silent amid the widening scandal at Rupert Murdoch's media empire.

BLOCK--Morris. In loving memory of Morris Block, Esq., on the centenary of his birth in New Rochelle, NY, July 19, 1911. Passed away September 30, 1986. Son of Max and Annie Silver Block. Gifted violinist as a youth, ambidextrous athlete, semi professional basketball player and in the first national rankings of table tennis players in 1931. Graduated from NYU Law School at age 22. Member of the Hebrew Mutual Alliance of New Rochelle, President of the New Rochelle Bar Association and a 33rd Degree Mason. Enlisted and served in the U.S. Army during World War II, attaining the rank of Captain. Married the former Colette Garfunkel, of Paris, France, March 4, 1956. A charming and gregarious storyteller and a no-nonsense straight shooter with a sound ethical and moral compass; an honorable and proper gentleman with a warm and giving heart. Survived by his wife and his son, David S. Block, also an attorney. Still and forever missed and eternally loved. He was a devoted husband and the best role model a son could have. Colette and David

While Americans are closely divided over whether the debt ceiling should be raised, the public gives President Obama higher marks than Congressional Republicans for his handling of the negotiations, according to the latest CBS News poll. The number of Americans who say the debt ceiling should be raised has increased from 24 percent last month to 46 percent this month, the poll found. Currently, 49 percent say it should not be raised, down from 69 percent in June. Majorities of Democrats and those who are following the debate very closely support raising the ceiling.

WASHINGTON -- With Republicans and Democrats still deeply divided over how to shrink the budget deficit and the national debt, the only way for them to avoid a financial crisis at this late date may be to perform a legislative magic trick. The idea, conjured by Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican leader, would allow Republicans to accede to an increase in the government's debt limit without actually voting for it or giving in to President Obama's demand for tax increases as part of any deal.

SEOUL -- On the day South Koreans rejoiced over the selection of Pyeongchang as the host city of the 2018 Winter Olympics, prosecutors continued to peel back layers of a long-hushed dirty secret of the nation's sports landscape. Since June, 55 professional soccer players have been indicted in the biggest match-fixing scandal in South Korean history. Prosecutors called the problem ''endemic.'' Almost 1 in 10 players in the K-League, Korea's professional league, have been indicted, prompting it to introduce lie-detector tests and to break into two eight-team divisions, with teams caught manipulating the outcome of games being relegated to the lower division. The league said it would also double the minimum annual salary for a player to almost $23,000, hoping the added pay would reduce the temptation to take bribes.

Several people were reported injured when a stage collapsed Sunday evening during a performance by Cheap Trick during the Ottawa Bluesfest, though the band members were said to be unharmed, according to The Associated Press. Canadian weather services had predicted a thunderstorm in Ottawa on Sunday night, which struck while Cheap Trick was performing on the festival's main stage. This YouTube video posted by a user named gastorch997 shows the stage coming down in a matter of seconds as stunned onlookers scream. A concertgoer named Meghan Hurley wrote in The Ottawa Citizen that she ''heard a loud bang,'' after which ''a frightened woman'' told her ''almost in tears that the stage had collapsed.'' Ms. Hurley added, ''I glanced over to where we had sat only moments before and all that remained was a heap of chairs that looked like a windswept pile of kindling for a bonfire.'' Marc Messier, a spokesman for the Ottawa Fire Services, told The A.P. that a 49-year-old man was in serious condition with abdominal, pelvic and leg injuries, another person had a spinal injury and a third person had experienced chest pains. At least eight more people received treatment at the scene for minor injuries and anxiety.

President Obama praised the nominee's record on the game show, calling it ''not too shabby.''

An article on July 8 about the Murdoch family's decision to shut down The News of the World, the newspaper at the heart of the hacking scandal in Britain, erroneously attributed a distinction to the newspaper. Before the paper stopped publishing, its circulation was the largest for a Sunday newspaper in Britain -- not the largest circulation of all the country's newspapers, including dailies. (That distinction is held by The Sun, another Murdoch newspaper.) The article also quoted incorrectly from a report on newspaper revenues. Hoovers, a company that tracks business information, said that annual revenues for News Group Newspapers -- not for The News of the World -- totaled $985 million. (The News of the World was part of that group.)

As the United States' biggest foreign creditor -- holding an estimated $1.5 trillion in American government debt -- China has been a vocal critic of what it considers Washington's politicized profligacy.

MACHNIKOFF--Philip. The partners and staff of Loeb & Troper express deep sorrow on the passing of Phil Machnikoff, retired senior partner and good friend. Our deepest sympathies go out to Tina Machnikoff, beloved wife, and Adena Kurlander, Daniella Muller and Zehava Atlas, beloved daughters and their children, as they mourn this great loss. Phil began his career with the firm in 1963 and quickly rose through the ranks, becoming well known for his convivial style with colleagues and clients. Over the years, he worked with some of the most prestigious organizations in the greater New York area and was considered an invaluable resource to leading executives and board members. He sat on the firm's Executive Committee and played an instrumental role in building the firm's practice. He was well known as the keeper of Loeb & Troper's rich and impressive history. Phil was admired by staff and clients alike and will be missed dearly. May Tina, Adena, Daniella and Zehava be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Partners and Staff Loeb & Troper LLP

LONDON -- And so the sorry story continues, as people from the corridors of power confess their crimes and await their judgments. The glamorous favorite of the tyrant has fallen from her high perch, and it is rumored that further depths of corruption are waiting to be plumbed. Reputations everywhere are in tatters. Such was the view on Saturday night - no, not of the television screen from my couch - but from a seat at the Donmar Warehouse toward the end of its production of ''Luise Miller.'' I had been reluctant to tear myself away from the ever-evolving news of the phone-hacking scandal, which could be relied upon to produce a fresh resignation or arrest at regular intervals. But leave it to Friedrich Schiller, the 18th-century German chronicler of the evil that politicians do, to provide a soap opera that's nearly as juicy as that surrounding Rupert Murdoch's News International organization (and Parliament and Scotland Yard).

Like Jon Chait and Matt Yglesias, I’m a little puzzled by the sudden wave of optimism about a potential deal based on the Gang of Six’s just-released bipartisan deficit reduction plan. So far as I can tell, the Gang of Six proposal bears a broad resemblance to the “grand bargain” that President Obama supposedly offered to John Boehner, except that the Gang’s tax reform proposals are more detailed (and raise more revenue) and its proposals for Social Security and Medicare cuts are less specific (there’s a lot of “requiring” Senate committees to come up with budget-cutting reforms). Depending on what came out of the entitlement reform process, I suppose that the Gang’s proposal could be a better deal for conservatives than what Obama offered Boehner. But more likely it would turn out to be a somewhat worse deal, with higher taxes and fewer real entitlement cuts, than the bargain House Republicans already inclined against when their own leader seemed to be considering it. (I recommend reading James Capretta for the sharpest conservative case against the Gang’s proposals, and Reihan Salam for some important qualifiers.)

Trash really can be treasure, or least ratings gold, as History proved with its much-publicized cross-over event of three of its most popular shows last week. The gimmick, in which the stars of “American Pickers,” “American Restoration” and “Pawn Stars” joined forces to find, purchase and restore a 1957 Chevy 150 to pristine condition, worked, as the average 6.7 million total viewers tuning in made clear. But just how well became clearer with a look at the Top 10 list among basic cable shows for the week ending Sunday, according to Nielsen: the three shows all finished in the Top 10, with “Pawn Stars” second only to the Japan/U.S.A. final in the Women’s World Cup. “Pawn Stars,” in which viewers are privy to the haggling prowess of a family of pawnshop owners, has proved to be a major hit for History, as its ratings keep growing; the most recent episode, on Monday night, garnered 6.67 million viewers.

This is the season of the less-is-more clutch, with handfuls (pun intended) of designers offering palm-friendly options for girls on the go. Add to the list Beth Goodman, who in 2009 launched Marie Turnor Accessories, a collection of bags modeled after the most ubiquitous strapless carrier of all — the lunch bag. The idea came to her in Paris when she spotted a woman holding a perfect red paper bag. “I saw it as being a clutch,” Goodman explained. “It just looked to me like it should be,  it was such a chic and simple shape. I knew I had to create one in leather.” Her signature style, appropriately named the Picnic, is made of buttery-soft leather and comes in red, black, tan and white. For summer, Goodman is including a range of limited-edition colors — pale pink, purple, gold, bright turquoise and a sparkling aqua. Versatile, featherweight and with minimal hardware, they’re a welcome relief for our wardrobes and shoulders both.

If you’ve had your fill of glossy Pop Art and are suffering from aesthetic indigestion, “Prelude: Paul Thek in Process,” set to open this week in Berlin, is a wonderful palate cleanser — not to mention a poignant reminder that, when it comes to art, the means can be as, well, meaningful, as the ends. The curator Susanne Neubauer has focused on the ephemeral nature of a visionary artist’s practice, assembling rare slides, photographs, taped interviews, letters and other documents. The installation echoes Thek’s work, which, like his process, often reflected a sense of transience. A cascade of newspapers from walls to floor and pools of chicken wire are meant to evoke the spirit of his 1969 piece “Chicken Coop.”

Why is your brain on Google better than your brain sans Google? Because it gives you somewhere to store all that trivia you would otherwise have to waste precious brain cells remembering. Or so says Jonah Lehrer, via Andrew Sullivan on the Daily Dish, who points out that Google not only helps us remember but also helps us correct our often faulty memories. “While the Web enables all sorts of other biases – it lets us filter news, for instance, to confirm what we already believe – the use of the Web as a vessel of transactive memory is mostly virtuous. We save hard drive space for what matters, while at the same time improving the accuracy of recall.” So forget all those warnings about how the Web just makes us dumber. It’s perfectly okay if you have to Google something you just read two seconds ago.

COOPER--Sidney, 92, died at home in Florida on Monday. One of the great big band and studio musicians and arrangers of his era, Sid played lead woodwinds in the Tommy Dorsey Orchestra, the Tonight Show Orchestra, and for Frank Sinatra. He was predeceased by his first wife Ethel, and is survived by his wife Patricia, daughters Carole (Richard) and Nancy (Bruce), grandchildren Adam (Amy), Jonathan (Mimi), and Emily and great-granddaughters Lily, Ellie, Melody and Jolie. His music will live on. Riverside Memorial Chapel, Thursday at noon. In lieu of flowers, donate to the Nat'l Endowment for the Arts at www.nea.gov.

Ask not for whom the East River bridges were tolled. They would have still been tolled for thee, except for the fact that 100 years ago on Tuesday, Mayor William J. Gaynor rescinded the fee. Decades later, advocates for mass transit and for maintaining public works are lamenting the loss of revenue had the tolls remained in effect.
LIEBERMAN--Evan. You were taken much too soon. We are all broken hearted. If you only knew how many lives you touched. Our sincere condolences to Ben, Debbie, Jamie and Rachel. The Birdoff's

The gay pride parade continues in Riverdale, the longtime home of Archie Andrews and his friends. Kevin Keller, the first openly gay resident of the town, who was introduced in issue No. 202 of Veronica in September, will have his own monthly comic book starting in February. ''He's proven to be incredibly popular,'' said Jon Goldwater, co-chief executive of Archie Comics. ''We're just so proud of the success of Kevin and the fact that he adds a new dynamic to Riverdale.'' The series, titled Kevin Keller, will follow a four-issue mini-series starring Kevin that began in July and has started filling out his background, including his relationship with his father, who serves in the military and is supportive of his son's desire to follow in his footsteps. Like those for the other Archie characters, Kevin's series will deal with his life in high school. ''He's going to be the class president,'' said Dan Parent, the writer-artist who created Kevin. But it won't all be a good time. ''Even the most popular kids are not popular with everybody,'' Mr. Parent said. ''There's some adversity he'll have to deal with.''

8 P.M. (TCM) LITERARY ROMANCE Turner Classic Movies presents five films adapted from beloved novels, starting with ''Pride and Prejudice'' (1940), the Jane Austen classic about five sisters out to nab husbands in 19th-century England, the better to produce an heir to save the family farm. Greer Garson plays Elizabeth Bennet, the eldest, most independent daughter; Maureen O'Sullivan, Ann Rutherford, Heather Angel and Marsha Hunt portray the others; and Mary Boland is their frantic mother. Laurence Olivier, above with Ms. Garson, is the dashing Mr. Darcy, Elizabeth's ardent suitor -- if only she could stand him. The lineup continues at 10:15 with ''Madame Bovary'' (1949), starring Jennifer Jones as Gustave Flaubert's country girl who sacrifices her marriage for what she thinks is true love; then with ''Anna Karenina'' (1935), the Tolstoy tale of a statesman's wife (Greta Garbo) who deserts her family for the affections of a young officer (Fredric March), at 12:15 a.m.; ''Little Women'' (1949), featuring June Allyson, Margaret O'Brien, Elizabeth Taylor and Janet Leigh in Louisa May Alcott's semi-autobiographical story about New England life during the Civil War, at 2; and ''Far From the Madding Crowd'' (1967), with Julie Christie as Thomas Hardy's romantic English lass who can't choose among three suitors (Terence Stamp, Peter Finch and Alan Bates), at 4:15. 9 P.M. (TNT) FRANKLIN & BASH A judge (Kathy Najimy) puts Bash (Mark-Paul Gosselaar) and Franklin (Breckin Meyer) under house arrest after they act up in court one too many times. And the niece of Infeld (Malcolm McDowell) is busted for marijuana possession by another judge (Tommy Chong).

KAHN--Grace. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime, cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her husband Frederick and their family. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Lois S. Nyren, President

HEDGE FUND GAINS While the hedge fund industry has largely been flat this year, a few closely watched managers stand out. D. E. Shaw, the hedge fund founded by David Shaw, left, has racked up 20 percent gains in one fund through June, compared with a meager 1 percent gain for the industry. The firm's multibillion-dollar composite portfolio is up more than 7 percent, according to an investor in the fund. Citadel, the hedge fund run by Kenneth Griffin, is up 11 percent for the first six months of the year, according to a person close to the firm. And SAC Capital, the hedge fund run by Steven A. Cohen, is up 10 percent, according to an investor in the fund.

FURST--Moshe, passed away Tuesday July 19th, 17 Tamuz in Rehovot, Israel where he resided for 38 years. Married for 58 years to the late Batya Furst. Loving father of Zev (Sandy), Malki (Dov Cymbalista), and Aryeh (Debi). Devoted grandfather to Donny (Jackie), Dalia (Eric Sussman), and David Furst; Shlomit (Yisrael Katz), Yair (Carmit), Eli (Einav) and Yonatan (Rivkah) Cymbalista; Rachel, Leah (Tzvi Hasten), Yosef, Miri, Tova, Hadassah Furst and 17 great-grandchildren. Former Director General of Yeshivat Hadarom and Executive Vice President of Yeshiva University.

Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg raised his offer on Tuesday to universities interested in setting up a school of engineering and applied sciences in New York City: along with practically free use of a swath of land, the city will contribute as much as $100 million. Mr. Bloomberg publicly presented an invitation to universities to bid on the chance to create a campus, either on one of three city-owned properties or elsewhere in the city. Issuing the request for proposals is the latest step officials have taken to try to make New York more competitive with Silicon Valley as a hub for technology-based businesses.

Mitch Winehouse, a former salesman and London cabby, is quick to say that he knows he is only getting a shot at being a professional jazz singer at the age of 60 because his daughter is Amy Winehouse, the British soul singer and songwriter whose struggles with addiction have been fodder for the tabloids. But he also makes it plain that he thinks he can sing, and says that he will dispel doubts about his talent. To hear him tell it, he is on a mission to unearth lovely but forgotten jazz and swing hits and introduce them to a new generation. In early April he released an album of seldom-covered jazz tunes, as well as four originals by the British songwriter Tony Hiller, a family friend who produced the recording.

SPORTS Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about Darren Clarke's victory at the British Open misstated the number of golfers from Northern Ireland who have won a major championship. Clarke is the fourth, not the third -- following Fred Daly, the 1947 British Open champion; Graeme McDowell, the 2010 United States Open champion; and Rory McIlroy, the 2011 United States Open champion.
KELLER--Ann, age 98, of West Palm Beach died peacefully on July 18. Adored by her late husband, Morris. Loving mother of Sylvia and Larry. Blessed with grandchildren and great-grandchildren.

An editorial on Friday about the Roman Catholic Church's handling of sex abuse cases incorrectly described current Irish law. A law has been proposed requiring abuse to be reported to civil authorities. It has not been enacted.

Even as the big banks stanch their losses, they are reckoning with an unfortunate reality: the anemic recovery is hurting their results. Second-quarter numbers on Tuesday from the nation's two biggest consumer lenders, Bank of America and Wells Fargo, showed the toll the sluggish economy was taking on revenue growth. As Americans increasingly dig out of debt, lenders' income is being reduced by a fall-off in mortgages, credit card and other types of consumer loans.

DUNBAR--Richard McKee. Beloved husband of Marianne Longo passed away on July 15, 2011 in New York City. He is mourned by all who knew him. A private service will be held. Gifts may be made in his memory to VNSNY Hospice Care in New York City.

INTERNATIONAL An article on July 12 about the release of a suspect arrested in the case of an Afghanistan woman mutilated in 2009 for leaving her husband misspelled the suspect's name at one point. As the article correctly noted elsewhere, it is Sulaiman, not Suleiman. (The suspect, like many Afghans, has one name.)

THE ARTS A picture caption on Saturday with an exhibition review of a display at the Empire State Building about the building itself may have left the incorrect impression that the picture showed the Hudson River. The river visible in the photograph, taken from the building's 103rd floor, is the East River. (The caption noted that the 103rd floor, which is not open to the public, also provides a view of the Hudson River.)

ROTHSTEIN--Sophie, 93, passed away peacefully on Sunday. Born in Warsaw, Sophie and her husband, Sidney fled Europe. They made a new life for themselves in New York: raising their children and involving themselves in many social issues. A gracious and intelligent woman with a beautiful smile, Sophie was a loving wife to Sidney. She was survived by her sons, Edward and Jeffrey, her daughter-in-law, Ellen and her grandchildren, Aaron and Emily. Services 9:30am Thursday at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel (91st and Amsterdam).

NATIONAL An article on July 7 about the closing of public pools nationwide because of budget cuts referred incorrectly to the operation of New York City pools in recent years. While the city proposed pool closings in its last two budgets, funds were ultimately provided and all pools were able to remain open; it is not the case that the city had to close pools, cut back hours or seek alternative financing as did several other major cities.

MACNEIL--Cornell. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of one of America's great baritones, Cornell MacNeil. For 28 years he performed major roles on our stage with a rare combination of rich voice, dramatic intensity, and impeccable style. His repertoire was broad, and he will be especially remembered for the range and depth of vocal tone and the incomparable characterization he brought to such Verdi parts as Don Carlo in Ernani, and the title roles in Nabucco, Simon Boccanegra, Macbeth, and Rigoletto. Rigoletto was his Met debut role in 1959 and the one he sang most often here, more than 100 times in all. He was also a close friend to many in our company, and we offer our sincere condolences to his wife Tania, his five children, including Walter who has also sung at the Met, his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and all those whose lives he touched.Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director

SCIENCE TIMES An article on Tuesday about Diana Nyad, who at age 61 is preparing to swim from Cuba to Florida, misstated her professional role. She is a commentator for the Los Angeles-based public radio station KCRW; she does not work for National Public Radio.

FELDMAN--Doris Lear, passed away surrounded by her family, on July 18, 2011 at age 84. Born in New Haven, CT to the late Samuel and Ida Lifschutz. Doris worked as a writer, a chef and a painter. Survived by her cherished children Susan (Charles R. Gordon), Bruce and Stephen Feldman, adoring grandchildren Jacqueline Naomi Gordon, Rebecca Judith Gordon, and loving brother Dr. Erwin Lear. She is predeceased by her beloved husband Julian and a brother David Frankel. Funeral service today, 11:30am at Congregation Keser Israel Cemetery, West Haven, CT.
