New York City officials, hoping to prevent confusion and disappointment as thousands of gay and lesbian couples prepare to marry, said Tuesday that the city would take the unusual step of limiting the number of marriages on Sunday, the first day the state will allow same-sex marriage. Facing an influx of requests, the city said it would make available 764 marriage licenses through a lottery. Couples who are turned down for Sunday will be able to try again during the rest of next week, when the clerk's offices in all five boroughs will be open for two extra hours each day.

HALL--George M. Jr. , 86, died at home in Greenwich Village July 15, 2011. Former Tuskegee pilot, organist, choirmaster, educator, George taught at Wingate, Stuyvesant and Taft High Schools as well as Manhattan School of Music and Wagner College. He served as organist and choirmaster at Holy Apostles, Trinity Lutheran, S.I. and Holy Name churches among others. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Chantal Bruchez-Hall and four children from a previous marriage, Althea, Howard, Leslie and Michael. A memorial service will be held in the Fall.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Tuesday about John S. Toll, a former president of Stony Brook University, misidentified, in some editions, the president to whom John H. Marburger III, who succeeded Dr. Toll at Stony Brook, was science adviser. It was President George W. Bush, not the first President George Bush.

A Reuters article on Tuesday about quarterly earnings at Gannett, the media company, referred imprecisely to the number of newspapers it publishes. It publishes USA Today, 81 other daily newspapers and nearly 1,000 weekly newspapers; it does not publish only 81 newspapers in addition to USA Today.

FINNEGAN--Patricia Marie. 83, died on July 16, 2011, at her home in Manhattan. She was preceded by her husband of 57 years, William R. Finnegan. She leaves behind sister Barbara, daughter Colleen, sons William, Kevin and Michael, daughters-in-law Caroline and Lacey, and adored granddaughters Masha, Leigh and Mollie. A Los Angeles native, Pat produced TV movies. She was executive producer of "Quicksand," "To Dance with Olivia" and "Keeping Secrets." Her many other films included "A Father for Charlie" and "The $5.20 an Hour Dream." She was the daughter of Arthur and Pauline Quinn. Her father was a refrigerator mechanic, her mother a nurse. Pat graduated from Corvallis, a San Fernando Valley Catholic high school. Known for her spirit of adventure, she set off traveling and working odd jobs -- in Yosemite, Nantucket and Manhattan. In the late 1940's she met Bill Finnegan, a colleague at the Hollywood Citizen-News. They married in New York in 1952. They raised their children in Los Angeles and Honolulu. In 1977 they founded Finnegan Associates - later, with Sheldon Pinchuk, the Finnegan-Pinchuk Co. - which became a leading supplier of TV movies. A 6-month shoot in Paris sparked, for both Pat and Bill, an enduring love affair with France. They were avid travelers and staunch liberal Democrats. Pat was a member of the Hollywood Women's Political Caucus. She loved New York, its music and theatre. In the 1990s she and Bill moved back to Manhattan. They spent summers in Sag Harbor with their children, their grandchildren and their many friends.

DAVIS--Gertrude "Trudi", 95, died May 20th, 2011. Trudi's generosity and warmth were an inspiration. Ms. Davis is survived by her three children, Rina Okonkwo, Laura Davis, and Charles Davis and their spouses, six grandchildren, and 11 great grandchildren.

FRONT PAGE The Common Sense column on Saturday, about Congressional efforts to cut back the budget of the Securities and Exchange Commission, misidentified the House committee led by Representative Spencer Bachus, a Republican from Alabama. He is chairman of the House Committee on Financial Services, not the Appropriations Committee.

Ecolab, the disinfectants maker, is near a deal to buy the water treatment company Nalco Holding Company for about $5 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Tuesday. Shares in Nalco closed on Tuesday at $28.87, giving it a market value of about $4 billion. Ecolab is expected to also assume Nalco's long-term debt, putting an enterprise value on the deal of close to $8 billion.
INTERNATIONAL FINANCIAL CONTAGION FEARED

POISTER--John J. Expert mixologist, distinguished author and prolific food and travel journalist and columnist for various publications, died on June 30. A resident of Manhattan for over 40 years. Son of the late Beatrice and Ralph Poister and the brother of deceased Patricia. He is survived by his beloved wife Carol Poister of 26 years. He has two sons, John, Jr. and Geoffrey, and a deceased daughter Diana, from his first marriage. A graduate of Drake University in Des Moines, Iowa. He served in the China-Burma-India Theater in World War II with the 490th Bombardment Squadron. After a career as creative director for various advertising agencies, in 1969 he founded General Strategics, Inc, a New York-based creative communications consulting firm specializing in food, beverages and travel marketing which encompassed two subsidiaries: International News Features Network and Poister Productions. He was a chevalier honoraire of the Confrere des Chevaliers du Tastevin and was a member of the International Association of Culinary Professionals, the Wine Media Guild, and the University Club. An accomplished outdoorsman, he was a lifetime member of the Camp Fire Club of America in Chappaqua, New York. His passion for Big Band music started in his teenage years at Chicago's New Hyde Park High School where he and classmate Mel Torme (the Velvet Fog) started a dance band. A memorial service will be held at a later date.

An earlier version of this article included an additional sentence about the United States' investigation into Mr. Lauder's business partners. That sentence has been removed as a result of an order handed down by a German court in a defamation suit brought by one of the partners, Boris Fuchsmann.

I feel that people I trusted -- I don't know who, on what level -- have let me down, and I think they have behaved disgracefully, and it's for them to pay. RUPERT MURDOCH, denying personal responsibility for the phone hacking scandal that has racked his media empire. [A10]

A few hours before the Mets distributed Ike Davis bobblehead dolls for fans attending Tuesday's game, the real-life version of the player created a ripple during an appearance at a Long Island day camp when he said that his chances of returning from an ankle injury this year were ''not good.'' Later, Davis told reporters in the Mets' clubhouse that he still held out hope that he could return this season - he has been out since early May - and would continue to work to that end, although he was unsure about his recovery timetable.

A music review on July 11 about the opening night at Tanglewood, using information from the program, misidentified the scene from Bellini's ''Norma'' in which the soprano Angela Meade performed the title role. It was Act I, Scene 4, not Scene 1. (Norma does not enter until Scene 4.)

LOWINGER--Fran, passed away peacefully on Monday. She fought leukemia for three years. She will be missed by her daughter Carol (Bob), her sons Stewart and Richard (Joy), and many relatives and friends. Fran's beloved husband Louis passed away in 2004. She was a clinical social worker for many years. Services noon tomorrow at "Sinai Chapels" in Fresh Meadows, 800-446-0406.

Goldman Sachs has long been known as a Wall Street firm with a Midas touch, wringing out significant trading profits in good times and bad. But another major market miss has analysts and investors wondering if the company has lost its way.

As Pilobolus continues its 40th-anniversary season at the Joyce Theater, the group, which started in 1971 and is named after a fungus, is -- by the looks of it -- working hard to maintain its playful edge. At least that was evident in Monday night's program, which was overlong and slightly improvised to make up for the dancer Eriko Jimbo's recent injury. In two works Renée Jaworski, the troupe's associate artistic director, took over part of Ms. Jimbo's repertory. Instead of ''Redline,'' we saw the glorified cardio-funk dance ''Megawatt,'' in which performers spasm on their backs as if they were sizzling scraps of bacon. More and more, it seems, there is always one idea in a Pilobolus dance, but rarely two.

Last year, Cole Real Estate Investments of Phoenix, a sponsor of nontraded real estate investment trusts, refunded $3 million to the West Warwick, R.I., pension board, which had bought shares in one of its REITs despite strenuous objections from its investment adviser, who resigned in protest. Cole took this unusual step after the Townsend Group of Cleveland, an adviser to the state pension board, reviewed the investment at the request of public officials and said it was unsuitable for a pension fund. Townsend's long list of reasons included the excessive fees paid by investors and the company's lack of liquidity and ''appropriate policies for investment valuation,'' public documents show.

SHARENOW--Audrey, 83, died July 18, 2011, survived by her children Elliot and Muriel Wiener, her grandsons Benjamin and Matthew Wiener, her daughter-in-law Wendy Naidich, her son-in-law Michael Blake, and her sister and brother-in-law Marilyn and Milton Brechner.

CAHILL--Thomas P.,on July 17, 2011. Cherished husband of Terri. Beloved father of Thomas. Brother of Karen Bartholomew. Uncle of Jennifer and Colin Bayly. Reposing Redden's Funeral Home, 325 West 14th St., New York City, Thursday, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial: Friday, 10am, Oratory Church of St. Boniface, 3 Metrotech Brooklyn, NY. Interment: St. Joseph's Cemetery, Newton, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations to National Stroke Association, Washington, DC or the Mary Manning Walsh Home, New York City.

GLASSMAN--Alexander Howard, born February 4th, 1934, died on July 19th at Roosevelt Hospital in New York City in the arms of his wife and children. A pioneer in the field of psychopharmacology, Sandy worked for over 40 years at the Columbia University School of Medicine. His success as a physician and an academic was fueled by an insatiable intellectual curiosity, great persistence, pure stubbornness, and a passion for the science of medicine. He loved tennis and he loved food and some years he loved the Knicks but mostly he loved and was loved by his family, who will miss him forever. He leaves behind his wife Judy after 53 years of mutual devotion and respect, as well as his children: Steven and Sylvia Glassman of Louisville, Kentucky and Doug and Laura Hercher of Edgemont, New York. He leaves behind six beloved grandchildren, Bennett, Devon, James, Katie, Dylan and Michael, who were the pride and delight of his final 25 years. Services 11:45am Thursday, July 21st at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Donations in his memory may be made to: NARSAD Brain and Behavioral Research Fund.

Carl C. Icahn is a whirlwind. He has agitated for change at General Motors, Time Warner, Yahoo and dozens of other companies over the last decade. But Mr. Icahn is as controversial as he is ubiquitous. In his latest move, the billionaire financier made an unsolicited bid to buyClorox, an offer that was promptly rejected by the board on Monday.
SIMON--Francine. Mayor Huldai and the Tel Aviv Foundation note with sadness the passing of our longtime partner and beloved friend.

BUSINESS DAY A chart on Tuesday with an article about foreign holdings of United States Treasury debt gave an incorrect figure for Germany. Germany holds $61 billion in American Treasuries, or .061 trillion dollars -- not $610 billion, or 0.61 trillion dollars. A corrected chart is at nytimes.com/businessday.

HARWOOD--Betty, July 17, 2011. As beautiful and unique as the flowers she created. Adored by her family -- husband, the late Milton Harwood; children, Janet Felleman (George), Victor Harwood, and the late Laura Harwood; grandchildren, Juliette Janssens (Mark), Susanna Felleman (Erik Feig), and Elizabeth Felleman Hammel (Jamie); and great-grandchildren, Annabelle, Cameron, Eleanor, Oliver and Alex. World-premiere productions of new plays by the Pulitzer Prize-winner John Patrick Shanley (''Doubt''), the filmmaker and writer Ethan Coen (''No Country for Old Men'') and the prolific playwright Adam Rapp (''The Metal Children'') are among the Atlantic Theater Company's lineup for the 2011-12 Off Broadway season, executives there said on Tuesday. Following the previously announced Simon Stephens play ''Bluebird,'' which begins performances on Aug. 9 and stars Simon Russell Beale, will be Mr. Rapp's ''Dreams of Flying Dreams of Falling,'' a surrealist look at wealthy families in America. The artistic director of the Atlantic, Neil Pepe, will direct the Rapp play as well as the other work on the fall schedule, Mr. Coen's ''Happy Hour,'' three one-act comedies about poor souls in unhappy circumstances.

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Syrian security forces killed at least 15 people on Tuesday in the central city of Homs, residents and activists said, in a violent escalation in a place that has emerged as a focal point of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad. Armed men loyal to the government opened fire as funeral processions for 10 protesters who were killed Monday left the Khaled Bin al-Waleed mosque. Among those who died were the mother and the son of a demonstrator killed Monday, said an activist in the Homs neighborhood of Bab Amr who identified himself as Mohammad and was reached by telephone.
SLONIM--Ethel, on July 19, 2011 in her 89th year. Devoted wife of the late Harry Slonim, and loving mother of Bert, Helaine, and Robin.

SANDERSON--Katie. The Board and Staff of The Moth express their deep sadness and profound sense of loss at the unexpected passing of their beloved colleague Katie Sanderson and extend their heartfelt condolences to her family.

Adele, the soulful British singer and songwriter who has dominated American and British charts this summer, was among the 12 artists nominated today for the Barclaycard Mercury Prize, along with the rapper Tinie Tempah and the electronic-music wunderkind James Blake. Considered the most prestigious music award in the United Kingdom, the prize is given each year to the best British or Irish act and the winner is chosen by a small group of journalists and music industry professionals. The roster of nominees usually has a mix of mainstream and lesser-known musicians, but the prize often goes to eclectic artists who have not enjoyed commercial success.

LONDON -- Rupert and James Murdoch said repeatedly during their extended testimony before a parliamentary committee in Britain that their involvement in managing the News Corporation's response to the phone hacking scandal was limited. Rupert Murdoch said he felt let down by ''the people that I trusted and then, maybe the people they trusted.'' Even so, the Murdochs' defense of their roles highlighted several issues that continuing investigations by parliamentary committees and the police are likely to examine in greater detail. Among them:

The writer John Patrick Shanley won a Pulitzer Prize in drama and a Tony Award for best play for “Doubt” in 2005 at his longtime theatrical home, the Manhattan Theater Club, which began producing his work in the mid-1980s. “Doubt” was the first in a trilogy; the second play, “Defiance,” was mounted in 2006 at the club and was popular with audiences (it had a healthy three-month run) but a bit less so with critics.

Egypt’s antiquities department has been downgraded from a ministry to a cabinet-affiliated office, according to the Los Angeles Times, which cited an Egyptian cabinet spokesman Thursday. The announcement came after a new Cabinet was sworn in that did not include an antiquities minister. Egypt’s antiquities agency had been elevated to a ministry by the former president, Hosni Mubarak, in the last days of his rule; previously it had been under the Ministry of Culture. It still remained unclear, however, who the government intends to appoint to run the office. Last Sunday, officials said the prime minister, Essam Sharaf, planned to replace Zahi Hawass, the longtime antiquities chief, as part of a cabinet reshuffling aimed at appeasing protesters. Since the revolution, Mr. Hawass has come under fire for his ties to the Mubaraks and his financial relationships with American organizations like National Geographic. Mr. Sharaf at first said that he would appoint Abdel Fattah el Banna, a professor at the University of Cairo, as the new minister of antiquities, but he reversed himself after the choice drew protests from archeologists. In the meantime, Mr. Hawass said that Mr. Sharaf had asked him to continue to go to work, according to the Art Newspaper.

Thursday marks the one-year anniversary of the date the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform act became law, and it is also the day many of the law’s provisions take effect. Some of those measures are controversial, like new enforcement powers for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and new limits on the fees banks can charge merchants for debit card transactions. Others have almost entirely escaped noticed. Among the little-discussed changes: a Depression-era ban on paying interest on business checking accounts has finally been retired. And big banks are quickly — and for the most part quietly — adapting.

Teen drama, both real and fictional, continues to be a winning formula for MTV. The network’s new scripted comedy series “Awkward” made its debut to strong ratings Tuesday night, following the hit show “Teen Mom,” a reality series whose title needs no explanation. Currently on its third season, “Teen Mom” drew 3.2 million viewers and was the most-watched cable show in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic for the night, a prize it has claimed each week since its season premiere on July 7, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers. “Awkward,” which focuses on the teenage life of one Jenna Hamilton (Ashley Rickards), who wants nothing more than to fit in at her high school, picked up slightly more than 1.7 million viewers.

Eataly, the Italian megamarket, will mark its first birthday with lots of products on sale, but also a special event: a dine-around in all its restaurants on Aug. 31. Groups of 40 people will go from restaurant to restaurant in the market, starting with Manzo for a taste of mortadella-stuffed suckling pig, then Le Verdure for a fresh vegetable soup, La Pizza for focaccia with toppings, next La Pasta for spaghetti alla chitarra with sea urchin, then Le Pesce for swordfish “filet mignon,” and finally La Piazza for dessert. Each course, served at communal tables, includes wine. The cost is $180 per person including tax and tip. This extravaganza can be booked at 45 minute intervals from 5 to 9:30 p.m.

Many economists have argued that the continually deteriorating housing market may be holding workers back from relocating to areas where jobs are more plentiful. If you can’t sell your home in Detroit, where the unemployment rate is 11.6 percent, you’re not able to move to Fargo, where the rate is a mere 3.5 percent. That creates a geographic mismatch in the labor market, and keeps job growth lower than it might otherwise be if workers were more mobile.

What will our cities look like in 30 years? That’s the question posed by joint shows in New York City and Amsterdam, as architecture centers in each city simultaneously display an international collaboration, “Glimpses of New York and Amsterdam in 2040.” The exhibition organizers challenged 10 architecture and design firms to imagine a healthier urban future that includes new waterside cityscapes, neighborhoods and transit systems for both cities. “Glimpses” will remain on view in New York at the Center for Architecture (536 LaGuardia Place; 212-683-0023; www.aiany.org) through Sept. 10, and at the Amsterdam Centre for Architecture/ARCAM (Prins Hendrikkade 600; 31-20-620-4878; www.arcam.nl) through Aug. 13.

No amount of coverage of the lives of the Beatles could make us say it's all too much, and the cable networks are surely relieved to hear it. Following an announcement by HBO that it had acquired a documentary about George Harrison, Showtime said on Tuesday that it would broadcast a nonfiction feature about Paul McCartney and his experiences in New York after the 9/11 terrorist attacks. The film, ''The Love We Make,'' will chronicle Mr. McCartney's journey from Sept. 11, 2001, when his plane was grounded on a New York tarmac, through his planning for and performance at the ''Concert for New York City'' at Madison Square Garden the next month. ''The Love We Make'' will feature footage from that concert as well as appearances by Mr. McCartney's friends and colleagues, including David Bowie, Eric Clapton, Mick Jagger, Keith Richards and Pete Townshend, as well as his daughter Stella. It is directed by Bradley Kaplan and Albert Maysles, the venerated co-director of ''Grey Gardens'' and ''Gimme Shelter,'' as well as the 1964 documentary ''What's Happening! The Beatles in the U.S.A.'' Mr. McCartney said in a statement: ''''It was an honor to be able to help New York and America at that time in its history. There was a feeling of shock and fear in the air that I thought we could help alleviate with music. And the fact that so many people stepped up to join us made for a very uplifting evening for us all.''

Q. How do I change the voice mail password on my iPhone? I don't even know if I have one, as I'm never prompted for it when I check my messages. I have AT&T. A. You were probably prompted to select a password when you bought the phone and set up an AT&T account. Once the setup work is done, the phone remembers the password for you, making it much quicker to tap in and retrieve voice mail messages.

That's one notion that seems to be circulating among small-business owners and their advisers lately. Consultants at McKinsey & Company floated the suggestion as part of their controversial report on employer views of health insurance. And in The Times's coverage of that report, Milt Freudenheim interviewed a small-business owner who said he was hoping to ''game the system.'' The owner, Gerry Harkins, who is also chairman of the National Federation of Independent Business's Georgia State Leadership Council, said he might split his Atlanta-based construction company into two smaller companies to evade the overhaul's employer mandate, specifically the penalties on companies that fail to offer affordable health insurance to employees. Unfortunately for Mr. Harkins (who did not return a call from The Agenda seeking an elaboration of his comments), the authors of the Affordable Care Act are one step ahead of him, according to several tax and benefit lawyers contacted by The Agenda. The authors included a provision that basically adopts parts of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 that say any group of companies under common control are to be treated as a single company. Common control is defined as the same five or fewer people owning at least 80 percent of the companies, according to Al Martin, a tax lawyer at the Kansas City law firm Lathrop & Gage. Spouses and children are generally considered one owner, according to Mr. Martin.

ECOLAB DEAL Ecolabagreed on Wednesday to buy Nalco Holding, a water treatment company, for $5.4 billion in stock and cash in the disinfectant maker's largest acquisition. Under the terms of the deal, Ecolab will pay either 0.7005 of a common share or $38.80 a share in cash, a 32 percent premium over Nalco's Tuesday closing price. Up to 30 percent of Ecolab's bid is payable in cash.

AT the Harry Potter premiere in London earlier this month, Emma Watson wore her growing-out pixie soft and wispy. For the New York premiere last week (above), she went super slick, a look that was all over the fall runways. If it looks as easy as dipping a comb in Dep, it turns out there are tricks to getting it right. ''The technique requires methodical product application,'' said Ms. Watson's hairstylist, Rodney Cutler. Who knew? He recommends combing a mix of Redken Sheer Straight and a smoothing serum through your hair, section by section, then applying a spray that adds shine (Mr. Cutler uses Cutler Shine Tattoo) and hairspray to seal in the works. ''This way, it repels the humidity and stops the underneath from bubbling out,'' he said. With longer hair, take your cues from the runway. At Saint Laurent, hair was side-parted with a low chignon pinned up in the back; at Gucci and Akris, it was pulled into ponytails.

Having returned from a humid if lucrative trip to Bangkok (to shoot the smash summer comedy ''The Hangover Part II'') with all of his digits intact, Bradley Cooper is headed to another sweltering location for his next movie - and we don't mean Australia. Mr. Cooper will portray Lucifer, the fallen angel turned ruler of Hell, in a film version of Milton's ''Paradise Lost,'' The Associated Press reported. The original epic, you surely recall, told the story ''of man's first disobedience, and the fruit of that forbidden tree'' that was used by Satan to tempt Adam and Eve away from God, and famously sought to ''justify the ways of God to men.'' While the blind Milton had to dictate his poem to secretaries, the ways of the film industry are a little different: Australian government officials announced on Wednesday that the special-effects-heavy ''Paradise Lost'' movie would be directed by Alex Proyas, the director of big-budget action features including ''I, Robot'' and ''Knowing,'' and would be filmed largely at the Fox Studios in Sydney, with some financial incentives from the government of New South Wales.

There are few series I can think of whose conclusions occasion feelings of sorrow. ''The Sopranos'' ended amid confusion and awe. We may miss the narrative and the ingeniously black comedy of it all, if not the actual characters, none of whom you really want tucking you into bed at night. The same can be said of ''Big Love,'' another of the greatest family dramas ever on television. Though we may miss its intelligent social commentary, we do not necessarily pine for the people in it to re-enter our lives. HBO renders characters ambiguously; we are not supposed to fall in love with each and every one of them. As a network series, ''Friday Night Lights'' operated under certain constraints and the result was not only an exquisite bit of anthropology -- life in a small, working-class Texas town - but a show in which beloved characters became intimates in our own lives. The series is over now, and I can genuinely say, I'm sorry that I won't be able to see how these lives further unfold -- how Tami and Eric make out in the Northeast, how Tim and Tyra do as a married couple, how Becky and Luke manage his time in the military, how Billy and Mindy will manage with twins.

Blake Shelton, the country singer who was one of the judge-slash-coaches on the hit NBC talent show ''The Voice,'' has ridden his new television fame to No. 1 on the music chart. Mr. Shelton's ''Red River Blue'' (Warner Brothers Nashville), his sixth album, has become his first No. 1 on the Billboard album chart, with 116,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. ''Red River Blue'' leads several high-charting new releases, including the rock band Incubus's first album in five years, ''If Not Now, When?'' (Epic), which opened at No. 2 with 80,000 and is the group's fifth to reach the Top 5. Another country singer, Chris Young, reached No. 4 with his new release, ''Neon'' (RCA Nashville), selling 73,000.

Ladies of the House, room H211 is open for business, if you need to do your business. For years, female members of the House of Representatives were forced to slog their way through Statuary Hall to the Lindy Claiborne Boggs Congressional Women's Reading Room to use the restroom, while men have long enjoyed the use of a men's room right off the floor of the House. While the number of female members of the house - there are currently 72 - has grown through the years, this issue was never addressed, even as a women's restroom was constructed adjacent to the Senate chamber in 1993.

''The Right to Fashion in the Age of Terrorism'' by Minh-Ha T. Pham in Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society. The Argument: Consumerism has long been considered a cornerstone of democracy and a civic obligation in American society. Ms. Pham examines why the fashion industry, in particular, became the emblem of freedom and economic revitalization following the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks. ''Freedom to shop is one of the fundamental liberties terrorists want to deprive us of,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared in October 2001 at the start of Fashion Week in New York. Ms. Pham, an assistant professor of art history and Asian-American studies at Cornell University, argues that the ability to express oneself through dress could be starkly represented as a symbol of democracy in comparison with the burqa, which was denounced as an example of Taliban repression and invoked when government officials listed the humanitarian justifications for the war in Afghanistan. Ms. Pham complains that this assumption about the burqa, however, ignores the desires of Muslim women who may choose to be covered and discounts the hostility that the Muslim veil has sometimes incited in Western societies.

The House Ethics Committee agreed Wednesday to take the unusual step of hiring an outside counsel to investigate its own actions before moving ahead again with the long-stalled inquiry into allegations of wrongdoing by Representative Maxine Waters, a Democrat from California. Billy Martin, a former Justice Department prosecutor who now works for a Washington law firm, was named as the special counsel. He was asked to first determine if Ethics Committee staff members violated House rules last year during the investigation of Ms. Waters by passing information inappropriately to certain Republican committee members and making statements that showed a bias against Ms. Waters.

When my grandparents moved into a retirement center, I helped with the garage sale. My cousin Claire and I were joking about how best to display the odds and ends from their 60 years together when I stumbled upon a gift from the gods of high kitsch. It was a letter opener, but this was not your typical letter opener. In the clear acrylic handle floated a mini uterus with two pills strategically placed where ovaries normally reside, alongside the drug's name, Hormonin. This promotional product was a gift from a drug company representative to my granddad, a doctor in Laredo, Tex. I tried to imagine how this token must have been received by the taciturn Dr. Puig. ''Thanks Hal, I'll put this next to my collection of kidney stones.'' Or, ''Do you have that on a T-shirt in an extra large?'' Highly doubtful. He probably focused on its utility and kept it right there on his desktop. Which is probably what the drug company's marketing department was counting on.

In a move escalating a long-standing rivalry between Simon Cowell and Simon Fuller, two of the most powerful television producers in England - and former partners in the success of ''American Idol'' - Mr. Fuller filed suit Wednesday in California against the Fox Broadcasting Company over the coming ''Idol''-like singing competition show, ''The X Factor.'' The suit was filed in Superior Court in California, according to a statement from Mr. Fuller's office. Executives at Fox said that they had not received the suit as of midday Wednesday and declined to comment until they did.

SOFIA, Bulgaria -- Arms pinned behind his back, Alexei ''The Tractor'' Petrov lay with his face pushed to the floor after heavily armed masked police commandos raided his home early last year. The police then hauled him off in one of Bulgaria's most pronounced efforts to take on the godfathers of racketeering, kidnapping and prostitution who have eroded trust in the country's institutions and day-to-day life. Released from jail in October 2010, then from house arrest this February, Mr. Petrov still faces serious charges like racketeering and threatening to murder a business partner. But that has done little to quash his bravado.

A report in the Nocturnalist column on Saturday misidentified the material used to create a puppet of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg that made an appearance at an exhibition of Jim Henson's work at the Museum of the Moving Image in Queens. Muppets, in general, are made of fleece, foam, fake fur and fabric. A spokeswoman for The Jim Henson Company refused to be more specific about the materials used to make Muppet Mayor Bloomberg (Bluppet to his friends), saying, ''We consider the 'magic' that goes into how we make our puppets as trade secrets and beyond the info I gave, we really can't be more specific.'' What is known is that Bluppet is not made of felt.

It is now more than three years since the economy took a nosedive. For most small businesses, this has been even more challenging than previous recessions because we have also had to deal with the real estate collapse, a credit crisis and changes in the marketplace brought on by the Internet and other forces. Not an easy time. And I don't see much evidence of a bounce back coming soon. I have come to the conclusion that it is time to reassess. First of all, Einstein had it wrong. Not his theory of relativity. That seems to be holding up quite well (not that I would know). But he's also the guy who said that the definition of insanity was doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results. Too often, I think that's really the definition of small business.

KRAFT--Myra. The officers, Board, and staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) deeply mourn the passing of our esteemed friend and beloved Board Member, Myra Kraft. An extraordinary leader in the JDC family, Myra's boundless generosity, wisdom, and dedication was an inspiration to both our lay and professional leadership. Passionately involved in JDC's worldwide programs, especially through her extensive travels, Myra's special focus and support of our work in Israel was invaluable. A JDC Board Member since 1994, she served with vigor as Chair of the JDC's Israel Committee, the Rescue Committee, and the Myers-JDC-Brookdale Institute Sub-Committees on Disabilities and Children. A philanthropist of profound energy, Myra's remarkable ability to improve lives was evident in her service as President and Director of the New England Patriots Foundation. She also proudly chaired United Jewish Communities' General Assembly and the Combined Jewish Philanthropies of Greater Boston (CJP), where she led the Israel Program Committee. In her local community, Myra served on the Board of Trustees of Brigham and Women's Hospital and was the first woman to chair the Boys and Girls Clubs of Boston. She championed a variety of organizations, including The Boston Foundation, The United Way, Catholic Charities, Brandeis University Board of Trustees, Temple Emanuel, and a number of private foundations in Boston. We extend our deepest condolences to Myra's beloved husband, Robert, her children Jonathan, Dan, Josh, and David, and her eight grandchildren. May her memory be for a blessing. Dr. Irving A. Smokler, President Judge Ellen M. Heller, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Chief Executive Officer

KRAFT--Myra, Sandy and I are so sad to hear about the loss of our dear friend, Myra Kraft, after a valiant battle against cancer. A vital woman, with many talents and interests, not the least of which was fishing. We were so lucky to have known Myra; she will be in our hearts forever. Rest in peace Myra dear. Love, Joan & Sandy Weill

DELACORTE--Valerie. The Board of Trustees, artists, and staff of The Public Theater mourn the passing of our dear friend and longtime Board member, Valerie Delacorte. Mrs. Delacorte and her husband George T. Delacorte supported The Public Theater since its earliest stages, and helped fund the establishment of The Delacorte Theater, which opened its doors in 1962 to provide free performances of Shakespeare in the Park to the people of New York City and it continues to do so to this day. Mrs. Delacorte was actively involved in the arts throughout her lifetime and had served on The Public Theater's Board of Trustees since 1992. Ah, Rebecca Black. As you sing in your new music video, ''My Moment,'' you've ''waited for so long'' for your moment to come. It's been five whole months since your first music video, ''Friday,'' made you famous in not quite the way you expected and was watched 160 million times on YouTube. You even turned 14 in the meantime. Now you're going to be famous on your own terms, at your own Web site, plus on your YouTube channel and, starting Tuesday, at iTunes. What that turns out to mean, as just about anyone could have guessed, is that you've traded guileless, catchy awfulness for smug, catchy soullessness, a classic pop-culture progression. Your new song, which went live Monday night, starts out with a rebuke: ''Weren't you the one who said/That I would be nothing?/Well, I'm about to prove you wrong.''

The Manhattan borough president, Scott M. Stringer, called on Wednesday for the abolition of the $49 million pot of money the City Council distributes each year to nonprofit groups, saying the process for giving out the grants had become overly political. Mr. Stringer, whose office conducted a yearlong study of the funds, said the current system had led to vast economic disparities. He pointed to one Upper East Side district that received twice as much in grants as a far less affluent district in Washington Heights.

The rigging contractor who worked on a giant crane that collapsed three years ago and killed seven people had his license revoked on Wednesday by the Department of Buildings. The decision by Commissioner Robert LiMandri to revoke the license of the contractor, William Rapetti, came in response to a 28-page report issued by an administrative law judge, who oversaw a seven-day hearing in December.

THE Southwest trend, with its Native American prints and electric-colored feathers, continues into fall -- just look at the Santa Fe-inspired patterns at Proenza Schouler or the Navajo embroidery and fringe at Isabel Marant. For a quick fix, we like these chunky silver rings from Fortune Favors the Brave, a jewelry line designed in Brooklyn by Shannon Davenport and Julia Wilson, who tweak traditional Western wear with a modern sensibility. The ring at left, their first design, was based on the concho, an etched silver piece traditionally used to adorn saddles and suede fringe jackets. The collection includes the stamped motif ring at right, as well as bolo necklaces and turquoise pieces. ''We try to use a lot of different shapes with our rings,'' Ms. Davenport said, ''so that they look like a cool geometric mash-up when they're next to each other on your hand.'' Wear them stacked with other rings, or start collecting to wear on each finger.
SEERSUCKER PUNCH New England's classic summer textile is reimagined in lightly puckered violet silk. With a swingy silhouette, the dress is airy enough for August's humid days.

Details of the agreement were not disclosed, but the statement said it would include participation of Europe's banking sector.

Today, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act is under siege and behind schedule. As worries mount that new regulations could hamper the nation's economic recovery, lobbyists are trying to undo or significantly weaken the law.

7 P.M. (SNY) RALPH KINER: 50 AMAZIN' YEARS Think about the Mets, and chances are you'll think about Mr. Kiner, the Hall of Fame slugger whose voice has been associated with the team since its inception in 1962. Now in his 50th season in the broadcast booth, Mr. Kiner (above, with an image from his playing days) discusses his career as an outfielder with the Pittsburgh Pirates, Chicago Cubs and Cleveland Indians; his signature home run into Kiner's Korner at Forbes Field in Pittsburgh; his postgame show by the same name in New York; and his personal life, including his romance with Elizabeth Taylor and his friendship with Bing Crosby. Mr. Kiner also reveals how he came up with his signature home-run call -- ''That ball is gone, goodbye'' -- and his role as an announcer today. Tom Seaver, Tim McCarver and Vin Scully offer reminiscences. 6:45 P.M. (MoreMax) INVICTUS (2009) This rousing drama from Clint Eastwood, based on the book ''Playing the Enemy'' by John Carlin, was inspired by a true story of revenge, reconciliation and athletic triumph. Morgan Freeman (near right) portrays Nelson Mandela, newly elected as South Africa's first black president, and Matt Damon (far right) is François Pienaar, the captain of the Springbok rugby team, a source of Afrikaner pride despised by many blacks. Mandela views the team as a vehicle to bring the country's races together, especially if it can win the Rugby World Cup, which South Africa is to host. '' 'Invictus' has implications beyond its immediate time and place that are hard to miss,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''It's an exciting sports movie, an inspiring tale of prejudice overcome and, above all, a fascinating study of political leadership.''

The International Monetary Fund pressed for gains in the yuan, drawing criticism from Chinese officials who blamed the global financial crisis for delaying a shift to a more consumer-led economy. The I.M.F.'s 24 directors ''generally agreed that, over the medium term, a stronger renminbi would be an important component in rebalancing the economy toward domestic demand,'' the fund said Wednesday.

Retired Adm. Noel Gayler, a highly decorated pilot who in the 1970s served as commander of American forces in the Pacific and director of the National Security Agency, but who was an ardent advocate for nuclear disarmament, died on July 14 in Alexandria, Va. He was 96. His death was confirmed by his wife, Jeanne.

PARIS -- Beyoncé Knowles's latest chart-topping album hit stores less than a month ago. But it is not the singer's music that has the fashion world buzzing. The fourth album by the artist, titled ''4,'' features a fold-out cover that looks more like a glossy fashion magazine spread than a record sleeve. As with other leading pop music divas like Lady Gaga, Rihanna and Katy Perry, fashion has always played a big role in Ms. Knowles's artistic persona. In her music videos, she uses outfits to take on different roles -- from sexy diva in sky-high heels and a leotard in ''Single Ladies (Put a Ring on It)'' to joyous bride in a wedding dress for her latest video ''Best Thing I Never Had'' -- while onstage, revealing ensembles spice up her live performances.

Leiby Kletzky, the 8-year-old boy who was killed last week after being kidnapped as he walked home alone from day camp, was drugged with painkillers and muscle relaxants before he was smothered to death, the city medical examiner's office announced on Wednesday. A statement by Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, the chief medical examiner, said the cause of death was not just suffocation, but also ''intoxication by the combined effects of cyclobenzaprine (muscle relaxant), quetiapine (antipsychotic), hydrocodone (pain medication), and acetaminophen (Tylenol).''

GLASSMAN--Alexander H.,MD. The faculty and staff of New York State Psychiatric Institute, the Department of Psychiatry, Columbia University Medical Center, and the NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital deeply mourn the passing of our beloved friend, admired teacher and distinguished colleague Alexander H. Glassman, M.D. Dr. Glassman was an internationally recognized clinical researcher whose innovative and scientifically rigorous contributions to our knowledge of serious mental illness changed the way we treat patients. Dr. Glassman was born in Chicago and received his M.D. degree from the University of Illinois. He joined the faculty of Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York, and, after service in the United States Army, returned to New York and joined the faculty at Columbia in 1969, rising to the rank of Professor. Dr. Glassman was a prolific researcher with broad vision. His work was among the first to document that monitoring the blood concentration of antidepressant medication was an effective method of improving treatment success. He was a pioneer and recognized expert on the impact of psychiatric medication on the heart and the impact of depression on the development of heart disease. His studies were among the first to document that mood disturbance following myocardial infarction was associated with a substantial increase in later mortality, and in a seminal study he showed that treatment of depression in this vulnerable population may well increase survival. In recent years, Dr. Glassman established the links between smoking and psychiatric illness, and formulated a neurobiological model that led to new treatments for nicotine addiction. His work was at the core of a sophisticated revision of our understanding of the relationship between mind, brain and the body. He authored over 350 publications in every major journal in medicine. He received numerous awards and honors including the American Psychiatric Association's Prize for Research, New York State Research Award, the NARSAD Distinguished Investigators Award, and the Anna-Monika Foundation Prize. He lectured around the world and was an important contributor to scientific meetings for over four decades. As a member of the Columbia faculty for over 40 years, Dr. Glassman trained generations of psychiatrists and mentored young researchers, many of whom have gone on to leadership roles themselves. Dr. Glassman was also an extraordinary clinician. His extensive knowledge of psychiatric illness, professional integrity and exceptional devotion made him the most sought after consultant. His exacting attention to detail, his love of his work, along with his marvelous creativity endeared him to all of us. He cared for his patients with warmth, wisdom and humanity. With profound sadness for this irreparable loss, we extend our deepest sympathies to Dr. Glassman's family.Jeffrey A. Lieberman, M.D.Chairman, Dept of Psychiatry Director, New York State Psychiatric Institute Lee Goldman, M.D.Executive Vice President and Dean Columbia University Medical CenterHerbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO, NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital

HANNELI MUSTAPARTA, model, fashion blogger and street-style photographer at hanneli.com. WHAT I'M WEARING NOW The shirt is Topshop. I was over everything being sequins, but this is not over-the-top shiny, and I love baby yellow. The shorts I just found in Paris. They were made from vintage white leather. The shoes are Acne. The blazer is Rag & Bone from this season. The sunglasses, my favorite in the world, I had specially made at Selima. I had the frames for reading and asked to have them made with black gradient lenses. I wore them nonstop, so I gave them a break all last year. Then I saw Anja Rubik in Paris wearing what looked like the same glasses, so I dug mine up because they are perfect for the season. It's fun to be reminded of things you already have in your closet.

Getting excited about a Bluetooth car speakerphone is a tough business. First, it's a Bluetooth device, so if you've seen one, you've seen them all. Second, it's a device made for the car so it's kind of useless for folks who spend time on the subway. That said, I'm actually impressed by (and willing to discuss) Jabra's Freeway speakerphone, a small, compact, battery-powered device that connects to almost any cellphone and offers surround-sound audio, hands-free calling, and FM transmission so you can listen to music and take calls on your stereo.

There are few things in life that I avoid as strenuously as video games. Sure, I played a bit of Pong and Pac Man in my day. But when games started becoming these immersive, life-devouring experiences, I stayed away. Not because I consider them stupid or beneath me. I don’t know whether such games make us smarter or if they represent important achievements of pop culture. All I know is that if I brought an Xbox into my apartment, I’m scared I might never do anything else.

SAN DIEGO— Patience is often in short supply on Comic-Con’s trade show floor, where lines of fans waiting to get an autograph or check out a particular booth snake through the already gridlocked aisles. Lionsgate, the studio that “Saw” built, is normally one of the biggest line generators, because it loads its exhibit area with technology. Last year, for instance, the studio invited attendees to make videos of themselves trapped inside a coffin; Lionsgate then emailed them the result to share with their friends online. The stunt promoted “Buried,” a thriller starring Ryan Reynolds, and it was a huge Comic-Con hit (although it didn’t pay off in box office success).

This brown butter cake is a happy landing pad for almost any summer fruit. Try it with apricots, sweet cherries, berries (a mix would be perfect) or plums. As long as the fruit is juicy and soft, it will work. The juicy factor, however, does rule out apples and most pears unless you poach or sauté them first — a good thing to keep in mind if you’re saving this recipe for fall.

Organizers of the annual Prospect Park Summer Soirée could not have picked a better night to throw a retro space-themed party. The landing of the Atlantis early Thursday morning, which marked the end of NASA’s shuttle program, and by extension, the end of an era in space exploration, had everyone thinking about starships and galaxies. If entering the event’s space, a charming 1905 Beaux Arts-style boathouse, to music from “2001: A Space Odyssey” felt a bit kitschy, well, so was the ’70s space-age-inspired look that prompted the party. Call it cosmic, but it worked.

Among the 823 couples who plan to marry in New York City on Sunday are many with children. Zahi Hawass, whose departure as Egypt’s minister of antiquities was announced in a cabinet reshuffle this week, said in an e-mail Friday that, while he continues to supervise the agency while his replacement is found, he will not be staying on for more than a few days “to help with the transition.” Mr. Hawass said, “I am retiring to focus on my own work, as a scholar and a writer,” adding he is looking forward to “living quietly as a private person, away from politics.” On Thursday, the Egyptian government said it is downgrading the antiquities department from a ministry to an office reporting to the prime minister, reversing a decision by former president Hosni Mubarak in the last days of his rule to elevate its status. It is still not clear who will run the office, which will again be known as the Supreme Council of Antiquities. Mr. Hawass was pushed out, along with several other cabinet members, as part of an effort by Prime Minister Essam Sharaf to appease protesters who had returned to Tahrir Square to demand further changes in the government.

Back in 2008, when Helmut Lang installed a busted up disco ball on the floor of the Journal Gallery in Brooklyn, he explained that, in his mind anyway, the piece related to the Janus mythology — looking back and moving forward. “It’s also about transitions and new beginnings, representing time as one half respects the past and the other one looks into the future,” he said. But with his new installation at the Fireplace Project in East Hampton, N.Y., it appears that the past is no longer an issue for the designer who took what turned out to be a permanent hiatus from fashion in 2005 and has been working full time as an artist pretty much ever since. “Make It Hard,” as the show is called, comprises about 20 pillar-like sculptures, which Lang created after he shredded the thousands of pieces that remained in his archive. Sad as it may be to think about all of those wasted moleskin coats, lace and rubber dresses and motocross pants, “Make It Hard” is a poignant realization of Lang’s long-held conviction that fashion and art have become one. On the eve of the opening, Lang talked to The Moment about art, the passage of time and why there will never be another Helmut Lang sample sale ever again.

While we wait (and wait, and wait …) to find out if John Boehner and Barack Obama are about to snatch a significant deal from the jaws of a parliamentary maneuver, I recommend reading Yuval Levin’s powerful case against the sort of larger bargain that I’ve been suggesting conservatives should consider in these negotiations. The problem with the “big” deals that have been floated to date, Levin points out, is that none of them seriously address the long-term growth of Medicare spending: The entitlement reforms being considered, from retirement-age increases to modest means-testing, will generate only extremely modest savings when set against the projected cost explosion in the coming decades. And so it would be a mistake, he argues, for Republicans to make a significant concession on taxes without getting genuine structural reform to Medicare (along the lines of the Ryan plan, or the more centrist Rivlin-Domenici alternative) in return — a policy mistake, because it would concede too much for too little, and a political mistake, because calling something a “grand bargain” would leave the impression that our deficit problem has somehow been dealt with, when in fact this round of negotiations is just the opening act for a much larger and necessarily more controversial process of reform.

“Talk to Me: Design and the Communication between People and Objects,” which opens on July 24 at the Museum of Modern Art, explores the ways in which people and objects communicate through design. In nearly 200 recent and new projects, the exhibition considers the “personalities” that designed objects now have through their interactive relationships with their users. Organized by Paola Antonelli, the senior curator in the museum’s department of architecture and design, and Kate Carmody, a curatorial assistant in the department, the exhibition examines everything from the now-famous MetroCard vending machines in New York to the Bat Billboard, which uses voice-recognition software to translate the calls of bats into messages that are displayed on the screen of the billboard. (The billboard itself also serves a low-tech function — that of housing the bats.)

Teen drama, both real and fictional, continues to be a winning formula for MTV. The network's new scripted comedy series ''Awkward'' made its debut to strong ratings Tuesday night, following the hit show ''Teen Mom,'' a reality series whose title needs no explanation. Currently on its third season, ''Teen Mom'' drew 3.2 million viewers and was the most-watched cable show in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic for the night, a prize it has claimed each week since its season premiere on July 7, according to an analysis of Nielsen ratings data by TV by the Numbers. ''Awkward,'' which focuses on the teenage life of one Jenna Hamilton (Ashley Rickards), who wants nothing more than to fit in at her high school, picked up slightly more than 1.7 million viewers. Meanwhile, Wednesday night's battle for ratings supremacy on the broadcast networks did not have a clear victor. CBS led with total viewers for the night as a new episode of ''Big Brother'' won the 8 p.m. hour with just over 7 million viewers. However, Fox claimed the top spot overall among the 18- to 49-year-old set, thanks to a two-hour edition of ''So You Think You Can Dance.'' Finally, NBC once again boasted the highest-rated program of the night, with a results show edition of ''America's Got Talent'' at slightly less than 9.9 million viewers.

An art review on July 8 about ''Mother India: The Goddess in Indian Painting,'' an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that includes the sculpture ''The Goddess Durga Killing the Buffalo Demon (Mahishasura Mardini),'' referred incorrectly to the buffalo demon at one point in recounting the story behind the sculpture. His name is Mahishasura, not Mahishasura Mardini. (''Mardini'' is a reference to the goddess as the destroyer of Mahihshasura.)

DETROIT -- The federal government on Thursday shed the last of its stake in Chrysler, giving majority control of the carmaker to Fiat, the Italian company, while leaving taxpayers $1.3 billion short of recovering the full investment they made two years ago to keep Chrysler from going out of business. The government had said in June that it expected to take that much of loss on its investment. But it has said that if it had not stepped in with a bailout and the company had been forced to shut down, the damage to the fragile economy would have been worse.

GOSIN--Irene. Newmark Knight Frank and its partners extend their sincere condolences to the Gosin family on the loss of their beloved family member, Irene Gosin. Mrs. Gosin is survived by children Barry, Richard, Howard and Sandy, twelve grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. KRAFT--Myra, Sandy and I are so sad to hear about the loss of our dear friend, Myra Kraft, after a valiant battle against cancer. Myra was truly a woman of substance, first and foremost, devoted to her beloved husband, Robert, and her adored children and grandchildren. She was a dedicated philanthropist, devoting her time and energy to make the world a better place. She was devoted to her Patriot family and was a loyal supporter and fan. A vital woman, with many talents and interests, not the least of which was fishing. We were so lucky to have known Myra; she will be in our hearts forever. Rest in peace Myra dear. Love, Joan & Sandy Weill

O'CONNOR--Dr. James V. Pelham Manor, NY. January 15, 1919 - July 14, 2011. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Madeline (nee Malley), his daughters Ann, Madeline, Janet, son James and brother Daniel. Predeceased by his daughter Mary. Loving grandfather of Madeline, Joseph, Genevieve and George. A WWII veteran and 1951 graduate of NYU Dental School, Dr. O'Connor retired at age 80 and spent his retirement years studying philosophy, literature and theology. He had also been an avid marathon runner into his 70's. We will miss him. Contributions in his memory may be made to Catholic Charities of New York, c/o Development, 1011 First Ave., NY, NY 10022.

DODD-FRANK VIDEO As the Dodd-Frank financial regulatory law turned a year old on Thursday, the law's chief architect has come to its defense. Representative Barney Frank, who was the co-author of the Dodd-Frank Act, said in a video interview that the law would help prevent a repeat of the financial crisis. He is worried, however, that Congressional Republicans will chip away at crucial components of the law, including new derivatives rules and tighter lending standards. BEN PROTESS and MAC WILLIAM BISHOP

In Major League Baseball, some teams' narratives have an easier time grabbing headlines than others. The Philadelphia Phillies and the Boston Red Sox have been the talk of the sport all season, in part because of their major off-season signings. The Yankees are, well, the Yankees - usually in contention and always in the national conversation. The San Francisco Giants are the defending champions, the Cleveland Indians are a surprising success story, and the Tampa Bay Rays continue to compete despite an enormous payroll disadvantage. Even the once-moribund Pittsburgh Pirates have received their fair share of attention recently, with their best start in nearly 20 years.

Scientific Reports, a Nature journal, published research on Thursday showing that a significant percentage of herbal teas tested contained ingredients the tea manufacturers failed to list. If that sounds shocking, so might this: The researchers included one freshman and two seniors at the Trinity School, one of Manhattan's top private schools.

Silent Barn, the underground performance space in Ridgewood, Queens, that has served as a launching pad for several celebrated indie bands, is struggling to raise money to remain open after thieves broke in last Saturday night, members of the collective who run the space said. Sometime late Saturday someone broke in through some windows at the back of the two-story house-turned-concert-space on Wyckoff Avenue and made off with more than $20,000 worth of sound equipment, computers and other gear, Joe Ahearn, one of six artists and curators who maintain the space, said.

8 P.M. (TCM) STAR OF THE MONTH: SINGING COWBOYS Turner Classic Movies celebrates the tuneful heroes of the Wild West, like Gene Autry and Roy Rogers, who could ride, shoot and slug it out with the best of them before sliding out of the saddle, grabbing a guitar and serenading listeners with ballads like ''Tumbling Tumbleweeds'' and ''Happy Trails.'' This 26-movie tribute, shown on Fridays in July, continues with four films starring Dick Foran, a New Jersey-born, Princeton-educated band singer and radio performer signed by Warner Brothers in 1934 as its answer to Autry. The lineup begins with ''Moonlight on the Prairie'' (1935), in which an unemployed rodeo star takes on cattle rustlers. ''Song of the Saddle'' (1936), about a cowboy who goes on a quest to avenge his father's murder, follows at 9:15; ''Treachery Rides the Range'' (1936), in which a cowboy takes on buffalo hunters out to stir up trouble with Indians, at 10:30; and ''Land Beyond the Law'' (1937), about an innocent rancher who gets mixed up with rustlers, at 11:30. Two films with Monte Hale, above, a rodeo performer who took over for Autry at Republic Studios and was considered the last of the great singing cowboys, wrap up the evening: ''Home on the Range'' (1946), in which a cowboy tries to protect bears from ranchers who think they are killing cattle, at 12:30 a.m., and ''Under Colorado Skies'' (1947), about a bank teller who recognizes a robber as his brother, at 1:30. 7 P.M. (Oxygen) LITTLE MISS SUNSHINE (2006) Abigail Breslin (above far left with, from left, Toni Collette, Steve Carell and Greg Kinnear) received an Academy Award nomination for her portrayal of the unlikely preteen princess Olive Hoover in this comedy about a family of everyday misfits determined to get a 7-year-old to a beauty pageant. Alan Arkin won an Oscar for best supporting actor as the heroin-snorting grandfather who helps put Olive's talent routine over the top; Mr. Kinnear and Ms. Collette play the parents driving the ravaged family and its equally dilapidated Volkswagen bus; Mr. Carell is Frank, Olive's suicidal gay uncle; and Paul Dano is Dwayne, the Hoovers' teenage son, who has decided to keep his mouth shut about the situation. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis called the film ''a tale about genuine faith and manufactured glory that unwinds in the American Southwest, but more rightly takes place at the terminus of the American dream, where families are one bad break away from bankruptcy.''

An article on Wednesday about important questions that the News Corporation is likely to confront as it continues to deal with the British phone hacking scandal misstated, in some editions, the age of James Murdoch, the company's deputy chief operating officer. He is 38, not 43.

An article on July 15 about reactions to proposed New York State rules governing a type of natural gas drilling known as hydraulic fracking referred imprecisely to watersheds where such drilling will be banned. Drilling will be banned in watersheds and aquifers supplying drinking water to about 57 percent of the state's population; it will not be banned in all watersheds and aquifers in New York State.

KRAFT--Myra H. The American Society of the University of Haifa notes with great sorrow the passing of its Board Trustee Myra H. Kraft. A cherished friend of the University of Haifa, she turned her passion and advocacy for civil societies, social justice, and innovation into support for the University's cancer research efforts and inclusiveness programs. A recipient of a Doctor of Philosophy, Honoris Causa from the University in 2005, her vision and passion will be difficult, if not impossible, to replace. We extend condolences to the Kraft and Hiatt families and to the many people whose lives she touched and inspired. Arthur K. Wachtel, Chair Board of Directors American Society of the University of Haifa

Who is that masked man? Anyone passingly familiar with American art of the past half-century will recognize the eerie, erotically menacing, leather-clad heads that Nancy Grossman produced between the late 1960s and 1990. Often including zippers, buckles, straps and chains, these sculptures most immediately evoke S-and-M bondage wear. Displayed in a high-end shop for the sexually adventurous, they would fit right in.

An article on Thursday about efforts to negotiate a rescue plan for Greece paraphrased incorrectly, in some editions, from a statement by the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, about the progress of talks. Mr. Sarkozy said that Germany and France had agreed on a plan to be presented to a summit meeting; he did not say that the plan would include the participation of Europe's banking sector. The article also misspelled part of the surname of the president of the European Council, who received the agreement. He is Herman Van Rompuy, not Van Rumpuy.

An article on Wednesday about the 16th stage of the Tour de France misidentified the team Andy Schleck rode for last year, when he lost to Alberto Contador by a slim margin. It was Saxo Bank -- not Leopard Trek, which is his team this year.

In 1955 a remorseful prisoner at Eastern State Penitentiary in Philadelphia started expressing his newfound Roman Catholic faith on the jailhouse walls. The inmate, Lester Smith, had been convicted of a string of armed robberies. At first, while in his prison cell, he painted portraits of saints. Then the Eastern State staff noticed his talent and invited him to line the Catholic chaplain's office suite with biblical murals. Under skylights in the chaplain's vaulted rooms, Mr. Smith depicted souls in purgatory and saints aloft. In one scene he also seems to have portrayed himself, in a uniform with the number 01010 printed across the shoulder blades, covering his face and kneeling before Jesus. (That was not his real number, scholars at Eastern State have determined.)

Jon M. Huntsman Jr.'s campaign manager has resigned less than a month after Mr. Huntsman began his bid for the Republican presidential nomination, officials for the campaign confirmed on Thursday. The manager, Susie Wiles, who had helped Rick Scott, a Republican, get elected governor in Florida last November, will be replaced by Matt David, the campaign's communications director, officials said.

An article on July 13 about the golfer Bernhard Langer's disappointments at the British Open misstated the reason that Tom Watson, who had recent success at the Open, had qualified for this year's tournament. Watson qualified because he is a past champion who had finished in the top 10 in the past five years (he was runner-up in 2009), not because he won the Senior P.G.A. Championship in May.

LEVINE--Jean Seligmann, 96, died peacefully at home July 19, 2011. She and her late husband, Milton I. Levine, M.D. co-wrote many books and articles, including The Wonder of Life, A Baby is Born, and a child-care column. Jean also co-wrote The Meaning of Music. Beloved by her two daughters, Carol (Gottfried) Paasche and Ann (Ted) Parker, six grandchildren and spouses, and 15 great-grandchildren. Contributions in memory can be made to City & Country School, 146 W 13 St, NYC 10014, where a memorial will be held on Aug. 21 at 2pm.

Katy Perry and Adele garnered the most nominations Wednesday night for the 2011 MTV Video Music Awards while Lady Gaga, who took home eight awards last year, got only three nominations this time around. Ms. Perry, 26, whose pop compositions have a playful, almost childlike quality, got nine nominations. She has had an extraordinary year with a string of hits - ''California Gurls,'' ''Teenage Dream,'' ''Firework,'' and ''E.T.'' Her ''Firework'' video, in which at one point fireworks shoot from her bosom, was nominated for video of the year and best female video. But it was her ''E.T.'' video, a dramatization of her song about a sex fantasy involving an alien, that got the most nominations: best collaboration, best art direction, best editing, best special effects.

Zygmunt Nagorski, a Polish émigré who wrote widely about East-West relations during the cold war and founded an organization that addresses ethics in international business, died on June 26 at a retirement home in Washington. He was 98. His death was confirmed by his son, Andrew.

Wall Street interns have gone from pampered to pummeled. In better days, college-age interns at the nation's largest investment banks, known as summer analysts, were treated like young royalty. Two of the nation's largest pharmacy benefit managers, Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions, said on Thursday that they wanted to combine forces in a $29.1 billion merger that would account for about four of every 10 prescription claims in the country. If federal regulators and the companies' shareholders approve the deal, the merger would create a company with more than $100 billion in annual revenue. Analysts say the deal could fundamentally change the dynamics of the market for overseeing prescription drug use for health plans and employers, but they predicted that the merger would face the thorny issues of antitrust that have swirled around other ventures involving pharmacy benefit managers.

An obituary on Thursday about the restaurateur Armando Orsini, misstated the location of Orsini's, the Manhattan restaurant he and his brother, Elio, ran from 1953 to 1984. It was on West 56th Street, not East 56th Street. The error was repeated in an accompanying picture caption.

The Beatles are breaking up even sooner than expected - on Broadway, anyway. My Sunday column argues that we usually think of national security challenges coming from terrorists or enemy countries, but one major challenge to American national security right now comes from the grotesque mishandling of the Washington budget battle. A default would do enormous damage to American interests, and some of the Republican budget cuts — particularly in education — have already done the same. I wish we were as vigorous in standing up to domestic threats to national security as foreign ones, but we’re not. Read the column and post your thoughts.

The best story about Myra Kraft to emerge among the touching remembrances following her death this week after a long battle with cancer came from her son Jonathan. He recalled how his mom, during a family trip to South Africa in the era of apartheid, demanded that a white police officer who was taking black men into custody arrest her, too. Jonathan remembered his dad, the Patriots owner Robert K. Kraft, telling him not to let his mother get in trouble. So he threw his mom, a petite woman, over his shoulder and hauled her away.

A new CNN poll finds that 55 percent of voters have a negative view of the Republican Party, tied for their second-highest unfavorable score since CNN began asking this question in 1992. The Republicans also achieved a 55 percent unfavorable rating in a poll conducted in April 2009, although the party’s all-time high, 57 percent, was recorded as the House of Representatives was in the process of impeaching Bill Clinton in December, 1998.

LEVINE--Jean Seligmann, 96, died peacefully at home July 19, 2011. She and her late husband, Milton I. Levine, M.D. co-wrote many books and articles, including The Wonder of Life, A Baby is Born, and a child-care column. Jean also co-wrote The Meaning of Music. Beloved by her two daughters, Carol (Gottfried) Paasche and Ann (Ted) Parker, six grandchildren and spouses, and 15 great-grandchildren. Contributions in memory can be made to City & Country School, 146 W 13 St, NYC 10014, where a memorial will be held on Aug. 21 at 2pm.

A relatively barren television landscape on Thursday night -- with the big four networks running either comedy repeats or reality shows -- allowed the Spanish-language Univision to score a ratings victory in the category advertiser-coveted demographic of 18- to 49-year-olds with its 8th Annual Youth Awards show, ''Premios Juventud.'' The three-hour ceremony, which featured performances from Ricky Martin and Pitbull, averaged 4.1 million total viewers. The winners were determined by online vote at univision.com. CBS had the most total viewers on the night thanks to a live eviction episode of ''Big Brother'' (6.7 million viewers). ''Love Bites,'' the sole NBC series not in repeats, fell to just under 1.8 million viewers for its (unplanned) final episode. The show was canceled earlier this week. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Sue was the cherished daughter of the late Pearl and Mitchell Bienen and beloved sister of Richard and Henry Bienen, sister-in-law of Leigh Bienen, Aunt of Laura Bienen, Claire Bienen, Leslie Bienen, Richard Bienen Jr., Michelle Bienen, Katie Bienen, Michael Bienen. She was companion to Sherman Greenwald. She was mourned at services in Connecticut on July 19th by dozens of family and friends. She will be dearly missed and always remembered.

R. Kelly, the rhythm and blues singer, was hospitalized briefly this week and underwent surgery to drain an abcess from one of his tonsils, his spokesman said. It is unclear when the 44-year-old Grammy award winning singer, known for his seductive vocals and lascivious lyrics, would be well enough to perform again. His appearance at a festival in Jamaica this weekend would likely be cancelled, the spokesman, Allan Mayer, said. On Tuesday morning, Mr. Kelly went to Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, where he resides, complaining of an extremely sore throat. Doctors operated that afternoon and he was sent home the following day, where he has been recuperating. Two weeks ago, Mr. Kelly finished a tour in Europe and the United States to promote his new album, ''Love Letter'' (Jive). Kelly won a Grammy in 1997 for his gospel-tinged ''I Believe I Can Fly.''

Homeowners, especially those who bought their houses after the real-estate bubble burst, are still having trouble accepting just how much the values of their properties may have fallen, says a new report from the real-estate site Zillow. Current sellers who bought their homes in 2007 or later, an analysis of the site's home listings shows, are overpricing their properties by an average of 14 percent.

The plan to slash the budget of the Office of Congressional Ethics failed Friday by a 302-to-102 vote, after House members were forced to go on the record instead of deciding the matter more anonymously by a voice vote. But the proposal still gave critics of the three-year-old office an opportunity to air their grievances on the House floor. The amendment to a bill setting Congress's annual budget called for a 40 percent cut in the ethics office's $1.5 million allotment, which would have severely curtailed its work.

Three gay couples who have ties to theater will wed on the Broadway stage of the St. James Theater on Monday night after the performance of the musical ''Hair,'' a day after New York State's new marriage law takes effect. Among them is the Broadway actress Terri White, who received strong reviews in the 2009 Broadway revival of ''Finian's Rainbow'' and will appear in the revival of ''Follies'' that begins next month. Ms. White will marry her partner, the jewelry designer Donna Barnett. The other two couples are Ryan Dietz, an actor, and Josh Levine, a playwright and staff member at the Theater Communications Group; and John Raymond Barker, a stage doorman at Broadway theaters, and Jared Pike, an usher for Jujamcyn Theaters (which includes the St. James). Audience members at ''Hair'' on Monday night can stick around to watch the weddings if they wish.

Filandia is a town set high in the mountain slopes of the Cordillera Central range in Colombia. It is not connected with Finland, a European country that is much larger and considerably farther north, and has a different flag. Fortieth Street, Brooklyn, runs through Sunset Park and a neighborhood once known as Finntown for its large Finnish population. It is not connected with Fortieth Street, Manhattan, which runs through Midtown.

LONDON -- Trying, perhaps, to live up to its name, the new ''Ghost: The Musical'' vanishes before your eyes. That it does so is a logic- and senses-defying mystery that I kept trying to figure out during a rainy-day matinee at the Piccadilly Theater, as if I were at a magic show where people keep asking, ''Now how do they do that?'' Because ''Ghost,'' adapted from the love-beyond-the-grave make-out movie of 1990, is full of flash and noise and blinding lights. (Advisory: bring sunglasses.) And yet somehow it simply isn't there. It all feels about as substantial as the swirling smoke it uses so abundantly. I diverted myself by trying to track said smoke's points of emanation from the floor of the stage. That's how engaged I was.

Zahi Hawass, whose departure as Egypt's minister of antiquities was announced in a cabinet reshuffle this week, said in an e-mail Friday that, while he continues to supervise the agency while his replacement is found, he will not be staying on for more than a few days ''to help with the transition.'' Mr. Hawass said, ''I am retiring to focus on my own work, as a scholar and a writer,'' adding he is looking forward to ''living quietly as a private person, away from politics.'' On Thursday, the Egyptian government said it is downgrading the antiquities department from a ministry to an office reporting to the prime minister, reversing a decision by former president Hosni Mubarak in the last days of his rule to elevate its status. It is still not clear who will run the office, which will again be known as the Supreme Council of Antiquities. Mr. Hawass was pushed out, along with several other cabinet members, as part of an effort by Prime Minister Essam Sharaf to appease protesters who had returned to Tahrir Square to demand further changes in the government. Mr. Hawass has been credited with boosting Egyptian tourism and promoting the return of cultural artifacts to their home country. But since the revolution, he drew criticism for his ties to the Mubaraks, his role in sending artifacts abroad on traveling exhibitions and his relationship with National Geographic, which paid him up to $200,000 a year as an explorer-in-residence. Last week, before he was removed, Mr. Hawass said that he had temporarily resigned from his post with National Geographic. At the time, he was listed among the current explorers-in-residence on the organization's Web site. His status has now changed to explorer-in-residence emeritus.
