O'CONNOR--Dr. James V. Pelham Manor, NY. January 15, 1919 - July 14, 2011. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Madeline (nee Malley), his daughters Ann, Madeline, Janet, son James and brother Daniel. Predeceased by his daughter Mary. Loving grandfather of Madeline, Joseph, Genevieve and George. A WWII veteran and 1951 graduate of NYU Dental School, Dr. O'Connor retired at age 80 and spent his retirement years studying philosophy, literature and theology. He had also been an avid marathon runner into his 70's. We will miss him. Contributions in his memory may be made to Catholic Charities of New York, c/o Development, 1011 First Ave., NY, NY 10022.

MOSCOW -- The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's media conglomerate embroiled in scandal, sold its billboard company in Russia to a consortium of investors led by a Kremlin-controlled bank, the bank announced on Friday. The sale of News Outdoor Russia had been under negotiation for at least months. The timing was apparently unrelated to the turmoil around the News Corporation in Britain, where Parliament is investigating a tabloid newspaper's practice of hacking into cell phones to obtain information.

An article on Tuesday about the impending retirement of Cardinal Justin Rigali, the Roman Catholic leader of Philadelphia, misstated his age and referred imprecisely to the process for retirement. The cardinal is 76, not 75. At age 75, bishops are required to offer their resignation and the pope can either accept it or allow them to continue to serve; 75 is not the ''customary retirement age'' for bishops. The article also misstated, in some editions, the name of the group to which Cardinal Rigali was elevated to in 2003. It is the College of Cardinals, not the House of Cardinals.

A mass of Christian Burial St. Vincent Ferrer, July 29, 3:30pm. Reception following at Colony Club New York.

An obituary on Thursday about Noel Gayler, a retired admiral who was commander of American forces in the Pacific and director of the National Security Agency in the 1970s, misstated the rank he held in 1945. He was a lieutenant commander, not an ensign. The obituary also referred imprecisely to Offutt Air Force Base, where Admiral Gayler was deputy director of strategic target planning. It was a base where, among other missions, nuclear targets were selected; it was not a nuclear weapons site.

ARLO-COSTA--Horacio, Professor of Philosophy, Carnegie Mellon University, died July 14. Visitation and burial July 23-24 in Astoria, Queens. In lieu of flowers, send contributions to the Arlo-Costa Memorial Scholarship. Details about funeral and contributions at www.hss.cmu.edu/philosophy

BOOKBINDER--Hyman. AJC notes with sadness the death of Hyman Bookbinder. Our Washington Representative from 1967 to 1986 and Washington Representative Emeritus until his passing, Bookie was an exceptionally wise and admired liaison between AJC and American and world leaders. Over more than six decades of distinguished public service, he was indefatigable in his efforts to pursue civil rights, human rights and social justice. Bookie served his country and the Jewish people passionately and with honor and distinction. His lifelong devotion to the promise of America, to Israel and to all humanity made him a treasured colleague and friend. He touched generations of people whom he never met but whose lives were made easier and more secure by his unwavering commitment to human dignity. We send our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife, Ida Leivick, his two daughters, three grandchildren and the rest of his grieving family. Robert Elman, President David Harris, Executive Director Jason Isaacson, Washington Representative

An article on Page 12 this weekend about the film ''Life in a Day'' refers erroneously to its direction. Kevin Macdonald was the documentary's sole director; he did not direct it with Joseph Michael, who was one of several hundred contributors to the film.

An article on Thursday about Countrywide Financial's pending distribution to mortgage customers of a $108 million Federal Trade Commission settlement misstated the percentage of borrowers who will receive the largest amounts. Those who will receive $5,000 or more under the program total 0.16 percent of participants, not 5 percent. (The dollar amount to be received by those customers is 5 percent of the total.) The article also erroneously attributed a distinction to the Countrywide settlement. It involves one of the largest groups of recipients in an F.T.C. case, but not the largest.

(Family) OVERBOARD (1987) In this comedy directed by Garry Marshall, the rich and spoiled Joanna Stayton (Goldie Hawn, right), is given a chance to experience life from a completely different (read: poor) perspective. A fall from her yacht gives Joanna amnesia; a vengeful handyman (Kurt Russell), whom she had refused to pay for work he'd done on her boat, claims her as his wife from the hospital where she is recovering. The handyman, Dean Proffitt, is initially interested only in getting what he is owed by putting her to work cleaning his house and, since he's a widower, taking care of his four boys. Dean calls her Annie, gives her some ill-fitting clothes and convinces her that the children are hers. Unsurprisingly, a love story unfolds, and the characters are given an opportunity to understand what truly makes them happy. NOON (13) RICHARD HEFFNER'S OPEN MIND The New York Times Op-Ed columnist Joe Nocera separates the good guys from the bad as he discusses his book ''All the Devils Are Here: The Hidden History of the Financial Crisis.''

Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about the sale of the government's stake in Chrysler misstated the process that Fiat, which now owns 53.5 percent of Chrysler, could use to acquire an additional 5 percent stake by the end of the year. That stake would be obtained by issuing new shares in Chrysler; it would not come from the United Automobile Workers union's health care trust fund. (Since Fiat and the union trust fund are the only remaining shareholders in the automaker, the issuance of the new shares would, in effect, reduce the size of the trust fund's stake in Chrysler).

Relativism about morality has come to play an increasingly important role in contemporary culture.  To many thoughtful people, and especially to those who are unwilling to derive their morality from a religion, it appears unavoidable.  Where would absolute facts about right and wrong come from, they reason, if there is no supreme being to decree them? We should reject moral absolutes, even as we keep our moral convictions, allowing that there can be right and wrong relative to this or that moral code, but no right and wrong per se.  (See, for example, Stanley Fish’s 2001 op-ed, “Condemnation Without Absolutes.”)[1]

With the Diavel, Ducati styling adds an alternative theme, moving away from the racetrack-replica sportbikes that have earned it an image as the Ferrari of two-wheelers. Ducati's ambition to establish its new model as a landmark product is evident in the name: Diavel is a reference in the Bolognese dialect for devil.Often characterized as a member of the muscle cruiser category, the bike hews more closely to the Monster model line -- naked bikes to enthusiasts -- than to the full-fairing design of the maker's super bikes. The Diavel's designer, Bart Janssen-Groesbeek, who came to the company in 2002 from Yamaha's design studio, took inspiration from the Yamaha-built Star VMax as well as the Harley-Davidson V-Rod and the Confederate Wraith. Mr. Janssen-Groesbeek, who was born in the Netherlands, said he was also influenced by the California customizer look.But above all, he has said, he wanted the Diavel to evoke the spirit of the American hot-rod and drag racing scene -- a flavor of Von Dutch in Italian performance. That theme is visible in the stance, a diagonal profile meant to evoke a sprinter poised in the starting blocks. At a low 30.3 inches, the seat height allows a relaxed riding position. The horizontal placement of the rear shock absorber helps make the low seat possible.

An article on July 10 about the television series ''Breaking Bad'' misstated the title, duration and year of a previous TV show of the creator, Vince Gilligan. It was ''The Lone Gunmen,'' not ''Lone Gunman.'' It was canceled after 13 weeks, not a year, and its fi rst broadcast was in March 2001, not after ''The X-Files'' ended in 2002.

IN 1811 Uruguay began the long process of winning independence. In this bicentennial year, Montevideo, the capital, has been adding new museums and expanding older ones as the country re-examines art and history. The most striking addition is the Espacio de Arte Contemporáneo (Arenal Grande 1930; 598-2-929-2066; www.eac.gub.uy), which opened in July 2010 in an abandoned 1888 prison occupying an entire city block between the Cordón and Aguada neighborhoods, an area with a post-industrial feel and unassuming working-class homes.

FURST--Rabbi Moshe (Milton). The entire Yeshiva University and Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary (RIETS) family of colleagues and friends are deeply grieved by the passing of a most devoted alumnus. A graduate of YC in 1943 and RIETS in 1946, Rabbi Furst served with distinction as the Executive Assistant to Dr. Samuel Belkin, the second president of Yeshiva University and RIETS, until his Aliyah to Israel in 1973, and was responsible for the Synagogue Campaign Division of RIETS. He and his wife Batya (Beatrice) Furst who predeceased him in 2005, were both deeply beloved by the members of the Rabbinic Alumni for their warmth, friendship and genuine commitment to strengthen RIETS and Yeshiva University together with members of their respective distinguished Bick and Furst families. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his devoted children, Zev (and Sandy) Furst, Aryeh and (Deborah) Furst, Malkah (and Dov) Cymbalista of Israel and his grandchildren and great-grandchildren, as well as to his beloved cousin, a Yeshiva University Trustee and Benefactor, Gerald (and Violet) Furst, the son of his beloved uncle and aunt, Sol and Hilda Furst, of blessed memory, for whom Furst Hall was named during his tenure. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University and RIETS Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor and Rosh Hayeshiva

''DEADLIEST CATCH'' has masculine mystique. Fans, and men in particular, boast of their love for this fishing saga on the Discovery Channel the way they once spoke of ''Iron Chef'' (the Japanese original), kung fu, motocross and, at least in the 1990s, Cuban cigars. On ''Catch'' the crab fishermen who make their living in the Pacific serve up a tableau of unshaven, unwashed, cigarette-stained, all-American masculinity that is a little like prison -- only with less sex and more foul weather gear.

THE UPSHOT Most Montevideo hotels are either big international chains or small, locally run operations, some unchanged since the 1960s. But the 21-room Don Hotel, opened in January 2011 in a 1938 nautical Art Deco building, is a new boutique choice.

BREWSTER--Rev. Charles E.,72, died July 8 in Dallas, TX, of ALS. Managing editor of New World Outlook magazine, 1967-82; beloved pastor for 26 years, First Presbyterian Church, 70-35 112 St., Forest Hills, NY, where a memorial service will be held Sunday, September 18, at 4pm. Reception following. In lieu of flowers, family requests memorial gifts to the church or the ALS Association.

AS Baz Luhrmann decides where to shoot his 3-D production of ''The Great Gatsby,'' starring Carey Mulligan, jewelry designers have come down with a case of Jazz Age fever. Tiered gold pieces in Jené DeSpain's fall collection make references to Art Deco monuments like the Empire State Building and Rockefeller Center. Rachel Dooley, who designs Gemma Redux, was also inspired by the New York skyline. Her necklaces have layers of metal and stones designed to look like spires and ziggurats. Her ideal customer, she says, is a Daisy Buchanan type: beautiful, but no fool. Jené DeSpain necklace, $298. Go to jenedespain.com. MADISON SHIMODA

HALL--George M. Jr. , 86, died at home in Greenwich Village July 15, 2011. Former Tuskegee pilot, organist, choirmaster, educator, George taught at Wingate, Stuyvesant and Taft High Schools as well as Manhattan School of Music and Wagner College. He served as organist and choirmaster at Holy Apostles, Trinity Lutheran, S.I. and Holy Name churches among others. He is survived by his wife, Dr. Chantal Bruchez-Hall and four children from a previous marriage, Althea, Howard, Leslie and Michael. A memorial service will be held in the Fall.

An Opinion article last Sunday about the increasing prevalence of droughts incorrectly described El Paso's use of recycled sewage. The city uses recycled sewage for irrigation, construction and manufacturing and releases a small percentage of the sewage into a local aquifer, where it eventually mixes with groundwater and, after several years, is pumped and treated for use as drinking water. It is not the case that ''40 percent of the tap water is recycled sewage.'' The article also incorrectly described earthquakes and tsunamis. They are geological phenomena, not forms of extreme weather. And the article misspelled the surname of a scientist at the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia University who studies climate model projections. He is Richard Seager, not Seagar.

B ODRUM, a former fishing village on the Aegean Sea, is now a popular upscale getaway: the St.-Tropez of Turkey. But it's not just the turquoise sea that glitters here. Although the shopping options may lack the sheer scale of Istanbul's Grand Bazaar, there is no shortage of intriguing items to be found. At spots like the Marina mall -- with its stunning view of Bodrum Castle and traditional Turkish wooden gulets, or yachts -- and the shopping strip on Barlar Sokagi, or Bars Street, boutiques and markets sell jewelry, carpets, housewares and curios.

In Vogue's August ''age issue,'' the editors gush about the style proclivities of the teenage Fanning sisters, Dakota and Elle, who appear in a full-page photograph turned out in puff-sleeved glad rags from Louis Vuitton. Elle, who described her look that day as ''Virgin Suicides meets Twiggy,'' is ''remarkably sartorially erudite for a 13-year-old,'' it was noted. Ms. Fanning, you may recall, has been showcased in Marc Jacobs's advertising campaigns since she was 11. She has also appeared in short films by Laura and Kate Mulleavy of Rodarte.

Magnus Carlsen is competing in Switzerland; Levon Aronian, Sergey Karjakin, Vassily Ivan- chuk and Teimour Radjabov in Ningbo, China; and Vladimir Kramnik and Hikaru Nakamura in Dortmund, Germany.But some of the most exciting play this month was a match be- tween Hou Yifan, the 16-year-old women's world champion, and Marie Sebag of France at an elite women's tournament in Hang- zhou, China.The opening was the Sicilian Defense, a double-edged system in which Black sometimes has to walk a tightrope to avoid trouble.Hou's 4 Qd4 was rare: White was basically forced to trade the light-squared bishop for a knight to maintain the queen in the cen- ter. After the trade, White had free rein in the center of the board, but after 11 Bd2, chances were about equal. That did not stop Hou from mustering an at- tack.Sebag did not take a pawn with 15 ... Ng4 because she did not want to open the file in front of her king, though after 16 Qg3 Nf6 17 Rhg1 Ne8, it would not have been easy for White to make much progress.Sebag should have played 18 Qd4, when after 19 Qg4 ef5 20 Qf4, chances would have remained equal.Hou erred with 19 Nf3. Sebag could have played 19 ... Nd3, when 20 cd3Qa2 would have giv- en Black a dangerous attack and an advantage. Another option was 20 Kb1 Nb2 21 Kb2 Qb4 22 Ka1 Rc3, when again Black would have been in a better position.But then Sebag tripped up again with 20 ... Bf8. She should have moved 20 ... Ng6, when after 21fe7 b4 Black would have been fine. Hou pounced with 21 g6; Black would be losing after 21 ... Ng6 22 Ng5 h6 23fg7 Bg7 24 Nf7.Hou's 26 Qg4 was also a mis- take; 26 Rg1 would have given her an overwhelming attack. But Sebag missed her chance. She should have played 26 ... Kg7. Af- ter 27 Rg3 g5 28 h4 Be7 29 Rd7 Qf1 30 Nd1 Qf4, White's advantage would have been minimal.Sebag was forced to play 27 ... Kg7 because 27 ... Bg7 would have lost to 28 Rf6, and Black would soon have been checkmated.The game's denouement was particularly nice: Hou sacrificed her queen to break down Black's defense. Sebag resigned rather than play 32 ... Kf8, when she would have been checkmated by 33 Rh8.

Hanna Raskin is the restaurant critic for The Seattle Weekly, but in 1998 she was a greenhorn reporter at The Commercial Dispatch in Columbus, Miss. Oprah Winfrey was jobbing around the country that year doing publicity for ''Beloved,'' a film she had commissioned and starred in with Danny Glover. News came that Winfrey was holding a screening in Attala County, where she was born, and Raskin's editor sent her across the state to watch it with the hometown fans. ''Beloved,'' based on Toni Morrison's novel, takes as its subject the impact of slavery on the human soul. Mystery, violence, sex and supernatural apparition are all part of the story.

ALT--Franz L. Born Vienna November 30, 1910, died New York July 21, 2011. Mathematician. A founder and third president of Association for Computing Machinery. Member 10th Mountain Division, WW II. National Bureau of Standards 1948-67 directing early use of computers at NBS and throughout federal government. Established citation indexing at the American Institute of Physics 1967-74. Awarded Ehrenkreuz fur Wissenschaft und Kunst, Austria's highest distinction for science and art, 2007. Lifelong hiker and chamber musician (violin, viola). Predeceased by first wife Alice Modern. Survived by daughter Theresa (Wayles) and son James (Elaine), granddaughter Rachel (Mark) and grandson Adam (Michele). Also survived by second wife Annice, her daughters Joyce (Heath), Helen (Stuart) and Claudia (Joseph), her stepdaughters Patricia and Barbara (George), and her grandchildren Susannah, Kathleen, Lucas, Alden, Jack, Victoria and Charlotte. Memorial to be announced in the fall.

OLLY MOSS'S newest project for Mondo, the print arm of the Texas theater chain Alamo Drafthouse, is a pair of posters for ''Captain America.'' Resembling propaganda fliers from World War II, each poster is 18 inches by 24 inches and screen-printed in a limited edition of 375. This poster's evil twin looks like the handiwork of an Axis artist, in German no less. But Mr. Moss is hardly a veteran of the last world war. He's a 24-year-old graduate of the University of Birmingham in England who has designed covers for video games like ''Grand Theft Auto'' and is often compared to Saul Bass, whose movie posters from the 1950s are classics of the genre. Mr. Moss's ''Star Wars'' posters, also for Mondo, sold out minutes after they were issued in 2010. BEN MARKS

Blue has taken the spotlight, from the intense hues of hydrangeas in gardens and markets, to the shades that the fashion world contributes: a handbag the color of opaline glass; long dresses for day, evening and significant birthdays. An East Hampton nursery was stacked with blue-glazed planters, and a vintage Citroën in the appropriate bleu tootled past on Fifth Avenue.

An obituary last Sunday about Geoff Fisken, a World War II fighter pilot from New Zealand, misstated the relative time frames for Japan's 1941 bombing of Pearl Harbor and its invasion of Malaya. The two attacks were launched almost simultaneously; the invasion of Malaya did not come a day after the bombing of Pearl Harbor. (The dates of the attacks were Dec. 7 and Dec. 8, but Hawaii and Malaya are on opposite sides of the international date line.) Corrections in other sections: Magazine, Page 6; Book Review, Page 6; Arts & Leisure, Page 2; Sunday Review, Page 2; Sunday Styles, Page 2; Sunday Business, Page 2; Real Estate, Page 2; Travel, Page 2.

An article on July 10 about Sheila Bair, former chairwoman of the F.D.I.C, misidentifi ed the agency that agreed to absorb some of the losses of the bank Wachovia to make it a more appealing takeover target for Citigroup during the early days of the recent recession. It was the F.D.I.C, not the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. (As the article noted, in the end it was Wells Fargo that took over Wachovia.)

A CO-OP at the Rosario Candela-designed 834 Fifth Avenue was the highest sale of the week, ac- cording to Streeteasy.com and city property records. The apartment was sold by Harold Prince, the Broadway producer and director, to Hamilton E. James, president of the private equity firm the Blackstone Group, for $24.9 million.The 11-room duplex has three bedrooms and four and a half bathrooms. Mr. Prince had put it on the market for $33 million in 2009, but dropped the price in late De- cember of last year to $24.9 million, when he listed it with Brown Harris Stevens, ac- cording to Streeteasy. The monthly maintenance is $16,442. Turnover is rare in the building; Rupert Mur- doch owns a triplex there for which he paid $44 million.Big Ticket includes closed deals from the previous week, ending Wednesday.

FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel is touring Cyprus, looking for signs of the many cultures that have influenced the strategically located island over the centuries. Then it's off to Lebanon, to close out the Frugal Mediterranean tour.

The ''In the Region'' article in some copies last Sunday, about signs of improvement in the market for age-restricted housing in New Jersey, misidentified the kind of property bought by John and Ann Marie Neidzwski at Escapes Ocean Breeze in Manahawkin. It was a single-family house, not a condominium. The error was repeated in the caption.

He wanted to meet inside the men's restroom in the undergraduate library. I said, ''No, outside, by the reference books.'' When he asked how he'd know me, I told him I'd be wearing a baseball cap and a Marilyn Monroe T-shirt. I didn't mention that I was a scrawny 115 pounds or that my face was ravaged by acne. And I didn't mention that the hair beneath the baseball cap was a newly dyed neon orange. He called the previous afternoon on the line my roommate and I shared. (This was 1992, before cellphones.) He asked for my roommate. What the voice on the phone said to me when I asked if I could take a message was too explicit to transcribe here. He named positions, body parts. He told me where he wanted me. What he wanted to do to me. What he was going to make me do to him. Several times I asked who it was, but he continued as before. ''I'll hang up,'' I threatened.
WILTON COLONIAL $899,000

Do you want to immerse yourself in a new culture? Emirates airlines has released a new radio app for those who want to explore before traveling or simply want to discover new places. The new app, Destination Radio, is free and available for the iPhone and iPod Touch. Destination Radio streams live radio from local stations in 97 cities that Emirates flies to. The London station, for example, is Heart 106.2,; in Dubai, listeners can tune into AME Info. There's one station per city, and if the connection fails, you can listen to the default, BBC World Service.

PLENTY of significant cars have crossed plenty of auction blocks over the years on the Monterey Peninsula in California as part of the Pebble Beach Concours d'Élégance week. The annual event in August draws no shortage of eye-popping consignments, as auction companies bring fresh, exciting cars to market. So let's talk for a moment about the sensuous redhead with a long racing history that is poised to dominate this year's sales.

An article last Sunday about a new stimulant known as ''bath salts'' erroneously included, in some editions, a drug among those that are Schedule I, a governmental classification that the Drug Enforcement Administration is considering for mephedrone and methylenedioxypyrovalerone, the manmade chemicals found in bath salts. Cocaine is a Schedule II drug, which can be prescribed for medicinal purposes. (Schedule I drugs cannot be prescribed.)

Herman--Deanne. On July 20th. Loving daughter of Anita, Adored sister of Beth, Beloved aunt of Anna, and dear friend to an extended family of friends. Obituary and memorial service notice to follow.

Because of an editing error, the cover article on July 10 about the Turkish island of Buyukada off Istanbul misstated the name of the sultan who was deposed in 1909. He was Sultan Abdul Hamid II -- not Sultan Ahmed II, who ruled at the end of the 17th century. The article also referred incorrectly to the commercial life of the island. There is indeed a Starbucks there; it is not the case that the company has no presence on the island.

A museum of ancient mosaics recently opened in Gaziantep, Turkey. On display at the Zeugma Mosaic Museum are mosaics depicting Greek and Roman mythology recovered from archaeological excavations at Zeugma, a nearby site on the Euphrates River that in the ancient world was an important crossroads of major trade routes. The antiquities reflect the taste of the town's elite as well as popular culture in the second and third centuries A.D.

On the night of June 12, Mike McKenry was scanning his groceries at the supermarket checkout line in Pawtucket, R.I., when his cellphone rang. McKenry, then a part-time catcher for the Boston Red Sox' Class AAA team, had no reason to expect what he was about to hear. McKenry's manager told him he had been traded to the Pirates, who were promoting him to the majors immediately. First came the shock. Then the groceries.

MINNEAPOLIS - In the late 1990s at Mount Lebanon High School in Pittsburgh, the baseball team included two future major league shortstops. One day, Josh Wilson would pitch and Don Kelly would play short. When Wilson did not pitch, he and Kelly alternated between middle infield spots. ''I guess I started bouncing around then,'' said Kelly, who grew up to hop to more positions than any active player in the majors.

To the Sports Editor: ''Advancing Slowly on a Daunting Road,'' July 19: If the meme about the 1999 U.S. women's soccer team was ''how nice, women can play'' the meme this year was ''awe-inspiring soccer by athletes who happen to be women.'' It's a shift that was possible only because of that 1999 team. They floated above the latent sexism to show everyone that women run, sweat and tackle, too.

HORWITZ--Arthur Jay, 87, of New York City, passed away July 10th in East Hampton, NY. He is survived by his long-time love, Brenda Ballin, of New York City and East Hampton, his sister Melodye (Horwitz) Kinkead, his three children: Jan (Horwitz) Abraham and her husband David of Pennsylvania, R. Jay Horwitz and his wife Lisa Desrosiers-Horwitz of Massachusetts; and Lisa (Horwitz) Booth and her husband Henry of Pennsylvania; his five grandchildren, Jordana (Abraham) Sackel and her husband David, Rose and Juliet Abraham, Laura and Nicholas Booth, cousins, nieces, nephews, and friends. He was married to the late Joan (Berman) Horwitz. A private memorial service will be held in September. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Endowment for the Arts: holboc@arts.gov 202-682-5480. Full obituary online.

An article on Page 12 this weekend about the film ''Life in a Day'' refers erroneously to its direction. Kevin Macdonald was the documentary's sole director; he did not direct it with Joseph Michael, who was one of several hundred contributors to the film.

O'CONNOR--Dr. James V. Pelham Manor, NY. January 15, 1919 - July 14, 2011. Survived by his wife of 55 years, Madeline (nee Malley), his daughters Ann, Madeline, Janet, son James and brother Daniel. Predeceased by his daughter Mary. Loving grandfather of Madeline, Joseph, Genevieve and George. A WWII veteran and 1951 graduate of NYU Dental School, Dr. O'Connor retired at age 80 and spent his retirement years studying philosophy, literature and theology. He had also been an avid marathon runner into his 70's. We will miss him. Contributions in his memory may be made to Catholic Charities of New York, c/o Development, 1011 First Ave., NY, NY 10022.

The powder-blue shirt worn by the home-plate umpire Bill Welke was soaked through by the sixth inning Saturday, probably because it was sunny and close to 100 degrees at Yankee Stadium. A. J. Burnett was also grinding through another start, making Welke's and everyone else's day longer. But Burnett, the Yankees' tall right-hander, actually seemed to be getting better until he walked his last two batters and reached the 100-pitch mark. Manager Joe Girardi received applause when he stepped from the dugout to replace Burnett, and Oakland went on to win, 4-3.

An article last Sunday about the movie ''Sarah's Key,'' a thriller that focuses on elements of the Holocaust, misstated the age of the film's director, Gilles Paquet-Brenner. He is 36, not 39. The article also misidentified the concentration camp in which Mr. Paquet-Brenner's Jewish grandfather died. It was Majdanek, not Birkenau.

On the cover of last week's Metropolitan section, Cara Buckley chronicled the rich history of two East Village buildings that became a refuge for artists and other urban pioneers in the 1970s and will soon be demolished to make room for a new 12-story building. Following are reader comments about the article. Readers also responded to Karen Hartman's essay about her long legal battle to dissolve her Vermont civil union with another woman so that Ms. Hartman -- who wryly called herself a ''hasbian,'' or former lesbian -- could marry a man. Those comments are drawn from NYTimes.com. Not since George Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue'' has somebody captured the heartbeat and soul of the city the way your piece did last Sunday. ... It's a classic example of why a quality newspaper will never be obsolete and what a newspaper can do like no other medium can.
Art Robin Pogrebin

To the Sports Editor: Re ''This Time, a Show Worth Watching,'' July 17: Women's soccer relies more on precision and beauty in its execution than the men's game. The question is whether the women's game is interesting in its own right. There was less faking and deception, and let's not ask them to catch up. The game moves fast and has skillful players.

In last week's City Critic column, Neil Genzlinger explored tattoo etiquette, and we asked readers to share their designs. We received more than 150 images of ankles, calves, shoulders and chests emblazoned with designs dedicated to mothers, brothers, sisters, fathers and grandparents, living and deceased. There were reptiles, pets and fish. You showed us your biceps covered in flags of your countries of origin, playing cards representing childhood games, a father's casino career and even death. We also received a protest about our project -- a tattooed number on the arm of a Holocaust survivor -- reminding us that not all tattooing is voluntary.

BERGER--Phyllis Belous. Died peacefully in her sleep July 16, 2011 surrounded by children Marsha and Peter, their spouses Jonathan and Nina, and grandchildren Danny, Theo, Laura and Lisa, shortly before her 87th birthday. Preceded in death by husband Alex in 2005. Proud to have helped break down barriers for future generations of woman by having been the 1st female mechanical engineer to graduate from Cooper Union and to chair a state board of engineers (NY) and a Engineering Dept. in CUNY history. She was a founding member of the Society of Women Engineers. Passionate about reading and improving the lives of those less fortunate, Phyllis will be missed by all who knew her.

Travelers with an interest in learning Amharic, Ewe, Patois or Mandarin can sign up for the new language programs offered by Projects Abroad (projects-abroad.org) in Ethiopia, Togo, Jamaica and China, respectively. This British service organization, with offices in New York and Toronto, recently added courses that combine volunteer work in developing areas with classroom instruction in one of 18 languages.

WALDMAN--Milton, a recognized Biblical and Talmudic Scholar, had been ordained as a Rabbi in 1957. He died peacefully on July 17th from a form of skin cancer. He was predeceased by his two sisters Florence Cohen and Miriam Deutsch. Contributions in his memory may be made to Colel Chabad, 806 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn NY 11213.

NOON (Fox Movie) NIAGARA (1953) Marilyn Monroe and Niagara Falls are both shining stars of this dramatic thriller. Honeymooners Polly (Jean Peters) and Ray Cutler (Casey Adams) arrive at their cottage by the falls to find that Rose (Monroe) and George Loomis (Joseph Cotten, above with Monroe) have not yet checked out. The Cutlers take temporary accommodations, and the two couples' lives quickly become intertwined, making secrets harder to keep. Polly soon discovers that Rose is cheating on her husband and that his jealous rage is likely justified, although he does seem a bit unstable. And George's uneven personality is caused by Rose's openly lascivious behavior around other men, which is part of her plan. You see, Rose's lover, Patrick (Richard Allan), is to murder George, and it will appear to be the unsurprising suicide or disappearance of a temperamental man. Murder plots rarely go according to plan, however. At 1:30 is the whodunit film noir ''I Wake Up Screaming,'' (1941) starring Betty Grable, Victor Mature and Carole Landis. Frankie (Mature), a promoter, has been accused of murdering Vicky (Landis), a model and aspiring actress. Frankie and Vicky's sister, Jill (Grable), are interrogated for hours and their answers turned into flashbacks reveal the plot. A very eager cop played by Laird Cregar torments and pressures Frankie, and circumstantial evidence against the suspect starts to pile up. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAY Daniel Craig, Don Cheadle and Aretha Franklin are guests. A paralyzed bride gets married. And the New York Yankees gear up for their 2011 Hope Week, a five-day community service program. The team will recognize an individual, family or organization worthy of recognition and support, each day.

STERN--Gertrude "Dee". Gertrude "Dee" Alman Stern of Boca Raton, Florida, formerly of Briarcliff Manor, New York, passed away on July 15, 2011. She was 85. Ms. Stern was the oldest of four daughters of the late Morris and Anna Alman. After Morris passed away when she was only 12, Ms. Stern had to work full time to provide for herself and her family. She attended Baruch College at night and graduated in 1949. She went on to become an executive vice president of Allied Stores Marketing Corporation, which was at the time one of the nation's largest department store organizations. In 1976, Business Week cited her as one of the most successful businesswomen in America, and her life story was included in "12 Who Made It Big," an account of the careers of twelve distinguished graduates of Baruch College. Ms. Stern was a pioneer in the apparel world, opening up the American market to European and Far Eastern fashions. She is survived by her loving sisters Ruth Cohen and Sylvia Pinto, brothers-in-law Bernard Cohen, Abe Greenspan and John Pinto, adoring nephews and nieces Marc (Lyn) Cohen, Mitchell (AnnaMarie) Cohen, Sheldon (Betty) Greenspan, Alan (Charlene) Cohen, April Wertheim (Gina Burrows), Brian (Renee) Greenspan, Eric (Ellen) Wertheim, Brett (Kelly) Cohen, Debra (Sheldon) Green, and many great and great-great-nieces and nephews. She is predeceased by her beloved husband Bruce and dear sister, Shirley Greenspan. Funeral services were held on July 18 at New Montefiore Jewish Cemetery, West Babylon, NY. Contributions in Gertrude's memory may be sent to Hospice of Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, Florida 33407, 877-494-6890, www.hpbcf.org

B ODRUM, a former fishing village on the Aegean Sea, is now a popular upscale getaway: the St.-Tropez of Turkey. But it's not just the turquoise sea that glitters here. Although the shopping options may lack the sheer scale of Istanbul's Grand Bazaar, there is no shortage of intriguing items to be found. At spots like the Marina mall -- with its stunning view of Bodrum Castle and traditional Turkish wooden gulets, or yachts -- and the shopping strip on Barlar Sokagi, or Bars Street, boutiques and markets sell jewelry, carpets, housewares and curios.

An article last Sunday about the e-book revolution's effect on a publishing course taught at Columbia University misstated the position that Drew G. Faust held in 2001, when the course was moved from the Radcliffe Institute of Advanced Study to Columbia University. She was dean of the institute when she gave her blessing to the move; she was not president of Harvard, her current post.

HANCOCK--Evelyn Wyckoff, July 7 in Kingston, NY at the age of 96. A prominent performer in musicals in the 40's and 50's, best known for her role as Laurey in Oklahoma! in 1943. Played opposite Danny Kaye in Lady in the Dark and well known to audiences around the country as Magnolia in Show Boat and Dorothy in the Wizard of Oz at the Muny Opera in St. Louis in 1942. Survived by her daughter, Barbara Valocore of Olivebridge, NY.

A woman in Andrew Plucinski's office is squealing. ''I don't want to look at it!'' She's lying out on a hospital bed, her legs exposed, an arm thrown over her eyes. ''It's nothing yet,'' Mr. Plucinski says. He is reaching into a jar of water, in which swim 20 or so leeches. When they dart, they look like calligraphic strokes - black and curved, tapered at their tails. Mr. Plucinski plucks one, wraps it in a twist of paper towel, and positions its mouth toward a spot on the woman's leg. When the leech begins its work - using its 360 minuscule teeth to scissor in - he laughs. ''Now we are into business!''

An article in some editions last Sunday about the John Jay Homestead Farm Market misidentified the relatives of John Jay who farmed his land in Katonah for 150 years. They were his descendants, not his ancestors.

LURIE--Alfred J. In his 84th year. Husband of the late Leslie Foster and Ellen Goldstick. Father of Leib and Barbara Lurie, Sara, Rebecca and Elly, the late Naomi, and Samuel. Stepfather of Laurie Foster and William Brady III. Grandfather of nine, step-grandfather of two. Brother of David and the late Barbara Hurwitz. Founder of Lurie Mortgage Corp. and a legal administrator. A 1948 alumnus of New York University, where he was editor-in-chief of the Heights Daily News. A humorist and anecdotal historian, he was a nationally-honored long-time Scoutmaster and Council Leader. Services at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 91St. New York City on Sunday, July 24 at 11:30am.

MILLER--Joseph H. It is with great sadness that the Order of Malta announces the death of American Association President Joseph H. Miller, 73, of New Canaan, Connecticut, on Wednesday, June 20 at his home surrounded by his loving family. He is survived by his wife of 48 years, Barbara, his five children: Joseph H. Miller III (Judith) of New Canaan, CT, Megan Creedon of McKinney, TX, Christopher P. Miller (Victoria) of Suwanee, GA, Beth MacInnes (Benjamin) of Rowayton, CT, Allison Lesson (Mark) of Rowayton, CT and 19 grandchildren. Professionally, Mr. Miller was founder of the New Canaan Group, a financial planning and investment firm. Devoted to charitable work and to supporting his Roman Catholic faith, Mr. Miller served on the boards of the Malta Foundation; Holy Family Hospital in Bethlehem in the Holy Land; Malta House of Good Counsel, where he was a founder; Malta Prison Ministry; The Inner-City Foundation for Charity and Education; Catholic Charities of Fairfield County and All Saints Catholic School. Over the years he raised millions of dollars for these and other charities. "Joe has shared fully his many blessings from God, certainly his time, talent and treasure," a friend said. "His life of service and love for his neighbors has never known local or cultural or social boundaries." Mr. Miller participated in 19 pilgrimages to the shrine of Lourdes, France, accompanying the sick and infirm on the annual journey sponsored by the Order of Malta. He served as president of five of those pilgrimages, running on-the-ground operations for the 400-person trip, and in 2008, he and Barbara were chairpersons of the "Lourdes 150th Anniversary Pilgrimage." When he assumed the presidency of the American Association, Mr. Miller pledged "to manage our physical and financial resources, to support, reinforce and reinvigorate our membership in the execution of our charism to serve the sick and the poor, and to defend the Faith." He was a Eucharistic Minister at Saint Aloysius Church in New Canaan and Norwalk Hospital. Mr. Miller graduated from Siena College in Loudonville, NY. Mr. Miller's professional life was spent principally with AXA/Equitable, progressing from agency manager to corporate vice president. He founded the New Canaan Group in 1991 and was a nationally distinguished leader in the insurance and financial services industries. With AXA/Equitable, he was recognized as a life member of the Million Dollar Round Table and a member of Equitable's Hall of Fame. Throughout, he was a trusted advisor to his clients and a model of integrity. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at 11am. on Thursday, July 28, 2011, at Saint Aloysius Church, New Canaan, CT. Calling hours are 3:00pm8:00pm. Wednesday, July 27, at Hoyt Funeral Home, 199 Main St., New Canaan, CT 06840. Mr. Miller's life will be celebrated at a Memorial Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New York City at a date to be determined.

HOW much money do I spend? How much time do I share with my loved one? Am I even lovable? Students at the School of Visual Arts agreed to grapple with such questions for Education Life, turning their answers into graphic snapshots of the grad-school experience.

''Our aura is diminished.'' Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moody's Analytics, on the reputation of the United States as it raced to reach a deal to keep the country from defaulting on its debt. ''For those of us who've been warning about the dangers of too much media power concentrated in too few corporate hands, this scandal is a godsend.'' Jeff Cohen, founding director of the Park Center for Independent Media at Ithaca College, on the News Corporation phonehacking scandal. ''Redundant systems and applications sprouted like weeds.'' Vivek Kundra, chief information officer for the federal government, which announced plans to shut 40 percent of its computer centers over the next four years to reduce its budget and improve efficiency.

While applications to undergraduate institutions continue to surge, the same can't be said for Master of Business Administration programs. According to the Graduate Management Admission Council, 53 percent of business schools reported fewer applications last fall for their two-year, full-time M.B.A. programs than in 2009 (41 percent saw increases and 6 percent no change). Bob Ludwig, GMAC communications director, says that when the dust settles for the coming semester, he doesn't expect that trend to be reversed. ''In these times of economic uncertainty,'' Mr. Ludwig explains, ''you have people that are more hesitant to quit their jobs to go to a full-time program.''

An article in some editions last Sunday about Nostylgia, a store and cafe in Inwood, erroneously attributed a distinction to the nearby Dyckman Farmhouse Museum. It is the last surviving Dutch colonial-style farmhouse in Manhattan, not in the entire city. (There are a number of them in the other boroughs.)

QUINLAN--Ellen Dorothy, died on July 21, 2011. Born in Hempstead, NY, Ms. Quinlan attended Sacred Heart School and the Finch University where she studied fashion design. She graduated from Marymount College with a joint B.A. in education and sociology. Ms. Quinlan taught Kindergarten and First grade for over 30 years. She taught in Barcelona, Spain and then in the New York public schools. In 1963, she joined the United Nations School where she dedicated her career teaching. She was a visionary teacher whose philosophy was to instill confidence in each child. Ms. Quinlan left the U.N. School in 1987 to provide devoted care to her parents John Leo Quinlan and Helen Reily Quinlan. She was predeceased by her twin sister Elizabeth who she missed with all of her heart. She volunteered for Hofstra University and Mercy Medical Center. She recently established a company named Lizell with her niece to distribute hand designed coloring books and crayons to hospitals for children. Ms. Quinlan loved the beach, reading, Broadway shows, and a great cup of coffee. Ms. Quinlan is survived by her niece Beth Tauro of Boston, her dear friend Linda Kopmann of New York, and her brother Michael E. Quinlan of Texas. She is also survived by four nephews, Joseph L and Christopher M. Tauro of Boston and John Michael and Peter Quinlan of Texas as well as by seven grand nieces, three grand nephews. Services will be held at 10am on July 26, at St. Thomas The Apostle Church West Hempstead, NY.

An article in the Mutual Funds Report, Part 2 of this section on July 10, about the growth of exchange-traded funds described one such fund, SPDR Gold Shares, incorrectly. It is designed to track the spot price of gold, not an index of gold-mining stocks.

JOHNSON--James Gann Jr.,aged 95, died on July 9 in New Rochelle, NY. He was born on October 15, 1915 to James G. Johnson and Marguerite Willing in Jackson, MS. The family moved to New York in 1918. He graduated from the Hill School, Yale University and Yale Law School. He was a member of Root, Clark, Buckner & Ballantine, served as counsel to the Office of the Lend Lease Administration, U.S. Department of State, United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration (UNRRA), and the United Nations. He served as legal adviser, later deputy director to UNRRA's China office. He joined Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton in 1946, specializing in corporate and international law until his retirement in 1983. Mr. Johnson was knighted by Belgium and France. He was a board member of the International Institute of Rural Reconstruction and chair (1987-1996). He was President Emeritus of Friends of the Reservoir, Inc., now the Larchmont Reservoir-James G. Johnson Conservancy. He served on the Board of Directors of LTCB Trust Company. He chaired the foreign law committee for the New York Bar Association and led the ABA's first formal mission to China. He served on Boards of Education in Virginia, Paris, and Mamaroneck, NY, served on and chaired the board of College Careers Fund of Westchester. For all his accomplishments, he was humble, down to earth, and caring for those who surrounded him in his family, in his communities, and in his world. Contributions may be sent to IIRR, the Sheldrake Center, or College Careers of Westchester.
MASON--Michael J. Beloved husband, brother, friend and therapist. Died peacefully at home on July 22, 2011.

The Getting Started column last Sunday, about requirements for renters, misstated the income guidelines for Insurent, a company that provides insurance for leases. Customers of Insurent must have a gross income of 27.5 times the monthly rent, not 27.5 percent of the monthly rent.

SOBEL--Michael V.,M.D. Michael V. Sobel, M.D., a rheumatologist and silver life master bridge player, died at his home in Tiverton, RI, early on Monday, July 4, of complications associated with diabetes. He was 76. Dr. Sobel came from a family of physicians. He counted his father, brother, two uncles, three cousins, and one of his sons as colleagues in the medical professions. Born May 10, 1935 in Brooklyn, New York, he spent his childhood in the Bronx, near the zoo and botanical gardens. He was a graduate of Cornell University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Despite the early onset of his own illness, he distinguished himself through a full career until his retirement in 2003. He was recognized as an astute clinician and served as a mentor to many, practicing medicine and teaching in New Haven, CT, Boston and Fall River, MA, and Ithaca, NY. An avid bicyclist, cook, woodworker, and serious student of history, he enjoyed reading, many forms of word play, and music. He met his wife, Pamela Cook, after he built a harpsichord from a kit and applied to her for lessons on how to play it. He is survived by his wife, their daughter, Amanda Sobel, two sons from a previous marriage, Jeremy and Daniel Sobel, and two grandchildren. His brother, Stephen, and sister, Dava, also mourn his loss. According to his wishes, Dr. Sobel was cremated. In lieu of a funeral, the family will hold a memorial service some months from now. Those who remember him fondly and wish to honor him are encouraged to make a gift to his favorite charity, Doctors Without Borders.

The five most-viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports for July 15 to 21. 1. JAPAN BATTLES BACK AGAINST UNITED STATES Japan won its first Women's World Cup in a triumph built on hope, renewal, patience, composure and no small amount of good fortune. (Published July 17)

DUCKLER--Naomi Weinstein, Died on July 17 at her home in the Catalina Foothills, in Tucson, AZ, surrounded by her four children and husband, Marvin Ira Duckler. She was to celebrate her 80th birthday, and 60th wedding anniversary this year. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Naomi held Bachelor's and Master's degrees in Nutrition and Food Science from Brooklyn College. Mother, nurturer, and beloved by her four children: Ariel Eva Duckler-Levy; Mordecai (Max) Sam Duckler; Ana Miryam Duckler Forest; Sara Rebecca Duckler. Proud grandmother of ten grandchildren, David, Lily, Gali, Nadav, Eva, Matan, Adam, Benjamin, Isabella, and Rachel. She is also survived by her two brothers, William Weinstein of Toronto, Canada, and the Hon. Judge Jack B. Weinstein, of the E.D.N.Y. Naomi was a mensch, with a beautiful character who always wanted everyone to be happy. A gentle and intelligent sense of humor, and a love and appreciation for all. She will be profoundly missed for her brilliant smile and laughter, sparkling blue eyes, her innocence and worldliness, her purity, truth, decency, honesty, faithfulness, her humor and generosity; a woman of honor and love. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your preferred charity.

NOT too long ago, Terence Koh, the notoriously cryptic artist with a penchant for all things white, contacted the photographer Tim Barber with a cryptic, albeit colorful, proposal. ''Tim,'' he said, ''I want to paint the floor blue and I want you to curate a show,'' recalled Mr. Barber, who has known Mr. Koh long enough to be able to decipher this haiku, and to take the offer seriously. ''Open Sesame (The Blue Floor Show)'' is now on view at the Asia Song Society, the occasional gallery that Mr. Koh runs out of his whitewashed apartment at 45 Canal Street. In the spirit of redecoration and also, perhaps, the color blue, Mr. Barber has selected photographs that have been reworked (''Outside the Hospital,'' by Sam Falls, left) and hang together in a ''color field sort of way.'' And in the spirit of friendship and also, perhaps, expediency, all but one of the artists represented in the show are veterans of Mr. Barber's Web site, Tiny Vices; tinyvices.com. ALIX BROWNE

The Barbizon, the 23-story brick building on the corner of 63rd Street and Lexington Avenue, has been reinvented several times over the last century, and the next chapter may be written by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission. At a city hearing scheduled for Tuesday, the building is up for consideration as a landmark. Most famously, it opened in 1927 as the Barbizon Hotel for Women. Its residents included Grace Kelly, Candice Bergen, Joan Didion and Sylvia Plath, as well as hundreds of other women who made their way to New York from across the country seeking work and finding a safe haven in the hotel. There, strict rules included a ban on men above the lobby floor.

MOGENSEN--Vernon L. Ph.D, age 59, on July 16. Mourned by his wife Carol and brother William who are saddened by his sudden passing, he was a scholar, teacher and activist, committed not just to understanding the world to but to changing it. A Professor of Political Science at Kingsborough Community College, CUNY, he published extensively in the areas of workers' rights and safety and health. Among his works are "Office Politics" and the editorship of "Worker Safety Under Siege." He graduated with a B.A. from Rutgers University and a Ph.D. with honors from the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. A fan of sports, travel, and conviviality, he embraced the world. He will be remembered for his great humor, compassion and courage.

KRAFT--Myra We celebrate the life, legacy and generosity of our dear friend and partner Myra Kraft. May her memory be a blessing. Lynn Schusterman and the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation

So, they shut down a 10-mile stretch of one of the world's busiest freeways for repair last weekend, in the nation's most driver-stressed metropolis, and gave it a scary name - Carmageddon. Predictions were that Los Angeles would look like Mike Huckabee's arteries before he lost a hundred pounds, and that chaos and road rage would reign under the tired sunlight of the Southland. Lo, the weekend came and went, and a miracle was proclaimed - ''a historic moment'' in traffic history, as Los Angeles County Supervisor Zev Yaroslavsky called it. The 405 freeway opened 17 hours ahead of schedule. Pollution and smog levels dropped. A trio of pedestrians even dined on linen in the middle of the empty road. Ya-a-a-ay for L.A.!

ROSEN--Marcia, Ph.D. The William Alanson White Psychoanalytic Institute & Society mourn the loss of Marcia Rosen, Ph.D., Training and Supervising Analyst and faculty member for decades. We remember her warmth, kindness, grace and keen sense of style. She taught a generation of colleagues about humane engagement with profoundly disturbed patients and reached out generously in recent years as a pioneer in teaching psychoanalysis in Russia and China. Jay S. Kwawer, Ph.D., Director, White Institute Lori C. Bohm, Ph.D., President, White Society Mitchell Kosh, President, Board of Trustees
'After 13 years of loyal service, needless to say this came as a shock.'

FURST--Moshe, passed away Tuesday July 19th, 17 Tamuz in Rehovot, Israel where he resided for 38 years. Married for 58 years to the late Batya Furst. Loving father of Zev (Sandy), Malki (Dov Cymbalista), and Aryeh (Debi). IN late 2008, Susan Holland met the Tony-winning Broadway producer Hal Luftig and his long-time partner, Stewart Adelson, a psychiatrist, at their Chelsea loft to discuss the wedding reception the two were planning for the coming spring. ''I was thinking afternoon cocktails,'' said Mr. Luftig, who had legally married Mr. Adelson in October. Mr. Adelson instead wanted something even more low-key, maybe just a few friends and some finger food. Ms. Holland, known for staging extravagant affairs (she planned the 2006 Connecticut wedding of Dallas Bryce Howard, the daughter of the director Ron Howard), refused.

On May 29, a young woman named Bushra al- Maqtari joined a group of several thousand protesters marching down a trash-strewn boulevard in the Yemeni city of Taiz. The Arab world's democratic uprising was five months old, and patience among the protesters in Taiz -- Yemen's second largest city -- was wearing thin. Maqtari had been one of the first and most fearless leaders of the movement. She is a remarkable figure: a 31-year-old university administrator and fiction writer, she is also a childless divorcee who refused, until recently, to wear the abaya, the all-covering gown that is practically mandatory for women in Yemen. Tiny and frail, she has a round, lovely face, with level brows and tranquil brown eyes. On that afternoon, Maqtari was standing in a crowd gathered around the city's General Security building -- an imposing six-story edifice flanked by guards -- when she heard cracking sounds. She looked up and saw that the officers on the building's roof were not just throwing rocks, as they had in the past. They were firing straight down into the crowd below. Within minutes, at least four people were dead and about 60 were wounded. Maqtari began running back toward ''Freedom Square,'' the intersection where thousands of protesters had been camped out for months demanding the resignation of Ali Abdullah Saleh, Yemen's strongman president. Then the real assault began. Armored vehicles, tanks and bulldozers began converging on the protesters' tent city from all sides. They fired tear gas and water cannons into the square and began shooting protesters at point-blank range. They doused the tents, which extended for hundreds of yards in every direction, with gasoline and lighted them on fire. None of the protesters had weapons. ''People were dying all around us, and there was nothing we could do,'' Maqtari told me. Some were burned alive. At around 11 p.m., Maqtari fled to her sister's house, about 200 yards uphill from the square. There, she and other protesters watched as flames engulfed the entire square, raging for several hours. Officers stormed through the local hospital and several field clinics where protesters were being treated, firing tear gas down the corridors, shooting up the ceilings and arresting doctors and nurses. Some thrust their gun butts into patients' wounds. Others were laughing hysterically, as if they were on drugs, Maqtari and others told me, and shouting into the darkness, ''Ali is your god!'' The next morning, amid the charred remains of the tents, someone had scrawled a sardonic reversal of the protesters' chants on a wall. ''The regime wants the fall of the people,'' it said.

MCHARGUE--Georgess, of Groton, completed her sixteen year long "dance" with breast cancer on Monday, July 18, 2011. She is survived by her beloved husband Michael Roberts, daughter Mairi McHargue Elliott, grandsons Colin Elliott and Griffin Elliott, stepdaughters Traci Roberts and Kelly Richardson, and innumerable friends. You are invited to join her family at a reception at the Badger Funeral Home, 45 School St., Groton, MA on Monday, July 25 from 4-7pm. Her dance with breast cancer drew her into various support groups and culminated in her involvement with and devotion to "the Virginia Thurston Healing Garden" in Harvard, MA. In lieu of flowers, you are urged to contribute to the Garden at 145 Bolton Road Harvard, MA 01451-0145 in her memory, or to the First Parish Church Unitarian, 1 Powder House Road, P.O. Box 457, Groton, MA 01450-0457. The dance may have ended, but for all who knew her, the music will never die. She always appreciated other people's gardens so if you would like to bring a sampling of yours, please do so in a vase you won't miss. A Memorial service will be held in the fall.

The picture on the cover last Sunday, with a review of ''The Art of Cruelty,'' by Maggie Nelson, was printed in mirror image. FREUD--Lucian, 1922-2011, We at Acquavella Galleries are deeply saddened by the death of our close friend Lucian Freud, a great artist whose works will live on to inspire others. Although Lucian always did things his own way, our partnership for the last twenty years could not have been more fulfilling. We were proud to represent him as an artist and will miss him even more as a good friend. William Acquavella and the Acquavella Family

It was during Prime Minister Gordon Brown's visit to the White House in March 2009, not during Obama's ''first visit to Downing Street.''

Ben Zulu was a quintessential entrepreneur who dedicated his life to development, the arts and communication in Africa. He was a graduate of Columbia University in Business and Economics. BOOKBINDER--Hyman. We mourn the loss of a true giant for justice, Hyman Bookbinder. Bookie, long-time representative for the AJC, set the standard for all of us involved in social justice advocacy. We are proud that for many years his office was in our building and are grateful for his inspiring mentorship. Bookie's legacy as a champion for social justice and Jewish values is a blessing to our nation. Our thoughts are with Ida and his entire family. Rabbi David Saperstein, Mark Pelavin and the staff of the Religious Action Center of Reform Judaism.

MERENDA--Joseph J. DVM.,died July 13th, 2011 at age 98 in Las Vegas, NV. A 1934 graduate of the Veterinary College at Cornell University, he was an early practitioner of small animal medicine at the Zepp Clinic on West 53rd Street, Manhattan, NY. In a 2007 interview with Dr. Donald F. Smith of Cornell, Dr. Merenda described his career from its beginnings as a college freshman through the years of developing methods and instruments for this nascent specialty. The complete interview can be found at: http://ecommons.cornell.edu/ bitstream/1813/12877/1/ Merenda,%20Joseph%20J.% 20'34%20BioInt.pdf He was always proud of his education at Cornell, attending many reunions, including his 75th in 2009. Dr. Merenda was a U.S. Army Reservist called to active duty during World War II. He served at several U.S. military installations and was active in the Army War Dogs program, retiring in 1972 as a Lt. Colonel. He was born August 19, 1912, in Newark, NJ, grew up on Long Island and lived most of his life in Brooklyn, NY. His wife, Dorothy A. Tedtsen, predeceased him. He is survived by his daughter, Dorothy Janowsky of Las Vegas, NV, his son, Joseph Merenda, Jr. of Rockville, MD, two granddaughters and five great-grandchildren.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''At Two-Year Colleges, Less Scrutiny Equals Less Athletic Equality,'' July 18: Team sport participation rarely translates into a lifelong habit of physical fitness. There are better and more practical ways to even up the provisions of Title IX.

For all the pitchers lost this season to Tommy John surgery - including Brett Anderson, Joba Chamberlain, Jorge De La Rosa, Daisuke Matsuzaka and Adam Wainwright - one recent patient has a message: returning to your old self takes time. Joe Nathan, the four-time All-Star closer for the Minnesota Twins, had reconstructive elbow surgery on March 26, 2010. He returned for opening day this season, but by the end of May, he had lost his closer's spot, had a bloated earned run average (7.63) and was back on the disabled list with a strained flexor muscle.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''A Resilient Team Soothes a Nation,'' July 18: Japan's euphoria in winning the Women's World Cup championship in a thrilling final was a fitting reaction. The victory epitomized the rallying spirit of the Japanese, whose country was battered by earthquakes and a tsunami. The team's persistence and resilience during the gut-wrenching penalty-kick shootout was the hallmark of their spectacular success.

Harriet Daimler, the protagonist of Iris Owens's 1973 novel, ''After Claude,'' has a knack for eviscerating self-satisfied urban types. After rolling her eyes at a slender girl passing a joint ('' 'I'm wrecked,' she bragged, as though it took a special talent to get stoned''), Harriet utters a relatable prayer: ''Lord, spare me these dimpled darlings who are always congratulating themselves for not having any thoughts or feelings.'' Harriet might have given those dimpled darlings a little more credit. Floating through life unencumbered by thoughts or feelings tends to be a lot more challenging than people might think. As the tabloids have demonstrated for decades now, even those with untold cash reserves and limitless adoration from the masses can't tamp down their bad desires or their neuroses for too long. Empowered to sip Champagne among half-naked nymphs beside glittering swimming pools, somehow these mortals still struggle mightily to keep their pesky thoughts and feelings from messing with their golden lives.

JACOBSON--Phyllis, passed away on July 21. Beloved mother of Georgia and Jon; grandmother of Amanda, Robert, and Lauren. A terrific golfer and life master bridge player. Long-time resident of Palm Beach. Supporter of the Arts. A lady of great class. She will be missed. Services held at Star of David, Palm Beach Gardens, 561-627-2277.

WADSWORTH--Lavinia T. The Board of Trustees and staff of China Institute express their deepest sorrow at the passing of Lavinia T. Wadsworth, and extend their heartfelt sympathy to her daughter, China Institute Trustee Mary Wadsworth Darby, and her family.

The best story about Myra Kraft to emerge among the touching remembrances following her death this week after a long battle with cancer came from her son Jonathan. He recalled how his mom, during a family trip to South Africa in the era of apartheid, demanded that a white police officer who was taking black men into custody arrest her, too. Jonathan remembered his dad, the Patriots owner Robert K. Kraft, telling him not to let his mother get in trouble. So he threw his mom, a petite woman, over his shoulder and hauled her away. Robert Kraft's office in Gillette Stadium is decorated with pictures of him with celebrities (there is a dazzling photograph near the door of him dancing with Jacqueline Kennedy), but the ones behind his desk, closest to him, are huge portraits of his family. Robert and Myra met as college students and Myra knew nothing of football until her husband bought the Patriots. Myra was raised in privilege herself, and then used the team's fame and success to enhance her own vast philanthropic efforts. She became a fixture around the Patriots, sitting next to her husband and children at games, and the outpouring of grief from former and current Patriots players speaks to how much of a presence she became in their lives. Curtis Martin, the former Patriots and Jets running back, told a story about how when he was sick of eating out, Myra gave him homemade soup. She was at the center of the pregame parties her husband threw, and was waiting outside the locker room for him when the games were over. She was far more than a cheerleader, though, so central to her husband's decision-making that when she famously objected in 1996 after the Patriots drafted Christian Peter, who had a history of violence against women, he was quickly cut. Last week, Dan Shaughnessy of The Boston Globe called her the conscience and soul of the Patriots.

OSLO -- The Norwegian man charged Saturday with a pair of attacks in Oslo that killed at least 92 people left behind a detailed manifesto outlining his preparations and calling for a Christian war to defend Europe against the threat of Muslim domination, according to Norwegian and American officials familiar with the investigation. As stunned Norwegians grappled with the deadliest attack in the country since World War II, a portrait began to emerge of the suspect, Anders Behring Breivik, 32. The police identified him as a right-wing fundamentalist Christian, while acquaintances described him as a gun-loving Norwegian obsessed with what he saw as the threats of multiculturalism and Muslim immigration.

In the aftermath of Bull Run, Washington was invaded — not by Confederate troops, but by a horde of stragglers, limping back in various degrees of discombobulation and post-traumatic stress. Some were soldiers, some simply hangers-on who had come out for the show and lost their way in the fog of war. One of the stranger-looking refugees was a short, bearded man with a straw hat and spectacles, and a watch fob dangling from his belt — along with a sword concealed awkwardly under his overcoat. A contemporary said he looked like “a Paris art student.” This confused apparition, more comical than belligerent, was Mathew Brady, the most famous photographer in the United States. Appropriately, he went straight to the nearest camera, and promptly recorded a not-very-heroic moment in American history.

“I never carried a real handbag until I started designing them,” says the debutante accessories designer Victoria Horning. “But now, every morning I take the bag I choose to wear so seriously!” Horning, a 24-year-old Manhattanite who graduated from some of fashion’s most prestigious prep schools (read: internships at Vogue, Alexander Wang and Nina Ricci), had terrific experience and no place to tote it. So, she started a label, making bags and cummerbunds out of calf hair, leather, alligator and stingray. It was a relatively modest project — that is, until word got out and her girlfriends wanted in. Today, the made-in-New York collection features six handbags, including the off-white lambskin one that Horning chose for her appointment with T (above). “I just hope to see lots of girls wearing them, especially the Kates,” she says. “You know, Bosworth and Moss.” Oh, yes.

In the artist Alia Penner’s eyes, everything looks better covered in rainbows. Not girly, pastel rainbows, but brilliant acid hues that bring to mind Peter Max and Sonia Delaunay. Now, after dipping her toes into fashion with illustrations for Erin Wasson’s RVCA ad campaign and the hand-lettered titles for a Missoni film by Kenneth Anger, Penner, the former fashion editor of Arthur magazine, has introduced Mombi, a line of dresses named for a witch in Frank L. Are you wilting faster than an overdressed salad? I am. It’s hot out, and to me that’s salad weather. (Actually, every season is salad weather to me, but I crave it more as the temperature rises.) The best-tasting salads rely on good greens lightly coated in a well-made vinaigrette, which is a snap to make once you know a few little tricks. The first is to always dissolve the salt in the acid before adding the oil. Then give it a good whisking or, even easier, shake, shake, shake it up in a jar. An ailing 94-year-old Brooklyn woman died from the heat on Saturday afternoon; it is the first heat-related death the city medical examiner’s office has certified this summer. The medical examiner’s office listed the cause of death, which occurred at 12:35 p.m., as “hyperthermia due to exposure to high environmental temperature with underlying natural disease.” It provided no other information about the woman or the circumstances of her death. At that time, the outside temperature was 92 to 95 degrees in New York City, the National Weather Service said.

A few thoughts about Forrest Blue, one of the N.F.L.’s best centers of the early 1970s. Blue was residing at an assisted-living facility in Carmichael, Calif., when he died last week at age 65 or 66 (There is some discrepancy as to whether he was born in 1944 or in 1945.) In pop culture as in politics, there are consumers so discerning that they will not commit disposable income or cast votes unless they know in advance exactly what they’re getting from a blockbuster movie or a candidate for office, and these people want their commitments up front – preferably in the form of a verbal oath or written pledge. If you make such a declaration as an election contender, you might be abdicating your “governing responsibilities in a period of incredibly rapid change and financial stress,” as Thomas Friedman has written, but if you do so as the star or creator of a forthcoming fantasy-themed work, you might just be participating in Comic-Con International, which wrapped up in San Diego over the weekend.

As you read ''The Swinger'' (Simon and Schuster), the new golf novel by Michael Bamberger and Alan Shipnuck based on the tribulations that grounded Tiger Woods, it's easy to catch yourself wondering: Is this what really happened? No one may ever know exactly what happened to Woods, and the book is fiction - keep repeating that with each turned page - but it provides invaluable insight into the life and times of Woods, even if the intimate details described are not verified, or meant to be.

(National Geographic) HITLER'S SUICIDE SHIP This is the story of one of Hitler's prized warships, the Admiral Graf Spee, above, which was blown up by its own captain, Hans Langsdorff, in December 1939 after a battle with British ships off the coast of Uruguay. Though the Graf Spee was more technologically advanced and had heavier artillery, Langsdorff tried to win by evading opponents instead of attacking. He then committed suicide. ''Gestapo Chief,'' at 9, follows the husband-and-wife team Serge and Beate Klarsfeld as they search for Nazis and try to bring them to justice. Kurt Lischka, once the Gestapo chief in Paris and responsible for the deaths of tens of thousands of Jews, was allowed to live openly in West Germany instead of paying for his crimes. The couple shadowed Lischka for almost nine years and eventually planned a kidnapping that ended in the couple's arrest in 1974. On ''Hunting Hitler's Generals,'' at 10, Allied operatives are ordered to capture or kill Gen. Erwin Rommel in his Libyan desert headquarters. Something went horribly wrong during the mission, and what really happened is still a mystery. 8 P.M. When Lisa Marion's roommates moved out of her apartment in Toronto in February, she scrambled to find replacements. But instead of finding one or two, she found 30. Ms. Marion, 26, has been using Airbnb, a Web site that streamlines the process of renting out her extra bedrooms to travelers. The service has unexpectedly turned her into a bed-and-breakfast owner, bringing in roughly $1,800 a month, a nice cushion as she works on starting her own business.

ALT--Franz L. Born Vienna November 30, 1910, died New York July 21, 2011. Mathematician. A founder and third president of Association for Computing Machinery. Member 10th Mountain Division, WW II. National Bureau of Standards 1948-67 directing early use of computers at NBS and throughout federal government. Established citation indexing at the American Institute of Physics 1967-74. Awarded Ehrenkreuz fur Wissenschaft und Kunst, Austria's highest distinction for science and art, 2007. Lifelong hiker and chamber musician (violin, viola). Predeceased by first wife Alice Modern. Survived by daughter Theresa (Wayles) and son James (Elaine), granddaughter Rachel (Mark) and grandson Adam (Michele). Also survived by second wife Annice, her daughters Joyce (Heath), Helen (Stuart) and Claudia (Joseph), her stepdaughters Patricia and Barbara (George), and her grandchildren Susannah, Kathleen, Lucas, Alden, Jack, Victoria and Charlotte. Memorial to be announced in the fall.

Gawker, the popular blog based in New York, is going to court to investigate the relationship between the Fox News chairman, Roger Ailes, and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey. On Monday, the company and one of its reporters, John Cook, plan to file a civil suit against Mr. Christie's office to try to obtain records of the communications between the two men. Mr. Cook, who regularly uses freedom of information and open public records acts to ferret out information for his Gawker articles, said the court action represents the first lawsuit filed by Gawker to obtain information.

BUSINESS DAY An article on Thursday about the increasing use of social media background checks in job recruitment erroneously listed one piece of personal information among those that are protected under federal employment laws. While companies are not supposed to ask about a person's religion, race, marital status or disabilities, information about sexual orientation is not federally protected.The article also misstated Dave Clark's position at Impulse Advanced Communications,which uses such background checks. He is its president, not its owner.

Kennedy -- died on July 6 at his home in Chicago. He was 84. Mr. Leslie died of natural causes, his niece Leslie McCullough Jeffries said.

It was all about the smash factor. My smash factor wasn't what it was supposed to be. It was off. It wavered. It was mushy. It wasn't smashing. I was getting fitted for new golf clubs, a process that begins with an audition of sorts. You hit your old clubs - in my case, an eight-year-old set of irons - as sophisticated monitors measure everything but your embarrassment.

Netflix's announcement on July 13 about changes to its subscription structure and an increase in its pricing may not have much of an effect on the demand for video-on-demand movies. Film fans are becoming accustomed to instant gratification, not only in their living rooms but on mobile devices as well. The top movies shown this year by cable and telecom providers include children's fare like ''Despicable Me'' and audience pleasers like ''Black Swan'' and ''Due Date,'' above, with Zack Galifianakis, left, and Robert Downey Jr. SHELLY FREIERMAN

After Wi-Fi, will there be... Li-Fi? Researchers around the world are fine-tuning technologies that use standard lighting equipment to cheaply transmit high-speed data streams wirelessly, even while the equipment appears to be producing nothing more than normal illumination. Generally, the technologies rapidly and subtly fluctuate the intensity of light-emitting diodes, or LEDs, in a way that is imperceptible to the human eye.

Pierrette Alarie-Simoneau, an internationally known Canadian soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1940s, died on July 10 at her home in Victoria, British Columbia. She was 89. Mrs. Alarie-Simoneau died of natural causes, her family said.
