For Sarah Solovay, a New York City-based singer and songwriter who opened for John Mayer this spring, summers are particularly sweet. Ms. Solovay spends her days recording music and her nights performing on the Lower East Side or working on new music. And she doesn't have to worry about physics tests or the pesky paper she needs to write about ''King Lear.''

RIDLESS--James Jesse, 90, of Great Neck, New York and Boynton Beach, Florida passed away on July 23 after a brief illness. Devoted husband to his wife of 65 years, Renee (nee Jacoby). Cherished father of Helene (David), Robin (Alan) and Jaymie (Jason). Loving grandfather of Jackie (Dave), Nicholas and Jake. Adoring great-grandfather of Gavin and Kaden. Beloved uncle. A World War II veteran, Jimmy flew sixty missions as a B-24 pilot in the 454 Bomb Group in Europe. Returning home, he commenced a successful career with the Cincinnati Time Recorder company that spanned over fifty years. A great teller of jokes and funny stories, as well as an incredibly loving, intelligent, honorable, kind and generous man, he will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held Monday, July 25, 1pm at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels in Great Neck.

AT the hearing into the News of the World phone hacking scandal in London this past Tuesday, the commissioner of Scotland Yard did something unusual for a policeman. He quoted Shakespeare. Explaining the swiftness of his resignation, he mangled a bit of Macbeth: ''If 'twere best it were done, 'twere well it were done quickly.'' The reference was perfectly fitting for a scandal whose defining adjective is coming to be ''Shakespearean.'' Many have noted superficial similarities between the scandal and Shakespearean tragedy: overheard messages, hired thugs. There's a hashtag sprawling through Twitter: #shakespeare4murdoch. (My favorite so far: ''remorse, remorse, my kingdom for remorse.'')

FIERMAN--Russ. To our dearest friend Ady. Our hearts go out to you, Adam, Arielle, Lucy, Robert and the rest of your family during this tragic time of profound sorrow. We will always remember Russ as the most vibrant, independent and caring friend. His devotion to his family was always paramount. We are grateful to have shared so many happy occasions together. Nancy Olnick, Giorgio Spanu, Eve, Robert, Stella & Sylvia Olnick

Vostu, a Brazilian company whose social games are popular in South America, filed a countersuit against the online gaming giant Zynga on Wednesday, responding to a suit from Zynga claiming that Vostu copied its game designs. The Zynga suit, which was filed in June, complained that Vostu had infringed the company's copyright by stealing game design layouts, game mechanics, game objects and storylines.

WOHLMAN--Vivian, (90), on July 23, 2011. She is survived by her daughter Leslie Wohlman Himmel and son-in-law Alan Shuch, her son, Gary Wohlman, and her loving grandchildren Andrea and David Himmel. Services will be held at 11:30am on Wednesday, July 27 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Vivian Wohlman to the Mount Sinai Department of Dermatology, The Development Office, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029.

THOMASES--Florence Josephson, mother of four, mentor of many, died July 24, 2011 at the age of 97. She was the loving wife of the late Fred Thomases and devoted mother to Robert, Matthew, Jeffrey and Susan. Mrs. Thomases was a founding member of the Ramapo College Board of Trustees and served several years as Board President. She supported countless students and faculty through endowed scholarships and grants for research and teaching excellence. Mrs. Thomases was an energizing figure in dozens of Jewish and civic organizations. She was a staunch supporter of the State of Israel, in particular the Jerusalem Foundation and the Israel Cancer Research Fund. She graduated from Hunter College in 1934 and served for a many years as a director of the Scholarship and Welfare Fund of the Alumni Association. A lifelong Democrat and political activist, Mrs. Thomases campaigned over the years to help elect scores of progressive candidates. At the age of 94, she was a passionate supporter of Hillary Clinton in the 2008 primaries and then volunteered for Barack Obama in the general election. The beloved grandmother of Holly, Andrew, Ken, Caroline, Josh, Ben, David, Danny, Greg, Shannon, Tom, Justine, Lili and Phoebe. Mrs. Thomases also took great pride in being the great-grandmother of 12. She grew up in the Bronx, raised her family in Englewood, New Jersey, and then relocated to Manhattan to spend the last 10 years of her life to be near what she loved doing most -- enjoying the cultural life of the city. Over the years, Mrs. Thomases sponsored many struggling artists. And, despite her failing health, she found time this past June to fund one last project -- a documentary film about the hard-working women in the cattle industry of rural Arizona. Services will be held at 10:00am, Tuesday, July 26 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave (at 91st St) New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Hunter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund The Jerusalem Foundation The Israel Cancer Research Fund.
POLSKY--Edwin, July 25, 2004. Dad I miss you every day. You're always in my heart. Gail

ASPEN, Colo. -- Frank P. Quattrone is the banker who helped set off the dot-com boom when he took Netscape public in 1995. Today he is having flashbacks. Answering the question on the tip of everyone's tongues in the tech world -- is there a bubble? -- he said that current times remind him not of the height of the last bubble but of the early days of the boom.

GRUENSPECHT--Fred, age 87, of Fort Lee, on Saturday, July 23, 2011. Beloved wife of Renee Gruenspecht. Devoted father of Karen and her husband Irwin Meyer, Howard and his wife Susan Gruenspecht. Adored grandfather of Joshua, Benjamin, Joseph and the late Jonathan. Cherished brother of the late Harry Gruenspecht. Fred proudly served in WWII as a veteran of the United States Army and was a member of the Fort Lee Jewish War Veterans Post. Religious Services Monday 1:30pm at the Jewish Community Center of Fort Lee, Stillwell and Anderson Avenue. Interment following at the family plot in Cedar Park Cemetery. For more info, www.edenmemorial.com or call 1-888-700-EDEN.

WEBER--Susan, 69. Daughter of the late Harry and Edith Weber. Beloved sister of Sara Weber and her husband Robert Langan, mother of Krystin and Bryon Rubin and his wife Jessica Zirkel-Rubin. Adoring grandmother to Max and Noa Rubin. Please make any donations to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.

FREUD--Lucian, 1922-2011, We at Acquavella Galleries are deeply saddened by the death of our close friend Lucian Freud, a great artist whose works will live on to inspire others. Although Lucian always did things his own way, our partnership for the last twenty years could not have been more fulfilling. We were proud to represent him as an artist and will miss him even more as a good friend. William Acquavella and the Acquavella Family

WEDNESDAY’S PUZZLE — There are those who believe that there are only a limited number of original ideas left for crossword themes and there are those who believe that original ideas are limitless and can come from anywhere. I tend to fall somewhere along the middle of that spectrum. Even if the way an idea is presented is not entirely original, I still appreciate and admire a theme that is solidly constructed and has some great entry/cluing combinations.

In Friday’s Fixes column, I wrote about the Medicines Patent Pool, a new organization trying to make AIDS drugs better, cheaper and available sooner to people who need them in poor countries.   It relies on voluntary donations of rights by patent holders, most of them pharmaceutical companies.   Its success is crucial;  new research shows that if we can dramatically increase the number of people on antiretroviral medicines, we can not only save millions of lives, but potentially cause the epidemic to die away.

After the E. coli outbreak in Europe last month — which sickened more than 3000 people and killed at least 50 — it was impossible not to think about irradiation. “What if,” I asked myself, “those little fenugreek seeds had been irradiated?” Might there have been fewer deaths, fewer cases of hemolytic-uremic syndrome (essentially, kidney failure; there were 900), fewer tragic stories?

The news often reads as if written by a hard-line surrealist. Look at the morning’s home page or front page headlines: The world appears to be nothing but a series of nonsequiturs, bizarre conjunctions at every turn, a bundle of isolated phenomena with no apparent meaning or connection. Take two very recent events, each of them entirely singular, extraordinary, and in their different ways tragic. Just a few days ago, I read about them on the same page of a newspaper, immediately adjacent to one another, separated only by a thin black line. I was shocked by the proximity. It was like an oxymoron, or a Zen koan, I couldn’t make any sense of it. Amy Winehouse and Anders Behring Breivik.

Cable television loves shows that pit the hunter vs. the hunted, and a crunching of last week’s Nielsen ratings reveals that a new king of the genre can be crowned. “Swamp People” on History, which follows Cajun alligator hunters who fight for their lives and their livelihood in the Louisiana swamp, pulled in 5.5 million total viewers for its Season 2 finale last week, overtaking “The Deadliest Catch” on Discovery, which had 3 million total viewers. It was the most-viewed cable show last Thursday in total viewers. Among all Thursday programming, including the broadcast networks, “Swamp People” was only bested by “Big Brother” in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic and finished the season up 32 percent over the viewership totals from Season 1. It also cracked the top 10 in the weekly cable chart at No. 6. Overall, History dominated the top of the chart with “Pawn Stars” (at No. 1 and No. 3, with just under 6.7 million and 6.4 million viewers, respectively) and “American Pickers” (at No. 5 with 5.6 million viewers).

As I pushed my way to the front of the thick crowd in the basement of Santos Party House, I encountered no less than a dozen shirtless dudes throwing themselves around, whirling sweat and crowd surfing. The Pablo Picasso were playing what could be described as the soundtrack to the March of the Alpha Male, and I expected them to look the part. On the contrary, the band of five boys is refreshingly nerdy in appearance. The endearingly scrawny lead singer could easily be mistaken an I.T. tech who broke free of his keyboard and grabbed a microphone, were it not for his surprisingly deep baritone wailing over heavy, rolling drums. The curator and photographer Tim Barber, who hosted the party, looked pleased with the chaotic state of affairs in the mosh pit, as he ambled about, pressing extra rolls of film into my hand to be sure the moment was documented.

LONDON – I heard the city singing as I walked along the South Bank on Monday night. O.K., what I really heard was just people talking – and occasionally yelling, barking or squealing. As usual. But because I had just left a show in which the line between song and speech had been thoroughly dissolved, my ears were suddenly tuned into previously unheard melodies lurking in human conversation. I felt kind of like Gene Kelly being an American in Paris, but in a grimmer, more reflective mood.

Long before Bono and the Edge were best known as the composers of the Broadway musical “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” they and their U2 band mates Adam Clayton and Larry Mullen Jr. were more immediately associated with best-selling rock albums like “Achtung Baby.” It is this more felicitous time in the band’s history that is revisited in Davis Guggenheim’s documentary “From the Sky Down,” which will open the 2011 Toronto International Film Festival, the festival’s organizers said on Tuesday. The new film from Mr. Guggenheim, the director of “An Inconvenient Truth” and “Waiting for Superman,” will chronicle the creation and legacy of “Achtung Baby,” the 1991 U2 album that included hits like “One” and “Mysterious Ways,” using archival footage and new interviews. It will make its debut at a gala presentation on Sept. 8.

Last night’s prime-time back-and-forth between President Obama and John Boehner was interesting political theater, and a useful digest of the arguments (“shared sacrifice” versus “no new taxes”) that we’re going to hear a lot over the next year or so — both in the presidential election and, if we only get a short-term increase in the debt ceiling, in the run-up to the next round of deficit brinksmanship. But it felt irrelevant to the endgame that’s currently taking shape in Congress. The president will almost certainly sign any bill that can pass both houses of Congress, and we’re down to three scenarios for how that happens. Assuming that Boehner can muster enough Republican votes to pass the plan he announced yesterday — which would cut a trillion dollars in discretionary spending, raise the debt ceiling for six months, and then empower yet another bipartisan commission try to negotiate a longer-term deal — and assuming that Harry Reid can find the votes to push his plan, with similar spending cuts but a longer debt-ceiling extension, through the Democratic-controlled Senate, then some compromise between the Boehner plan and the Reid plan seems like a natural solution to the impasse. (Ezra Klein has one plausible example of what such a compromise might look like.) However, enough Republicans regard Boehner’s plan as a sellout to begin with that the speaker of the House might not be able to make that compromise, in which case it becomes a question of who cracks first: Enough moderate Senate Democrats to push the Boehner plan through that body, or enough moderate House Republicans to push a version of the Reid plan through the House. (Note that Nancy Pelosi has endorsed Reid’s plan, suggesting that most House Democrats would vote for it if necessary.)

The penny is a neglected coin. Frequently orphaned on the street. Mercilessly taunted for its mediocrity. In an age of trillion-dollar debt and billion-dollar bank bailouts, America’s lowest common denomination seems to bear little value as an individual monetary unit. Yet the copper-toned coin bearing Lincoln’s profile still holds a unique place in our national identity. Phrases like Benjamin Franklin’s “A penny saved is a penny earned” and the actual artifact itself (shown above is a photographic penny spectrum by the designer Bob Dinetz,) are as American is it gets. The same cannot be said of the origins of its designer.

If you have a pitcher who is a candidate to be traded — James Shields, Jeff Niemann, Erik Bedard, Hiroki Kuroda or Wandy Rodriguez, for example — things are more likely to get worse than they are to get better. That’s because most of the prospective buyers are teams in hitters’ parks. None of the teams with the most extreme pitchers’ parks — the Mariners, the Rays, the Athletics, the Padres, the Mets, the Dodgers or the Marlins — are buying right now, and that means your pitcher is likely to wind up in Yankee Stadium, Arlington, the Great American Ballpark, Miller Field, U.S. Cellular Field or some other place where baseballs tend to fly into the seats. The presumably better run support will help, as will not having to face that team’s offense anymore, but if you’re a Shields owner, you would probably rather the deadline come and go uneventfully.

WOODBRIDGE, Va. -- Hispanic families accounted for the largest single decline in wealth of any ethnic and racial group in the country during the recession, according to a study published Tuesday by the Pew Foundation. The study, which used data collected by the Census Bureau, found that the median wealth of Hispanic households fell by 66 percent from 2005 to 2009. By contrast, the median wealth of whites fell by just 16 percent over the same period. African Americans saw their wealth drop by 53 percent. Asians also saw a big decline, with household wealth dropping 54 percent.

The Sea Shepherd Conservation Society, the environmental group featured on the Animal Planet series ''Whale Wars,'' may be down one ship in its fleet at present, but that hasn't discouraged that cable network from ordering a second series about the group and its efforts to halt whale hunts around the world. On Monday, Animal Planet announced that it had started filming on a program tentatively titled ''The Faroe Islands Project,'' which it said will chronicle Sea Shepherd's campaign to stop an annual whale hunt known as ''The Grind'' in the Faroes, an island group and Danish protectorate between the Norwegian Sea and the Atlantic Ocean. Animal Planet said in a news release that the new series will feature many of the Sea Shepherd crew members from ''Whale Wars,'' including Capt. Paul Watson, Peter Hammarstedt, Chris Aultman and Chad Halstead, as well as their ships the Steve Irwin and the Brigitte Bardot. The Steve Irwin, the group's 194-foot flagship vessel, was recently impounded by a Scottish court following a claim filed by a Maltese company, which seeks damages from a 2010 incident in which Sea Shepherd released bluefin tuna from the company's nets near Libya. A statement from Animal Planet described the ship's seizure as ''an unforeseen hurdle,'' and Sea Shepherd says it must post a bond of about $1.4 million or it will lose the ship.

WOHLMAN--Vivian, (90), on July 23, 2011. She is survived by her daughter Leslie Wohlman Himmel and son-in-law Alan Shuch, her son, Gary Wohlman, and her loving grandchildren Andrea and David Himmel. Services will be held at 11:30am on Wednesday, July 27 at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please make donations in memory of Vivian Wohlman to the Mount Sinai Department of Dermatology, The Development Office, One Gustave L. Levy Place, Box 1049, New York, NY 10029.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. -- The whinny of the paper shredder into which a fate-changing letter is dispatched inspires startled laughter in the Williamstown Theater Festival's production of ''A Doll's House,'' starring Lily Rabe as the theater's most famous door slammer, Nora Helmer. This is possibly not a good sign, and yet the reaction isn't hard to explain. Even as the climactic moments of this revival of Henrik Ibsen's epoch-making play approach, it can be difficult to remember that we are meant to be in contemporary America, not 19th-century Norway, and that Ms. Rabe's soon-to-be-liberated Nora could be charting her journey toward self-realization with the assistance of an iPhone.

Which ''Glee'' stars will still be with the cast of that hit Fox musical comedy at this time next year? The answer seems to depend on whom you ask and when you ask it. In the most recent response to that question, Brad Falchuk, a creator and executive producer of ''Glee,'' said on Sunday that the lead actors Lea Michele, Chris Colfer and Cory Monteith will remain with the series in Season 4, days after remarks by Ryan Murphy, a fellow creator and executive producer, were interpreted to mean that those actors were departing after Season 3. The alarm bells - or, at least, the graduation chimes - were sounded earlier this month when Mr. Murphy gave an interview to The Hollywood Reporter in which he said that the characters played by Ms. Michele, Mr. Colfer and Mr. Monteith would leave their fictional high school after the coming season of ''Glee.''

An article in the Square Feet pages on Wednesday about nontraded real estate investment trusts referred incorrectly to the value of one, American Realty Capital Trust. The trust recently reported that its net tangible book value -- not its current value -- is $6.62. (The current value is not known; shares initially sold at $10.)

An Op-Ed article on Monday comparing the Murdoch scandal and Shakespearean tragedies incorrectly described Claudius's wife in ''Hamlet.'' Claudius has married his brother's widow -- not his brother's sister.

TAYLOR--William C.,M.D. The Department of Medicine of the NYU Langone Medical Center is saddened by the passing of our longtime colleague, Dr. William C. Taylor, in his 81st year of life. A School of Medicine graduate, house officer, Senior Chief Resident, and member of the faculty since 1963, Dr. Taylor served with distinction until his retirement in 2010. Dr. Taylor was a beloved physician and teacher. We extend our deep condolences to his entire family.Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair, Department of Medicine NYU Langone Medical Center

FIERMAN--Russ. To our dearest friend Ady. Our hearts go out to you, Adam, Arielle, Lucy, Robert and the rest of your family during this tragic time of profound sorrow. Nancy Olnick, Giorgio Spanu, Eve, Robert, Stella & Sylvia Olnick

HAAS--Saul, 84, of Manhattan, died peacefully on June 21 after a brief stay at Berkshire Medical Center in Massachusetts. A soldier in the U.S. Army in WWII, he helped free Auschwitz and transported high-ranking German officers to Nuremberg. After several ventures including a very brief baseball career, he went on to receive a business degree from NYU. He subsequently worked in the textile home furnishings industry until his death. He loved tennis, golf, travel, and preparing gourmet meals. He is survived by his wife of fifty years, Mary, his sons Christopher and Matthew, and numerous extended family and friends. A memorial service will be held in September in New York City. Donations may be made to God's Love We Deliver, to which Saul so enjoyed donating his time during life.

An article on July 2 about problems confronting an international flotilla that planned to defy Israel's naval embargo on Gaza, more than a year after Israeli commandos stopped another Gaza-bound flotilla on May 30, 2010, and killed nine activists on the lead ship, misstated the nationalities of the dead in that confrontation. They included eight Turkish citizens and one American citizen of Turkish descent. They were not all Turkish citizens. (Turkish officials had announced at the time of the incident that one had dual citizenship. After a reader raised the issue with The Times, the Turkish Foreign Ministry gave the paper the corrected information.) The error also appeared in articles on Jan. 25 and on April 2, and in numerous articles in 2010, including six articles last June and six more last July.

Updated, 3:54 p.m. | When Brooklyn's borough president, Marty Markowitz, took trips to Turkey and the Netherlands on official city business several years ago, he also accepted free travel expenses for his wife, Jamie Markowitz. The city's Conflicts of Interest Board deemed it an ethical violation and fined him $20,000, according to the findings released on Monday. (See below.)

''Too big to fail'' is something to be feared and loathed in Washington - except on the softball field. The phrase, which typically refers to big banks whose collapse would endanger the financial system, doubles as the team name for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's softball team. The banking regulators have posted a meager two wins this season, putting them near the bottom of the Congressional Softball League.

When the city officially recognized Douglaston Hill in Queens as a historic district in 2004, the community celebrated. Three years later, residents of Dumbo, Brooklyn, breathed a sigh of relief when their neighborhood, too, finally won its historic designation. With landmarking, the neighborhoods' buildings would be protected by the city and all changes to the area would need the city's approval. But it would be hard for a passer-by to know. Years afterward, the distinctive brown ''historic district'' street signs that are supposed to be part of the package -- the clearest evidence that the city had given thoughtful consideration to the district's historic significance -- have still not been installed.

AHERN--Margaret Rose "Peggy", 80. Prominent New York City educator Margaret Rose "Peggy" Ahern of Ridge, New York, died peacefully in her sleep July 23 of natural causes. Born in Jamaica, Queens, Peggy received her Masters in Education from St. John's University. She was a lifelong educator, who began her career as a teacher at the School for the Deaf in New York City. She taught for many years in the New York Public School system before becoming a principal in Rockaway, Queens. Peggy moved to Jamestown, Rhode Island in the late 1970s, where she continued her work as an educator teaching ESL at the Naval War College in Newport. For several years, Peggy spent the school year on Cuttyhunk Island teaching in a one-room schoolhouse, flying home to Jamestown for many weekends and the summers. Always at her side were her two beloved Irish Setters, Rhody and York. While in Jamestown Peggy pursued many passions including painting, golf and bridge. She was a member of the Jamestown Historical Society, a Docent at The Breakers in Newport and volunteered for 15 years with In-Sight, reading magazines, brochures and books onto audiotapes for the blind and visually impaired. The youngest of six, Peggy is survived by her sisters Eileen A. Sullivan of Albany, New York, and Mary Phelan of Melville, New York; her brother-in-law Frank Phelan; and the many, many children who loved her, including her 16 nieces and nephews. Peggy was predeceased by her brother Cornelius Ahern and sisters Veronica DeGloria and Ann Farrell. Peggy was passionate about the arts, attending theater both on and off Broadway. While her family most fondly recalls frequent trips with her to the Bronx Zoo, she most loved introducing them to culture, which included field trips to her most beloved museums: The Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Museum of Natural History and The Whitney. She was an avid golfer, bridge player and traveler, as equally comfortable on the Green Course at Bethpage State Park as she was in the streets of Haifa. A avid environmentalist who began recycling gift cards, wrapping paper and plastic bags in the 1960s, Peggy loved the ocean. She was never without her 'summer bag', which was always chock full with just-in-case extras and was never without a dog-eared deck of Royal Playing Cards. Visiting hours be held at Vernon Wagner Funeral Home, 655 Old Country Road, Plainview, NY, Wednesday July 27 from 4:00-8:00pm. A Funeral Mass will be held Thursday, July 28 10:00am at St Pius X Church, 1 Saint Pius Court, Plainview, NY. Internment will be at St. John's Cemetery, Queens. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: INSIGHT, 43 Jefferson Blvd, Warwick, RI 02888.

THE FACTS In the midst of a nasty heat wave, air-conditioning can make life so much easier to bear. But some people believe that sudden drops in temperature can play havoc with the immune system. Others say air-conditioners act as germ-spewing machines, cultivating bacteria and viruses like petri dishes and then blasting and recirculating them in enclosed spaces.
An article on Monday about Web sites that offer short-term room rentals misstated the number of rental listings offered by one site, Airbnb. It is more than 100,000, not just 15,000.

Alex Ferguson, Manchester United's famously prickly Scottish manager, has probably answered more questions from reporters in the two weeks of the club's current United States tour than he entertains, and deigns to respond to, during a typical English Premier League season. During a news conference in Manhattan on Monday, two days before his Red Devils face a team of All-Stars from Major League Soccer at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., Ferguson was positively garrulous compared with some of his legendary snits. They are known as hair-dryer treatments, in which he gets in the face of an unfortunate and pins his hair back, as if the recipient had just been to the salon.

STANFORD--Anne Agee, 81, of Bronxville, died on 23 July 2011 at Kendal-on-Hudson, Sleepy Hollow, New York, after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Robert. Loving mother of Elizabeth and Chris Agee. Cherished grandmother of Jacob, Miriam, Indigo, and Orion Agee. Anne was born on March 28, 1930 in West Hollywood, Los Angeles, California to Ralph and Ruth Inman Stanford. A resident of Bronxville for over 40 years, she worked as a legal secretary in New York City and Director of Meals on Wheels at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. An article last Tuesday about the death of Ketzel, the cat who wrote a piano composition, misspelled the surname of a founder of the Paris New Music Review and misstated his role in its One Minute Competition, which gave Ketzel's piece a special mention. It was Guy Livingston, not Livingstone, who co-founded and edited the review. But while he oversaw the contest, he was not one of the judges. The errors also appeared on Nov. 10, 1997, in a brief article about Ketzel.

SAN FRANCISCO -- The F.B.I.'s arrests of 14 people last week were the most ambitious crackdown yet on a loose-knit group of hackers called Anonymous that has attacked a string of government agencies and private companies over the last eight months. But at least some of the suspects are not your typical hard-core hackers, judging from interviews with two of them and the online traces of others. Some did not bother to cover their digital tracks as they participated in what they saw as an online protest. And some say they were unaware that their feverish clicks on a home computer may have been against the law.

LIEMER--Martin, MD. Born in Brooklyn, NY March 12, 1931, died in Lee, MA July 24, 2011. Honored husband of Jeanette. Father of David (Toni), Ben, Susan (Jeff), Jane. Grandfather of Ross, Josh, Colby, Jeremiah, Quinlan, Zachary, Jonathan. Brother of Charlotte Gandler. The Liemer Family

Alexander Dale Oen of Norway won the 100-meter breaststroke by almost three-quarters of a second at the world championships in Shanghai. Then he made a gesture that had nothing to do with swimming. He pointed to the Norwegian flag on his cap, rose from the water and flexed his biceps in a show of strength to those back home in Norway, where 76 people were killed in a bombing and shootings on Friday. ''I guess I was racing a little bit more with my heart today than I was technically,'' Dale Oen said. Last week, Cesar Cielo of Brazil was cleared of a doping charge by the Court of Arbitration for Sport after an emergency hearing in China. Then he won the 50-meter butterfly on the second night of the eight-day meet. After defeating the Australian Matthew Targett, Cielo, left, leaned on a lane rope, looked at the scoreboard and began to cry. ''It feels like the biggest relief of my life to overcome something like that and be able to compete,'' he said.

(13, 49) HISTORY DETECTIVES A man in Kittery Point, Me., discovers an unusual wooden telescope in his great-aunt's house that may have been used during the American Revolution. A California man hopes the detectives can tell him about his family's past by examining a cane carved with Japanese characters he can't read. The item belonged to his grandparents, who were sent to a relocation camp after the attack on Pearl Harbor. And a man in Colorado thinks a strange drawing may be a piece of gold-rush history.

A deal was better than a disaster. But last week's plan to rescue Greece has the astonishing byproduct of increasing the country's debts. It also lets private creditors off lightly while making taxpayers elsewhere in the euro zone pay through the nose. It doesn't even mean the end of the crisis. True, the sustainability of Greek debt has been improved. Greece's government will receive 109 billion euros of new 15- to 30-year loans from the euro zone at an interest rate of 3.5 percent. Private sector creditors will swap or roll over 135 billion euros of existing bonds into new, longer-term instruments.

TAYLOR--William C.,MD, died on July 23rd at the age of 80. A graduate of the Western Reserve Academy, Princeton University and the NYU School of Medicine, Dr. Taylor practiced Internal Medicine for over 50 years and was a Professor of Clinical Medicine at NYU. He served as a flight surgeon in the US Navy and as an usher at St. Thomas Church Fifth Avenue for many years. He is survived by his longtime partner/spouse; Aalan Kobritz, one brother; John Huntington Taylor of Westfield, NJ, a sister-in-law; Eliza Kennedy Taylor, also of Westfield, four nieces; (Kate, Creighton, Lee and Anne); one nephew (John, Jr.) and several great nieces and nephews. A man of great integrity, intelligence, kindness and humor, he will be remembered and loved by everyone whose life he touched. Funeral Service will be held at St. Thomas on Wednesday, July 27th, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, a donation in his memory may be made to the St. Thomas Choir School or the NYU Langone Medical Center.

The news that the presidential candidate Michele Bachmann suffers from severe migraines has touched off a national discussion about a surprisingly common disorder that is little understood and often undertreated. Migraine patients are coming forward with their stories. And while each one is different, they have two common threads: suffering and trying to cope.

FITZPATRICK--Joseph M.,one of the founding partners of the New York City law firm of Fitzpatrick, Cella, Harper & Scinto, died on Friday, July 22. He was 86. Following his graduation from Georgetown Law School in 1951, Joe Fitzpatrick began his career with the Patent Section of the Anti-Trust Division of the United States Justice Department. After several years in private practice at another firm, in 1971, he helped found Fitzpatrick, Cella, Harper & Scinto, which now numbers over 175 lawyers with offices in New York, Washington, DC, and California. The Fitzpatrick law firm is one of the leading intellectual property law firms in the country. For more than 40 years, Mr. Fitzpatrick served as lead counsel on behalf of major multinational and US corporations in intellectual property proceedings and trials, representing some of the world's technology leaders such as Canon Inc., Merck & Co., Bristol Meyers. E. I. Du Pont, Union carbide and countless others. He was selected as a top business litigator and intellectual property law practitioner in the 2005-2010 editions of Best Lawyers in America and the in the 2006-2011 issues of Who's Who: Legal Patent. He was elected as a Fellow the American College of Trial Lawyers. In 2009, Joe Fitzpatrick celebrated his twenty fifth anniversary as a member of Daytop Family Association. Joe served Daytop in many capacities, including Chairman of Daytop Village, Inc. from 2003-2005 and Chairman of Daytop International from, 2005-2008. With 26 sites across the country, Daytop is one of the largest and oldest drug free, self help programs in the United States. Joseph Mark Fitzpatrick was born on May 27, 1925 in Jersey City, New Jersey, the only son of Joseph Francis and Meave Wilson Fitzpatrick. His father, also an attorney, served as Secretary of the State of New Jersey from 1926-1931, and was active in the Democratic party in both Jersey City and New Jersey for most of his professional life. Joe Fitzpatrick graduated from St. Peter's Prep in Jersey City and Stevens Institute of Technology in 1945, He also served in the United States Navy, where he achieved the rank of Lieutenant JG. Joe married Elizabeth Keane on June 18, 1949. Together, they raised a family of four children in Scarsdale, NY. Joe is survived by his wife and children: Nancy of Bronxville, NY, Susan of Buffalo, NY, Christopher of Pittsfied, VT and Stephen of Sleepy Hollow, NY. He is also survived by 12 grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren. The funeral will be at Immaculate Heart of Mary in Scarsdale, NY on Tuesday, July 26, 2011 at 10:00am. Donations may be made in Mr. Fitzpatrick's memory to Daytop Village, 54 West 40 St., New York, NY 10018.

Medical examiners in London were unable Monday to pinpoint what killed Amy Winehouse, the 27-year-old pop singer found dead in her home Saturday, and it will take at least two weeks before toxicology tests are completed, the Metropolitan Police said, according to the Associated Press. Sales of Ms. Winehouse's records increased in the hours after her death and continued to grow over the weekend as news of her promising career being cut short spread. Her distraught parents met with mourners outside her home in north London, where a makeshift memorial has begun to grow, a mountain of flowers, candles, drawings and handwritten cards.

An article on Wednesday about the Syrian government's violent repression of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad misstated the number of people that human rights advocates estimated had been killed in Syria since the uprising started in mid-March. The estimate up to that point was 1,400, not 14,000. (Latest reports put the number at 1,600.)

Three years later, residents of Dumbo, Brooklyn, breathed a sigh of relief when their neighborhood, too, finally won its historic designation. LOOKING TO SELL Israel Englander, below, is in talks to sell a minority stake in his hedge fund, Millennium Management, a move that comes in a year of strong performance and tremendous asset growth at the 22-year-old firm, according to a person with knowledge of the conversations. The talks with Foundation Capital Partners, an upstart private equity shop with $1.5 billion in assets, are continuing and not certain to result in a deal, this person said, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The stake would be for less than 20 percent of the hedge fund. AZAM AHMED

John C. Kenefick, a former chief executive of the Union Pacific Railroad who steered the company through an era of industry consolidation and deregulation, died on July 15 at his home in Omaha. He was 89. His death was confirmed by Bob Turner, the railroad's senior vice president of corporate relations.
PATSNER--Neva. We've all missed you terribly these past two years. Please forgive me - I always did the best I could. Your husband Bruce

KARZ, Afghanistan -- The marble grave of the Afghan president's half brother, assassinated two weeks ago by one of his own men, lies in this scruffy village that is near Kandahar and bears the family name. The white stone has a quiet to it that stands in stark contrast to the din he left behind. Ahmed Wali Karzai's killing put the region's spoils up for grabs, and the tribal elite of Kandahar are watching, waiting, and above all, calculating their next move. They all want a piece of the future, and among them are strong men with guns.

THOMASES--Florence Josephson, mother of four, mentor of many, died July 24, 2011 at the age of 97. The loving wife of the late Fred Thomases, devoted mother to Robert, Matthew, Jeffrey and Susan and caring mother-in-law to their respective partners, Jo, Jean, Mary Kay, and Bill (who left us too early), she dedicated her life to family, friends and philanthropy. She graduated from Hunter College in 1934 and served for a many years as a director of the Scholarship and Welfare Fund of the Alumni Association. Mrs. Thomases was a founding member of the Ramapo College Board of Trustees and served several years as Board President. She supported countless students and faculty through endowed scholarships and grants for research and teaching excellence. Along with her late husband, she founded The Florence and Fred Thomases Foundation which supports many agencies and projects (both domestic and off-shore) that concern themselves with hunger, education, health, and economic development. Mrs. Thomases was an energizing figure in dozens of Jewish and civic organizations. She was a strong supporter of the State of Israel and, in particular, the Jerusalem Foundation and the Israel Cancer Research Fund. A lifelong Democrat and political activist, Mrs. Thomases campaigned over the years to help elect scores of progressive candidates. At the age of 94, she was a passionate supporter of Hillary Clinton in the 2008 primaries and then volunteered for Barack Obama in the general election. She grew up in the Bronx, raised her family in Englewood, New Jersey, and then relocated to Manhattan to spend the last seven years of her life to be near what she loved doing most -- enjoying the cultural life of the city. Over the years, Mrs. Thomases sponsored many struggling artists. And, despite her failing health, she found time this past June to fund one last project -- a documentary film about the hard-working women in the cattle industry of rural Arizona. The beloved grandmother of Holly, Andrew, Ken, Caroline, Josh, Ben, David, Danny, Greg, Lili, Phoebe, Shannon, Tom, and Justine, Mrs. Thomases also took great pride in being the great-grandmother of 12. Services will be held at 10am, Tuesday, July 26 at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave (at 91st St.) New York City. The family will be receiving visitors following interment, Tuesday evening and Wednesday after 2pm at Mrs.Thomases' residence. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: Hunter College Scholarship and Welfare Fund, The Jerusalem Foundation, The Israel Cancer Research Fund.

WASHINGTON -- Leaders of both parties have said for months that the need to raise the nation's borrowing limit offered a ''unique opportunity'' for a bipartisan deal that would constrain the mounting federal debt. Instead, it is shaping up to be a lost opportunity.

In the 1980s it was discovered that some bottlenose dolphins in Shark Bay, Australia rip up marine basket sponges from the seafloor and place them on their noses for protection as they forage for food along rocky substrate. It is the only known instance of tool use by dolphins in the wild. Now Janet Mann and Eric Patterson, biologists at Georgetown University, report that the dolphins do this because it allows them to uncover prey undiscoverable by echolocation.

NATHAN--Elizabeth V. (nee Angelier), born in Cumberland, MD., August 15, 1915, passed away July 16 in Washington, D.C. Beloved, devoted mother of Gay Theodora Nathan of Santa Fe, NM, and Joy Elizabeth Stern and son-in-law Carl Stern of Washington, DC; adored MomMom of grandsons Lawrence Hughes Stern and Theodore Nathan Stern, grand daughter-in-law Cristine Romano and great-grandson Teddy Carl Stern; precious Auntie Libby to nieces and nephews; cherished cousin; treasured sister of the late Helen, Iris, Roland and James; dearest Betty to countless loving friends. Arriving in Manhattan at age 12 she became the quintessential sophisticated New Yorker residing more than 70 years at the Parc Vendome on W. 57 St. With upswept red hair and flawless, fair complexion, distinctive style and flair she was an exquisite presence in the era of the city's most glamorous night spots and the prettiest Mommy. She met her darling late husband of almost 60 years Theodore Reade Nathan while at George Washington High School. She worked with him in his theatrical endeavors, was vice-president and art director of the advertising firm bearing his name and helped edit his several books and numerous publications. In her 80's she was cast in several commercials. Her favorite pastime was traveling and vacationing with her family, especially to Venice, Italy. Recent volunteer work included the NYC Opera and over 10 wonderful years at Channel 13. Sweet and lovely, her inspiring, magical life, spirited essence, extraordinary beauty and charm, gracious hospitality, creative artistry, impeccable taste, wisdom and warmth will live forever in the hearts of all who knew her.

FISHER--Karen, on July 23, 2011, in New York, NY. She is survived by her brother, Bart Fisher; her sister-in-law, Margaret Fisher; and her nephew, Ross Fisher. Karen was Founder and President of Designer Previews, a member of the Interior Design Hall of Fame, and taught design classes at New York University and Parsons School of Interior Design. A memorial service will be held at noon on Tuesday, July 26, at the Brotherhood Synagogue, 28 Gramercy Park South, New York, NY. Memorial contributions may be made in Karen's name to the Aplastic Anemia & MDS International Foundation, 100 Park Avenue, Suite 108, Rockville, Maryland 20850. Democratic leaders in the House have called for an immediate ethics investigation into allegations that Representative David Wu, a Democrat from Oregon, engaged in unwanted sexual activity with a teenage daughter of a donor. The allegations arose in an article in The Oregonian, which reported that a distraught young woman had left a voice mail message at Mr. Wu's Portland office accusing him of what the newspaper described as ''aggressive and unwanted sexual behavior.''

To study evolution, Jason Munshi-South has tracked elephants in central Africa and proboscis monkeys in the wilds of Borneo. But for his most recent expedition, he took the A train. Dr. Munshi-South and two graduate students, Paolo Cocco and Stephen Harris, climbed out of the 168th Street station lugging backpacks and a plastic crate full of scales, Ziploc bags, clipboards, rulers and tarps. They walked east to the entrance of Highbridge Park, where they met Ellen Pehek, a senior ecologist in the New York City Parks and Recreation Department. The four researchers entered the park, made their way past a basketball game and turned off the paved path into a ravine.
The largest dam removal project in American history will take away barriers that have contained the Elwha River in Washington State for nearly a century.
Adam Serwer, left, of The American Prospect and Katherine Mangu-Ward of Reason debate Obama's negotiating skills during the debt ceiling showdown.

We are so accustomed to seeing terrorism through the lens of 9/11 that it may be hard to recapture how shocking it was to realize, 16 years ago in Oklahoma City, that devastating terrorism can be completely homegrown. The mass murder committed in Norway last Friday by a Norwegian anti-immigrant extremist brings Oklahoma City forcefully to mind for the first time in a long while. The bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building on April 19, 1995, by two disaffected Americans killed 168 people. At the time, it was the worst single incident of terrorism ever committed on American soil. Today’s young adults, not yet then even in their teens, may barely remember it.

Earlier this week our colleague Joe Sharkey reported on a lapse in federal airfare taxes. Congress failed last week to authorize airlines to continue to collect taxes on domestic and international flights. In theory, that would mean lower fares. But most airlines decided instead to raise their ticket prices by about the amount of the taxes.

The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit has taken a chainsaw to the Securities and Exchange Commission’s proxy access rule, striking it down in a 21-page opinion. A panel of three judges from the appeals court based its ruling last week on what it perceived to be the S.E.C.’s failure to fully consider the costs and the benefits of this rule. With the S.E.C. wounded and proxy access seemingly on life support, if not dead, the question is what comes next?

For decades, young doctors and nurses have been fleeing poor countries for the bright lights and fat paychecks of wealthier nations, abandoning the parts of the world with the highest burden of disease and most desperate need for medical help. Sixty percent of medical doctors who trained in Ghana in the 1980s have since left the country, and there are more Ethiopian doctors in Washington DC than in all of Ethiopia. Sub-Saharan Africa today houses more than a tenth of the world’s population, and shoulders a quarter of the global burden of disease, but it has just three percent of the world’s health care workers.

New York design aficionados who are looking to beat the heat will find nothing but cool this summer at Ralph Pucci International, where a series of exhibitions, all on view through the end of the year, illustrates the very different approaches of their subjects. “Revival,” by the French designer Jerome Abel Seguin, contains nine sculptural pieces made of slices of enormous mahogany trees that were felled in central Java early in the 20th century. Our colleagues at Economix report that many of those grasping for a sign of economic optimism these days have pointed to the auto industry. The argument is that as supply chains come back on line after the Japanese earthquake and tsunami, more automobiles will be available for sale to consumers who have been waiting for cars to arrive. But don’t expect a roaring comeback yet. A report released on Wednesday by AlixPartners, a business consulting firm, projects modest sales growth for the foreseeable future. The report forecasts that United States auto sales will reach 12.7 million units this year, up from the 11.5 million of 2010, but still far below the 16-million-plus that the industry regularly posted in the mid-2000s. John Boehner’s debt ceiling proposal, which the House will presumably vote on (and pass, I suspect) tomorrow, would raise the debt ceiling sufficiently to allow the government to function through February of 2012. In the mean time, it would empower a bipartisan commission to come up with $1.6-1.8 trillion in further savings by November of 2011, which would then be voted on in both houses of Congress under up-or-down, no filibusters allowed rules. If the bipartisan commission’s recommendations are passed, the president would be authorized to request a further debt ceiling increase that would carry the country through the rest of his first term.

For those of us hoping to keep our brains fit and healthy well into middle age and beyond, the latest science offers some reassurance. Activity appears to be critical, though scientists have yet to prove that exercise can ward off serious problems like Alzheimer’s disease. But what about the more mundane, creeping memory loss that begins about the time our 30s recede, when car keys and people’s names evaporate? It’s not Alzheimer’s, but it’s worrying. Can activity ameliorate its slow advance — and maintain vocabulary retrieval skills, so that the word “ameliorate” leaps to mind when needed?

WALLACH--Stanley, Dr. The Paget Foundation announces the death of Dr. Stanley Wallach (82). Dr. Wallach was a founder of The Paget Foundation, the first Chairman of the Foundation's Advisory Medical Panel from 1977-1984, a member of the Foundation Board of Directors from 1990 to his death including serving as Board President for many years. Dr. Wallach was Chief, Medical Service, Veterans Administration Medical Center, Albany, NY from 1973-1983 and Chief, Medical Service, Veterans Administration, Bay Pines, FL, from 1983-1990. He was Professor of Internal Medicine, University of South Florida, from 1988-1992. His military service included active duty in the U.S. Naval Reserve, Medical Corps from 1958-1960 and Captain in the U.S. Naval Reserve for thirty one years. Dr. Wallach served as Director, Endocrinology and Metabolic Bone Disease Center, Hospital for Joint Diseases, New York, NY from 1993-2001. He also served as Chief Executive of the American College of Nutrition from October 1993 to October 2003. He served as President of the American College of Nutrition from 1987-1989 and received its Mastership Award in 1999. Dr. Wallach is survived by Pearl his beloved wife of thirty eight years and his loving family. Dr. Wallach will be cremated. Interment will be at the Bay Pines Veterans Cemetery in St. Petersburg, Florida at 2:15pm Thursday July 28th. A service will take place Friday July 29 at 2:00pm at Temple Beth-El, 400 Pasadena Ave S. St. Petersburg, Florida. The Paget Foundation

GOLDIN--Aaron. After a long hospitalization, Aaron passed away July 23rd. He was but 68 and died before he could complete his mission in life. An unusually complicated and unique personality. He was the "accountant's accountant" and brooked no interference in his representation of his clients. He was a partner in the firm of Kurz & Kurz of Jericho, NY and New York, NY for as long we can remember. He first was our accountant while we were part of the New York Real Estate firm of Charles H. Greenthal & CO from 60s to the 90s. The essence of the man can not fit into this column. He had strong opinions about everything. He was the best manager the New York Mets never had. He patronized, every week, what he claimed was the best seafood restaurant on Long Island, "The Jolly Fisherman". He loved his three kids David, Stacy and Jeffrey and David's wife Rory and the adored, Skyler; Stacy's husband Andrew and the newborn, Sydney. Boy, did they all make him proud. Then there was the love of his life, his wife Susan whose premature death left him married to work. Any who crossed his path will have no trouble in recognizing the passing of an almost indescribable person and friend. There is alot that will be missed but it is a small thing that we embrace. Aaron called every day and left the same message, every day, "Call Aaron". Would that we could. Joyce and Bernard West Stacy and Peter Clark Jane West William West

John Lithgow will return to Broadway next spring to star in ''The Columnist,'' playing the famous midcentury newspaperman Joseph Alsop in a new drama by David Auburn, who won both the Pulitzer Prize for drama and the Tony Award for best play in 2001 for ''Proof.'' Mr. Lithgow, a two-time Tony winner for ''Sweet Smell of Success'' (in which he also played a columnist) and ''The Changing Room'' (his Broadway debut in 1973), was last on Broadway in the 2008-9 season in the revival of ''All My Sons.'' He has also won five Emmy Awards for various television roles, most notably for his starring role on ''Third Rock From the Sun.'' Alsop was an influential columnist on politics and foreign affairs from the 1940s through the 1970s; his reputation was muddied in the 1960s, however, because of his support for the Vietnam War and ongoing whispers that he was a closeted homosexual who had been caught on camera by the K.G.B. while having sex with another man. Mr. Auburn's play is a work of fiction but nevertheless deals with this history as Mr. Lithgow's character navigates political turmoil, social change and personal troubles in the early 1960s. The play will be directed by Daniel Sullivan, who won a Tony for staging ''Proof,'' and produced by Manhattan Theater Club, where that earlier Auburn work also ran. ''The Columnist'' is scheduled to begin previews at the Samuel J. Friedman Theater on April 3, 2012, and open on April 25.

Gwirtzman, a Washington insider who advised John, Robert and Edward Kennedy and wrote speeches for them while helping the family navigate difficult political seas and emotional traumas over the years, died Saturday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 78. The cause was a metastatic melanoma, said his wife, Katherine Krents.

An eclectic group of 13 writers was chosen on Tuesday for the longlist of this year's Man Booker Prize, considered the most prestigious award for fiction in the English-speaking world. Stella Rimington, the chairwoman of the judges, said in a statement: ''We are delighted by the quality and breadth of our longlist, which emerged from an impassioned discussion. The list ranges from the Wild West to multiethnic London via post-cold war Moscow and Bucharest, and includes four first novels.'' The prize honors what the judges deem to be the best novel of the year by an author in the former British Commonwealth, Ireland or Zimbabwe. Winnowing the list from 138 titles, the judges selected: ''The Sense of an Ending,'' Julian Barnes (Jonathan Cape); ''On Canaan's Side,'' Sebastian Barry (Faber and Faber); ''Jamrach's Menagerie,'' Carol Birch (Canongate Books); ''The Sisters Brothers,'' Patrick deWitt (Granta); ''Half Blood Blues,'' Esi Edugyan (Serpent's Tail); ''A Cupboard Full of Coats,'' Yvvette Edwards (Oneworld); ''The Stranger's Child,'' Alan Hollinghurst (Picador); ''Pigeon English,'' Stephen Kelman (Bloomsbury); ''The Last Hundred Days,'' Patrick McGuinness (Seren Books); ''Snowdrops,'' A.D. Miller (Atlantic); ''Far to Go,'' Alison Pick (Headline Review); ''The Testament of Jessie Lamb,'' Jane Rogers (Sandstone Press); ''Derby Day,'' D.J. Taylor (Chatto & Windus). A shortlist of six authors will be announced on Sept. 6, and the winner on Oct. 18.

The New York Times Company's About Group, which publishes the advice and informational Web site About.com, has appointed a new chief executive. Darline Jean, formerly About's chief financial officer, will take over the top position on Sept. 1, the company said Tuesday. The appointment was part of a broader management shuffle at the company in which new heads for the sales and finance divisions were also named.About has been struggling with declining revenue and Web traffic since Google changed both the way it directs traffic to informational sites like About.com and the way it allows those sites to collect revenue from ads that users click on. In the second quarter, About's revenues dropped 17.3 percent to $27.8 million.
The Wines of The Times column last Wednesday, about California sauvignon blancs, misspelled the name of the producer of Dry Creek Valley Fig Tree Vineyard sauvignon blanc. It is Quivira, not Quivera.

It was one of those steamy New York summer nights where the humidity hangs in the air, clings to your clothes and licks at your face, when the announcement landed in our e-mail inbox: Mickey Spillane, that no-nonsense writer of pulpy detective mysteries and creator of the quintessential literary gumshoe, Mike Hammer, hadn't told his last tale just yet. The independent publisher Titan Books said it had acquired the worldwide and digital rights to three unpublished Mike Hammer novels from Spillane's archives that would be completed by the mystery writer Max Allan Collins and released between 2012 and 2014. The first is called ''Lady, Go Die!'' and is planned for publication in May 2012. It comes from a substantial fragment of a book that Spillane wrote between ''I, the Jury,'' the 1947 novel that introduced the Mike Hammer character, and its 1950 follow-up, ''My Gun Is Quick.'' A second unreleased novel, ''Complex 90,'' is described as a cold-war thriller and scheduled for release in May 2013; the third unreleased novel, ''King of the Weeds,'' is slated for May 2014.

HARMER--Bernard Bertram Dorkin, died July 22 at age 97. Son of Henry Revell Harmer, founder of the Harmer family stamp business, he became a premier philatelist in his own right. He is survived by his three children, Alison (Jack), Keith (Joan), Christopher (Andrea) and six grand children. A memorial is scheduled for October 14th at The Collectors Club of New York. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The Club at, 22 E 35th St, New York, NY 10016.

11:14 a.m. | Updated Amy Winehouse was mourned by family members and colleagues from the music industry at a private funeral in London on Tuesday, The Associated Press reported. The ceremony for Ms. Winehouse, the retro-soul singer who died on Saturday at age 27, was held at Edgwarebury Cemetery in the north of the city. The service included English and Hebrew prayers, a eulogy given by the singer's father, Mitch, and a rendition of Carole King's ''So Far Away,'' which was one of Ms. Winehouse's favorite songs.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE KIDS ARE ALL RIGHT (2010) Directed by Lisa Cholodenko, this dramatic comedy, above, tells the story of Jules (Julianne Moore) and Nic (Annette Bening), a gay couple whose teenage children were brought into the world with the help of an anonymous sperm donor. Their daughter, Joni (Mia Wasikowska), at the insistence of her brother, Laser (Josh Hutcherson), does some digging and finds the donor, Paul (Mark Ruffalo). After a bit of awkwardness at their initial meeting, Paul is surprisingly eager to be around for the kids and assumes a familial role that is perhaps overstepping his bounds and disrupting the clan. He and one of the mothers also find themselves sharing an attraction. Writing in The New York Times, A. O. Scott called Ms. Cholodenko's film, which she wrote with Stuart Blumberg, ''canny in its insights'' and ''agile in its negotiation of complex emotions,'' adding, ''It is outrageously funny without ever exaggerating for comic effect, and heartbreaking with only minimal melodramatic embellishment.'' 8 P.M. (TCM) SITTING PRETTY (1948) In this comedy directed by Walter Lang, Clifton Webb stars as an arrogant genius and a stern but lovable baby sitter for unruly children. The character comes from a novel by Gwen Davenport and was also the basis for a sitcom in 1985. In ''The Nanny'' (1965), at 11:15, Bette Davis stars as a markedly different sort of caretaker, one who may have killed one of her charges. William Dix plays a boy who spent two years in an institution for mentally ill children after he was blamed for his sister's death. He is convinced that the nanny is to blame, and upon his return he keeps a watchful eye on her.

A map on Monday with the Port Gamble S'Klallam Reservation Journal article, about American Indians in Washington State and British Columbia who travel for weeks by canoe each summer to converge at the home of a host tribe, omitted the routes and the landing and launch sites. An entry in the ''What's On Today'' television highlights in some editions last Wednesday about five films adapted from novels on Turner Classic Movies, including ''Pride and Prejudice,'' referred incorrectly to an element of that novel's plot. Mrs. Bennet wants her daughters to marry wealthy men for financial security, not to produce an heir to save the family estate. (There is already an heir to the estate, a cousin of Mr. Bennet.)

SHARPIE, whose permanent markers were immortalized by NFL receiver Terrell Owens when he pulled a Sharpie out of his sock to sign a football after scoring a touchdown, is turning to more minor celebrities to promote its products. The marker company is officially introducing a revamped Web site on Wednesday as part of its 2011 back-to-school marketing campaign, which also features avid, though lesser-known, Sharpie fans, and urges consumers to ''start something'' with its products. Directed at teenagers, the campaign also includes new print, TV, Internet and cinema advertising, extensive use of social media, and new packaging, markers and colors.

An article on Tuesday about a group of people arrested last week in connection with a hacking attack on PayPal's Web site misstated the surname of one suspect. He is Keith Downey, not Downing. The error was repeated in a picture caption.

BID REJECTED Clorox said on Tuesday that its board had rejected a revised $10.7 billion takeover bid by Carl C. Icahn, saying that the offer remained inadequate. In a letter to Mr. Icahn, Clorox wrote that his offer still undervalued the company and lacked firm details about its financing and closing conditions. Last week, Mr. Icahn raised his bid for Clorox to $80 a share in cash, from $76.50. He also owns a 9.4 percent stake in the company that would be rolled into his offer. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

Ryan Lochte overtook Michael Phelps in the 200-meter freestyle to win one of the most highly awaited races of the world championships in Shanghai on Tuesday. His victory was a reminder that he is a threat to replace Phelps, his American teammate, as the world's top swimmer. Lochte touched in 1 minute, 44.44 seconds. Phelps took second. Lochte beat Phelps in the 200 individual medley and the 200 backstroke at last year's United States championships. TUESDAY'S RESULTS There was another American gold in the women's 100 breaststroke, with Rebecca Soni leading from start to finish in 1:05.05 to successfully defend her title from two years ago. In the men's 100 backstroke, Camille Lacourt and Jeremy Stravius of France finished in a rare dead heat for gold. Also, Lotte Friis of Denmark won the women's 1,500 freestyle, a non-Olympic event, in 15:49.59, with the world-record-holder Kate Ziegler of the United States taking second.

PRISTINTamara Duboisky, 93, of New York City and Westhampton Beach, NY, died peacefully at her Manhattan home on July 26. No country was too remote to be explored nor opera too obscure to be enjoyed. Fluent in several languages and endlessly curious about other cultures, she roamed the globe to satisfy her passion for art, music and theater. Married for 61 years to Seymour Pristin, who died in 2007, she leaves a daughter, Terry, and a son-in-law, Ronald Silverman. Service Thursday, 1pm, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera Office of Development, Lincoln Center, New York, NY 10023.

In the course of the Seattle Mariners' 17-game losing streak, the play of shortstop Brendan Ryan has been one of the few bright spots. Sabathia's perfect game with one out in the seventh inning with a looping single to left-center field, extending his hitting streak to 10 games. He has hit .364 during that stretch.

In ''The Patsy,'' a revival of a forgotten 1925 comedy by Barry Conners presented by the Transport Group, David Greenspan plays the title character, an all-American Cinderella who outwits her scheming sister to land a swell guy. The next hearing in the sexual-assault case against Dominique Strauss-Kahn has been postponed to Aug. 23 from Aug. 1, lawyers for both sides confirmed on Tuesday. The latest rescheduling comes two days after Mr. Strauss-Kahn's accuser, Nafissatou Diallo, gave magazine and television interviews that raised further doubts about the viability of the prosecution's case.

FRANKFURT - Two of Europe's largest financial institutions delivered a reminder on Tuesday that investment banking remains a fickle source of revenue, as UBS issued a profit warning and Deutsche Bank reported earnings that were below expectations. UBS, Switzerland's biggest bank, warned that it would probably miss an earnings target set two years ago after its profit fell by half in the second quarter, in part because of a dismal performance at its investment banking unit. Deutsche Bank fared better, reporting a 6 percent increase in net profit that still missed forecasts. Revenue from trading fell because of uncertainty caused by Europe's debt crisis, the bank said, while warning that profit from investment banking would fall short of targets.

BOOKEY--Shirley, of Great Neck, born 1926 in Brooklyn, died on July 22, 2011 after a long illness. Widow of Theodore, sister of the late Mildred Ginsberg and Harold Cabak. She leaves behind her son Seth, his partner Eric Schwartz; her son Sandford, his wife Lynne, and her beloved grandchildren , Theo and Melody. She loved her family, her home, and the arts. FINEGOOD--Freddi Sue, who called both Los Angeles and New York home, died peacefully at her home in New York late Monday night after a long illness. Freddi was an amazing human being who had an enormous impact on the lives of many. Beloved wife of Ethan Horwitz, devoted daughter of Rae Finegood and the late Dave Finegood, loving and proud mother of Emily, Matt, Jessica and Jason and grandmother of Liba Shifra, much loved sister of the late Danny Finegood and sister-in-law of Bonnie Finegood, Brenda and Abbey Horwitz and adoring aunt of Matthew, Natalie, Michael, Shayna, and Jonathan. With her warmth and generosity of spirit, Freddi had a very large number of devoted friends, all of whom join her family in the terrible sense of loss. Freddi was born on July 27th, 1950 and raised in Los Angeles under the Hollywood sign; she graduated from Hollywood High School and UCLA. After an early career as a fundraiser in the Jewish community and then with the family furniture business, she relocated to NYC where she used her extensive knowledge of fine art to start a business as an art consultant. She later co-launched a juvenile bedding company called BananaFish and also served on the board of the Juvenile Products Manufacturing Association. Freddi was a steadfast patron of the arts. She loved contemporary and fine art, theater and jazz in particular. She was a true product of her family's extraordinary and generous philanthropic leadership. She was active in the Los Angeles Federation and served on the board of the Furniture Division of the LA Jewish Federation. Ultimately she joined the national Young Womens Leadership Cabinet of the UJA. When she came to New York, her philanthropy continued on the Federation Distribution Committee, and then the board of Dorot. She became President of Dorot three years ago, actively steering Dorot while battling her illness; she was recently reelected to another term as President. No one loved life and her family and friends more than Freddi. She will be truly missed. The Funeral will be at 11am on Thursday, July 28th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, between 90th and 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in Freddi's memory can be made to Dorot at 171 West 85th Street, NY, NY 10024 or at www.dorotusa.org or to the Institute for Myeloma and Bone Cancer Research at 9201 Sunset Blvd, Suite 300, West Hollywood, CA 90069.

Mr. Wu, a seven-term member of Congress, has not publicly discussed the allegations by the woman, who was 18 at the time, although he has said their encounter was consensual. But the episode is only the most recent part of a public unraveling over the last year in which Mr. Wu, 56, had acknowledged mental health issues and erratic behavior.

A coalition of 28 American universities is throwing its weight behind a plan to build ultra-high-speed computer networks -- with Internet service several hundred times faster than what is now commercially available -- in the communities surrounding the participating colleges. The project, which is named GigU and will be announced on Wednesday, is meant to draw high-tech startups in fields like health care, energy and telecommunications to the areas near the universities, many of which are in the Midwest or outside of major cities. These zones would ideally function as hubs for building a new generation of faster computer networks, which could make the United States more competitive internationally.

FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — Well. This is an interesting-looking grid. And it’s not meant to represent anything other than your standard Friday crossword grid. It’s certainly not implying that it’s anything else, unlike a certain Sunday puzzle from not too long ago that I am still getting mail about, by the way.

In 1965, in an impoverished rural county in the Mississippi Delta, the pioneering physician Jack Geiger helped found one of the nation’s first community health centers. Many of the children Geiger treated were seriously malnourished, so he began writing “prescriptions” for food — stipulating quantities of milk, vegetables, meat, and fruit that could be “filled” at grocery stores, which were instructed to send the bills to the health center, where they were paid out of the pharmacy budget. When word of this reached the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington, which financed the center, an official was dispatched to Mississippi to reprimand Geiger and make sure he understood that the center’s money could be used only for medical purposes. Geiger replied: “The last time I looked in my textbooks, the specific therapy for malnutrition was food.” The official had nothing to say and returned to Washington.In some ways, the United States has come a long way since Lyndon Johnson declared the “war on poverty.” But in others, we’re still at square one. We now have a variety of federally-supported nutrition programs, but the health care system remains senselessly disconnected from the “social determinants of health.” In this regard, the United States has fallen behind the rest of the world. If a politician in India announced a public health plan that neglected malnutrition, he would be ridiculed. Here, leaders make this kind of omission all the time. Almost all of the debate about the 2010 Affordable Care Act was consumed with questions about health care access and quality. But if we really want to improve the health of millions of people, we have to address the conditions that make them sick.

It didn’t take long for Horace Greeley, the nation’s most loved, hated and widely read newspaper editor, to become impatient with the progress of the war. From the moment news of Major Robert Anderson’s surrender at Fort Sumter reached New York City, drumbeats and bugle calls for immediate military action could be heard in the columns of Greeley’s paper, the New-York Tribune. Never mind the logistical challenge of assembling, arming and training a suitable military force — the people, or at least the editors, were ready, and there was hardly a moment to lose. What appeared to be lacking, from Greeley’s perspective, was a necessary vigor from President Lincoln and his administration.

Hideki Irabu, the former Yankees pitcher who struggled to live up to grand expectations after coming over from Japan, was found dead in Los Angeles on Thursday. He was 42. Police are investigating Irabu’s death as a possible suicide, according to various reports. Irabu came to the United States in 1997 billed as one of Japan’s premier right-handed pitchers. The Padres owned his rights, but Irabu refused to play for any team but the Yankees. San Diego traded him to the Yankees, who signed him to a four-year, $12.8 million contract. His career began with such promise, when he struck out nine and allowed two runs as the Yankees defeated Detroit in his major league debut, on July 10, 1997. That start proved the highlight of the season. He was banished to the bullpen and the minor leagues, and he finished the year 5-4 with a 7.09 earned run average. In 1999, Steinbrenner erupted after Irabu failed to cover first base during an exhibition game, calling him a fat toad.   In three seasons with the Yankees, Irabu was 29-20 and pitched in only one postseason game, when he came out of the bullpen to allow eight runs to the Red Sox in Game 3 of the 1999 American League Championship Series. Two months later, Irabu was traded to Montreal, where he started 14 games over 2000 and 2001, before finishing his career with Texas in 2002. He retired in 2004 after pitching two seasons for the Hanshin Tigers in Japan.

While it has been known that Netflix and Hulu streaming users are consuming internet bandwidth at a huge and ever increasing rate, what hasn’t been widely reported is just what they’ve been watching with these services. According to a recent survey conducted by Nielsen, less than half of Netflix users watch on their home computer, instead opting to connect via video-game consoles hooked up to their television. Conversely, almost 90 percent of Hulu users watch directly on their computer. Thirty-six percent of all Netflix users watch both movies and television shows while, unsurprisingly, 73 percent of Hulu users watch television programs. Only 9 percent who use Hulu use the service to watch movies. Streaming on mobile devices such as cellphones or tablets like the iPad hasn’t gone beyond early adopters just yet – only 6 percent of Netflix users and 3 percent of all Hulu users watch on the go.

In the interest of talking about something besides the debt ceiling for a moment, here’s an engaging Chuck Klosterman piece comparing moral agency on “Mad Men,” “The Wire” and “The Sopranos” to the moral landscape of AMC’s returning hit “Breaking Bad” (currently the best show on television, for my money). Klosterman notes that “all of these series grapple with morality — more than anything else, it’s the reason they’re better than the shows around them.” But he argues that “the first three examples all create realities where individual agency is detached” and questions of personal moral choice aren’t foregrounded: “Mad Men” because it’s set in the 1960s, making its characters’ actions more a “commentary on the era” than a window into their souls, “The Wire” because it’s “more political than philosophical,” bent on constantly emphasizing the way “everyone is simultaneously good and bad” in order to offer a critique of American society as a whole, and “The Sopranos” because the fact all its major characters were involved with organized crime and its protagonist murdered people for money meant that there were never any unresolved questions over Tony Soprano’s ‘goodness.'” (We knew he was “fundamentally bad,” Klosterman argues, because “otherwise he couldn’t exist as the person he was.”)

Other films that will be shown in competition at the festival, which will run from Aug. 31 through Sept. 10, include Roman Polanski’s “Carnage,” his film adaptation of “God of Carnage,” starring Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly; “Dark Horse,” a new film by Todd Solondz, starring Mia Farrow, Christopher Walken, Justin Bartha and Selma Blair; William Friedkin‘s film version of “Killer Joe,” starring Matthew McConaughey and Emile Hirsch; and David Cronenberg‘s “Dangerous Method,” his drama about Carl Jung and Sigmund Freud. The festival’s out-of-competition lineup will include “W.E.”, a new film directed by Madonna; “Contagion,” directed by Steven Soderbergh; and “Wilde Salome,” directed by and starring Al Pacino. The festival’s closing-night film will be “Damsels in Distress,” the first new feature in more than a decade from Whit Stillman.

When Wade Slitkin leaves a room, the most common utterance is: “That kid’s gonna do big things.” Slitkin just has this air about him — of intelligence and keen intuition. He’s the kind of guy you would trust with your puppy. A street-smart product of inner-city public schools, Slitkin worked in “special markets” for several major book publishers, until it became clear that he was building rocket ships in the belly of a dinosaur. Two years ago, he scraped up his savings and, together with two of his buddies, Stephen Lynch and Brett Dovman, created Panelfly, an app designed to revolutionize storytelling in modern times. Cryptically described as “SuperMedia,” Panelfly, according to the official description, unlocks the full potential around a media franchise, pulling related films, books, games, interviews and art together into a singular experience, transforming how we experience entertainment altogether. At a time when everyone in the publishing and media industries is scratching their heads and bordering on desperation, Slitkin is being heralded as a boy genius.

Steve Baltin had been toiling as a freelance music writer for a decade when an entrepreneur named Jason Turner approached him a year ago about resurrecting Creem magazine, the irreverent and sardonic publication that defined rock in the 1970s. The offer to edit a once-famous magazine was tempting, to say the least. ''He talks a very good game, and he has these grand ambitions of creating this vast music network,'' Mr. Baltin said. ''I'm old enough to have grown up with Creem, and like many people who were hooked into this, I was excited about being involved.''

Q. What purpose does the D: hard-drive partition serve on a Windows computer? Could it be used as a backup? A. The function of the D: drive usually depends on the computer's manufacturer and how the Windows system was originally set up. While the computer's programs and the Windows operating system itself typically live on the C: drive, some companies create a separate D: drive partition on the hard drive to stash backup and recovery software that can be used if something goes wrong with the computer.
