Take a lesson from ''Star Wars'': you can have all the resources in the galaxy at your disposal, and sometimes the little guy still prevails. In this case, that little guy is Andrew Ainsworth, a British artist who helped design the stark, almost featureless costumes worn by the villainous storm troopers in George Lucas's original 1977 space-adventure movie, and who has won the right to sell replicas of those costumes without permission from Mr. Lucas or his studio, Lucasfilm. BBC News reported that the Supreme Court in Britain, the highest court of appeal for civil cases in that country, ruled on Wednesday that the costume replicas created by Mr. Ainsworth were functional rather than artistic works and thus not fully subject to copyright laws.

The numbers are in: Amy Winehouse, who died last Saturday at age 27, will re-enter the Top 10 of the Billboard album chart this week, with her music racking up greater sales in the days after her death than it had since January. Another British soul singer will retake the top spot on the Billboard album chart this week, with Adele claiming her 11th week at No. 1. But it was the online sales rush in the wake of Ms. Winehouse's death that was the biggest news on the pop chart. ''Back to Black'' (Island), Ms. Winehouse's breakthrough second album, sold 37,000 copies in the United States in the week that ended Sunday, reaching No. 9, according to data released by Nielsen SoundScan on Tuesday evening. That was the highest weekly sales for the album since March 2008, two weeks after she won five Grammy Awards. ''Frank,'' Ms. Winehouse's less-known first album -- it was not released in the United States until 2007, four years after it came out in Britain -- sold 7,600 copies. Along with the handful of her other album titles, including a B-sides collection and a live record, she sold a total of 50,000 albums last week, 95 percent of them as digital downloads; up until last week her album sales for the year were only 44,000.

If you make such a declaration as an election contender, you might be abdicating your ''governing responsibilities in a period of incredibly rapid change and financial stress,'' as Thomas L. Friedman wrote. But as the star or creator of a coming fantasy-theme movie or TV show, you might just be participating in Comic-Con International, which wrapped up in San Diego last weekend. Here are some of the stranger or more surprising pledges made at this year's Comic-Con by talented people involved with projects that will not be released or even filmed for several months. SHIMEL--Charles. Beloved by many, passed away peacefully on July 25, 2011. Charles Shimel, born in Bronx, New York, April 7, 1925, graduated Columbia University 1950, earning his degree in civil engineering. In World Was II he served as a medic in the army. Long before Bono and the Edge were best known as the composers of the Broadway musical ''Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,'' they and their U2 band mates Adam Clayton and Larry Mullen Jr. were more immediately associated with best-selling rock albums like ''Achtung Baby.'' It is this more felicitous time in the band's history that is revisited in Davis Guggenheim's documentary ''From the Sky Down,'' which will open the 2011 Toronto International Film Festival, the festival's organizers said on Tuesday. The new film from Mr. Guggenheim, the director of ''An Inconvenient Truth'' and ''Waiting for Superman,'' will chronicle the creation and legacy of ''Achtung Baby,'' the 1991 U2 album that included hits like ''One'' and ''Mysterious Ways,'' using archival footage and new interviews. It will make its debut at a gala presentation on Sept. 8. Other screenings planned for this year's festival, which runs through Sept. 18, include ''A Dangerous Method,'' David Cronenberg's drama about Sigmund Freud, Carl Jung and Sabina Spielrein; George Clooney's political thriller ''The Ides of March''; Bennett Miller's ''Moneyball,'' adapted from Michael Lewis's book about Billy Beane and the Oakland Athletics; Luc Besson's ''The Lady,'' starring Michelle Yeoh as Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the pro-democracy leader in Myanmar; and ''W.E.,'' a film directed by Madonna about a woman (played by Abbie Cornish) who becomes obsessed with the love affair between Wallis Simpson and King Edward VIII. The festival's special presentations schedule also features new films by Fernando Meirelles, Roland Emmerich, Todd Solondz, Alexander Payne and William Friedkin.

BAGHDAD -- When the commander of an elite Iraqi counterterrorist unit escaped arrest on a bribery charge earlier this year, a melee between his bodyguards and the police was captured on video and landed on YouTube. It was leaked, according to the commander and two people involved in the case, by American officials who believed he was innocent and wanted to discredit the Iraqi investigation by portraying it as a circus.

A year later, the mystery of why the tombstone of a woman who died in 1910 was found on the Lower East Side remains unsolved, but the tombstone has finally been installed in its rightful place: at the grave site of the woman, Hinda Amchanitzky, who wrote what has been described as the first Yiddish cookbook published in America. -Last July, The New York Times reported the odd find on East Fourth Street in Manhattan by John Lankenau, an artist and part-time cook and caterer. Since you can find just about anything on the sidewalks of New York, Mr. Lankenau took the grim discovery in stride and carted the granite marker, which is two and a half feet high, home for safekeeping.

HELLENBRAND--Samuel H. 94, died peacefully on July 26, 2011 surrounded by his family and friends. He is survived by his daughters, Kathy H. Rocklen, and her partner, Debi E. Karlinsky, and Linda C. Silberstein, his grandsons, Alex E. Silberstein and Jesse R. Silberstein, his brother, Julius A. Hellenbrand, his nephew, Harry Hellenbrand, his longtime companion, Shirley Samis, and many dear friends. Mr. Hellenbrand was formerly the Vice Chairman of Amtrak and a member of the boards of directors of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and Security Capital Corp. He was the Vice President of Real Estate for International Telephone & Telegraph Corp. and previously, the Vice President of Real Estate for the Penn Central Railroad. Mr. Hellenbrand graduated from Brooklyn Law School, magna cum laude, in 1941. He was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society and the Editor-in-Chief of the Brooklyn Law Review. He received an LLM in taxation, magna cum laude, from Brooklyn Law School in 1942. Mr. Hellenbrand practiced law for 69 years and loved the law as he loved life. He was a kind, compassionate and generous man who lived life to the very fullest and was deeply loved by all who knew him.

An article on Wednesday about the decision by Representative David Wu, Democrat of Oregon, to resign following a young woman's accusations of an unwanted sexual advance last year erroneously attributed a distinction to him. While he is the first Chinese-American elected to the House of Representatives, he is not the first elected to Congress. (Hiram L. Fong, a Republican from Hawaii, served as a senator from 1959 to 1977.)

'THE ANTI-EMPATHIC TURN' by Robin L. West, professor of law and philosophy at Georgetown University; Georgetown Public Law and Legal Theory Research Paper No. 11-97. THE ISSUE Ms. West states that throughout the 20th century the great jurists agreed that empathy -- the ability to share the perspectives of others -- was crucial to justice, that to make decisions about discrimination, malpractice or injury one must know the law and history. But Ms. West adds: ''One must also know something about feelings of loss: What does it feel like to lose the use of a hand, or to lose even just a slight possibility of years of life?'' How, she wonders, did this mainstream idea ''in the first decade of the 21st century, become positively toxic, at least in the context of confirmation battles to the Supreme Court.''

A picture caption on Tuesday with the Reuters Breakingviews column, about the European rescue plan for Greece, gave an incorrect identification from the wire service for the organization to which Evangelos Venizelos, the Greek finance minister, spoke on Monday in Washington. It is the Peterson Institute for International Economics, not the Institute of International Finance.

Most mornings, the Museum of Modern Art is as crowded as a Midtown subway station. So it didn't seem all that odd to witness two middle-school students, Ariel Rogiers, 13 and Javonna Cato, 12, from the Robert F. Kennedy School on the Upper East Side, lining up recently on the museum's third floor to check the balances on their MetroCards. A MetroCard machine is now parked on the museum's third floor, in all its graffiti-proof, scratch-proof, tank-like steel solidity, fully functioning and ready to accept cash, credit card or ATM card. It's part of the museum's new ''Talk to Me'' design exhibition, which looks at how products and devices are growing increasingly sophisticated at communicating with users.

An article and a picture caption on Wednesday about a plan to build ultrahigh-speed computer networks around American universities misstated the number of member institutions supporting the project, known as GigU. There are 29, not 28. (Project officials omitted George Mason University from a list of participating colleges.)

The latest splashy stock debut had all the markings of a sizzling technology start-up company: a better-than-expected offering price, a swarm of investors clamoring for shares and a first-day pop that defied a broader market drop. But the company was not an online music service or a social networking site. It was a fast-food chain that sells bite-size Munchkin donuts and extra-large cups of coffee.

10 P.M. (HBO Signature) WALL STREET: MONEY NEVER SLEEPS (2010) Michael Douglas returns as the reptilian financier Gordon Gekko, who, after serving an eight-year prison sentence, has landed in the public spotlight once again for writing a critical and prescient book about the state of the markets. Shia LaBeouf (above right, with Mr. Douglas) is the investment banker Jake Moore, one of Gekko's fans -- and the live-in love of Gekko's estranged daughter (Carey Mulligan). Frank Langella is the old-school broker who has been like a father to Jake. And Josh Brolin is the newest snake in town. Let the games resume. ''The vendettas simmering among the various titans of the Street seem like shabby Mafia stuff when measured against the scale of ruin these petty rivalries are meant to explain,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''Even ostensibly real values, as opposed to the notional riches confected by credit default swaps and other derivatives, are expressed in monetary terms. To the question 'What went wrong?' the film offers an answer that is both irrefutable and unsatisfying: human nature.'' And yet, Mr. Scott added, something vital here works. Oliver Stone, the film's director, ''is not the man to explain Wall Street, or to stoke public indignation at its crimes,'' he said. ''But no one else could turn it into a show like 'Wall Street.' '' 8 P.M. (ABC) WIPEOUT Teams of employees and their bosses compete on the extreme obstacle course for a chance at $50,000. On the reality competition series ''Expedition Impossible,'' at 9, only eight teams remain. Groups of three race through deserts and over mountains in Morocco, and now they must try cliff diving.

A report in the Observatory column on Tuesday about bottlenose dolphins in Shark Bay, Australia, described their use of seafloor sponges as a foraging tool incorrectly. The dolphins place the sponges on their beaks, not on their noses. (Despite the dolphin's name, its ''nose'' is actually its blowhole.) The article also described incorrectly the group of 54 Shark Bay dolphins known to use sponges. Most -- not all -- are female.

WASHINGTON -- The first thing we see on entering the new exhibition at the Smithsonian American Art Museum here is a life-size painting of a formally dressed, graciously welcoming, aged gentleman. He is lifting a heavy red drape and gesturing as if inviting us to visit the marvels within. Beyond the curtain we glimpse walls lined with hundreds of glass cases, each containing stuffed birds. We see visitors strolling past, engaged in contemplation or struck with amazement. We also spot part of a mastodon skeleton, discovered in 1801 by the same man who lifts the curtain. He is the image's painter, Charles Willson Peale. And he is welcoming us into the museum he created in early-19th-century Philadelphia.

SAN DIEGO -- Here in a laboratory perched on the edge of the continent, researchers are trying to construct Life As We Don't Know It in a thimbleful of liquid. Generations of scientists, children and science fiction fans have grown up presuming that humanity's first encounter with alien life will happen in a red sand dune on Mars, or in an enigmatic radio signal from some obscure star.
An article last Thursday about the hotelier Vikram Chatwal misstated the year in which he graduated from the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania. It was 1994, not 1984.

A theater review on Wednesday about ''The Patsy,'' at the Duke on 42nd Street, and a listing of credits with it, using information from the program, misspelled the surname of the set and costume designer. He is Dane Laffrey, not Laffery.

If you've tried to search for tweets on Twitter's built-in search box, you know it can be frustrating. For a currently popular topic, you'll get dozens of recent tweets. For an older topic, you may get no results at all. Twitter has an advanced search page, but a better alternative is Topsy, a dedicated Twitter search engine. It's so good that even Twitter's official guide for journalists suggests using Topsy to research news topics.

Because of an editing error, an obituary on Wednesday about the actor G. D. Spradlin described incorrectly, in some editions, a scene from ''The Godfather Part II,'' in which Mr. Spradlin played a corrupt United States senator. In the scene, the senator threatens to ''squeeze'' the Mafia boss Michael Corleone, played by Al Pacino; Michael Corleone does not threaten the senator.

For more than a decade, anthropologists and historians pieced together the history of a short-lived African-American community that was snuffed out in the 1850s by the creation of Central Park. They combed vital records and tax documents, scanned parkland using radar and studied soil borings. But because the vestiges of the community were buried beneath the park, the leaders of the Institute for the Exploration of Seneca Village History -- a consortium of three professors from City College, Barnard College and New York University -- were kept from doing the one thing that would open a window onto the daily existence of the some 260 residents: digging.

KALAGHER--Lynne. I will always remember the wonderful times we had together. Your devotion to your family and friends was paramount. My heart goes out to your beloved husband, Steven, your parents, your extraordinary children, Janine, Paul, and Jim, their spouses, and your grandchildren. With my love and deepest sympathy to you all, Sue Merinoff

After enduring a brutal spring in the public opinion polls, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg seems to be making some inroads with the public, according to the latest poll by Quinnipiac University. In July, more New Yorkers approved of Mr. Bloomberg's overall performance than disapproved. His approval rating was 45 percent, compared with 40 percent in May, when Mr. Bloomberg was still smarting from the failed appointment of his schools chancellor and the city's botched response to the December blizzard.

We extend our condolences to the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

An article on Tuesday about the evolution of organisms in urban areas referred incorrectly to the treatment for infection with Klebsiella pneumoniae, a newly evolved strain of bacteria discovered in New York City. Doctors typically prescribe drugs from a large class of antibiotics known as carbapenems; there is no single antibiotic called carbapenem.

An art review on Friday about ''Nancy Grossman: Heads,'' at MoMA PS1, and ''Nancy Grossman: Combustion Scapes,'' at the Michael Rosenfeld Gallery in Manhattan, misidentified the method Ms. Grossman used to paint the framed assemblages on display at the gallery. They were painted by hand, not spray-painted.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. - The news at Giants camp Wednesday was a lot like the weather in London: if you did not like it, you could wait an hour for it to change. And when Plaxico Burress is involved, the winds are always shifting. Amid the news that the Giants had signed center David Baas to fill a big void on their offensive line and had given a one-year contract extension to Coach Tom Coughlin, the possibility of Burress's return loomed ever larger over the Giants' practice center.
GRUSZKA--Robert J. August 26, 1942 - July 27, 2010. Beloved husband. You were and always will be my 'Hannu' my 'Habibun' my 'Polish Prince'. Forever missed and eternally loved. Ilham Albasri Gruszka

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has never catered to the late-night crowd, but on Aug. 6 and 7, the last two days of its blockbuster exhibition ''Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty,'' it will keep the show open until midnight. Having combed through the museum's records, officials there said they believed that this would be the first time the Met has stayed open so late. The exhibition, which chronicles the work of the British fashion designer who committed suicide last year at age 40, opened on May 4, and its galleries have been mobbed ever since, with people sometimes waiting in lines for two hours. The museum has already extended the duration of the show twice, given access to members earlier in the day and offered $50 tickets to visitors who want to come on Mondays, when the museum is normally closed. But it is not able to keep the show up past Aug. 7 because taking it down will be a complicated and lengthy process and it needs to clear the galleries to begin installing ''Wonder of the Age: Master Painters of India, 1100-1900,'' which opens on Sept. 28.

Q. Apple has been promoting this iCloud thing that's coming out in the fall, but what will happen to the iDisk part of MobileMe?A. Apple is phasing out its MobileMe suite of tools-- including the iDisk online storage feature, the Gallery for posting pictures and videos and space for sites created and published with the company's iWeb software. The shutdown will not happen immediately, but Apple has given June 30, 2012, as the final day before it pulls the plug on the MobileMe service for good. In the meantime, files, photos and Web sites stored online in MobileMe accounts will need to be moved off the service if they are to be saved. To help users with this process, Apple has a document describing the transition on its site. Links to articles that explain how to transfer iWeb sites, Gallery photos and iDisk files are included.

FINEGOOD--Freddi Sue, who called both Los Angeles and New York home, died peacefully at her home in New York late Monday night after a long illness. Freddi was an amazing human being who had an enormous impact on the lives of many. Beloved wife of Ethan Horwitz, devoted daughter of Rae Finegood and the late Dave Finegood, loving and proud mother of Emily, Matt, Jessica and Jason and grandmother of Liba Shifra, much loved sister of the late Danny Finegood and sister-in-law of Bonnie Finegood, Brenda and Abbey Horwitz and adoring aunt of Matthew, Natalie, Michael, Shayna, and Jonathan. With her warmth and generosity of spirit, Freddi had a very large number of devoted friends, all of whom join her family in the terrible sense of loss. Freddi was born on July 27th, 1950 and raised in Los Angeles under the Hollywood sign; she graduated from Hollywood High School and UCLA. After an early career as a fundraiser in the Jewish community and then with the family furniture business, she relocated to NYC where she used her extensive knowledge of fine art to start a business as an art consultant. She later co-launched a juvenile bedding company called BananaFish and also served on the board of the Juvenile Products Manufacturing Association. Freddi was a steadfast patron of the arts. She loved contemporary and fine art, theater and jazz in particular. She was a true product of her family's extraordinary and generous philanthropic leadership. She was active in the Los Angeles Federation and served on the board of the Furniture Division of the LA Jewish Federation. Ultimately she joined the national Young Womens Leadership Cabinet of the UJA. When she came to New York, her philanthropy continued on the Federation Distribution Committee, and then the board of Dorot. She became President of Dorot three years ago, actively steering Dorot while battling her illness; she was recently reelected to another term as President. No one loved life and her family and friends more than Freddi. She will be truly missed. The Funeral will be at 11am on Thursday, July 28th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, between 90th and 91st Street. In lieu of flowers, donations in Freddi's memory can be made to Dorot at 171 West 85th Street, NY, NY 10024 or at www.dorotusa.org or to the Institute for Myeloma and Bone Cancer Research at 9201 Sunset Blvd, Suite 300, West Hollywood, CA 90069.

Confederate Gen. G.T. Beauregard was worried. It was the afternoon of July 21, 1861, and fighting had raged since daylight after General Irwin McDowell’s Union army attacked Beauregard from across the small Virginia stream known as Bull Run. The battle seesawed throughout the day, but fresh troops rushed in from the Shenandoah Valley had finally given Beauregard the advantage. Now, just as victory seemed certain, he spied a heavy column of troops more than a mile away maneuvering on his flank.

In this week’s Mechanic Muse column for the Book Review, I look at how vast new databases and techniques can help scholars of the digital humanities zero in on the nitty-gritty of literary style, right down to the level of individual words. An exciting development over the past few years is that many of the tools that scholars use to plumb the depths of literary usage are now publicly available online. These resources aren’t locked up in an ivory tower, accessible only to an elite band of researchers. Call it the democratization of digital scholarship.

The fashion guru Tim Gunn and the model Heidi Klum made a not quite triumphant but still satisfactory return to New York City as “Project Runway” had its Season 9 premiere on Lifetime on Thursday night.  The fashion designer competition averaged 2.7 million total viewers according to Nielsen, making small gains over the premiere from last season.  It was certainly an eventful episode, as four of the twenty contestants were eliminated by the 20-minute mark.

It was a long time ago – 1994, to be precise – when George Lucas produced his last film that was not connected to his “Indiana Jones” or “Star Wars” fantasy franchises. Now his long-in-the-works film about the fighting men of a very different war finally has a release date: on Friday, Lucasfilm said that “Red Tails,” a film about the Tuskegee Airmen, the all-black pilot group that fought in World War II, would be released on Jan. 20. The film is directed by Anthony Hemingway, who has directed for television series including “Treme,” “True Blood” and “CSI: NY,” and its ensemble cast features Cuba Gooding Jr., Terrence Howard and Bryan Cranston, as well as Tristan Wilds (of “The Wire” and “90210”), Cliff Smith (better known as the rapper Method Man), Ne-Yo and Elijah Kelley.

After months of hand-wringing by industry lobbies and environmental groups, President Obama announced the new round of Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards, known as CAFE, on Friday in Washington. The standards call for a 5 percent annual increase in fuel economy for passenger cars from 2017 to 2025, culminating in a mandated 54.5 miles per gallon.

The Texas installation artist Erick Swenson is known for turning heads with his portrayals of hybrid creatures that look hauntingly real. His 2004 Whitney Biennial contribution showcased an animal with a fawnlike body, ears of a rabbit and a nose of a dog, frozen in a dramatic stance over what appears to be a woven rug (but is actually hand-painted fiberglass). He once created a half-eaten carcass of a killer whale and laid it across a monstrous crumpled-up ice floe — a piece so well done, critics said, it could be a natural history museum display. So how does Swenson fit in here with our downtown playlist, brought to you by Sean Hanratty? Hanratty chose Swenson for The Jam’s fifth installment not only because of their shared Texan roots but also because, he says, “I’ve always been so intrigued with the sort of fantastical nature of his work and materials. I knew his playlist would contain a lot of classic songs with a very strong backbone.”

Good tomatoes are in, finally. Real, farm-grown meaty tomatoes, like classic Beefsteak and Brandywine and Lemon Boy, and sweet cherry tomatoes of different colors. So a fine tomato salad comes to mind, but what about a sandwich? Not a BLT; not tomato, avocado and sprouts. Rather, a Mediterranean sandwich of tomatoes with capers, anchovy and basil, piled into a freshly baked roll. A little bit soggy, completely heavenly. And no need to turn on the oven. Read about it, along with a few other sandwich reveries, in this week’s City Kitchen.

Amazon.com, which has an estimated 70 percent of the online book market in Britain, got closer this week to controlling the rest of it when the Irish Competition Authority approved its pending purchase of a major rival, the Book Depository. But the blessing of the main regulatory body, the Office of Fair Trading, is no sure thing in a country that appears to be more concerned about media monopoly in the wake of the News Corporation hacking scandal.

Last Sunday the magazine published a story about two brothers and their creation of the computer game Dwarf Fortress. The story presented a visual challenge — a photograph of  Tarn and Zach Adams working on computers seemed like an unsatisfactory option. Instead, we had the idea of creating portraits of Tarn and Zach Adams from the ASCII characters and 16 colors (seen below) that are the building blocks of their game. So we contacted Tarn to see if he would help us with this. What ensued sort of blew our minds.

Nicholas Ray, the director of the 1955 film classic “Rebel Without a Cause,” was pretty much banished from Hollywood in the early 1960s as a result of his drug and alcohol addictions, and volatile temper. But his early work influenced a generation of filmmakers. Now his voluminous archives have been bought from his widow, Susan Ray, by the Harry Ransom Center, a humanities research library and museum at the University of Texas at Austin.

LONDON — Women without knickers kept showing up on the stage the other day, in two different theaters. And, honestly, I wasn’t hanging out in those hole-in-the-wall clubs in Soho, land of gentlemen’s entertainments bathed in sad neon light. No, I was in respectable fringe theaters, watching earnest and worthy productions of plays with big themes – which happened to involve women in search of sexual satisfaction removing their underpants and then waiting for something to happen.

Susana Baca, the acclaimed singer and soul of Afro-Peruano music, became the first black cabinet minister of independent Peru when she was sworn in as minister of culture on Thursday by the country’s new president, Ollanta Humala. Baca, 67, is revered for mixing Andean and African rhythms and has played a key role in the revival of Afro-Peruano music and dance — folkloric traditions long sidelined in Peru.

Linda Ronstadt is joining the music memoir club with her own book, “Heart Like a Wheel,” said her publisher, Simon & Schuster. The memoir, titled after her hit 1974 album, will focus on her long career, during which she has sold more than 100 million records. “Few singers have been as wide-ranging or as distinctive in their artistry,” Jonathan Karp, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, said in a statement. “Linda Ronstadt has a singular voice, and that is true on the page as well.” The book is tentatively scheduled for publication in 2013.

What Americans really think about Medicare: They like it. They don’t want to see it significantly changed. But they’re conscious of the federal deficit and willing to consider a number of strategies to reduce the gap, including raising taxes on high earners, spending less on foreign aid and overseas military commitments, and limiting tax deductions for large corporations. They’re even amenable to certain cost-cutting measures in Medicare itself.

On Friday in Frankfurt, BMW showed working prototypes of its i3 electric runabout and i8 plug-in hybrid sports coupe. A new wrinkle, however, is the addition of an optional gasoline-burning range extender for the i3, an otherwise purely electric car.

“Whiskey nerds” is how George Ruotolo and his brother, Justin, describe themselves. With another partner, Rob Magill, they own bars, including The Whiskey Brooklyn, next to which they have carved out a wee dram of a shop with more than 100 different whiskeys. The GDP estimates for second quarter are out, and they're ugly. Basically, very weak growth for the first half of 2011 -- indeed, growth well below the economy's potential, so we're actually losing ground in the effort to reduce the gap between what we should be producing and what we're actually producing. This is a recipe for rising, not falling, unemployment.

The world’s population is expected to pass seven billion in late October. A few weeks ago, I joined my colleague Celia Dugger in writing about worrisome new population projections from the United Nations. Instead of peaking in this century, as previously expected, the new projections suggested that the human population would continue growing all the way into the next century, probably topping out above 10 billion.

Like many small-business owners, Keith Goldstein often has so much on his plate that it’s hard to keep track of it all. So Mr. Goldstein, who owns 60-employee Everest Waterproofing and Restoration in San Francisco, does what most people do to remember what needs to get done: He writes it down on a “to-do” list. Sometimes he scribbles a list in a notebook, but he prefers to type it into his iPad, whence it’s zipped by app to his e-mail. “I use my inbox as my real to-do list,” he said. “If a note isn’t an action item I move it out of the inbox, so whatever is in there is about something I need to get done.”

Fans of the late Alexander McQueen who fear that the world of fashion has lost forever a designer who can combine boundless theatricality, scrupulous styling and high art might be heartened by the “Fashion Art” exhibition, which collects works by Manuel Fernández, a designer with a similar flair. A selection of 100 of his breathtaking gowns and jackets are now on view through Sept. 18 at the handsome Tomas Y Valiente Center of Art (Calle Leganés, 51, Fuenlabrada; 34-91-492-1120; www.fundacionfai.org), about 20 minutes by train from Madrid.

Last July, our staff writer Susan Dominus, who was then working as the paper’s Big City columnist, wrote a story about Jenny Rosenstrach, the keeper of a wonderful cooking blog called Dinner: A Love Story. The blog contains plenty of great (sometimes Bittman-esque) recipes — for grilled pizza, say, or minty peas (and also Manhattans) — and if you have any interest in the cooking or eating of food, it won’t disappoint. But it also occasionally contains book recommendations for kids. Usually, the suggestions come from Jenny’s daughters or from her husband, Andy. But in the past few weeks, something amazing has been going on over at DALS. The recommendations are coming from authors, and not just any authors, but some of the greatest children’s lit (or any lit) writers alive. Here is Pseudonymous Bosch’s summer reading list, for instance. And here are the recommendations made by Lemony Snicket (a k a Daniel Handler, who was the subject of this profile in our magazine back in 2001). And here is the summer reading list provided by George Saunders, whose genius is impossible to overstate and whose name popped up on our own great-fiction list just a couple weeks ago. Maybe once we finish contemplating our favorite sentences (and by the way, speaking of George Saunders, there are many amazing sentences in his most recent short story in the New Yorker), we’ll move on to our own subjective rankings of children’s books. Until then, these are pretty solid guides.

Reading in today’s paper about recent bear attacks in Colorado, I was reminded of Darcy Frey’s prescient story from a few years ago about particularly audacious bears in the Canadian town of Whistler and the biologists who study them. Frey wrote about “bears that lift the door handles of trucks to take possession of the cabs; bears that manage to snag the bait from a trap with one foot while holding the steel gate open with the other; bears that stroll munificently through the crowds at the Canada Day parade; bears in the pubs, the hotels, the day care centers, the landfills, meat lockers, grease vents, underground parking garages. In Whistler, if a bear doesn’t get into something humans are guarding, it’s usually because too many other bears got there first.”

LONDON – Never let it be said that the pig is not a lady. Yes, the title character of “Betty Blue Eyes,” the slyly winning new musical at the Ivor Novello Theater, is irrefutably porcine. She emits odors that cause everyone around her to gag, and you do need to watch where you step after she’s been in the room. STEVENS--Tony. 63, director, choreographer, teacher, and dancer of extraordinary talent passed away July 12 of Hodgkins Lymphoma. Beloved by his peers and students, Stevens danced in over ten Broadway shows in the 1960's and 70's and was seen on every major television variety show filmed in New York. He then began choreographing, working with Peter Gennaro, Gower Champion, Michael Bennett, as well as Bob Fosse on the original landmark musical '' Chicago''. When Fosse became ill and ''Chicago'' rehearsals were postponed, Fred Ebb conceived the club act ''Chita Plus Two'' for Chita Rivera, including Tony and Christopher Chadman. What started out as a modest venture, overnight became the hottest act to hit New York. They played Las Vegas, Miami, and Los Angeles and it became the standard for all other acts that followed. In 1974, frustrated with how dancers were treated, Tony and Michon Peacock organized a couple of all-night taped talk sessions in which dancers shared their experiences about their lives and professions. With Michael Bennett's involvement, that material eventually became ''A Chorus Line''. Tony choreographed television specials for Mary Tyler Moore, Disney, and The Peoples Choice Awards. Movies he choreographed include ''The Great Gatsby'' and ''The Best Little Whorehouse In Texas''. He directed and/or choreographed for Bernadette Peters, Dolly Parton, Betty Buckley, Liza Minnelli, Joel Grey, Gene Kelly, and Debbie Reynolds, and was a highly respected teacher in New York. His love and support for show business and everyone in it was legendary. He is survived by his sister and brother-in-law Sharon and Fred Gray, niece and husband Lisa and Phil Rothweiler, great niece and nephew Stacy and Nick Rothweiler, his companion Nathan Samson, and hundreds of friends on Broadway, where his light will shine forever. Donations in his memory may be made to The Dancers Resource at the Actors Fund, 729 Seventh Avenue, New York, NY. 10036.

SEOUL, South Korea -- An Asiana Airlines cargo plane crashed into waters off the southern coast of South Korea on Thursday after reporting a fire in its cargo compartments, government officials said. The maritime police were searching for any sign of plane's two pilots about 70 miles west of Jeju, the southernmost island off South Korea, in an area where a seat, a wing tip and other pieces of wreckage were recovered.

GLECKMAN--William B.,of New York City and East Hampton, died on July 25. He was 79 years old. Born in New Bedford, MA, he attended New Bedford High School. After graduating from MIT in 1954 with a degree in architecture, he served in the army in Heidelberg, Germany. He loved Europe, and decided to do postgraduate studies in city planning at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich. After working in architectural firms in Zurich (where he met his wife-to-be), Lausanne, and Geneva, he returned to the United States, where he started his own architectural practice in New York City. His work consisted primarily of apartment-building renovations, restaurants, and foreign consulates, in New York City, as well as houses in East Hampton, Amagansett and Sagaponack. He was included in Architectural Digest's AD 100 in 1991. Aside from his lifelong passion for architecture, he was an avid reader, history buff and traveler and loved classical music and crossword puzzles. He is survived by his wife, Magdalena, his daughter, Suzanne Gleason, his son, Nicholas Gleckman, daughter-in-law Lana Gleckman, and five grandchildren.

Though it was bad news for Julius Caesar ''The Ides of March'' has already proved a good-luck charm for George Clooney: his new political thriller of that title will make its debut as the opening night offering of the Venice Film Festival, its organizers said on Thursday. Mr. Clooney directed the film, which is adapted from the Beau Willimon play ''Farragut North,'' and stars as an aspiring presidential candidate who turns to a novice press secretary (played by Ryan Gosling) to help manage his campaign. Other films that will be shown in competition at the festival, which will run from Aug. 31 through Sept. 10, include Roman Polanski's ''Carnage,'' his film adaptation of ''God of Carnage,'' starring Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly; ''Dark Horse,'' a new film by Todd Solondz, starring Mia Farrow, Christopher Walken, Justin Bartha and Selma Blair; William Friedkin's film version of ''Killer Joe,'' starring Matthew McConaughey and Emile Hirsch; and David Cronenberg's ''Dangerous Method,'' his drama about Carl Jung and Sigmund Freud. The festival's out-of-competition lineup will include ''W.E.'', a new film directed by Madonna; ''Contagion,'' directed by Steven Soderbergh; and ''Wilde Salome,'' directed by and starring Al Pacino. The festival's closing-night film will be ''Damsels in Distress,'' the first new feature in more than a decade from Whit Stillman. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

7:54 p.m. | Updated Senator Charles E. Grassley is examining whether Education Department officials disclosed confidential government information to hedge fund managers, including the well-known stock picker Steve Eisman.

The British drug maker AstraZeneca has settled in principle nearly all of the American product liability lawsuits over Seroquel, its blockbuster antipsychotic drug, the company said in a quarterly earnings report on Thursday. All but 250 of the 28,700 cases have been settled, most with written agreements, AstraZeneca said in the securities filing. It had previously reported settling most of those cases, but the new filing showed how far the company has whittled away at the remaining product liability litigation. Last quarter, it had reported 2,600 outstanding cases.

We were proud to represent him as an artist and will miss him even more as a good friend. William Acquavella and the Acquavella Family

IMMERMAN--Robert M.,of New York City passed away July 22, 2011 while in California. Robert was a Research Scholar at the Weatherhead East Asian Institue, Columbia University for the past twenty years. Prior to that he served as a US foreign service officer for over thirty years. He is survived by his brother William and sister-in-law Ginger of Los Angeles, nephews Scott and Eric Immerman and niece Lara Myrene. A memorial service will be held September 19, 2pm, at the Columbia University Chapel. Additional memorials are being planned for Washington, DC and Tokyo, Japan.

NATO and Serbian government officials sent emergency reinforcements to two border crossings between Serbia and Kosovo on Thursday, seeking to maintain calm after two days of violence. Lt. Col. Ralph Adametz, a spokesman for the 5,000-strong NATO-led mission in Kosovo, said his force had sent in several hundred more troops. ''It is now again in control there,'' he said. ''The situation is calm but not stable.'' An ethnic Albanian policeman from Serbia was fatally shot on Tuesday, after skirmishes between Serbian and Kosovar police forces. On Wednesday, Serbs near the border fired at NATO troops. No one was hurt, Colonel Adametz said.

The reverberations of Washington's impasse over a debt deal are already being felt in the short-term credit markets, a key artery of the economy that daily supplies trillions of dollars of credit. Over the last week, big banks and companies have withdrawn $37.5 billion from money market funds that invest in Treasury debt and other ultra-safe securities, the biggest weekly drop this year. Meanwhile, in the vast market for repurchase agreements, in which many financial firms make short-term loans to one another, borrowers are beginning to demand higher yields.

BUSINESS DAY The Media Equation column on Monday, about a phone hacking scandal's effect on the News Corporation, referred imprecisely to the conditions under which Peter Chernin, a former chief executive, and Gary Ginsberg, a former communications executive, left the company. While the executives resigned, they were not ''pushed out'' by Rupert Murdoch to make room for his children.

SPORTS An article on July 11 previewing the British Open misidentified the golf course where the Scottish Open was held the weekend before. It was at Castle Stuart Golf Links -- not Loch Lomond, which had been the site in previous years.

In the middle of production of its highly anticipated second season, ''The Walking Dead,'' AMC's much-talked-about drama about the survivors of a zombie infestation, has replaced its show runner. On Thursday the channel confirmed widespread reports that the ''Walking Dead'' producer Frank Darabont had been replaced by Glen Mazzara, effective immediately. Mr. Mazzara, who is best known for his work on the FX drama ''The Shield,'' was an executive producer of the first season and the writer of the fifth episode, ''Wildfire,'' which featured a group of survivors traveling to the Centers for Disease Control headquarters in Atlanta.

Because of an editing error, an article last Friday about the conversion of apartments to rentals for tourists in San Francisco mis-spelled the surname of the executive director of the San Francisco Tenants Union. He is Ted Gullicksen, not Gullickson.

FRONT PAGE An article on Thursday about efforts by a handful of researchers to create life in chemicals in test tubes using the tools of modern genetics misspelled, in some editions, the given name of a Yale professor who shared a Nobel Prize for his work with RNA. He is Sidney Altman, not Sydney.

SPORTS An article on Saturday about the success of golfers from Northern Ireland misidentified a course where Rory McIlroy, the United States Open champion this year, set a course record as a 16-year-old in 2005. It was at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland, not at Royal County Down in Newcastle.

In April, along a grassy bank in a garden preserve in the Bronx neighborhood known as West Farms, Nicolas Dumit Estevez, clothed in white robe, head nearly shaven, was baptized with the not-so-pure water of the Bronx River. Not as a Christian - as a Bronxite. It was a rite of passage Mr. Estevez, formerly of the Upper West Side, organized to celebrate his rebirth as a native of the Bronx and kick off ''Born Again,'' a collection of video interviews, photographs, props and other documents testifying to the phenomenon of Bronxhood, on view at the Longwood Art Gallery at Hostos Community College through next Wednesday.

1 P.M. (HBO2) LOOKING FOR RICHARD (1996) Long before his Tony-nominated turn as Shylock in ''The Merchant of Venice,'' Al Pacino, left, in his directorial debut, tried to communicate his abiding love of Shakespeare while exploring the twists of the Machiavellian play ''Richard III.'' In this documentary -- part theater, part commentary -- Mr. Pacino takes on the title role, while Alec Baldwin plays Clarence, Kevin Spacey is Buckingham, Aidan Quinn is Richmond, and Winona Ryder is Lady Anne. Kenneth Branagh, John Gielgud, Vanessa Redgrave, James Earl Jones, Kevin Kline and Derek Jacobi offer insight. ''Mission accomplished,'' Janet Maslin declared in The New York Times. ''With all the makings of a monstrous vanity production, Mr. Pacino's quick-witted, illuminating 'Looking for Richard' somehow emerges as a complete delight.'' 9:45 A.M. (AMC) MICHAEL CLAYTON (2007) George Clooney (above right, with Tom Wilkinson) plays a fixer who cleans up the messes at a large New York law firm. Tilda Swinton, in her Oscar-winning role, is chief counsel for an agrichemical behemoth that is about to settle a multibillion-dollar lawsuit with the firm's help. Then the star litigator (Mr. Wilkinson) has a breakdown. The film's director, Tony Gilroy, ''hasn't reinvented the legal thriller here, but I doubt that was his intention; at its best and most ambitious, the film plays less like a variation on a Hollywood standard than a reappraisal,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''It's a modest reappraisal, adult, sincere, intelligent, absorbing; it entertains without shame.''

THE ARTS A picture on Thursday with an exhibition review of ''The Great American Hall of Wonders,'' at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph, of the Charles Willson Peale painting ''The Artist in His Museum,'' which is in the exhibition, should have been credited to the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, not to the Smithsonian American Art Museum.

HELLENBRAND--Samuel H. 94, died peacefully on July 26, 2011 surrounded by his family and friends. He is survived by his daughters, Kathy H. Rocklen, and her partner, Debi E. Karlinsky, and Linda C. Silberstein, his grandsons, Alex E. Silberstein and Jesse R. Silberstein, his brother, Julius A. Hellenbrand, his nephew, Harry Hellenbrand, his longtime companion, Shirley Samis, and many dear friends. Mr. Hellenbrand was formerly the Vice Chairman of Amtrak and a member of the boards of directors of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce and Security Capital Corp. He was the Vice President of Real Estate for International Telephone & Telegraph Corp. and previously, the Vice President of Real Estate for the Penn Central Railroad. Mr. Hellenbrand graduated from Brooklyn Law School, magna cum laude, in 1941. He was a member of the Phi Beta Kappa Society and the Editor-in-Chief of the Brooklyn Law Review. He received an LLM in taxation, magna cum laude, from Brooklyn Law School in 1942. Mr. Hellenbrand practiced law for 69 years and loved the law as he loved life. He was a kind, compassionate and generous man who lived life to the very fullest and was deeply loved by all who knew him.

Lazard said on Thursday that its second-quarter profit rose 23 percent from the period a year ago as increasing deal activity and growth in assets under management bolstered results, the investment bank said on Thursday. Another investment bank, Evercore Partners, reported on Thursday a 119 percent gain in second-quarter revenue, to $142 million.

The Museum of Modern Art, faced with what it calls ''escalating costs in virtually all aspects of operating the museum,'' is raising its admission price to $25 for adults from $20, where it has been since 2004. The change takes effect on Sept. 1. Admission will remain free for children 16 and under; the charge for full-time students will rise to $14 from $12. MoMA is following the Metropolitan Museum of Art. In June the Met announced that its suggested admission price would rise to $25 from $20 starting in July. Unlike the Met's suggested fee, MoMA's is mandatory. Membership rates for the Museum of Modern Art are rising as well, as of Nov. 1. Individuals will have to pay $85 to be a member rather than $75; a dual membership will be $140 instead of $120, and it will cost a family $175, up from $150. ''These carefully considered increases in admission prices will help ensure that the museum is able to maintain financial stability and a balanced budget,'' a statement from the museum said.

NEW YORK A picture on Tuesday with an article about neighborhoods' long wait for historic district street signs was published in error. (It was also published in error on Sept. 30, 2007, with an article about a proposed historic-district designation for Fiske Terrace and Midwood Park.) The photograph showed West Midwood, not the Midwood Park-Fiske Terrace historic district. The article on Tuesday, using information from the Historic Districts Council, also misstated the estimated number of districts that lacked signs. It is as many as 28 districts, not as many as 37.

The Brooklyn Philharmonic has announced its first season under a new music director, Alan Pierson: a slate of grab-bag community concerts with a strong popular-music inflection. The organization will offer a series of concerts in three neighborhoods -- Brighton Beach, Bedford-Stuyvesant and downtown Brooklyn -- to be played in theaters, at a Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. and at the Brooklyn Public Library, among other sites. Each set of concerts includes an orchestral affair, chamber music performance and family workshop. The orchestra stopped performing at the Brooklyn Academy of Music after financial woes forced it to cut back on activity two years ago. In Brighton Beach the orchestra will play music from Russian cartoons. Downtown it will perform an eclectic mix of Brooklyn-related compositions. In Bedford-Stuyvesant the main concert features the hip-hop artist Mos Def, a tribute to Lena Horne and a remix of music by Beethoven. Details are available on the orchestra's Web site.

JU RGEN KLINSMANN A star for Germany on and off the field, Klinsmann nearly got the job in 2006, but his demands for control of the entire U.S. program, top to bottom, was a nonstarter. Imagine that, a man with a coherent plan. He's now a consultant to Toronto F.C. of M.L.S., which is a bit like being the national team coach of Azerbaijan.

STANDING FIRM Transatlantic Holdings rejected a $3.2 billion hostile bid by Validus Holdings and took up a number of defenses, including suing Validus and instituting a poison pill. Transatlantic said that it remained committed to its own planned merger with another insurer, Allied World Assurance, which it asserted would create more long-term value for shareholders. Edward J. Noonan, above, Validus's chief executive, maintained that it had a financially superior offer and accused Transatlantic's board of entrenching itself instead of negotiating. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

KGO Television in San Francisco reports that the ''Jeopardy!'' host Alex Trebek appeared Wednesday at the National Geographic World Championship on crutches, having torn his Achilles tendon earlier that morning when he chased after a burglar who broke into his room and tried to steal cash and other items from him. (The suspect, a 56-year-old woman, was arrested and charged with felony burglary and possession of stolen property.) While the alleged crime and Mr. Trebek's injuries are no laughing matter, it seems impossible to talk about the incident without resorting to terrible, ''Jeopardy!''-inspired jokes. So with respect to Mr. Trebek, whom we wish a speedy recovery, let's put 60 seconds on the proverbial clock and see how many we can come up with, shall we?-''I'll take unexpectedly resilient game-show hosts for $600, Alex.''-''What is...the most humiliating way that an attempted robbery could possibly be thwarted?''-''If you think that was tough, you should see what Mr. Trebek does to the contestants who don't phrase their responses in the form of a question.''-''Mr. Trebek's wardrobe furnished by Botany 500. The suspect's wardrobe soon to be furnished by the California Department of Corrections and Rehabilitation.''-''She must have thought she broke into Bob Barker's room, because someone just got spayed or neutered.''-''Daily Double!'' (O.K., we couldn't come up with one for Daily Double.)-''Police said that a second suspect, the noted Scottish actor Sean Connery, remained at large.''-Did you know that the ''Jeopardy!'' ''Think!'' music was originally composed by the game show's creator, Merv Griffin, as a lullaby for his son, Tony? Pretty cool, right?-''You don't get to come back tomorrow. You don't even get a lousy copy of our home game. You're a complete loser.'' (Thanks for that one to Don Pardo and Weird Al Yankovic.)And finally:-''Let's hope the suspect isn't tried twice for this crime, because that would be...double jeopardy.''

REINWALD--Charles Anthony Age 85, passed away due to prostate cancer June 2, 2011. Charles lived in Scarsdale NY from 1964-2004, and then in Tequesta, Florida. Charles was born in 1925, in Flushing Queens, New York to the late Charles Anthony Reinwald, Sr. and Estella Mary Brake Reinwald. He leaves his wife of 49 years, Anne, and three children: Charles, Jr. and his wife Sarah, Lisa Silverman and her husband Robert, and Andrea Dabbar and her husband Paul, and a sister, Shirley R. Johnson, and five grandchildren: Andrew, David and Samantha Silverman, and William and Katherine Dabbar. Charles graduated Yale Univ. in 1946 from Navy officer training program, attending during World War II, and received a degree in history. He received a law degree from NYU Law School in 1949. He was an attorney with Allstate Insurance Co. When both he and his wife were diagnosed with cancer in 1999, he founded the Cancer Cure Coalition, dedicated to the cure and prevention of cancer. The coalition made efforts in patient advocacy including hosting a conference, and sponsored journalistic research. He continued his work with stock investing, surveying new cancer treatments and working on a book on cancer treatments, and managing the Cancer Cure Coalition as long as his health permitted. He participated in in local government and organizations including the Scarsdale American Legion, and the Masons. He participated in chess clubs and tournaments and attained the rank of chess master. He was an avid reader with broad interests. He occasionally attended meetings of the Religious Society of Friends. Charles is remembered as caring, genuine, and brilliant. He always had a smile and a story to tell.

KELTY--Alfred J.,August 24, 1935 to July 27, 2011. Beloved husband to his wife of 52 years, Anne, and father to Susan (Charles) Law, Carol (Doug) Moses, Eileen (Colin) O'Neill, John (Daria) Kelty and Meg (Brian) Lawler. A graduate of Fordham Prep, he received a BA from Fordham University and an MBA from Iona College. Following college, Al served 5 years as a US Naval Aviator, and retired from Nynex in 1992. Al is also survived by 14 grandchildren. Calling Hours at Fred H. McGrath Funeral Home, Bronxville on Friday, 2-4 and 6-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joseph's Church, Bronxville, Saturday, 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations to Calvary Hospital.

WOODSTOCK, N.Y. -- At the age of 7, he was deemed to be the 17th reincarnation of the Karmapa -- one of the most revered figures in Tibetan Buddhism -- and whisked from the yak-hair tent of his nomad family in the Himalayas to be groomed in a monastery for leadership. Now 26, his mere appearance on the stage alongside the Dalai Lama at a major ceremony in Washington this month sent a flutter of excitement through the Tibetans in the crowd. Here was more evidence to them that the Dalai Lama had taken the young Karmapa under his wing, serving as teacher and father figure in India, where both live in exile, because China claims sovereignty over Tibet.

New York City has reached an agreement with animal-advocacy groups under which it will avoid having to build full-time shelters in Queens and the Bronx, but will step up its efforts to sterilize feral cats and to require owners to spay or neuter free-roaming cats. RYAN--Dr. Douglas Thomas. Dr. Douglas Thomas Ryan was born on June 12, 1921 in Brooklyn, NY and passed away on July 27, 2011 at the age of 90. Growing up he went to PS10 in Brooklyn and the Arts Students League. After serving in the Army during WWII, Douglas went to work for Bendix Corporation and then moved to Palm Beach, Florida and went to work for Palm Beach International Airport. There, he attended Palm Beach Junior College and Florida Atlantic University. After moving from Florida to Mississippi, Douglas obtained his doctorate degree from Southern Mississippi College and began his career as a Professor for numerous colleges in Mississippi. He is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Margaret W. Ryan; daughter, Dr. Margaret R. Morris; son, Douglas P. Ryan and wife Sandra; grandchildren, Donald T. Kimbrough and Kitty Morris-Carter; sister-in-law, Irene Ryan and numerous other loving family members and friends. A visitation will be held from 6:00-8:00pm at Oak Hills Mortuary on Monday, August 1, 2011. A graveside service will be held at 1:30pm on Tuesday, August 2, 2011 at Ft. Sam Houston National Cemetery. Oak Hills Mortuary 8332 Fredericksburg Rd. San Antonio, TX, 78229. 210-616-0510

ALTMAN--R. Peter, MD. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend and colleague Dr. R. Peter Altman, the Rudolph N. Schullinger Professor Emeritus of Pediatric Surgery (in Surgery and Pediatrics) at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. A beloved member of the New York-Presbyterian/ Columbia community for more than thirty years, Dr. Altman made many important contributions to the care of infants and children. During his extraordinary career, he held several leadership positions, including Physician-in-Chief for the New York-Presbyterian Children's Health System and Surgeon-in-Chief at Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital. He played a major role in the development of Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital, from conceptualization to completion and beyond. A distinguished clinician and researcher, he introduced a surgical technique to correct the fatal congenital liver condition biliary atresia, helping numerous children live into adulthood. A leader in pediatric surgical education, he mentored scores of fellows who went on to have distinguished careers. We remember Dr. Altman for his wry wit and his serious commitment to helping children and their families. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his wife, Hanna; sons Robert and James; four grandchildren; sister, Linda; and the entire Altman family. Lee Goldman, M.D. Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia University Medical Center Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO Steven J. Corwin, M.D. Executive Vice President and COO Robert E. Kelly, M.D. Group Senior Vice President NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital Craig R. Smith, M.D. Chair, Department of Surgery Lawrence R. Stanberry, M.D. Chair, Department of Pediatrics Charles L.H. Stolar, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief, Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital

A stream of hospital administrators, a state assemblyman, doctors and advocates for immigrants took the microphone at a sometimes raucous hearing in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday to plead with state officials not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough. The advocates identified at least 5 of the 17 hospitals in the borough -- those serving some of Brooklyn's poorest patients -- that they believe are endangered: Interfaith Medical Center, Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center, Brooklyn Hospital Center, Wyckoff Heights Medical Center and Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center.

ALTMAN--R. Peter, M.D. On behalf of those trainees fortunate to have been educated in pediatric surgery by Peter, on behalf of those children and families fortunate to have been cared for by Peter, on behalf of those pediatric surgeons fortunate to have been mentored by Peter, and on behalf of those fortunate to have smiled at his wry humor, we all mourn this loss. The gifts he gave us live forever. Our deepest condolences to Hanna, Robbie, Jimmie, Linda and all the grandchildren. Charles Stolar, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital, Columbia University Medical Center

I’m actually off on vacation in Ashland, Oregon, enjoying the Oregon Shakespeare Festival with my family, and I hadn’t intended to write a column for Sunday. But then I saw that John Stott had died, and I didn’t want to miss the chance to write about him and evangelicals more broadly — hence my Sunday column on the subject. We in the op-ed world don’t write about religion perhaps as much as we should: it’s a huge force shaping society and policy, and yet rarely makes the op-ed pages. And evangelicals in particular, especially serious ones, tend to be neglected since there are so few evangelicals in major news organizations. About one-third of America is evangelical, yet you’d be hard pressed to find many (with the exception of black evangelicals, whose politics are very different from white evangelicals) in leading news organizations.

Orlowska--Jadwiga Stanislawa M.D.,died on July 26, 2011, at the age of 84 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. She was born in Stary Sacz, Poland to Antoni and Kunegunda (Pasiut) Uczkiewicz. After surviving World War II, she enrolled at the Wroclaw Medical University in Wroclaw, Poland, where she met her future husband, Marian Orlowski, a Holocaust survivor, during a class on anatomy. They shared a love of hiking in the Tatra Mountains with their friends, and defied convention by marrying despite being of different faiths. When they completed their degrees they both started on careers in medical research, but Jadwiga put hers on hold to raise their son, Robert. The family immigrated to America, where Jadwiga cried at her first sight of a supermarket after having endured years of hardship under Communist rule. Later, she returned to a medical career by finishing her training in physical medicine and rehabilitation at Mount Sinai in New York. She expressed her passion for humanity by caring for patients with spinal cord injuries before retiring. This devotion was also evident in her care for Marian after he fell ill from a form of Alzheimer dementia, which allowed him to die with dignity at home on July 16, 2009. Jadwiga loved and tended all manner of living things, including her orchids, all animals, and especially her family and the people around her, whom she would feed with old-world dishes and baked goods that were unrivaled by any. Many of her last months were spent doing the same for Robert and his wife Carol, and their four-legged child Lucy. She is survived by her son Robert and daughter-in-law Carol of Bellaire, Texas, and her sister-in-law Sabina Sass of New York, New York. A viewing will be held at Walkers Funeral Home (120 West Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27516, 919-942-3861) on Sunday, July 31st, from 3:00-5:00pm. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at St. Thomas More (940 Carmichael Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27514, 919-942-1040) on Monday, August 1st, 2011, at 11:00am, followed by a reception. Memorial donations may be made to MD Anderson Cancer Center, The Marian and Jadwiga Orlowski Endowment Lectureship (P.O. Box 4486, Houston, TX 77210-4486, or 1-800-525-5841 or www.mdanderson.org/gifts).

Have any gift cards from Borders stashed away in your desk? You might want to fish them out and buy some books with them - sooner rather than later. Borders began liquidating on Friday, and is expected to shut down its remaining 399 stores by September. The company says it is honoring gift cards.

ALTMAN--R. Peter, MD. The Columbia University Department of Surgery mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Dr. R. Peter Altman, who in 1980 assumed the position as Professor of Surgery of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, and as the Surgeon-in-Chief of the Babies & Children's Hospital of New York (now Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital of NewYork-Presbyterian/ Columbia). Throughout his career, Dr. Altman was committed to improving and advancing the surgical care of infants and children. He wrote extensively for journals and textbooks, and was a visiting professor of pediatric surgery world-wide. His scientific interests centered on hepatobiliary diseases, pediatric surgical oncology, and surgical education. He served as President of the American Pediatric Surgical Association, was a member of the Grant Review Committee of the National Institutes of Health, and consultant to the American Board of Surgery. He was a member of the Graduate Education Committee of the American College of Surgeons and served on the Residency Review Committee for Surgery. Under his guidance more than 40 pediatric surgeons were trained, of whom many are now division chiefs and chairmen. He will be best remembered for the children and families who benefited from his advocacy and care. His successor, Dr. Charles Stolar, described Dr. Altman as one of the most influential pediatric surgeons in modern times. Dr. Stolar states, "He was the consummate mentor, teacher, and friend." Our condolences to his loving wife, Hanna, and extended family. Craig R. Smith, MD, Chairman Columbia University Department of Surgery NewYork-Presbyterian/ Columbia University MedicalCenter

Here are the kinds of questions that keep ''Game of Thrones'' fans up at night. (You might want to have a pencil and paper handy for this one.) The first season of that Emmy-nominated HBO drama was, more or less, a straight adaptation of the George R. R. Martin fantasy novel ''A Game of Thrones,'' the first book in his ''Song of Ice and Fire'' series. To date, Mr. Martin has published four more books in his planned seven-book series: ''A Clash of Kings,'' ''A Storm of Swords,'' ''A Feast for Crows'' and, most recently, ''A Dance with Dragons.'' The elapsed time between ''Crows'' (released in 2005) and ''Dragons'' (released earlier this month) was nearly six years. Even if we allow that the television adaptations of some of these novels could require more than one season, is it possible that the ''Game of Thrones'' HBO series could run out of material before Mr. Martin has finished writing the books?

Folks, this may come as a surprise from a man who, in lieu of giving an acceptance speech at an awards show chose to recite a bit of verse from an obscure poet, but Mark Rylance, it seems, has done something eccentric. Mr. Rylance, who last month won a Tony Award for his portrayal of a hard-living quasi-mystical itinerant man in the Jez Butterworth play ''Jerusalem,'' has given away that trophy to a British man who helped inspire his performance. The Independent of London reported that the new owner of Mr. Rylance's Tony Award is Mickey Lay, a 71-year-old builder and resident of Pewsey, a village west of London which inspired the setting for ''Jerusalem,'' and with whom Mr. Rylance consulted in creating the character of Johnny ''Rooster'' Byron, the caravan-dwelling ex-daredevil at the heart of the play.

Nicholas Ray, the director of the 1955 film classic ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' was pretty much banished from Hollywood in the early 1960s as a result of his drug and alcohol addictions, and volatile temper. But his early work influenced a generation of filmmakers. Now his voluminous archives have been bought from his widow, Susan Ray, by the Harry Ransom Center, a humanities research library and museum at the University of Texas at Austin. The cache of original treatments, annotated scripts, photographs, journals, notes, video recordings and film includes 64 storyboards from ''Rebel Without a Cause,'' which starred James Dean, Sal Mineo and Natalie Wood. They show that Ray initially envisioned a different ending, in which Plato (Mineo) is shot from the top of a planetarium.

Linda Ronstadt is joining the music memoir club with her own book, ''Heart Like a Wheel,'' said her publisher, Simon & Schuster. The memoir, titled after her hit 1974 album, will focus on her long career, during which she has sold more than 100 million records. ''Few singers have been as wide-ranging or as distinctive in their artistry,'' Jonathan Karp, the publisher of Simon & Schuster, said in a statement. ''Linda Ronstadt has a singular voice, and that is true on the page as well.'' The book is tentatively scheduled for publication in 2013. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

Jerome Liebling, whose subtly powerful pictures and the lessons he drew from them influenced a generation of socially minded photographers and documentary filmmakers, died on Wednesday in Northampton, Mass. He was 87. His death was announced by Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., where he taught for more than two decades.

More than a week after a sewage discharge contaminated New York's waterways, city officials have finally told residents the magic words: Your rivers' fecal coliform readings have returned to acceptable levels. Closure notices and pollution advisories were lifted by Thursday night for four beaches: South Beach, Midland Beach and Cedar Grove Beach in Staten Island and Sea Gate Beach in Brooklyn.

An article last Saturday about the record-breaking heat referred incorrectly to sewage advisories at Midland Beach, on Staten Island. While several beachgoers said they did not see any advisories, the parks department put up about 40 signs by midafternoon.

The Australian cyclist Cadel Evans, fresh off of his first Tour de France victory, has confirmed that he will compete in the inaugural USA Pro Cycling Challenge in Colorado this month, the race's organizers said. Stacie Lange, a spokeswoman for the race, said there was ''a good chance'' that the other podium finishers at the Tour -- Andy and Frank Schleck -- would also compete.

ALTMAN--R. Peter. Pediatric Cancer Foundation mourns the loss of Dr. R. Peter Altman. In early 80s his work was the recipient of PCF support. Loved by all that knew him; particularly the children, many now adults and indebted to his interventions and work. Our condolences to his beloved wife, Hannah, and wonderful family.

ALTMAN--R. Peter, M.D. On behalf of those trainees fortunate to have been educated in pediatric surgery by Peter, on behalf of those children and families fortunate to have been cared for by Peter, on behalf of those pediatric surgeons fortunate to have been mentored by Peter, and on behalf of those fortunate to have smiled at his wry humor, we all mourn this loss. The gifts he gave us live forever. Our deepest condolences to Hanna, Robbie, Jimmie, Linda and all the grandchildren. Charles Stolar, M.D. Surgeon-in-Chief Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital, Columbia University Medical Center

HASSLER--Howard Edward. Dad, our lives parted too soon, but we are forever grateful for the times we shared, the many great things you taught us and for your love. We love you always. Susan, Barbara, Robert & Craig

RYAN--Dr. Douglas Thomas. Dr. Douglas Thomas Ryan was born on June 12, 1921 in Brooklyn, NY and passed away on July 27, 2011 at the age of 90. Growing up he went to PS10 in Brooklyn and the Arts Students League. After serving in the Army during WWII, Douglas went to work for Bendix Corporation and then moved to Palm Beach, Florida and went to work for Palm Beach International Airport. There, he attended Palm Beach Junior College and Florida Atlantic University. After moving from Florida to Mississippi, Douglas obtained his doctorate degree from Southern Mississippi College and began his career as a Professor for numerous colleges in Mississippi. He is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Margaret W. Ryan; daughter, Dr. Margaret R. Morris; son, Douglas P. Ryan and wife Sandra; grandchildren, Donald T. Kimbrough and Kitty Morris-Carter; sister-in-law, Irene Ryan and numerous other loving family members and friends. A visitation will be held from 6:00-8:00pm at Oak Hills Mortuary on Monday, August 1, 2011. A graveside service will be held at 1:30pm on Tuesday, August 2, 2011 at Ft. Sam Houston National Cemetery. Oak Hills Mortuary 8332 Fredericksburg Rd. San Antonio, TX, 78229. 210-616-0510

Merck will cut about 13,000 jobs by the end of 2015, in addition to the 20,000 jobs it has shed since a merger in 2009, the pharmaceutical company announced Friday in its quarterly earnings report. The cutbacks continue a decade-long trend in the pharmaceutical industry of cutting employment to maintain profits in the face of increasing competition from low-price generics.

An article on Friday about the man deemed to be the 17th reincarnation of the Karmapa, one of the most revered figures in Tibetan Buddhism, gave the incorrect context for a quotation by Robert J. Barnett, director of the Modern Tibetan Studies Program at Columbia University. When he spoke of the ''birther controversy'' involving President Obama, he was referring to continuing accusations that the Karmapa, Ogyen Trinley Dorje, is a Chinese spy. Mr. Barnett did not compare the unending birther debate to another controversy in which the Karmapa's rival, Trinley Thaye Dorje, claims to be the 17th reincarnation.

Can data about electronic money transfers be used to help create credit scores for people who rely on them? That's the subject of a study to be undertaken by the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The agency, which officially opened for business on July 21, was directed to look into the matter by the Dodd-Frank financial reform law. The new agency is also reviewing ways to provide clearer disclosure of the exchange rates and fees charged for the transfers, which can be substantial - up to 13 percent of amounts up to $200, according to a preliminary report from the agency.

An article in some editions on Friday about a hearing in Brooklyn at which hospital administrators and others urged members of the state's Medicaid Redesign Team not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough misstated the operating margin -- or net revenues -- for Lutheran Medical Center, based on a miscalculation by the state. It is 1 percent, not negative 8 percent.

The world swimming championships had a second dead heat for a gold medal Friday, with Jeanette Ottesen and Aliaksandra Herasimenia finishing in 53.45 seconds in the women's 100 freestyle. In the men's 100 backstroke Tuesday, Camille Lacourt and Jeremy Stravius of France finished in a dead heat. Britta Steffen of Germany, the defending champion and world-record holder in the women's 100, dropped out of any remaining races after finishing 16th Thursday in morning heats.

A former portfolio manager at SAC Capital Advisors was sentenced to two and a half years in prison on Friday after he pleaded guilty in April to insider trading. The manager, Donald Longueuil, 35, was swept up in the federal government's latest front in its crackdown on insider trading on Wall Street, which has focused on so-called expert networks. Expert networks are essentially matchmakers, connecting hedge fund managers with industry executives who offer insights about their businesses.

STRATFORD-UPON-AVON, England -- Christian and Jew, man and woman, master and servant: they're all ugly Americans in the Royal Shakespeare Company's popular new version of ''The Merchant of Venice.'' Everyone in Rupert Goold's flash-filled production, at the Royal Shakespeare Theater in Stratford-upon-Avon, sounds like a wise guy or a redneck, or some squawking combination of the two. On occasion, you can hear the bardic tones of classically trained British actors slipping out, but they are usually soon quashed by less mellifluous noises.

8 P.M. (HBO) THE TOWN (2010) Ben Affleck, above with Blake Lively, crops his hair and drops his R's in this crime drama, which he directed, wrote (with Peter Craig and Aaron Stockard) and stars in. He plays Doug MacRay, a bank robber from the Charlestown section of Boston who wants nothing more than to get out of the game -- if only his best friend, Jim (Jeremy Renner), who is also his surrogate brother and stickup partner, would let him. With a father (Chris Cooper) serving a life sentence in the penitentiary, Doug has added incentive. But then a heist goes wrong, and a young bank teller (Rebecca Hall) is taken hostage. Jim wants to deal with her before she talks to the law. Instead, after she is freed, Doug starts dating her. The sequence in which the crew knocks over the bank, ''like most of the other action set pieces in the film, is lean, brutal and efficient, and evidence of Mr. Affleck's skill and self-confidence as a director,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. The romantic development, on the other hand, ''is perhaps meant to heighten the emotional intensity of his predicament but instead disrupts the film's tough mood with sentimental preposterousness.'' Still, ''the performances in 'The Town' are strong enough to make it watchable, and the sense of place -- of topography and architecture, if not of actual social life -- is vivid and enjoyable. A climactic caper at Fenway Park blows holes in the film's narrative and emotional credibility, but it is fast and exciting all the same, perhaps especially for Yankees fans. Otherwise, the main attraction is the blaring music of those accents. It's a lark, a spark, a walk in the park.'' 10 A.M. The 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks will be a grand but subdued affair in New York City that will involve two presidents, poetry readings and visits by victims' family members to the new memorial, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said Friday. President Obama and his predecessor, former President George W. Bush, will attend, Mr. Bloomberg said in an appearance on WOR-AM (710). Former Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who were in office during the attacks, will participate, as will Mr. Bloomberg, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey.

Earlier this week our colleague Joe Sharkey reported on a lapse in federal airfare taxes. Congress failed last week to authorize airlines to continue to collect taxes on domestic and international flights. In theory, that would mean lower fares. But most airlines decided instead to raise their ticket prices by about the amount of the taxes. The expiration of the tax, though, leaves some fliers in an unusual situation: they paid taxes on tickets bought before the tax lapsed on Saturday at 12:01 a.m. for travel during the tax expiration period. Are they entitled to a refund?

The New York Film Festival has announced its opening-night selection, but its director is not likely to walk the red carpet. Jodie Foster, Kate Winslet, Christoph Waltz and John C. Reilly star.
