I have always been a better reader than athlete, and as a teenager, I imagined that I could improve my golf game just from studying a book, “Five Lessons: The Modern Fundamentals of Golf,” by Ben Hogan. It took me years, during which I may have done myself permanent damage, before I realized that the Hogan swing, with its emphasis on pronation (whatever that is) and rapidly unwinding the hips, only makes sense if you’re Ben Hogan. If you’re me — and if you’re you, probably — the Hogan swing works about as well as a car engine that has thrown a rod.

Republicans began the Civil War as the party of Union, not the party of Freedom. They did not become the celebrated destroyers of slavery until almost two years into the war, with the Emancipation Proclamation, issued Jan. 1, 1863. But during the summer of 1861 the direction of change was unmistakable, as Republicans took the first, crucial steps in a mounting attack on the South’s “peculiar institution.” Long-held beliefs about the immorality of slavery combined with the challenges posed by an escalating conflict, explain the evolving outlook of the Republicans.

Administrivial Tournament “Save the Date” Alert! Will Shortz has announced the date of the 2011 Westchester Crossword Puzzle Tournament, the proceeds of which benefit the Pleasantville Fund for Learning. Save Oct. 21 (exact starting time to be determined) if you will be in the area and would like to have a fun, low-key tournament experience, meet some of your favorite constructors and help raise money for a great cause. Plus, if history holds, the desserts provided are not to be believed. The location will be Will’s brand-new table tennis club — the Westchester Table Tennis Center, located at 175 Tompkins Ave., in Pleasantville, N.Y. It’s three and a half blocks from the Pleasantville train station on MetroNorth. I’m told that the space is twice as large as the former location, which should nicely accommodate the growing legions of tournament fans, and you can even arrive early and play some table tennis! You can read more about the club here, and registration for the tournament is accepted at the door.

A new museum honoring Arnold Schwarzenegger, the bodybuilder, movie star and former California governor, opened on Saturday in the Austrian village where he was born, Thal, near Graz, to coincide with his 64th birthday. The museum, located in the house where Mr. Schwarzenegger lived from birth until he departed in 1966 for England and then the United States, clearly has his blessing: exhibits include not only his childhood bed and first weight-lifting equipment but also a sword from “Conan the Barbarian,” memorabilia from the “Terminator” movies and a copy of the desk he used as governor. Despite the recent blows to Mr. Schwarzenegger’s image in the United States with his disclosure that he fathered a child out of wedlock, “his career was so exciting and so special and I think the Austrian people are really proud” of him, Helga Forstner, the museum coordinator, told the BBC.

Smurfs humiliated a cluster of Hollywood’s heaviest weights at the weekend box office. Analysts had predicted that “Cowboys & Aliens” — starring Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford, directed by Jon Favreau (“Iron Man”) and produced by Brian Grazer and Steven Spielberg — would easily dominate ticket sales. Instead, it was a photo finish with “The Smurfs,” a cartoon-live action hybrid. Both films took in an estimated $36.2 million at North American theaters, as “The Smurfs” outperformed expectations, and “Cowboys & Aliens” failed to capture young men in significant numbers.

FULLER--Blair Fairchild, passed away in Petaluma, California, on July 23rd at the age of 84. A Paris Review editor since shortly after the publication's founding, and co-founder of the Squaw Valley Community of Writers, Blair made his home in San Francisco in the early 1960s when he took up a teaching position in Stanford's Creative Writing Department. Still, his family and literary roots remained in New York. He was born to sculptor Jane Sage White Fuller and architect Charles Fairchild Fuller in Bedford, NY on January 18, 1927, and his stepfather was Harper and Row publisher Cass Canfield. His novels and short stories were shaped by his experiences working for Texaco in West Africa in the 1950s, his World War II service in the U.S. Navy, his year in Algeria as a Fulbright Professor. His recent work consisted in short personal memoirs, the last of which - "An Evening with J.D. Salinger" appeared on the Paris Review blog in February. Blair is survived by his wife, Arlene Hogan Fuller; his sisters, Sage Fuller Cowles and Jill Fuller Fox; his stepbrother, Cass Canfield Jr.; and his children from earlier marriages: Maria Gubiena Fuller, Anthony Blair Fuller, and Diana Whitney Fuller.

PARIS -- Long disgruntled European soccer clubs are mounting a muscular new challenge to FIFA, the international soccer federation, by pressing a dispute over finances and decision-making into the political arena, where the powerful body will face scrutiny of its management. Poland, which holds the rotating presidency of the European Union, said on Friday that sports ministers from 27 nations who are due to meet in October will debate the issue of ''good governance,'' a theme provoked by ongoing corruption allegations involving FIFA.

Orlowska--Jadwiga Stanislawa M.D.,died on July 26, 2011, at the age of 84 in Chapel Hill, North Carolina. She was born in Stary Sacz, Poland to Antoni and Kunegunda (Pasiut) Uczkiewicz. After surviving World War II, she enrolled at the Wroclaw Medical University in Wroclaw, Poland, where she met her future husband, Marian Orlowski, a Holocaust survivor, during a class on anatomy. They shared a love of hiking in the Tatra Mountains with their friends, and defied convention by marrying despite being of different faiths. When they completed their degrees they both started on careers in medical research, but Jadwiga put hers on hold to raise their son, Robert. The family immigrated to America, where Jadwiga cried at her first sight of a supermarket after having endured years of hardship under Communist rule. Later, she returned to a medical career by finishing her training in physical medicine and rehabilitation at Mount Sinai in New York. She expressed her passion for humanity by caring for patients with spinal cord injuries before retiring. This devotion was also evident in her care for Marian after he fell ill from a form of Alzheimer dementia, which allowed him to die with dignity at home on July 16, 2009. Jadwiga loved and tended all manner of living things, including her orchids, all animals, and especially her family and the people around her, whom she would feed with old-world dishes and baked goods that were unrivaled by any. Many of her last months were spent doing the same for Robert and his wife Carol, and their four-legged child Lucy. She is survived by her son Robert and daughter-in-law Carol of Bellaire, Texas, and her sister-in-law Sabina Sass of New York, New York. A viewing will be held at Walkers Funeral Home (120 West Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27516, 919-942-3861) on Sunday, July 31st, from 3:00-5:00pm. A memorial service to celebrate her life will be held at St. Thomas More (940 Carmichael Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27514, 919-942-1040) on Monday, August 1st, 2011, at 11:00am, followed by a reception. Memorial donations may be made to MD Anderson Cancer Center, The Marian and Jadwiga Orlowski Endowment Lectureship (P.O. Box 4486, Houston, TX 77210-4486, or 1-800-525-5841 or www.mdanderson.org/gifts).

An article on July 17about Representative KevinMcCarthy, the House majoritywhip, misstated the level of cutsin government spending relativeto gross domestic product asproposed in the legislation passedby the House of Representativesin April. It would have shrunk thepercentage of federal nonsecuritydiscretionary spending, notthe percentage of overall federalgovernment spending, to pre-Great Depression levels.

A Florida judge on July 20 said Ford misled the court and federal safety investigators by concealing documents in a case decided in Ford's favor in 2010. According to the judge, the documents proved that unintended acceleration in certain vehicles could have been caused by electromagnetic interference with those vehicles' cruise control systems. There was ''clear and convincing evidence'' that Ford engaged in ''misconduct'' in an attempt to keep information from the jury and influence the outcome of last year's trial, wrote Judge William T. Swigert of the Circuit Court of the Fifth Judicial Circuit for Sumter County.

Here's a reader's comment about Dave Kehr's Video column about the 1968 movie ''Skidoo,'' a psychedelic generation-gap comedy by Otto Preminger that has just been released on DVD. Groucho Marx played God in the film. ''I was delighted that Mr. Kehr reviewed 'Skidoo,' one of my favorite wannabe countercultural films of the late 1960s. But I'd like to point out that, contrary to conventional Hollywood practices then, Preminger cast the path-breaking African-American fashion model Donyale Luna as God's mistress, with no references whatsoever to her race. Seeing the angular Luna (in a part originally written for Faye Dunaway) flirt and more with Groucho, John Phillip Law, Frankie Avalon and Cesar Romero was clearly part of Preminger's subliminal 'romantic revolt' in the film.''

The Ghost Hunter has Louis Vuitton floor mats, and this I did not expect. He arrives at my building in a customized white Mitsubishi Eclipse with a sound system that's Madison-Square-Garden-loud and a TV hidden in the dash. It's less Ghostmobile, more getaway car. I'd forgotten that, esoteric hobbies aside, the Ghost Hunter was born and raised in Brooklyn. And like a lot of guys from Bergen Beach, he loves his car. It is 10:07 p.m. and we are barreling across the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to Staten Island. The sky above is as black as devil's food cake. It's also the Fourth of July, which says a lot about our respective social lives, the Ghost Hunter's and mine.

Michael Phelps won his third gold medal of the swimming world championships Saturday in Shanghai, breezing to a victory in the 100-meter butterfly in 50.71 seconds. So far, Phelps has three golds, two silvers and a bronze with one more event to go -- the 4x100 medley relay Sunday, the final night of competition. ''In all, it's been an O.K. week,'' Phelps said. Melissa Franklin, 16, of the United States continued a breakout performance. She won the 200 backstroke, the first major individual gold of her career, and swam the anchor leg as the United States won the gold medal in the 4x100 medley relay for the first time since 1998. Franklin has three golds and five medals in all. ''I totally made sure I came in here and left everything in the pool, and I did,'' Franklin said. ''I'm thrilled.''

A picture caption on July 17 with an article about Gerard Mortier, artistic director of the Teatro Real in Madrid, misidentified one of the performers in the six-hour opera he staged in a sports arena outside the city. And a correction in this space last Sunday misspelled part of the name of the opera. It was Alejandro Marco-Buhrmester -- not Wiard Witholt -- who performed in ''St. François d'Assise,'' not ''St. Françoise d'Assise.''

IN the summer of 1909, a year after the giant house on Westerleigh Road in Purchase, N.Y., was built, it was described by The New York Times as ''one of the finest country mansions in Westchester County.'' Now, 102 years later, the mansion, which had been on the market for the last six years, is headed for the auction block.

MARMOREK--Gertrude, age 97, on July 28th. She was the devoted mother of Lynne Brody and Kay Marmorek, dear sister of Greta Steiner, adored grandmother of Loren Brody and Nicole Fiftal and great-grandmother of Eliana and Ethan Brody. Service Sunday, July 31, 10:00am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week: Helen Schulman on her novel ''This Beautiful Life''; Ben Zimmer on how computers can expose the jargon of the novel; Julie Bosman with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-/seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. ExcerptsSelections from ''Jamrach's Menagerie,'' by Carol Birch; ''True Things About Me,'' by Deborah Kay Davies; and other books.

AS the curator of the New York Botanic Garden Peggy Rockefeller Rose Garden, Peter Kukielski stops and smells the roses on a regular basis: all 4,000 of the 91 varieties. In honor of rose season at the garden, which started last month and goes through October, The Moment asked him to weigh in on a favorite imposter, the Shakespeare in Love fragrance from A Dozen Roses. ''A lot of David Austin English roses today are bred for scent,'' Mr. Kukielski said. ''I could see this being one of those roses. It's very sweet. It is much more in your face. It has the Damask essence with a combination of some really nice fruity smells, which I mentioned before and which again in my mind are in the rose family. I like the Shakespeare scent because it allows me to remember all of the roses I've smelled in my career.'' It's $95 for 3.4 ounces at select Neiman Marcus locations. HOLLY SIEGEL

A chart last Sunday comparing admissions statistics for about four dozen M.B.A. programs included incorrect costs from George Washington University for its program's annual tuition and fees. One year is $37, 278 -- not $74,730, which is the cost of the entire program.

KNAPP--Thomas Paton, II, 90, died July 24, 2011 at VNA Hospice House, Vero Beach. He was born in Blue Point, New York and lived in Vero Beach for 33 years, coming from Remsenburg, New York. Tom served as a Lieutenant in the US Navy during World War II. He earned his undergraduate degree from Princeton University and his master's degree from Columbia University. He was a Stock Analyst and Partner with Tweedy, Browne Corporation from 1957-1989. Tom was a member of The Sayville Yacht Club, Princeton Club in Manhattan, Quantuck Beach Club Westhampton Beach, New York, Westhampton Yacht Club, John's Island Club, Grand Harbor Club, Moorings Club and Quail River Club. Survivors include his wife of 38 years Virginia M. Knapp of Vero Beach, Florida and Remsenburg, New York, sons, Gideon Knapp (Sherry), Jonathan Knapp (Debbie), Shepard Knapp, all of Vero Beach, Florida, David Schmitt of Colorado Springs, CO, daughters, Jane Whelhan (Christopher) of The United Kingdom, Jessie Knapp Mendelsohn (Mark) of Vero Beach, Margie Knapp of Vero Beach, step-sons Russell (Christine) Weisenbacher of Manorville, New York and Justin Weisenbacher of Jupiter Island, Florida as well as many grandchildren and many great-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to The Humanists of The Treasure Coast, 1550 NE Ocean Blvd. Suite F301 Stuart, FL. 34996 or VNA Hospice, 1110 35th Lane Vero Beach, Florida 32960. Tom was interred at John's Island Cemetery, Vero Beach, Florida surrounded by his immediate family. Services by Strunk Funeral Home and Crematory Vero Beach, Florida.
An article last Sunday about Susan Holland, a wedding planner, reversed the given and middle names of one of her clients. She is Bryce Dallas Howard.
ADAMS--Bret. Always together side by side. P

ALTMAN--Dr. R. Peter, on July 27, 2011. Loving Husband of Hanna. Brother of Linda Levine, spectacular father of Jimmy and Robby. Grandfather of Spencer, Charlotte, Madeline and Kate. Father-in-law of Rikki and Ali. Funeral Service Monday, 10:15am at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd St.

IS there a creature as imaginative or as indefatigable as the city child in search of a place to play? New York would seem to have been designed for everything but youthful frolic. And, to be sure, it can hold great perils. Yet from generation to generation, ever since children sang ''Ring Around the Rosie'' and ''London Bridge Is Falling Down,'' the sidewalks of New York have yielded to youngsters' inexhaustible need to frisk, exult, screech, plot and plunge.

ROET--Harold David, 84, on July 26, 2011 in Denver, CO. Hal was a structural engineer, finishing has career as a vice president at Leslie E. Robertson Associates, and retired in 1992. He worked on the following buildings: US Steel Building, Pittsburgh; Insurance Company of North America, Philadelphia; World Trade Center, New York; Bank of Oklahoma Tower, Tulsa; AT&T Building, New York, PPG Industries, Pittsburgh; and the Bank of China Tower, Hong Kong. Hal's greatest personal joy was reading the New York Times everyday of his life. He read it on the subway, he read it on the commuter train, and he read it at home. This continued in Colorado where the paper is still delivered to us daily. He once said to me that he wouldn't mind dying if the subscription would continue into posterity. He is survived by his wife, Marian, their three children, Jeff and his wife Jeanette, Dan and his wife Beverly, and Emily and her husband Michael, six grandchildren, Glenn and his wife Christine, Pamela, James, Adam, Nissa, and Jordana, and his sister, Sylvia Shunfenthal and her family. For those who remember Hal and wish to honor him, the family requests memorial gifts to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation.
PARNES--Sidmore. Forever Loved. David Schneider

In 1965, in an impoverished rural county in the Mississippi Delta, the pioneering physician Jack Geiger helped found one of the nation's first community health centers. Many of the children Geiger treated were seriously malnourished, so he began writing ''prescriptions'' for food - stipulating quantities of milk, vegetables, meat, and fruit that could be ''filled'' at grocery stores, which were instructed to send the bills to the health center, where they were paid out of the pharmacy budget. When word of this reached the Office of Economic Opportunity in Washington, which financed the center, an official was dispatched to Mississippi to reprimand Geiger and make sure he understood that the center's money could be used only for medical purposes. Geiger replied: ''The last time I looked in my textbooks, the specific therapy for malnutrition was food.'' The official had nothing to say and returned to Washington.In some ways, the United States has come a long way since Lyndon Johnson declared the ''war on poverty.'' But in others, we're still at square one. We now have a variety of federally-supported nutrition programs, but the health care system remains senselessly disconnected from the ''social determinants of health.'' In this regard, the United States has fallen behind the rest of the world. If a politician in India announced a public health plan that neglected malnutrition, he would be ridiculed. Here, leaders make this kind of omission all the time. Almost all of the debate about the 2010 Affordable Care Act was consumed with questions about health care access and quality. But if we really want to improve the health of millions of people, we have to address the conditions that make them sick. One of the most impressive organizations in the country that is developing an approach to do this is Health Leads, which mobilizes and trains about 1000 volunteers each year who staff resource desks located in the waiting rooms of 23 hospital clinics or health centers in Baltimore, Boston, Chicago, New York, Providence, R.I., and Washington. At these sites, doctors now regularly ''prescribe'' a wide range of basic resources - like food assistance, housing improvements, or heating fuel subsidies - which Health Leads' volunteers ''fill'' - applying their problem solving skills (and tenacity) to identify resources anywhere they may be available.

FRANKFURTBMW'S designers and engineers have long vowed that the company's eventual battery-powered cars would not be geekmobiles but true BMWs, with all the zip, handling and style that the German automaker is known for. Norbert Reithofer, the chief executive, is fond of saying that an environmentally friendly auto should not be ''a vow of poverty on wheels.'' BMW fans can soon decide for themselves whether the company has delivered on its promise. On Friday in Frankfurt, BMW unveiled working prototypes of the i8, a plug-in hybrid sport coupe that will carry a six-figure price tag, and the i3, a four-seat battery-powered compact car aimed at a wider market.

YOU can learn a lot about Dalston, a district in East London, from the storefront for the Mr. Bagel restaurant. On one side, a bright orange sign announces, ''We do Indian and Caribbean food.'' Opposite, Arabic script spells out the word ''halal.'' A traditionally Jewish area, this remote pocket of East London has, in recent years, begun absorbing immigrants from around the globe, transforming it into a multiethnic working-class enclave. Now, thanks in part to the recent extension of the London Overground rail lines -- which added two new stations in the formerly hard-to-reach neighborhood -- Dalston is welcoming its latest wave of new arrivals: young creative types and self-styled bohemians in search of cheap rents and a lively vibe. The result is a new crop of cafes, bars and boutiques that are worth a visit. SETH SHERWOOD

When the Rail Europe app for the iPhone and iPod Touch was announced, the idea of booking rail tickets on the fly seemed a welcome addition to the growing library of travel apps. This free app, aimed at North American travelers, allows users to see train schedules, check prices and book tickets. For those traveling from stations that offer e-tickets, tickets can be purchased in advance or on the day of travel. Travelers can print tickets at home or pick them up at a kiosk at the train station.

SUSPICIOUS fires, pregnant pauses and empty streets dominate Gregory Crewdson's photographs, which expose the dark side of Norman Rockwell's America to a ''Twilight Zone'' glow. These images are the centerpiece of ''In a Lonely Place'' (Abrams; $40), a new book that for the first time binds three of the artist's most hallucinogenic series in an evocative album format. The pictures in ''Beneath the Roses'' (2003-8) show the influence of Edward Hopper and David Lynch on Mr. Crewdson's approach to psychological menace. Each suggests a crime scene in which estranged, befuddled or naked suburbanites figure as the locus of paranormal events. The documentary, black-and-white images in ''Sanctuary'' (2009), shot in the abandoned back lots of the Cinecittà film studio in Rome, portray a landscape of neglect as haunted by its neo-realist past. And no less fraught is the nocturnal ''Fireflies'' (1996), although this time the demons are mating Tinker Bells fighting the darkness. LINDA YABLONSKY

CRISCIONE--Dr. Joseph P.,of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of the Bronx, died peacefully on July 26, surrounded by his beloved wife Joan, and his adoring daughters Joanie and Jeanne. He is survived by his son-in-laws Arthur Cooper and Dean Brizel and his loving grandchildren Alex and Danielle. Forever missed and eternally loved.

Eduardo Perez had worked more than five years as an analyst for ESPN before the Florida Marlins hired him as hitting coach in June. Perez, 41, played in the majors as recently as 2006, but the lessons he took from his television producers have come in just as handy as anything he learned as a player. ''Be able to say what you want to say, right off the bat, in that first sentence,'' Perez said, referring to his on-air technique. ''Make the impact in that first sentence and then explain why. And I take the same approach with the players. I tell them exactly what it is at the beginning and then I explain to them why. I think it really hits them, and they get it right away. I'm not a coach to be on them 24/7. I let them play.''

SCHWARTZBERG--Melvin, on July 28, 2011. He lived a full life. Beloved husband, father, grandfather. Accomplished WWII Veteran. Teacher, Executive in insurance and real estate. Services: Sunday, 2:30pm at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

BEATTY--Adelaide "Adi" Louise, of Oyster Bay, NY, died July 23rd, 2011. She was a graduate of Friends Academy, Locust Valley, NY; Pine Manor College, MA; and Bucknell University, PA. Adi did her post-graduate studies at the New School for Social Research, NY, and was a retired Director of Development at Mt. Holyoke College. She had a long and successful career in fund raising, was an avid sailor and active member of the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club. She is survived by her late brother Frank W. Beatty II's children: Frank W. Beatty III, Brooke Beatty Wallace, Winifred Beatty Brunsickle, and by a loving family-of-friends and her beloved cats Molly and Kit Kat. The Oyster Bay Funeral Home has arranged for burial to take place at 5pm, Tuesday, August 2nd at the Matinecock Cemetery, in Locust Valley.

Did Niagara Falls host the first same-sex wedding in New York State? Hard to say. But New York's Twitter users did reward the upstate attraction with heavy traffic early Sunday morning, when a picture of the waters, illuminated in the colors of the rainbow, made the cyber rounds.

An article on July 17 about a pair of buildings in the East Village that are to be torn down to create a new condominium misstated the sequence in which two buildings in the neighborhood were constructed. The construction of a building housing Whole Foods began in 2003, and the Church of All Nations was demolished and replaced by a condominium afterward. The Whole Foods building did not rise two years after the church was torn down.

An article last Sunday about ''Aerial America,'' a Smithsonian Channel series that depicts the United States from the air, misstated the year that Hurricane Katrina struck New Orleans and the Gulf Coast. It was 2005, not 2006.

WHEN the artist Alia Penner isn't painting rainbow-framed portals into alternative universes, she brings her pop psychedelic sensibility to album covers and posters for Los Angeles bands and happenings. Now, after dipping her toes into fashion with illustrations for Erin Wasson's RVCA campaign and the titles for a Missoni film by Kenneth Anger, Ms. Penner has introduced Mombi, a line of dresses named for a witch in L. Frank Baum's Oz series. Created with her friend the designer and stylist Katie Casey, Mombi came into being when the photographer David Mushegain asked Ms. Penner to participate in a pop-up shop for his ''Don't Call It Cool'' show of California youth culture at Colette in Paris. She needed something that could fit in a suitcase. That led to Cosmic Love and Sail '77, two whisper-light chiffon frocks digitally printed with Ms. Penner's intricate prismatic collages. STEFFIE NELSON

10 P.M. (Animal Planet) HEIDI FLEISS: PROSTITUTES TO PARROTS Formerly known as the Hollywood Madam, Ms. Fleiss oversaw a high-end brothel in the 1990s and acquired the accouterments to match, including a mansion and millions in the bank. Then her empire crumbled. Now living in Pahrump, Nev., after serving more than three years in prison for tax evasion and spending time in rehab to deal with drug addiction, Ms. Fleiss is focusing on the Laundromat (name: Dirty Laundry) she owns, the luxury dog hotel she is set to open in Las Vegas and the newest loves of her life: more than 20 macaws. ''I never, ever thought that I would end up here, but everything happens for a reason,'' Ms. Fleiss says. ''It's been a crazy way to reinvent myself, but I love my birds, and I will be successful, no matter what I do.'' 9 A.M. Schumer, Democrat of New York; Representative Jason Chaffetz, Republican of Utah; and Mark Zandi, chief economist for Moody's Analytics, about the debt-ceiling negotiations in Congress.

HASSLER--Howard Edward. Dad, our lives parted too soon, but we are forever grateful for the times we shared, the many great things you taught us and for your love. We love you always. Susan, Barbara, Robert & Craig

An essay on Page 13 this weekend about the defunct British newspaper News of the World misspells the name of the city in Italy where the writer, Paul McNamara, stayed while traveling from off the coast of Libya back to the newspaper's offices in London this month. He was in Sorrento, not Torrento.

HURST--Norman, 67, of Cambridge, MA (AB, Harvard '66), lost a lengthy battle with cancer at his home in Newton on July 27, 2011. He was the devoted husband of Katherine Burton Jones, loving stepfather to Gregory Burton Garmil, and beloved son of Elaine Hurst and the late Jefferson Hurst of Albany, OR. Norman is also survived by sisters Anne Dewey of Portland, OR and Susan Derrickson of Lebanon, OR. He was a much admired and inspirational uncle to Alex Dewey of Palo Alto, CA and Lydia Dewey of Portland, OR. Norman was one of the foremost art dealers and certified appraisers of tribal art and antiquities with a Gallery in Harvard Square, Cambridge, MA, nationally and internationally respected for his expertise and loved for his kindness and gentle nature. Norman traveled widely and there was never a museum, archaeological site, or art gallery that he missed during these trips. A private service will be held in his home in Newton, MA. Memorial services will be held in Cambridge and Albany, OR. Norman was a competitive and accomplished tennis player; the family asks that donations be made in his name to the Museum of the International Tennis Hall of Fame, Newport, RI. Alternatively, donations may be made in his name to fund the research of Dr. Eric Wong, Beth Israel Deaconess Hospital (neurooncology), Boston, MA. Online guestbook at: www.pemurrayfuneral.com

THE military trains its personnel to do battle, and so does fashion. The techniques and methods may differ, but the core precepts are the same. ''There are so many ways to be manipulated and set back, so many people out to get you, that you have to maintain integrity,'' said Caesar Stovall, a 24-year-old Army medic who has served tours of duty in Iraq and Afghanistan. ''It's very easy to lose yourself.''

The ''Living In'' article last Sunday, about Woodlawn, the Bronx, misstated the title of Margaret Fogarty of the Woodlawn Heights Taxpayers and Community Association. She is a former second vice president, not a former president.

Mariah Carey and Barack Obama each had something to sell this week, and they made live videos to do it. Both videos bombed. Ms. Carey's pitch on HSN, for tracksuits and other sundries from her fashion label, was too weird. Mr. Obama's pitch on the networks for Congressional compromise wasn't nearly weird enough. Both impresarios made the same mistake. They failed to understand the shifting dynamics of the very small screen, and instead aimed to produce traditional TV spots. Spots like these nearly always misfire when they are played on the Web, where most people now see them. And analyze them. And satirize them.
Readers react to Wednesday's letter urging a more ambitious space program focusing on Mars. The Letter

The five most viewed articles on nytimes.com/sports from July 22 to 28. 1. TIGER WOODS'S CADDIE STEVE WILLIAMS RESPONDS TO DISMISSAL The split between Woods and his longtime friend and confidant has taken on the appearance of an ugly divorce.

When I sit down to work, I keep a small bowl of garlic croutons on my desk. These are little rewards for good ideas and strong lines, Pavlovian pellets to keep my spirits up. Recently, I began to wonder what fuel writers have relied on, and the answers turned out to be all over the culinary map. Walt Whitman began the day with oysters and meat, while Gustave Flaubert started off with what passed for a light breakfast in his day: eggs, vegetables, cheese or fruit, and a cup of cold chocolate. The novelist Vendela Vida told me she swears by pistachios, and Mark Kurlansky, the author of ''Salt'' and ''Cod,'' likes to write under the influence of espresso, ''as black as possible.'' For some writers, less is more. Lord Byron , a pioneer in fad diets as well as poetry, sipped vinegar to keep his weight down. Julia Scheeres , the author of the memoir ''Jesus Land,'' aims for more temporary deprivation. ''When in the thick of writing I minimize food intake as much as possible,'' she told me. ''I find I work better when I'm a little starved.''

BUXBAUM--Dr. James Monroe, 83, passed away on Friday, July 15, 2011, at his home in San Luis Obispo, California. James, the fourth and youngest child of Edward Buxbaum and Theresa Gross Buxbaum, was born in Jamaica, New York on March, 1928. Dr. Buxbaum is survived by eight nieces and nephews: Anita Broad Scott, Kenneth Green, Roger Green, David Broad, Steven Buxbaum, Ruth Buxbaum Gross, Robert Buxbaum and Harriet Buxbaum Pinansky, as well as many grand nieces and nephews and cousins. He was preceded in death by his parents and his three siblings, Muriel Buxbaum Green, Frances Buxbaum Wegner, and Alan Buxbaum. A memorial celebration honoring Dr. Buxbaum's life will be held at 11:00 a.m. on August 6, 2011 at the St. Stephens Episcopal Church, 1344 Nipomo Street, San Luis Obispo, after which his remains will be interred at the church. In lieu of flowers, you are encouraged to donate to the Hospice Partners of the Central Coast, or to a charity of your choosing. Please sign his guest book at www.sanluisobispo.com/ obituaries.

Moscow, April 16, 2011 I just had dinner with my wife and our best friend when we decided to take a walk in Red Square. It was very cold, but the view was worth it: the Kremlin looked amazing, the moon was beautiful and there were couples walking hand in hand. I spotted this person cleaning the square, almost stone by stone. The dust he was kicking up was illuminated by the lights in the store right in front of Lenin's mausoleum. It felt magical. We soon realized they were cleaning up the square for a parade celebrating an anniversary of a victory over the Nazis during World War II.JULIÁN HERNÁNDEZ, Hong Kong

''I guess being ignorant has its benefits.'' On the cover of last week's Metropolitan section, Alison Leigh Cowan traced 15 generations of Van Dusens, a Dutch family descended from a miller who arrived in Manhattan in the 1620s. Following are reader comments drawn from e-mail to The Times. Readers also responded to Neil Genzlinger's City Critic column about playing miniature golf as a way to curb bad impulses: I was delighted to read your informative and insightful article on the Van Deusens and the influence of the Dutch here in N.Y.C. As a descendant of Conrad Burghardt who lived in Van Deusenville, Mass., as a little boy, I have fond memories of my older brother, twin sister and I sneaking into the deconsecrated church (now owned by Arlo Guthrie) on Halloween and ringing the church bell, then running like crazy so as not to be caught. As less than 10 people lived nearby, our fears were perhaps overblown.

CLARK--Barbara M. ("Babs"). Passed away July 24, 2011, in New York City. Born July 19, 1938, only child of George P. Clark and Evelyn McCann Clark. After graduation from Marymount College, Arlington, VA, Barbara enjoyed a lengthy, successful career at CBS Television Network. She was selected as the first female network sales executive and earlier worked in the New York Yankees organization, then a division of CBS. "Babs" had a zest for life which uplifted those around her. Our dear cousin, godmother and friend of many, "Babs" will be missed by all who knew her. Mass of Christian Burial was held July 30 at Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church, Forest Hills. Donations in her name to the Make-A-Wish Foundation will be appreciated. THOMPSON--Stephanie, age 77, died July 26 in Manhattan. Passionate devotee of athletics and the performing arts. Past board member of the New York Turtle and Tortoise Society. Former staff member of The New Yorker magazine. Graveside service Wednesday, August 3, 1pm at Westchester Hills Cemetery.

OK Go, a band as famous for its inventive, choreographed videos as for its power pop music, had another novel concept for its latest video, ''All Is Not Lost'': bodies intertwining atop a glass table, seen from below. Yet when planning the shoot, the four-piece band discovered that it needed more bodies. In what the video director Trish Sie describes as ''a perfect storm of timing,'' OK Go's lead singer, Damian Kulash, got a call from the Pilobolus dance troupe, proposing a collaboration. The resulting video added Pilobolus dancers to the mix, their bodies used to create shapes and letters. Kulash says that having Pilobolus work on the band's concept was ''like asking a superchef to make green beans,'' and Itamar Kubovy, the executive director of Pilobolus, returns the compliment. ''This cool result needed an enormous amount of calculation,'' he says. ''And these OK Go guys led beautifully.'' Year OK Go was formed: 1998. Studio Albums: ''OK Go'' (2002), ''Oh No'' (2005), ''Of the Blue Color of the Sky'' (2010). YouTube views for all 15 of their videos: 125 million. Grammy Award: Best Short-Form Music Video (2006), for ''Here It Goes Again.''

SKATERS of outer Long Island no longer need to hoof it to Manhattan or go online to buy a board. Wampum, a new skateboard shop, has opened in Bridgehampton, thanks to two local skater brothers, Marley and Lennon Ficalora. (Yes, they are named after who you think.) The store offers small brands from both coasts and around the world, like Katin out of Huntington Beach, Calif.; Acapulco Gold from New York; and KFCC from Australia. ''We are carrying lines that people will not see together in any other shop,'' said Marley Ficalora (at right in photo). To support the local art scene (one of their goals for the shop), the brothers gave 10 artists a blank deck to do as they pleased. The results are on Wampum's walls, at 2487 Main Street, Bridgehampton, N.Y.; wampumny.com. ABBY AGUIRRE

Any commoner with deep pockets can now get the sort of arrival and departure service at Heathrow Airport near London usually reserved for royalty and popes. The new Heathrow by Invitation (heathrowbyinvitation.com) service offers travelers access to 20 newly remodeled private lounges formerly exclusively used for visiting dignitaries.
Pop Nate Chinen

NEWMANN--Mary Misch. Mary Misch Newman, 69, of Cambridge, MA, died peacefully of cancer on July 24, 2011, in Polson, Montana, surrounded by her loving family and the serenity of Flathead Lake. Kind, playful and generous of spirit, Mary enjoyed life to the fullest until the very end. She died with the same rare grace and strength with which she lived. Mary was born in Manhattan in 1941 to Robert and Janet Misch. Educated at Dalton and Riverdale Country School, she graduated from Mount Holyoke College in 1963 and earned masters degrees from Bank Street and NYU School of Social Work. A lifelong leader in education, Mary began her career as founder of an international high school in Jakarta, Indonesia. In 1980, she became Director of the Churchill School and Center and then in 1986, Head of The Town School, both in Manhattan. In 1992, Mary was named Head of School at Buckingham Browne & Nichols in Cambridge where she played a critical role in integrating faculty and curriculum across three campuses. She was also largely responsible for rebuilding the upper school campus and for establishing partnerships with Boston institutions, including the Museum of Fine Arts. She was committed to fostering a sense of creativity, self-expression and wonder among children. Mary retired briefly in 2001, returning in 2003 to head Cambridge Friends School, where she again united a community committed to diversity, respect and social justice and built a foundation for future success. Her success in leading four different schools stemmed from her profound faith in the unlimited capacity of children and a deep respect for teachers as professionals. These values permeated the vision and culture of each institution. Mary served on the boards of the Cambridge Community Foundation, Shady Hill School, Breakthrough for Children, Primary Source, Early Steps and Prospect Hill Academy. Above all, Mary was a magnificent human being. The same qualities that enabled her to build and lead schools infused her relationships with family and friends. Her deep sense of caring, respect for differences, and ability to bring out the best in everyone drew people together and created enduring ties. Mary was the one to whom family, friends and colleagues turned for guidance, nurturing and inspiration. Mary is survived by her beloved daughters Sara (Doug Sovern) and Emily (John Darrah) and their father John, her life partner Ted Smith, sister Katherine Koritzinsky (Allan), granddaughters Maxine and Sadie Newmann Darrah, niece Carolyn Fertig (Matt), nephew Bradley Koritzinsky (Keren) and grandnephews Jacob and Cameron Fertig and Yaniv Koritzinsky. A Celebration of Mary's Life will be held September 24 at 3:30pm at First Parish Unitarian Universalist Church in Cambridge. Contributions may be made in Mary's memory to enrich the lives of students and teachers to Cambridge Friends School for the Mary Newmann Student Enrichment Fund or to Buckingham Browne & Nichols for the Mary Newmann Faculty Fund.

Five-star hotels and luxury buses may not be the first things that come to mind when you think of Cuba. But now they can be part of the experience. Abercrombie & Kent, the luxury travel company, is offering trips to Cuba from the United States made possible by President Obama's loosening of travel restrictions earlier this year. According to the new policies, any United States citizen can now go to Cuba as long as the trip is with a group licensed by the Treasury Department. Abercrombie, the first elite travel company to offer this type of tour, has partnered with the Foundation for Caribbean Studies, a nonprofit organization, to plan an itinerary that would put visitors in touch with people who could teach them about Cuba's history and culture.

RABEEA ZIA KHALIL, 28: I met my husband, Umar, on a school trip when we were 12. Growing up 40 minutes outside of London, we did the ''cheesy Valentine's Day card'' thing and kept in touch when we went to university. After seven or eight years, we told our families, ''We really want to do this.'' Our wedding celebration last August was an extravagant, traditional Asian affair with 400 guests, and I worked hard to make it feel quite personal, even though it is actually four distinct parts over four days: two mehndis, which are henna parties; the actual wedding ceremony, which is seen as the girl's event; and then the boy's version of the wedding the following day, which is more of a party.

The condo has approximately4,800 square feetof space, four bedrooms andfive and a half baths. The buyerwas listed under a LimitedLiability Company.Mr. Wagner bought theapartment in 2007 from Michael Hirtenstein, aprolific real estate investor, paying $27 million,according to property records. Before selling toMr. Wagner, Mr. Hirtenstein, who bought theplace for $16 million in 2004 but never livedthere, rented it to Jay-Z.Big Ticket includes closed deals from the previousweek, ending Wednesday. RYAN--Dr. Douglas Thomas. Dr. Douglas Thomas Ryan was born on June 12, 1921 in Brooklyn, NY and passed away on July 27, 2011 at the age of 90. Growing up he went to PS10 in Brooklyn and the Arts Students League. After serving in the Army during WWII, Douglas went to work for Bendix Corporation and then moved to Palm Beach, Florida and went to work for Palm Beach International Airport. There, he attended Palm Beach Junior College and Florida Atlantic University. After moving from Florida to Mississippi, Douglas obtained his doctorate degree from Southern Mississippi College and began his career as a Professor for numerous colleges in Mississippi. He is survived by his loving wife, Dr. Margaret W. Ryan; daughter, Dr. Margaret R. Morris; son, Douglas P. Ryan and wife Sandra; grandchildren, Donald T. Kimbrough and Kitty Morris-Carter; sister-in-law, Irene Ryan and numerous other loving family members and friends. A visitation will be held from 6:00-8:00pm at Oak Hills Mortuary on Monday, August 1, 2011. A graveside service will be held at 1:30pm on Tuesday, August 2, 2011 at Ft. Sam Houston National Cemetery. Oak Hills Mortuary 8332 Fredericksburg Rd. San Antonio, TX, 78229. 210-616-0510

Polly Platt, a Hollywood producer, designer and screenwriter who was responsible for the aesthetic of several of Peter Bogdanovich's early films, died on Wednesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 72. The cause was amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, her family said.

Which adjective best describes Ruben Amaro, the general manager of the Philadelphia Phillies. Ruthless? Relentless? Both work pretty well. Amaro made another significant trade on Friday, acquiring the two-time All-Star outfielder Hunter Pence from the Houston Astros for three minor leaguers and a player to be named later. - Since July 2009, Amaro has now used the farm system to acquire Cliff Lee, Roy Halladay, Roy Oswalt and Pence. During that time he also traded Lee to re-stock the farm system, a move that backfired badly and seems to have taught Amaro a lesson, on some level. Ever since, he's been all in, all the time -- championship or bust. Yes, Amaro was raised in Philadelphia.-The Phillies badly needed Pence. Their offense looked frail this week against two ghosts from last October, Matt Cain and Tim Lincecum of the Carlos Beltran-fortified San Francisco Giants. The Phillies were clearly too left-handed, too susceptible to the kind of dominant lefty relievers they should see in October, like Javier Lopez and Jeremy Affeldt of the Giants or Jonny Venters and Eric O'Flaherty of the Atlanta Braves. Pence has a .290 career average against lefties - exactly the same as his mark against righties.

A theater entry in the Long Island calendar of events in some editions last Sunday misstated the ticket price for the musical ''Hairspray,'' playing at the John W. Engeman Theater in Northport through Aug. 28. It is $60, not $15.

The N.F.L. is back in business, and its 32 coaches are scrambling to cram months of preparation into a couple of weeks. There are some underemployed football coaches out there, but Jerry Glanville, though idle, had the pedal to the metal in the hills of north Georgia. ''Can you hear me?'' Glanville said by cellphone, yelling to be heard over the snarling engine of his 1984 Thunderbird. ''I'm driving around the mountains. If I lose you, call right back. I have to go drop this car off and pick up another.''
Gladsaxe, Denmark THERE may be fewer than 500 electric cars on Danish roads, but signs of progress in building an infrastructure to support a larger population of E.V.'s. are already evident.

By the time Johnny Cueto was born, in the Dominican Republic in 1986, Luis Tiant was a decade removed from his heyday as a twirling contortionist of a right-hander for the Boston Red Sox. Tiant had a singular flair, with a spinning, gyrating delivery, but if any pitcher comes close today, it is Cueto. For Cueto, a Cincinnati Reds right-hander, the style is working. He had a 1.88 earned run average through his first 15 starts, in the last several of which he has used Tiant-style mechanics. Working from the windup, Cueto lifts his left leg and turns his shoulders to center field, so the hitter sees the 47 on his jersey, but not his face. Then he uncoils toward the batter, somehow picks up the catcher's target and fires.

The history of crossbred cars is filled with hits and misses. You might end up with the McLaren F1, arguably the best application ever of a BMW engine, or you might end up with the Chrysler TC by Maserati. If you don't recall the TC, it was a mid-'80s Chrysler LeBaron with a Maserati trident. That mongrel gave opera windows a bad name, which is saying something. The TC is a cautionary tale of mashups gone wrong, and it's relevant because Fiat Group, which owns Chrysler and Maserati, is readying another Maserati with American roots: an S.U.V. based on the platform shared by the Jeep Grand Cherokee and Dodge Durango. According to numerous reports, the new creation will be unveiled at the Frankfurt auto show in September.

FORTY-SECOND STREET has long catered to the needs of New Yorkers, tourists, theater lovers, moviegoers, small-time hustlers, global corporations, shoppers, restaurateurs, news hounds, thrill seekers, hopefuls and has-beens. But until the New 42nd Street Studios was completed in 2000, there was precious little space for performing artists to rehearse. The New 42nd Street, the nonprofit corporation established by the city and state in 1990 to take responsibility of the block's seven historic theaters and to help revitalize Times Square, decided to fill that gap with a $34.7 million rehearsal, office and theater complex. The 10-story building, between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, has 14 rehearsal studios on five floors; three floors of office space; and a 199-seat theater, the Duke on 42nd Street, which, despite being in the heart of Broadway, is classified as an Off Broadway theater because it has fewer than 200 seats.

STEIN--Howard, 84, passed away very peacefully at home in Southampton, NY, on July 26th. He is survived by Janet Stein, his beloved wife of 52 years, and by his five daughters and their families including his six granddaughters. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Howard worked in financial services, eventually joining The Dreyfus Corporation where he became chairman and CEO. With many innovations to his credit including some of the first money market and municipal bond funds as well as groundbreaking marketing and advertising strategies, Howard was considered one of the founders of the modern mutual fund industry. A quiet, even shy man of great vision, Howard was known for his keen intuition and his deep insight into the human spirit. He challenged those around him to reach beyond the traditional and the mundane and he insisted that complicated information be distilled into clear and concise ideas. His intense focus and determination helped turn those ideas into meaningful action. His remarkable sense of timing ensured that action was often taken at the perfect moment. Fascinated with the creative side of business, Howard had a lifelong interest in the arts and sciences. He was an avid gardener, spending many happy hours tending his seaside plantings on Long Island. He supported pioneering research in medicine. He came to love photography and assembled a notable collection spanning early masterworks and contemporary, experimental images. Howard's collection became the basis for his charitable foundation, Joy of Giving Something, Inc., which focuses on photography and video as an aid to education, social awareness and societal transformation. Over twenty years, Howard generously and selflessly helped to establish, support and nurture the careers of many artists in the field. Howard was an optimist who deeply believed in our ability to shape our future for the better. He inspired many around him to feel the same way. That may be his greatest legacy. He will be greatly missed by his family and his friends and associates. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Joy of Giving Something, Inc., 954 Lexington Avenue, Box #

Whether the scandal afflicting News Corp. represents the beginning of the fall of the House of Murdoch or just another thrilling episode in the career of the Teflon tycoon, I can't say. There is plenty enough spectacle without speculation. Nor is this the place to celebrate a rival's troubles. True, I did pull from my files and savor the indignant letters we received from News of the World's top editors last year as we prepared to publish an investigation of the paper's phone-hacking culture and Scotland Yard's timidity -- work that has been fully vindicated in recent weeks. But even if it is true, as online wags put it, that Murdoch's troubles threaten to deplete the world supply of schadenfreude, I don't plan to join the party.
Film Neil Genzlinger

As day broke over Libya a few weeks ago, so did reports that News of the World hacked the phones of a murdered teenager, the victims of the 7/7 London bombings and possibly soldiers killed in Iraq and Afghanistan. I was on a 410-foot-long British Navy warship that was firing missiles into Libya, covering the war for News of the World. I called my boss. ''It couldn't be much worse, son,'' he said. ''Get home.'' I hitched a ride on a naval supply ship to Sorrento, Italy. I cycled between rage at the unthinkable acts of abhorrent former reporters, editors and private investigators to despair for the families that were their targets; a little bit more rage; and eventually to self-pity. In a crumbling '70s hotel in Sorrento, I switched on the BBC, which said my newspaper was closing down after 168 years. The 286 staff members who would lose their jobs (or the vast majority, at least) were either not there when the crimes occurred or not involved.

The first manned balloon flight took place in France during the early 1780s and, not surprisingly, people began thinking of how to turn the balloon into an implement of war. Within a few years, the French army was using observation balloons in battle, and Benjamin Franklin even suggested that balloons might actually be used to convey soldiers into the fray. In 1849 the Austrian high command sent some 200 unmanned balloons, laden with timed explosives, over Venice. Unfortunately, the wind shifted, carrying them back over the hapless Austrians.

In a  recent essay about moral relativism in The Times’s philosophy series The Stone, Paul Boghossian cites a 2001 op-ed of mine as an example of the contradictions relativists fall into. At one moment, he says, I declare the unavailability of “independent standards” for deciding between rival accounts of a matter, and in the next moment  I am offering counsel that is “perfectly consistent with the endorsement of moral absolutes.”   I don’t  regard that as a contradiction, and I would say that to think of it as one is to fail to distinguish between relativism as a philosophical position — respectable, if controversial — and relativism as a way of life, something no one recommends and no one  practices.

January is often the cruelest month for Broadway box offices, as holiday tourists head home, students go back to school and New Yorkers hibernate from the cold and snow. Last winter the lead producers of the Broadway revival of “Promises, Promises” closed the show on Jan. 2 rather than gamble money on recasting their two stars, Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth, and risk a slide in ticket sales. Those same producers are now behind another Broadway revival, “How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,” but they have opted to replace their star, Daniel Radcliffe, who finishes his run as the scheming executive J. Pierrepont Finch on New Year’s Day. Confirming rumors that have been circulating for a couple of weeks, the producers announced on Monday that Mr. Radcliffe (of “Harry Potter” fame) will be succeeded by a lesser-known actor, Darren Criss, who has become popular recently on the Fox series “Glee” playing a gay high school student and show choir member who exudes charisma and self-confidence. In casting Mr. Criss the producers are seeking to appeal to at least some of the teenagers, women and gay men who often mob Mr. Radcliffe at the stage door after performances. Mr. Criss is scheduled for only a three-week engagement, Jan. 3 through 22. In their statement announcing Mr. Criss the producers did not say if they plan to cast another actor after him, close the $8.5 million production after he departs, or try to extend his run. A spokesman for the musical said the producers had not made decisions about the future of the show after the Criss run.

CBS scored another ratings victory on Sunday night, beating out the other broadcast networks in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. “Big Brother” is particularly starting to look like a ratings juggernaut on Sundays, doubling every other show on the broadcast schedule in the 18-to-49 group except for a repeat of “Family Guy” on Fox. It also accumulated more than 8 million total viewers, up from 6.9 million last week. “60 minutes” did its part as well for CBS, as it was once again the most-watched program of the night with 8.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, “The Bachelorette: The Men Tell All Special” won the 9 p.m. time slot for ABC in total viewers with 5.1 million but was down considerably compared with last season’s edition, which drew 8.9 million. Still, it gave ABC its best summer Sunday rating with entertainment programming in five years (the 2010 special appeared on a Monday).

Mathematical folklore is rife with legends of imprisoned people who won their freedom or escaped death by solving a mathematical problem. We’ve featured a number of such problems here including the Josephus Problem, which, according to legend, allowed the 1st-century Jewish historian Flavius Josephus to save himself from death. (In our version, it was a firing game featuring Donald Trump and Ryan Seacrest.) We’ve also featured the Prisoners and Light Bulb problem and the Prisoners and the File Drawers problem, in both of which prison authorities give their detainees a mathematical problem to solve to gain their freedom. Today’s puzzle features a similar scenario. It concerns a medieval king who, in a rare fit of potential mercy, promises to free 5 of his prisoners on condition that they solve a problem. This problem is based on a submission by the prolific Numberplay contributor Ravi Kumar Meduri, from Hyderabad, India.

(HBO) KORAN BY HEART (2011) Each year during Ramadan about 100 students from more than 70 countries converge on Cairo for the International Holy Koran Competition, in which children as young as 7 try to recite the religious text from memory. This documentary from Greg Barker follows three 10-year-olds who have dedicated their lives to honoring their families, their countries and their culture through the competition. Kristina Nelson, the author of ''The Art of Reciting the Qur'an,'' explains the rules of pronunciation and intonation, and Salem Abdel-Galil of the Ministry of Religious Endowments in Egypt discusses the correlation between heaven and the memorization of the Koran. 8 P.M. Two months after Scholastic, the world's largest publisher of children's books, was hit with a barrage of criticism for distributing an unbalanced curriculum sponsored by the coal industry, the company is cutting back its InSchool marketing division's corporate-sponsored projects, and creating a new review board to vet its materials. ''We have to improve our standards, and make sure there's not a scintilla of anything that could be suggested to be biased,'' said Richard Robinson, the president and chief executive of Scholastic. ''The vast majority of our programs are not controversial, but once in a while there was a slip-up in editorial judgment.''

OLSON--Martha, who lived in both New York City and Southampton, died peacefully at her New York home surrounded by friends on July 30, 2011 after a long illness. Martha was a proud achiever and built a distinguished career in public relations. She and two partners started a PR firm in St. Louis that was so successful it was acquired by Farley Manning in New York, where she became a Sr. Vice President. She later joined Hill & Knowlton, rising to Sr. Vice President before her retirement. During the course of her career, Martha advised such powerful clients as the Principality of Monaco, Mexico's Department of Tourism (supervising the launch of Cancun), the Virgin Islands, Anheuser-Busch, E. I. du Pont de Nemours, Pet Milk and Chevron Chemical. Her hands-on style and creative ideas earned her major industry awards, including the Prisms Award presented by the Los Angeles chapter of the Public Relations Society of America in 1980, and two years later, she was one of the first women in the country to win the Silver Anvil Award, the highest honor given by the PRSA. Martha Annette Olson was born in Ft. Stockton, Texas on Christmas day 1920, the daughter of Auburn Elizabeth Bransford and John Nels Olson, a Swedish immigrant. She spent her formative years in Parsons, Kansas before moving to St. Louis and finally to New York. In an interview with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch in January 1958 regarding her public relations success, Martha said, "Speed somehow always seems to have been part of my life." Indeed she loved life in the fast lane, whether driving one of her low-slung sports convertibles, flying a single-engine plane as a 19-year-old student pilot and later becoming an airport traffic controller, or much later riding her horse, Dusty, in the Hamptons. Martha is survived by her sister and brother-in-law Jean and Joseph Stevens of Montecito, CA and her brother and sister-in-law Jack and Alice Olson of the National Forest north of Tucson, AZ. She is also survived by her close friends and real estate partners Jody Donohue and Etta Froio, and her beloved Wirehaired Fox Terrier Bentley, named for one of her flashy fast cars she loved to drive.

MEXICO CITY -- A principal leader of a drug gang who the authorities believe was the mastermind behind the killings of three people connected to a United States consulate in northern Mexico last year and other bloody attacks has been captured, Mexico's federal police said Sunday. The leader, José Antonio Acosta Hernández, a former police officer known as El Diego, was arrested Saturday. The police said that he confessed to ordering 1,500 killings as the head of La Línea in Ciudad Juárez, the country's most violent city.

Donations in her name may be made to Planned Parenthood.

MCCRACKEN--Daniel D.,died peacefully at home July 30th, just after his 81st birthday. Survived by: Helen Blumenthal, wife of 31 years; seven children; a stepson; many grands and greats. Twitter said on Thursday that ads from companies, known as Promoted Tweets, will now show up at or near the top of users' timelines. A new museum honoring Arnold Schwarzenegger, the bodybuilder, movie star and former California governor, opened on Saturday in the Austrian village where he was born, Thal, near Graz, to coincide with his 64th birthday. The museum, located in the house where Mr. Schwarzenegger lived from birth until he departed in 1966 for England and then the United States, clearly has his blessing: exhibits include not only his childhood bed and first weight-lifting equipment but also a sword from ''Conan the Barbarian,'' memorabilia from the ''Terminator'' movies and a copy of the desk he used as governor. Despite the recent blows to Mr. Schwarzenegger's image in the United States with his disclosure that he fathered a child out of wedlock, ''his career was so exciting and so special and I think the Austrian people are really proud'' of him, Helga Forstner, the museum coordinator, told the BBC. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

FIELD--Nancy, died peacefully on July 28. She was fortunate to enjoy the company of her loving family and steadfast friends till her final days. She is survived by her devoted daughters, Sally Hoover Zeckhauser and Gretchen Rennell Court and their husbands Richard and John, loving grandchildren Benjamin and Bryn and her husband Clift, and great grandchildren Charlotte and Annabel, who rejoiced in her company. Nancy was always an active volunteer, particularly in the educational and environmental domains. She served as a trustee of Sarah Lawrence College and the Westover School, as librarian and book reviewer for Jupiter Island, on the Advisory Board of the National Park Service, and as Vice President and Editor of the Bulletin of the Garden Club of America. In lieu of flowers, to reflect Nancy's love of books, please send contributions to a library of your choice. Services will be private.

PARIS -- David Servan-Schreiber, a psychiatrist and best-selling author whose cancer diagnosis at the age of 31 compelled him to explore and then popularize the use of natural and holistic methods in dealing with cancer and depression, died on Sunday in a hospital near Fécamp, Normandy. He was 50. The cause was brain cancer, which had recurred last year, his brother Franklin said.

The Afro-Peruvian folk singer Susana Baca has been named minister of culture in Peru for the new populist government of President Ollanta Humala, who took office last week. Ms. Baca, whose CD ''Lamento Negro'' won a Latin Grammy award in 2002, is the first black Peruvian to be named a cabinet minister in that country since it gained its independence from Spain in 1821, and she provides another example of a recent South American trend to put artists in charge of government cultural policy. Previously, for example, the pop singer-songwriter Gilberto Gil served as culture minister in Brazil, and the actress-director Paulina Urrutia in Chile. Despite her new duties, Ms. Baca intends to go ahead with a tour of the United States and Europe scheduled to begin this month, according to her publicist, Jesse Cutler. The performances are to include one in New York City on Aug. 21, at the City Winery.

Smurfs humiliated a cluster of Hollywood's heaviest weights at the weekend box office. Analysts had predicted that ''Cowboys & Aliens'' - starring Daniel Craig and Harrison Ford, directed by Jon Favreau (''Iron Man'') and produced by Brian Grazer and Steven Spielberg - would easily dominate ticket sales. Instead, it was a photo finish with ''The Smurfs,'' a cartoon-live action hybrid. Both films took in an estimated $36.2 million at North American theaters, as ''The Smurfs'' outperformed expectations, and ''Cowboys & Aliens'' failed to capture young men in significant numbers. The difference, beyond the pedigree of the filmmakers and stars, is cost. Sony Pictures Entertainment spent about $110 million to make ''The Smurfs.'' ''Cowboys & Aliens'' cost at least $163 million, with Mr. Spielberg's DreamWorks Studios providing the bulk of the financing; Universal Pictures distributed and holds a minority financial stake. Moreover, the box-office future looks brighter for ''The Smurfs,'' which young moviegoers gave an A score in exit polls; ''Cowboys & Aliens'' got a B.

BERLIN -- While Europeans and Americans traveling abroad continue to face steep roaming charges, Chinese travelers can call home for as little as it costs to make a local call. For instance, when Su Xiaoqin, a Chinese translator living in Du sseldorf, calls Shanghai, she does not use the mobile network of her German operator, O2. Instead, she relies on service from China Mobile via a SIM card. As a result, Ms. Su's calls home cost as little as 44 cents a minute, a small fraction of what a call us- ing the German system would run. That's because China Mobile, the world's largest operator with 617 million customers, recently slashed its international roaming rates, following similar cuts by its domestic rivals, China Unicom and China Telecom. ''The word has gotten around that the Chinese operators now have the best rates to China,'' Ms. Su said. For American travelers abroad, however, the charges can still be shockingly high. In May, Paul O'Brien, the general legal counsel of an interna- tional industrial sealants maker based near Philadelphia, returned home after a business trip to Milan and Rome, to a $2,300 roaming bill, which he incurred in two days. Mr. O'Brien described his iPhone activity as moderate, involving calls to the United States through Telecom Italia, and downloading and reading e-mail. Just two days into what was a four-day trip, his American cell- phone operator, which he declined to name, shut off his service, citing his company's policy. ''I was blindsided,'' Mr. O'Brien said, adding that he did not know the limit that he had exceeded. Local operators (in Mr. O'Brien's case Telecom Italia) tend to reap the most profit from roaming charges, said Deep Basu, the vice president for product strategies and consumer products at Roamware, a software maker in San Jose, Calif., which helps operators manage roaming traffic. But the American cellphone carrier -- which has more customers than Telecom Italia and thus more clout in negotiating deals on roaming rates -- would have received a sizable slice as well. The European Union in 2007 stepped in to limit the price of mobile roaming charges in the 27 nation bloc, but those retail price caps, now 35 euro cents (51 cents) a minute for making a call, are higher than those paid by Chinese consumers. In the United States, the level of roaming charges is not regulated by the government but set by American and international operators through private agreements. Customers of China Unicom, that country's No. 2 operator with 182 million mobile users, now pay the equivalent of about 44 cents a minute to call China from most nations in Europe, and as low as 24 cents from America. The operator makes its low rates possible by running an extensive phone callback program, called the **100 Program, which assigns local landline phone numbers to its mobile customers while abroad, and then has a Cost cuts that are unlikely to be adopted in Europe or the U.S.company computer in China call them back over less expensive landlines to complete their long distance calls.China Unicom introduced the service in May, effectively slashing its roaming rates by as much as 90 percent. Sophia Tso, a spokeswoman for China Unicom in Hong Kong, said the decision to substantially lower roaming prices was made to better serve the company's customers. ''Decreasing the price is not merely marketing, it is to meet the user's needs and to meet business development and the in- herent requirement for developing the telecom industry,'' Ms. Tso said. She added that despite the price cuts, China Unicom was still covering its costs. Unicom's low international roaming charges, she said, ''are able to cover all the cost that is agreed between China Unicom and the international operators.'' Daniel Yu, an analyst in Hong Kong at Pyramid Research, said European and American operators, largely protected from outside competitors like the Chinese operators, have no incentive to reduce their own roaming profits. ''I don't think it will do much damage in Europe,'' Mr. Yu said, referring to the Chinese price cuts. But, he added, ''E.U. operators can adopt the same technique, but with the E.U. Commission continuing to reduce roaming rates across the Continent, the incentive to provide the service will be minimized.''

Trying to locate this year’s fifth annual Pie Off in Laurelhurst Park in Portland, Ore., was like a sketch from the TV show “Portlandia”: first you had to pass by what was billed (in chalk on the asphalt path) as an “organic free-range wedding,” then a free performance of Shakespeare’s “Much Ado About Nothing.” Finally, in the northeast corner of the park — marked by a bluegrass band and pennant banners made from recycled fabric, strung between the linden trees — were four tables spilling with pies. There was everything from the classic (Grandma Jane’s apple pie, berry with a lattice crust) to the quintessentially Portland (a gluten-free “Rawvocado-chocolate” — avocado, chocolate, raw macadamias, dates and shredded coconut). Hopeful eaters of all ages clustered around the tables, compostable forks and paper plates at the ready, waiting for four judges to sample all 60 pies that had been entered in one of four categories: savory, sweet non-fruit, sweet fruit and “creative.”

Next year Toronto could feature an outfield of Jose Bautista, Rasmus and Travis Snider/Eric Thames, and an infield with Adam Lind, Brett Lawrie and Yunel Escobar, to go along with a power-hitting catcher in J.P. Arencibia. With Ricky Romero and Brandon Morrow developing and Brett Cecil recently building on a solid rookie year, the Jays could crash the Yanks-Sox-Rays triumvirate as early as 2012.The Indians coughed up some top pitching prospects (Drew Pomeranz and Alex White) for Ubaldo Jimenez, and it makes you wonder why the Yankees didn’t offer a similar package (including Dellin Betances and Manny Banuelos), or, if they did, why the Rockies didn’t want it. Jimenez has a good contract and is under team control through 2014, so unless Colorado suspected there was something wrong with him, this seems like a good price. It’s not entirely true that there’s no such thing as a pitching prospect, especially when you’re talking about players who blew away the high minors like Tim Lincecum and Tommy Hanson or mega-talents like David Price or Stephen Strasburg. But for the next tier down, which is how I view both the Indians’ and Yankees’ duos, the failure rate is awfully high. It’ll be interesting to see how Jimenez fares with all his starts at sea level, albeit in the American League.

How should the government improve the food label? A project at the University of California, Berkeley, School of Journalism has taken on the task of designing a better food label, asking for ideas to replace the current black and white Nutrition Facts label that appears on every food package. Although the designs aren't part of the official effort to redesign food packages, the Berkeley project has generated dozens of new ideas that are likely to be considered by the United States Food and Drug Administration, which is in the process of revising the existing food label. This fall, the Institute of Medicine is expected to release its own report on food packaging and labeling.

To someone stepping off a stifling hot 125th Street, the Apollo Theater - cool, dark and empty, as it was on a recent afternoon - felt like hallowed space. A tap-dancing man in a fedora beat out rhythms onstage, while a few musicians stood together collectively improvising a new song. But things snapped to order when a slim man in a black tuxedo strode across the stage, glanced at his watch and told the musicians, ''Time to do it.''

Robert C. W. Ettinger, a science fiction writer and physics instructor whose idea of freezing the dead for future reanimation repelled most scientists, inspired Woody Allen and Mike Myers to some of their best work and persuaded at least 105 game humans to pay $28,000 each to have their bodies preserved in liquid nitrogen at his Cryonics Institute in suburban Detroit, died on July 23 at his home in Clinton Township, Mich. He was 92. The cause was respiratory failure, said his son, David, who added that Mr. Ettinger's body was placed in a cryonic capsule and frozen at minus 371 degrees Fahrenheit, after several days of cooling preparation. Mr. Ettinger was the institute's 106th client, David Ettinger said.

A mere 32 years after she played Eva Peron to his Che Guevara in ''Evita,'' Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin will reunite on Broadway for 63 performances of a theater concert, beginning Nov. 16. The production, ''An Evening With Patti LuPone and Mandy Patinkin,'' at the Barrymore Theater, is directed by Mr. Patinkin and includes musical staging by his fellow Broadway veteran Ann Reinking. The Broadway premiere follows appearances across the United States and in Canada, Australia and New Zealand. ''Evita'' has not been revived on Broadway since the production that earned Ms. LuPone, above left, and Mr. Patinkin, above right, Tony Awards, but a version starring Elena Roger and Ricky Martin is to open next year. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

The Metropolitan Opera and the union that represents its orchestra announced that they had reached a new agreement early Monday morning, a few hours after the current contract expired at midnight on July 31. No details were provided. Joseph Volpe, the Met's former general manager, acted as the opera's chief negotiator. The agreement with Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians comes on the heels of the opera's new contract with the union representing singers, stage managers, dancers and staff stage directors.

An article on July 25 about cloud computing in Europe misstated a provision of European data privacy law. The law allows the transfer of information about individuals to organizations in the United States that adhere to seven principles aimed at preventing accidental disclosure or loss of data, known as the Safe Harbor Principles. It does not forbid the transfer of information outside the European Union. (In practice, not all European countries recognize the Safe Harbor Principles and are more restrictive in data transfers.)

America Movil, controlled by Carlos Slim Helu, bid on Monday for the 40 percent of its former parent, Telmex, that it does not already own, aiming to consolidate the Mexican billionaire's telecommunications holdings. America Movil said in a statement that it would pay 10.50 Mexican pesos, about 90 cents, a share for Telmex, formally known as Telefonos de Mexico. That is an 11.1 percent premium to Telmex's 30-day average stock price.

CBS scored another ratings victory on Sunday night, beating out the other broadcast networks in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic. ''Big Brother'' is particularly starting to look like a ratings juggernaut on Sundays, doubling every other show on the broadcast schedule in the 18-to-49 group except for a repeat of ''Family Guy'' on Fox. It also accumulated more than 8 million total viewers, up from 6.9 million last week. ''60 minutes'' did its part as well for CBS, as it was once again the most-watched program of the night with 8.8 million viewers. Meanwhile, ''The Bachelorette: The Men Tell All Special'' won the 9 p.m. time slot for ABC in total viewers with 5.1 million but was down considerably compared with last season's edition, which drew 8.9 million. Still, it gave ABC its best summer Sunday rating with entertainment programming in five years (the 2010 special appeared on a Monday). This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.
