It is a sad truth, eloquently expressed by Joni Mitchell, that you don't know what you've got until it's gone. And judging by sales, the record-buying public seems to feel that way about Amy Winehouse, the troubled British soul singer found dead in her London home on July 23. Just eight days after her death, Ms. Winehouse's 2006 album ''Back to Black'' reached No. 1 on the British album chart while 5 of her songs were in the Top 40, the BBC reported. Her debut album, ''Frank,'' was at No. 5 on the album chart. In the United States, ''Back to Black'' also re-entered the Billboard album chart at No. 9, with 37,000 sold in the week after her death, Billboard reported.

MALGADY--Robert G.,age 51, a Montrose, NY resident, passed away on July 31, 2011. He was a former Professor at New York University, and currently a Professor of Educational Administration and Leadership at Touro College. Mr. Malgady was born in Newark, NJ on November 14, 1949, to George and Marie Calabrese Malgady. On June 20, 1986 he married Gerardita Colon in New York City. Among his many attributes, he also served as Associate Director of the Hispanic Research Center at Fordham University, Senior Research Associate at both Cornell-Weill Medical College, and Fordham University at Lincoln Center, and as visiting Professor at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. Professor Malgady served on several Editorial Boards and National Panels. Among his many memberships were the American Psychological Association--Fellow, Division 45-Society for the Psychological Study of Ethnic Minority Issues, Fellow, Division 5-Measurement, Evaluation and Statistics, and also the American Orthopsyciatric Association Fellow. He was the recipient of many awards, honors and Citations. He has a multitude of publications in the areas of Cultural Diversity and Sensitivity, as well as Quantitative Research. Robert is survived by his wife, Gerardita, and two sons, Jason, and Jeffrey Malgady, all of Montrose. He was predeceased by his parents, and also a sister, Carol A. Foster. There will be a Memorial Mass on Wednesday, August 3, 2011 at 11:00am at St. Christopher's Church in Buchanan. For directions call Joseph F. Nardone Funeral Home, Peekskill, NY at 914 737-1363.

LONDON -- There is timely comedy, which is what most satire, stand-up and sitcoms are. And then there is timeless comedy, which, properly performed, should feel as old as the hills and as fresh as ocean air. Or in the case of ''One Man, Two Guvnors,'' Richard Bean's smash play at the National Theater, ocean air scented with the fumes of warm beer, melting taffy and frying fish and chips. Staged by Nicholas Hytner (the National's artistic director), ''One Man, Two Guvnors'' is set in the seaside resort of Brighton in the early 1960s. The plot is based closely on that of Carlo Goldoni's ''Servant of Two Masters,'' from the mid-1700s, which in turn was inspired by far older tales and types from commedia dell'arte. So figure we've got at least half a millennium's worth of comic traditions operating here.

There were a few moments of truth during Mountain Man's austere, engrossing performance at the Mercury Lounge on Thursday night. One came after midnight, just before the encore, as the three young women in the group -- Molly Erin Sarle, Alexandra Sauser-Monnig and Amelia Randall Meath -- gathered at the lip of the stage. They had been singing without accompaniment for much of the preceding hour; now they also went without microphones, on a version of ''The Earth Has No Skin,'' by the way-out indie folk singer Jana Hunter. The lack of amplification was a reminder, if any were needed, of rural Vermont, where they met at Bennington College and began singing together at house parties just two years ago. The song choice was a reminder of the underground circles in which they now travel, the loose but thriving scene to which they belong.

Rikers Island officials have long compiled lists of foreign-born inmates who end up in their custody. They routinely give this information to federal immigration officials, who have their own office at the jail. Deportations often follow. With the city's assistance, immigration authorities annually detain and deport thousands of inmates charged with a range of offenses, from misdemeanors for theft to felony drug dealing.

PERELMAN--Ruth Caplan. The Trustees and staff of the University of Pennsylvania are deeply saddened by the death of Ruth Caplan Perelman, our compassionate benefactor, tireless advocate, and friend. A true civic leader and champion of the City of Philadelphia, Ruth and her husband, Raymond, were partners in creating innovative and bold philanthropy that advanced the missions of Penn. In May, Ruth and Raymond made a historic gift creating a permanent endowment for the School of Medicine, which was renamed the Raymond and Ruth Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania. Ruth was a driving force in creating the warm and inviting patient-centered experience in the state-of-the-art Ruth and Raymond Perelman Center for Advanced Medicine. In addition, Ruth and Raymond established the first endowed professorship devoted to an active, full-time clinician. They also generously supported programming, scholarships, and endowed chairs throughout the University. Ruth's gracious spirit and strong commitment to education, medicine, and culture in Philadelphia will be remembered for countless generations to come. David L. POWELL--Margaret Frances, was born July 07, 1937, and went home on July 20, 2011. Margaret was employed by the New York Times from September 14, 1970 until retiring on July 31, 1999. Despite being a native New Yorker she did not ride the New City Subway System. She was an avid reader, and self educated in many ways. Her husband William James Powell predeceased her in 1979. She is survived by her children, Michele and triplets, Tracey, Lance and Kim. As well as her siblings Jeannette, Charles, Beatrice, Richard and Howard; her grandchildren, Phillip, William, Alexis and Victor; and a host of nieces and nephews and grand nieces and nephews.

January is often the cruelest month for Broadway box offices, as holiday tourists head home, students go back to school and New Yorkers hibernate from the cold and snow. Last winter the lead producers of the Broadway revival ''Promises, Promises'' closed the show on Jan. 2 rather than gamble money on recasting their two stars, Sean Hayes and Kristin Chenoweth, and risk a slide in ticket sales. Those same producers are now behind another Broadway revival, ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying,'' but they have opted to replace their star, Daniel Radcliffe, who finishes his run as the scheming executive J. Pierrepont Finch on New Year's Day. Confirming rumors that have been circulating for a couple of weeks, the producers announced on Monday that Mr. Radcliffe (of ''Harry Potter'' fame) will be succeeded by a lesser-known actor, Darren Criss who has become popular recently on the Fox series ''Glee'' playing a gay high school student and show choir member who exudes charisma and self-confidence. In casting Mr. Criss the producers are seeking to appeal to at least some of the teenagers, women and gay men who often mob Mr. Radcliffe at the stage door after performances. Mr. Criss is scheduled for only a three-week engagement, Jan. 3 through 22. In their statement announcing Mr. Criss the producers did not say if they plan to cast another actor after him, close the $8.5 million production after he departs, or try to extend his run. A spokesman for the musical said the producers had not made decisions about the future of the show after the Criss run. This is a more complete version of the story than the one that appeared in print.

OLSON--Martha, who lived in both New York City and Southampton, died peacefully at her New York home surrounded by friends on July 30, 2011 after a long illness. Martha was a proud achiever and built a distinguished career in public relations. She and two partners started a PR firm in St. Louis that was so successful it was acquired by Farley Manning in New York, where she became a Sr. Vice President. She later joined Hill & Knowlton, rising to Sr. Vice President before her retirement. During the course of her career, Martha advised such powerful clients as the Principality of Monaco, Mexico's Department of Tourism (supervising the launch of Cancun), the Virgin Islands, Anheuser-Busch, E. I. du Pont de Nemours, Pet Milk and Chevron Chemical. Her hands-on style and creative ideas earned her major industry awards, including the Prisms Award presented by the Los Angeles chapter of the Public Relations Society of America in 1980, and two years later, she was one of the first women in the country to win the Silver Anvil Award, the highest honor given by the PRSA. Martha Annette Olson was born in Ft. Stockton, Texas on Christmas day 1920, the daughter of Auburn Elizabeth Bransford and John Nels Olson, a Swedish immigrant. She spent her formative years in Parsons, Kansas before moving to St. Louis and finally to New York. In an interview with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch in January 1958 regarding her public relations success, Martha said, "Speed somehow always seems to have been part of my life." Indeed she loved life in the fast lane, whether driving one of her low-slung sports convertibles, flying a single-engine plane as a 19-year-old student pilot and later becoming an airport traffic controller, or much later riding her horse, Dusty, in the Hamptons. Martha is survived by her sister and brother-in-law Jean and Joseph Stevens of Montecito, CA and her brother and sister-in-law Jack and Alice Olson of the National Forest north of Tucson, AZ. She is also survived by her close friends and real estate partners Jody Donohue and Etta Froio, and her beloved Wirehaired Fox Terrier Bentley, named for one of her flashy fast cars she loved to drive. View guestbook online at legacy.com

ROLO--Helen (Mendelson), 84, of NYC died peacefully on July 26. She was the daughter of Abraham and Fannie Mendelson. Helen attended both The High School of Music & Art and Julliard. She graduated from NYU in 1948. Helen was married to Charles J. Rolo from 1953-1968 and worked for Time Magazine and Harpers Bazaar which she left in 1958 to be with her family. She will be missed deeply by her son, Claude, his wife Kelly and her grandchildren, Kyler and Owen whom she lived for. She is also survived by her brother, Irving Mendelson.

WASHINGTON -- After months of partisan impasse, the House on Monday approved a budget agreement intended to head off a potential government default, pushing Congress a big step closer to the conclusion of a bitter fight that has left both parties bruised and exhausted. Despite the tension and uncertainty that has surrounded efforts to raise the debt ceiling, the vote of 269 to 161 was relatively strong in support of the plan, which would cut more than $2.1 trillion in government spending over 10 years while extending the borrowing authority of the Treasury Department. It would also create a powerful new joint Congressional committee to recommend broad changes in spending -- and possibly in tax policy -- to reduce the deficit.

HALL--Perry Edwards, 73, of Far Hills, NJ, died peacefully on July 30, 2011 in the company of his loving wife, Jeanne, and his children. He was born in Short Hills, NJ on January 23, 1938. A son of Herbert and Molly Hall, Perry grew up with four siblings: Seymour, Brooks, James and Holly. He graduated from Phillips Academy Andover in 1956, and Princeton University 1961, where he played hockey and lacrosse. Perry enjoyed a 40 year career in finance and retired in 2001 from Morgan Stanley in New York. He will be remembered for his extreme generosity to all he knew and his enthusiastic spirit. He maintained a beautiful farm in Far Hills, NJ, and enjoyed time on Long Beach Island, NJ and in Dorset, VT. Most importantly, Perry was a devoted husband, father, grandfather and friend. He is survived by his wife Jeanne, son Perry and his wife Lynn, son Brooks and his wife Sally, son Ben and his wife Laura, step-daughter Sandra Cane and her husband Michael, step-daughter Gennifer Puppe and her husband Kevin, eleven grandchildren, siblings Seymour, James and Holly, first wife Virginia Birch, many nieces and nephews and his dog Hunter. A funeral service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, NJ on Wednesday, August 3rd at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, expressions of sympathy may be made in Perry's memory to The American Cancer Society, P.O. Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK 73123.

Jude Law is Dickie Greenleaf, the scion whose father has hired Tom to bring him back to the United States from Italy; Gwyneth Paltrow is Marge, who must share Dickie's affections with his new friend. He said pilots keep the devices on “airplane mode” during takeoff and landing.

It felt to me like a whole new level of bungling was needed before I met my standard of a new entry for the Beekeeper's Journal.  Yes, I had lost both hives during an exceedingly cold snap in the preceding winter.  Yes, I had gone through the process of ordering packaged bees from Georgia and had even managed the workaround of securing two northward-trucked hives when the Georgia apiaries delayed shipment because of a devastating southern winter.  Yes, I had somehow installed the queens and hives, which involved the usual banging and subsequent pouring of nearly 3,000 bees into their new home, even though I was sure I had broken my hand earlier that day (a gangly kid on "Nature Walk" at school got tangled in my feet and dropped me to the pavement).  Yes, I watched in June as a cluster of 10,000 bees swarmed from one hive and coagulated on a tree branch sixty feet above the ground.  None of these events taken alone seemed to merit an instructive tale.  It was the swarm, however, that lay the groundwork for my recent mid-Summer bungle.

Type specimen books are the plumbing-parts catalogs of graphic design. They show graphic designers the ways in which different sizes and weights of letters sit together as typeset words, and how they showcase typographic form and style. A specimen book enables a designer to visualize the mix and match new and old typefaces. Although digital type foundries now sell their fonts online, most still issue the occasional specimen books and booklets, as a nod to tradition.

The actress Lauren Ambrose, best known as the rebellious Claire Fisher in the HBO series “Six Feet Under,” was not an obvious first choice for the Barbra Streisand role in the Broadway-bound revival of the musical “Funny Girl.” But a combination of acting skill, comic timing, singing talent — including the high belt that is critical for well-known numbers like “Don’t Rain on My Parade” — and a “quirky, surprising fearlessness” (in the words of the director Bartlett Sher) helped win Ms. Ambrose the role, the revival’s producers said on Wednesday.

Oxfam, the antihunger group, has been running a campaign to call attention to the global food crisis, its consequences and its potential solutions. The Times outlined the challenge of future food security on a warming planet in this article several weeks ago, and this week my colleague Jeffrey Gettleman described the appalling famine unfolding in Somalia. The Somalia situation has a drought component, although the causes of the suffering seem to be primarily political.

Like corpses in a bad horror movie, the women in the D.S.K. scandal pile up behind every door and under every bed. But the woman behind the man,  Anne Sinclair, has remained a somewhat shadowy figure. Vanessa Grigoriadis’s piece in New York magazine, borrowing heavily from interviews in Le Monde, Le Nouvel Observateur and the biography Madame DSK, which is currently available only in French, is filled with details of the marriage (both left spouses for each other; she prefers Paris, he their riad in Marrakesh; she broke off a friendship when her friend suggested D.S.K.’s affairs were too numerous to be forgivable even by a Frenchwoman). It also reminds us of Sinclair’s striking readiness, past and present, to stand behind and by her man, despite having a prominent career as a TV host and holding the purse strings.For those of you hankering for more of the “other woman,” it’s worth reading the account of one Marie-Victorine M. in the Daily Beast, who claims to have found D.S.K. irresistibly magnetic (their eyes met across a room and for four months they had a torrid affair), and yet who believes the account of the Sofitel maid is true. What convinced her?  “When I read the first articles in the American press containing for example the detail that he was supposed to have taken his presumed victim from behind, that encouraged me to believe this woman.”

In a small-business guide to accounting that we’ve just published, Darren Dahl writes about Bart Justice, who started a document-destruction business, Secure Destruction Service, in 2004. The business, based in Huntsville, Ala., grew from $70,000 in annual revenue its first year to $500,000 four years later. To finance his growth, Mr. Justice kept borrowing money from the bank, not realizing that the more he grew, the more he needed to borrow because his revenue was not covering his expenses. The loans meant he had money in his accounts — but it was borrowed money. “I knew how to print a financial statement from QuickBooks, but I couldn’t tell you what it meant,” he said. It took the intervention of business owners in a peer group Mr. Justice joined to convince him that if he didn’t master his finances he was going to lose his business.

It’s unusual for an opening act to outshine the headliner, but for Nightmare and the Cat it’s becoming par for the course. Led by the barely legal frontman Django James and his brother Samuel Stewart, the Los Angeles group is a rock ‘n’ roll force to be reckoned with. With moves not seen since Elvis Presley last took the stage, James and his cohorts are utterly captivating to watch and bring an energy to their live show that is increasingly rare. Nightmare performed at Mercury Lounge recently, celebrating the release of their self-titled EP, and held a dancing crowd under their spell from start to finish. Their showmanship is a testament to the brothers’ rightful position in the royal court of pop music as the children of the Eurythmics’ Dave Stewart and Bananarama’s Siobhan Fahey.

A bit magically unpretentious, a bit Disney in its polished quaintness, Hydra, a car-free Greek island, has long been home to Athenian nobility and far-flung laureates alike: Leonard Cohen emigrated in the 1960s; Brice Marden has kept residences here since the ’70s. But as of late, the island is perhaps best known to the art world as the site of the annual events of the über-collector Dakis Joannou’s Deste Foundation, which were inaugurated three years ago with an epic performance collaboration between Matthew Barney and Elizabeth Peyton. This June, Deste hosted more than 300 international guests for Doug Aitken’s video-enhanced stage show set on a repurposed freight ship, Black Mirror, starring Chloe Sevigny.

LOS ANGELES — Oprah Winfrey will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award and the actor James Earl Jones and the makeup artist Dick Smith will receive honorary Oscars for lifetime achievement this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said late Tuesday. The awards will be presented at a Governors Awards banquet, to be held in the Hollywood district of Los Angeles on Nov. 12. The academy’s governors, who give up to four special awards each year, did not grant an Irving Thalberg award for lifetime achievement by a film producer this year.

An annual report by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation commended the ABC Family cable channel for its representation of gay, lesbian and bisexual characters in its programming and for the racial diversity of those characters. In its fifth annual Network Responsibility Index, which Glaad issued on Wednesday, the organization gave a rating of “Excellent” to ABC Family, whose shows include “Pretty Little Liars,” “The Secret Life of the American Teenager,” “Greek” and “Switched at Birth,” and said that 55 percent of that channel’s 103 hours of original programming from June 2010 through May 2011 included “LGBT-inclusive images.” Herndon Graddick, the senior director of programs at Glaad, said in a statement, “Viewers expect to see television environments that accurately reflect what it’s like to be a young adult, and today that includes young adults who happen to be gay.”

Summer’s heat wave has many of us running for cover. Here, cool portable cotton “Sombrillas” from the Australian company Hollie and Harrie are a delightful alternative to unwieldy stick-in-the-sand umbrellas. Designed by Skye Hollingsworth and Claire Harris, longtime friends, the cheerful beach tents fold up to roughly the size of a yoga mat and come with a clever matching carrying case. Clean lines, 95 percent UV protection and three pitch-perfect summer colors — Moroccan blue, French stripe and a sunny yellow — ensure that our last days of summer will be stylish and sunburn free.

The return of the space shuttle Atlantis to the Earth’s atmosphere two weeks ago marked the close of NASA’s 30-year space shuttle program. Retirement of this popular and very visible shuttle program further strains the already diminished agency. “Space experts say the best and brightest often head for the doors when rocket lines get marked for extinction, dampening morale and creating hidden threats,” according to The Times. This is not the first time in NASA’s history when the agency faced publicity troubles. Back in 1974, after the success of the Mercury and Apollo programs, but before the initiation of the Shuttle Program, NASA was convinced by the National Endowment for the Arts to participate in its “Federal Graphics Improvement Program,” and do what many companies these days do to revive their image: undergo a redesign.Up until that point, NASA had been primarily using an insignia adapted by James Modarelli, the head of NASA’s Lewis Research Center Reports Division. This logo, created in 1959 and affectionately dubbed “The Meatball,” relied heavily on multiple visual metaphors. According to NASA’s Web site, “the sphere represents a planet, the stars represent space, the red chevron is a wing representing aeronautics (the latest design in hypersonic wings at the time the logo was developed), and then there is an orbiting spacecraft going around the wing.” Although charming in its quirkiness, the meatball proved difficult to reproduce given the printing technology available at the time and the variety of applications it would need to adorn.

Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, sends out a news release each month summarizing the automotive evaluations of the coming month’s issue. BUCKLEY--Richard D. United Stations Radio Networks mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend Rick Buckley. Rick was a beloved husband and father, and to us, will also always be remembered as both a peer and a mentor in the world of broadcasting. He was an ardent and passionate champion of the medium of radio, and was among the last of the influential broadcasters to operate his business in a family tradition with an eye towards the communities he served. His ability to identify and nurture his fellow broadcasters, inspire young entrants into the field and to do it all with grace and enthusiasm cannot be replaced. His recent induction into The New York State Broadcasters Hall of Fame is a testament to just a portion of his lasting legacy. He was a generous, caring and trusted friend who acted as a guiding light for both the broadcasting industry and for anyone who knew him personally. We will miss him always. Our hearts go out to his beloved wife Connie and his wonderful daughter Jennifer. Bonnie & Nick Verbitsky

BROTMAN--Adolph E. July 5, 1918 - July 31,2011. Died at home in Roslyn, NY. Graduate of Pratt Institute. Chief Specialist of Intelligence for the US Navy. Highly recognized as an outstanding illustrator of books and publications. Member of the NY Society of Illustrators. Avid traveler, classical music aficionado; model railroad enthusiast and builder. We will miss your wit, smile and sense of humor. He is survived by wife Doris, children Karyn, Judd, Jennifer and three grandsons. Donations to Nassau County Hospice of Woodbury, 99 Sunnyside Blvd., Woodbury, NY 11797-2901 or charity of your choice.

The Kings of Leon canceled the remainder of their United States tour on Monday, saying their lead singer, Caleb Followill, was ''suffering from vocal issues and exhaustion'' after becoming ill at a concert in Dallas last week, said a publicist for the group, Ken Weinstein. ''The band is devastated, but in order to give their fans the shows they deserve, they need to take this break,'' Mr. Weinstein said in a prepared statement.

SWORTZELL--Nancy. July 30, at age 80. The NYU Steinhardt School of Culture, Education, and Human Development mourns the death of our esteemed faculty member Nancy Swortzell, associate professor and co-founder of our educational theatre program. Generous, passionate, and nurturing, Nancy was devoted to her students, her craft, and the theatre community she helped to create. Nancy was a revered director, whose work -- honored by many educational theatre associations--touched the hearts of national and international audiences alike. We will miss her abiding friendship and presence in our daily lives. Donations in her memory may be made to the Lowell S. and Nancy Swortzell Graduate Scholarship Fund for Educational Theatre, c/o Barbara Kotlikoff, NYU Steinhardt Development, 25 West 4th Street, 4th Floor, New York, NY 10012.

COHEN--Eileen Sue Bernstein, age 72, died peacefully at home on August 2, 2011, surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband, Stephen A. Cohen, her children, David and his wife Ivy, Peter, Jonathan and his fiance Dara Silverstein, and her grandsons Jacob and Eli all the delights of her life. She is also survived by her sister Cynthia Wiesenthal and her nieces and nephews. Eileen was born in Brooklyn and grew up in Lawrence, New York. She attended Boston University and graduated from New York University School of Education, cum laude. She taught in public schools in New York City and Long Island, and at the Solomon Schechter Day School in Jericho, New York. Eileen was a role model in Port Washington, New York, serving as a leader in many organizations within her community. In 1979 Eileen broke boundaries when she was elected as the first woman President of Temple Beth Israel, where her family worshiped for 40 years, a testament to her determination, strong sense of character, and spiritual convictions. Eileen was devoted to the family she created and whom she loved so dearly. For her family, she always had boundless energy and enthusiasm. Throughout her life Eileen touched all who met her with her unique but simple acts of kindness and beautiful spirit. She lived each day with a quiet dignity that spoke loudly to all whom she encountered. Eileen was a bright light in everyone's life. She taught her family and friends a profound life lesson: love is pure, unconditional and infinite. She confronted cancer with remarkable courage and determination never with complaint or anger. She fought a valiant battle, and for six years was the victor. An avid skier, visiting Park City, Utah each winter was one of the highlights of her year. Skiing Deer Valley, making turns down Sidewinder, having lunch at the Empire Lodge, a Shabbat service at the Sunset Cabin, chamomile tea and a warm pretzel at the Stein, dinner with long term family friends, all surrounded by her loving family, was the perfect day for her. Eileen gave all of us more than we could ever give her in return. We are grateful for every day we spent with her, thank her for her love, and will honor her for as long as we live. She will always be in our hearts with love, respect and admiration. Services Wednesday 11am, August 3, 2011 at The Riverside W 76th St and Amsterdam Ave Interment to follow at Beth Moses Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions can be made to the Ovarian Cancer Translational Research Center at Mount Sinai School of Medicine.

PROUT--Evelyn Betts, of Manchester, VT, died after a brief illness July 29, 2011 at the age of 91. Born June 14, 1920, Evelyn Gloria Ohman grew up in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Smith College in 1941. She married Allan Whitney Betts in 1945 and settled in Oyster Bay, LI, raising three children. After her husband retired, they spent summers in Manchester, VT and winters in Jupiter Island, FL. Evie loved playing golf and Bridge with her many friends and spent many happy hours at her easel painting, her little dog Scooter by her side. After the death of her beloved husband Allan in 1986, she remarried to William W. Prout in 1990, her close companion until her death this week. Evelyn is predeceased by her husband of 41 years, Allan W. Betts and sister Dorothy Ericsson. She is survived by her sister Anne Wood of Rutland, VT, her three children Roland Betts of NYC, Nancy Betts of San Francisco and Alison DeWitt of Weston, MA. She is also survived by her husband of 21 years William W. Prout, her daughter-in-law Lois Betts, her son-in-law Robert DeWitt, and her five grandchildren, Margaret and Jessica Betts, and Zachary, Andrew and Brooke DeWitt. Evie will be remembered and cherished for her beautiful smile, her easy-going nature, her sense of humor, and her kind heart. She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend, loved by many people. A memorial service will be held later in the fall in Manchester, VT.

PERELMAN--Ruth. The board of directors, members, and staff of the Food Allergy Initiative mourn the loss of Ruth Caplan Perelman, mother of our dear friend, Ronald O. Perelman. Together with her husband, Raymond, and Ron, who served for many years as Corporate Dinner Chair of our Food Allergy Ball, Mrs. Perelman was committed to our mission to find a cure for life-threatening food allergies. Her legacy of philanthropy and compassion lives on in every generation of her family. We offer our heartfelt condolences to Ronald, to Ray, and to the entire family. May they be comforted by the knowledge that this extraordinary woman touched thousands of lives. Todd J. Slotkin, Chairman Sharyn T. Mann, Vice Chairman Food Allergy Initiative

Black bears are in abundance in Arizona, but they are not easy to spot. They scavenge for food over vast distances and generally keep to themselves. For a guaranteed glimpse of them, though, there is a place called Bearizona. About an hour's drive south of the Grand Canyon, Bearizona is one of those drive-through wilderness parks that are a step up from a zoo but far removed from the actual wild. One motors along a two-mile road through 160 acres, getting glimpses of wolves, sheep, bison, mountain goats, burros and then, finally, fenced off to themselves, the bears that lend this place its name.

The Park Avenue Armory will present a mini-festival dedicated to Philip Glass, putting on four performances of his music and of works by artists who have inspired him, on Feb. 23-26, the armory said on Monday. Those performing include Patti Smith and her band, as well as the jazz guitarist Bill Frisell. The Philip Glass Ensemble will play the composer's ''Music in Twelve Parts'' and the Brooklyn Youth Chorus, the Collegiate Chorale and Michael Riesman, playing the organ, will give the composer's ''Another Look at Harmony'' its first New York performance. Mr. Frisell and an ensemble will play a work he composed to accompany a reading of the Allen Ginsberg poem ''Kaddish.'' Called the Tune-in Music Festival, the event marks Mr. Glass's 75th birthday, which falls on Jan. 31.

Brian Friel's Tony Award-winning play ''Dancing at Lughnasa'' will return to New York 20 years after it opened on Broadway as part of the Irish Repertory Theater's new season. Told mostly through the memories of a narrator, ''Dancing at Lughnasa'' is about five unmarried Irish sisters living in a house in County Donegal in 1936, and a brother who returns to the home after spending 25 years as a priest at a leper colony in Uganda. ''Dancing at Lughnasa'' opened on Broadway in October of 1991, and won the Tony Award for best play. A 1998 film adaptation, written by the playwright Frank McGuinness, starred Meryl Streep and Michael Gambon.

5:35 p.m. | Updated Shakespeare surrounds us this season, perhaps even more than usual. Every summer brings the usual array of Shakespeare productions in parks and outdoor amphitheaters and, in New York at least, parking lots. The fare naturally tends toward the lighter and friskier side of the Shakespeare canon: on any given summer day, somewhere in America, you can see fairies frolicking alongside young lovers in flight from Athens in ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' In New York this summer we are dining - or rather feasting - on unusually ambitious and knotty plays. The Public Theater, in its Shakespeare in the Park, has chosen to present two of the playwright's dark late comedies, ''All's Well That Ends Well'' and ''Measure for Measure,'' while the Royal Shakespeare Company packed only one true comedy, ''As You Like It,'' in its trunks for its presentation of five Shakespeare plays in repertory at the Park Avenue Armory.

Bloomberg from conducting an orchestra Oct. 25 to celebrate the reopening of City Center. Not bad for a guy who quit piano lessons after a year because he hated to practice and whose favorite piece remains the C major scale. In homage to the dedication of the West 55th Street building in 1943 by his predecessor Fiorello H. La Guardia, Mr. Bloomberg will conduct the Encores! orchestra at the gala reopening to start a celebratory season at the landmark city-owned hall originally built as the Ancient Order of the Nobles of the Mystic Shrine in 1923.

4:57 p.m. | Updated | LOS ANGELES-- MSNBC said Tuesday that it had signed its top star, Rachel Maddow, to a new multi-year contract, cementing her position at the cable news channel for several years. The new contract comes a little more than six months after Keith Olbermann hastily departed MSNBC, shaking up the channel's prime time lineup. Mr. Olbermann, the 8 p.m. host, had been the top draw for viewers; now the top draw is Ms. Maddow, the 9 p.m. host, a protege of Mr. Olbermann who started hosting her show two months before the presidential election in 2008.

''Whiskey nerds'' is how George Ruotolo and his brother, Justin, describe themselves. With another partner, Rob Magill, they own bars, including The Whiskey Brooklyn, next to which they have carved out a wee dram of a shop with more than 100 different whiskeys. (They like to say 99 at any given time.) Most are bourbons, ryes and blended whiskeys made in America, often by craft distillers from Brooklyn to Berkeley, Calif. They also stock their own smooth, fairly light-bodied blended Kentucky whiskey, called Tom Lawless after a Ruotolo maternal grandfather. Whiskies from Ireland, Scotland, Canada and Japan also line the towering shelves, along with a couple of gins, a vodka and a rum. Down the road, some brandies will be crammed into the compact space. Jonathan Wingo, who runs the store, can tell you everything you need to know. He will pour tastes of the ones he has opened, but the bar next door, the Whiskey Brooklyn, has more of them, and will serve tasting flights. el4The Whiskey Shop, 44 Berry Street (entrance on North 11th Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 384 7467, is open 3 to 11 p.m. weekdays, except Tuesday, when it is closed; and 1 to 11 p.m. Saturday and Sunday. The Tom Lawless is $38 for a liter. A tasting flight of three whiskeys is $18 at The Whiskey Brooklyn.

El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan has appointed Margarita Aguilar, a vice president and specialist in Latin American art at Christie's, as its new director, the museum announced on Tuesday. Ms. Aguilar, 54, was a curator at El Museo from 1998 to 2006 before going to Christie's. ''It's a very good homecoming for me,'' she said in a telephone interview. She said that the museum's annual attendance had doubled since she left, to roughly 250,000 visitors, and added that she would like to see it increase still further. ''We want to be sure that we reach all of our constituents, including New Yorkers, Latinos and Latin Americans,'' she said. El Museo was founded in 1969 to serve the largely Puerto Rican population of East Harlem but has since expanded its scope to focus on Latino, Caribbean and Latin American art. Its previous director, Julian Zugazagoitia, left last year to become the director of the Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art in Kansas City, Mo. In June El Museo laid off four staff members as part of an effort to trim $1.1 million from its budget, which is now $5.6 million. Its finances are now stable, the museum's chairman, Tony Bechara, said. Ms. Aguilar, who was born in Cuba, has a master's degree in art history from Hunter College and is a doctoral candidate in art history at the Graduate Center at the City University of New York.

When it comes to produce, there is local, there is hyperlocal, and then there is the Riverpark Farm at Alexandria Center. This rather formal designation is the name of a two-week-old farm that has found a temporary home in a stalled Manhattan construction site bounded by plywood. It is less than 100 feet from the kitchen of Tom Colicchio's Riverpark restaurant on East 29th Street near the East River, and it is supplying produce for that 245-seat restaurant, as well as a 175-seat 'Wichcraft next door.

10 P.M. (Sundance) WHITE NIGHT WEDDING (2008) This double bill from Baltasar Kormakur, the Icelandic director, writer and actor, is introduced with his adaptation of Chekov's ''Ivanov,'' in which a middle-aged professor (Hilmir Snaer Gudnason) prepares to marry a former student (Laufey Eliasdottir) half his age -- if he doesn't get cold feet. The film swept seven categories at the Edda Awards, considered the most prestigious in Iceland. It is followed at 11:40 by ''Jar City'' (with Theodor Juliusson, above), Mr. Kormakur's moody 2006 thriller about a weary homicide detective (Ingvar E. Sigurdsson), who investigates the death of an old man and opens up a hornet's nest of crimes and secrets. ''The picture of Iceland that emerges'' in the film ''is vivid and powerful but not something the country's tourist board would be likely to endorse,'' A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. ''The landscape has its austere poetry, to be sure -- mountains framing the apartment blocks of Reykjavik, spits of volcanic rock jutting into a churning sea -- but a fog of damp unhappiness seems to pervade every face and conversation. And yet by the end of this film, based on a popular mystery novel by Arnaldur Indridason, it is hard not to feel a certain affection for the place.'' Mr. Scott described the movie as ''intricate and pointed, conjuring a haunting, satisfying puzzle out of violence and chaos.'' 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: BETTE DAVIS This all-day tribute begins with ''The Working Man'' (1933), starring Davis as a shoe company heiress who toils under cover for her business's chief rival. In ''The Petrified Forest'' (1936), at 6:30 p.m., she is a diner waitress with dreams of France who is caught between a destitute drifter (Leslie Howard) and a gangster (Humphrey Bogart). And in ''Jezebel'' (1938), at 10, she plays a tempestuous Southern belle whose willfulness destroys those who care for her.

The woman who is accused of robbing the hotel room of the ''Jeopardy!'' host Alex Trebek could face a life sentence under a California law for repeat offenders. Lucinda Moyers, 56, who last week was arrested on charges of felony burglary and receiving stolen property after Mr. Trebek pursued her from his room, has two previous burglary convictions on her record, a district attorney's spokeswoman told The San Francisco Chronicle. Ms. Moyers herself told The Chronicle that the two convictions stem from incidents at San Francisco hotels in 1990 and 1991, and that she would now be charged under California's three-strikes law, under which defendants can be sentenced for 25 years to life for a third felony conviction. Ms. Moyers said she had also served an 8 and 1/2-year sentence for a 1997 burglary conviction, but The Chronicle said this was not listed as a strike in the Trebek case.

FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — By the time we solvers get to Friday, we’re ready to sink our writing implements into some toothsome, long entries and wrestle with some clues that really make us think. That’s the kind of puzzle Barry Silk offers us today, along with some Scrabbly consonant mashups to help slow you down a bit.

LOS ANGELES — If those who give the Oscars are looking for laughs, action and the occasional outrage from their annual awards show, they are on the right track. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences on Thursday said Brett Ratner, a filmmaker known for directing the raucous “Rush Hour” series and for producing “Horrible Bosses,” will join Don Mischer in producing the next Oscar show, which is set to air Feb. 26 on ABC. Last year’s broadcast, produced by Mr. Mischer and Bruce Cohen, had soft ratings and was widely criticized for a lackluster performance by one of its hosts, James Franco. If energy is the issue, Mr. Ratner should be able to provide a fix. He is known as a film aficionado and an ambitious filmmaker whose is currently making a Snow White project for Relativity Media, and has dozens of projects in development. Recently, Mr. Ratner directed “Tower Heist.” That action picture, due Nov. 4 from Universal Pictures, has uncertain Oscar prospects, but counts Ben Stiller, Eddie Murphy, Matthew Broderick and Gabourey Sidibe among its stars.

The New York architecture firm Lewis.Tsurumaki.Lewis (LTL) is taking up residence on Hollywood’s Walk of Fame with “4 Projects: 4 Scales,” a new exhibition at Woodbury University’s Hollywood outpost, at 6518 Hollywood Boulevard. Riffing on Rem Koolhaas’s iconic 1990s book “S, M, L, XL,” the exhibition focuses on projects that range in size from the micro to the massive, in a mix of built and speculative work. For the site-specific installation, LTL inserted a three-sided container with etched and printed surfaces into a long, narrow gallery space. Visitors entering the container make their way through the exhibition from the largest of the four projects on view to the smallest, walking on a white-painted wood floor that is laser-etched with the plans of each project. Canted walls of backlit panels provide photographs, architectural drawings and descriptive text. “Water Proving Ground,” at 69 million square feet, is LTL’s extra-large project. This visionary master plan for the northwest corner of New York Harbor was conceived as part of MoMA/P.S. 1’s recent “Rising Currents” initiative, which studied the impact of anticipated sea-level change on the city. The other projects in the show are all built works: Arthouse, a contemporary art center in Austin, Tex.; the Sullivan Family Student Center at the University of Wyoming in Laramie; and Lobby Wall, a site-specific sculpture for the lobby of Memorial Sloan-Kettering’s new Manhattan building, which is the smallest of the projects at 108 square feet.

Since their debut record, “North Hills,” came out two years ago, the Los Angeles-based folk-rock band Dawes has been eliciting breathless comparisons to some pretty illustrious names — Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young, the Eagles, the Band. Partly it has to do with their origin myth: they recorded the album at the renowned producer Jonathan Wilson’s studio in Laurel Canyon after playing a run of small hootenannies there. But mostly it has to do with their sound, which has a warm, stripped-down Americana feel frequently described as “vintage.” Recently, the group got about as big a nod as four guys playing folk rock could hope for: Robbie Robertson, the somewhat reclusive songwriter from the Band, asked them to back him in a series of rare performances. Now in the middle of an East Coast tour to promote their follow-up record, “Nothing Is Wrong,” which was released this summer, Dawes seems both honored and amused to have been credited with leading a revival of the Laurel Canyon sound.

SHANGHAI — In “Run of the Red Queen,” a new book about China’s innovation drive, Dan Breznitz and Michael Murphree lay out a contrarian view of this country’s path. They argue that China should worry less about coming up with breakthrough technologies and focus more on what it already does best: making incremental innovations in everything from manufacturing to logistics.

LOS ANGELES - Oprah Winfrey will receive the Jean Hersholt Humanitarian Award and the actor James Earl Jones and the makeup artist Dick Smith will receive honorary Oscars for lifetime achievement this year from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, the academy said late Tuesday. The awards will be presented at a Governors Awards banquet, to be held in the Hollywood district of Los Angeles on Nov. 12. The academy's governors, who give up to four special awards each year, did not grant an Irving Thalberg award for lifetime achievement by a film producer this year. Ms. Winfrey, who received an Oscar nomination for her acting work in ''The Color Purple,'' was cited by the film academy for her involvement in a number of charitable enterprises, including the Oprah Winfrey Foundation. Mr. Jones has appeared in dozens of films including ''The Great White Hope,'' for which he received an Oscar nomination, and the original ''Star Wars'' trilogy, in which he provided the voice for Darth Vader. Mr. Smith earlier won an Oscar for his work on ''Amadeus,'' and was cited by the academy's governors for his contributions to ''The Godfather,'' ''Taxi Driver,'' ''The Exorcist'' and other films.

ROME -- As markets continued to hammer Italy, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on Wednesday rebutted calls for his resignation, saying Italy's economic fundamentals were strong and pledging that his government was ''up to the task'' of fostering economic growth. ''The country is economically and financially solid. In difficult moments, it knows how to stay together and confront difficulties,'' Mr. Berlusconi said in his first public remarks in a tense month. ''Today more than ever, we need to act all together.''

An article on Monday about a decision by Scholastic, the biggest publisher of children's books, to cut back its corporate-sponsored lesson plans for teachers quoted incorrectly from comments by Richard Robinson, the president and chief executive. He did not say ''there are corporate programs that have some value, that spread information that otherwise might not be heard.''

The JF3 Freedom Bluetooth stereo headphones from Jaybird are made for this heat wave - the headphones are designed to be sweat-proof. They even come with a lifetime guarantee against damage caused by sweat. Intended for use in the gym, the in-ear phones have a housing that is seamless and sealed. Even the microphone hole is covered in protective gauze that allows sound through but also blocks moisture. While moisture resistant, the earphones aren't moisture-proof-the access for the microphone means the earphone cannot be completely submerged.

'MINING THE WEB FOR THE ''VOICE OF THE HERD'' TO TRACK STOCK MARKET BUBBLES' by Mark T. Keane, chairman of computer science, University College Dublin, and Aaron Gerow, graduate student at Trinity College Dublin. Proceedings of the 22nd International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence in Barcelona, July 2011. THE EXPERIMENT Stock market bubbles occur when everyone is talking about the market and has a positive view of it, which is why John D. Rockefeller reputedly got out of the market when a bellhop asked him for a stock tip, Mr. Keane and Mr. Gerow write. They wondered if it would be possible to take a different sort of tip from Rockefeller and listen to the ''voice of the herd'' by tracking the language used by financial commentators. They analyzed 17,713 finance-related articles online from The New York Times, The Financial Times and the BBC from 2006 to 2010. Their hypothesis was that financial commentators would come to repeat the same optimistic words and terms to express a shared positive view of the stock market, evidence that a kind of group think has grabbed hold in the period leading up to and during an economic bubble.

Other pieces to mix and match include a minidress with knit sleeves, $380, and trousers with a flap front, $450. E DDIE BORGO, he of the spiked collars and studded cuffs, looked to nature, of all places, for inspiration for his new fall collection. Citing influences like ''Flora,'' the Nick Knight volume of flower photographs, Mr. Borgo conjured cuffs with ladybugs and dragonflies, sculptural spider necklaces and the swingy silk tassel necklace and earrings framing the face and dusting the shoulders of Tabitha Simmons (top) in his new online campaign. Mr. Borgo, who in the past has summoned oh-so-fashionable friends like Giovanna Battaglia and Kate Lanphear as his stars, called on the stylist and shoe designer this season. ''Tabitha has a neo- romantic, gothic sensibility about her,'' he said. ''The look is sincere to who she is.''

SACERDOTE--Peter M. We mourn the loss of our dear friend and longtime member of the Weill Cornell Medical College Board of Overseers, Peter M. Sacerdote. Mr. Sacerdote's wise counsel, in his roles as chair of the Business & Finance Committee and member of the Executive, Development and ad hoc Planning Committees, has contributed greatly to Weill Cornell's growth in New York and globally. A graduate of Cornell University with a degree in electrical engineering, he had an abiding interest in science. Together with his wife, Bonnie, he was a generous patron and loyal friend of Weill Cornell, supporting urologic oncology, women's health and gene therapy. Among his many outstanding contributions, he and Bonnie served as co-chairs of the Cabaret gala in 2002, endowed the Bonnie Johnson Sacerdote Clinical Scholar Award in her honor in 2006, and was a substantial supporter of the current Discoveries That Make a Difference Capital Campaign. In recognition of his leadership and vision, the College established the Peter M. Sacerdote Urological Research Laboratory and the Peter M. Sacerdote Distinguished Professorship in Urologic Oncology. Measured, thoughtful and modest, he was an extraordinary colleague and will be greatly missed. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bonnie; his children Alexander, Alisa and Laurence; and the entire Sacerdote family. Sanford I. Weill Chairman, Board of Overseers Antonio M. Gotto Jr., M.D., D.Phil. Dean Weill Cornell Medical College

LASTAVICA--John, of Manchester, MA died at home on July 29, 2011 of cancer. He was born on March 2, 1930 in Novi Sad, Serbia, son of Milan Lastavica and Danica Mihailovich Lastavica. John's father was a mining engineer and professor, who at age 17 volunteered with the Serbian Army fighting on the Salonica front and died in 1932. In 1947, after spending WWII in Belgrade, John escaped from communist Yugoslavia by crossing the Adriatic Sea to Italy on a fourteen-foot sailboat with his mother and two of his sisters. From Italy they went to Peru where he received a Doctorate in Economics from the Catholic University in Lima and worked for General Motors. In 1958 he came to the United States to Yale University where he met and married the late Rita Scimia of Haverhill, MA; they divorced in 1963. He worked for the Ford Motor Company in Detroit and then became an officer of the Bank of Boston with his focus on Operations Research. John's volunteer positions included: President of the International Institute of Boston, Chairman of the Board of the Landing School of Boat Building and Design in Kennebunkport, ME, and Trustee of the Museum of Fine Arts Boston. In New York in 1964, John was reunited with his uncle Steven Lastavica, the first Bishop of the Serbian Orthodox Church appointed to the United States and Canada after WWII. The Bishop was falsely accused of being a communist and he successfully argued his case before the United States Supreme Court. John was a genial gentleman of many talents who did not hesitate to rise in support of the truth. His wife of thirty four years, Catherine Coolidge Lastavica, MD., his daughter Maria and her husband Alain Briancon, his granddaughter Alicia and grandsons Marc and Aidan survive him. A Memorial Service will be held on Coolidge Point Tuesday, August 30, at 11am. Donations in his name may be made to The Thomas Jefferson Heritage Society, P.O. Box 4482, Charlottesville, VA 22905-4482. For online condolences please visit www.campbellfuneral.com

SOYER--Janet Putnam, May 20, 1921 July 31, 2011, was an accomplished harpist, talented painter, creative and energetic spirit, and beloved wife of the late David Soyer. A graduate of the Curtis Institute of Music, she was a member of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra and a leading jazz harpist, who can be heard on numerous recordings with Frank Sinatra, Billie Holiday, Sarah Vaughan, Miles Davis, and Artie Shaw. She left professional life to support her husband David's career as cellist of the Guarneri Quartet. A woman of great beauty, sharp intellect, keen curiosity, strong opinions, and a never-failing sense of humor, she had a gift for gathering friends and connecting people in circles of caring and sharing. Gifts in her memory may be made to the Marlboro Music Festival, 1616 Walnut St. Suite 1600, Philadelphia, PA 19103.

BUCKLEY--Richard D. United Stations Radio Networks mourns the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend Rick Buckley. Rick was a beloved husband and father, and to us, will also always be remembered as both a peer and a mentor in the world of broadcasting. He was an ardent and passionate champion of the medium of radio, and was among the last of the influential broadcasters to operate his business in a family tradition with an eye towards the communities he served. His ability to identify and nurture his fellow broadcasters, inspire young entrants into the field and to do it all with grace and enthusiasm cannot be replaced. His recent induction into The New York State Broadcasters Hall of Fame is a testament to just a portion of his lasting legacy. He was a generous, caring and trusted friend who acted as a guiding light for both the broadcasting industry and for anyone who knew him personally. We will miss him always. Our hearts go out to his beloved wife Connie and his wonderful daughter Jennifer. Bonnie & Nick Verbitsky

PETER PAN collars, those demure relics of the Eisenhower era, turned downright naughty on the fall runways, and nowhere more so than at Louis Vuitton, where they appeared in nearly all of Marc Jacobs's provocative looks. Mr. Jacobs, in full fetish mode, showed the collars in leather on tailored French maid uniforms, as an attached bib front, and in black patent leather on military jackets and corseted tops (left). And now, it seems, the collars are finding favor with cool girls all over town. Karen Elson (near right) wore a Valentino embroidered Peter Pan-collared dress with a leather miniskirt to perform at a Lincoln Center benefit; Brooklyn Decker (far right, top) chose a collared Alexander Wang number with a plunging neckline for a Sephora event; and the actress Emily Browning (far right, bottom) wore a Vuitton abbreviated cashmere jumpsuit with a varnished leather collar, and thigh-high stockings, to an amfAR gala in Paris. Think about it: You'll never have to grow up.

Lisa Schiff, Chairman Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman Adrian Ellis, Executive Director

New bells and whistles aren't the only reason to upgrade to Lion. The new version of Apple's operating system for the Mac also includes updated security features. Macs have long been safer than Windows PCs, because they are very rarely chosen for attacks, probably because of the Mac's much smaller market share and to crooks' extensive expertise in writing malware for Windows. But now, they are also more secure than PCs, thanks to several crucial security improvements in the operating system itself, Mac OS X 10.7 ($30 download from the Mac App store).

Nordstrom has a waiting list for a Chanel sequined tweed coat with a $9,010 price. Neiman Marcus has sold out in almost every size of Christian Louboutin ''Bianca'' platform pumps, at $775 a pair. Mercedes-Benz said it sold more cars last month in the United States than it had in any July in five years. Even with the economy in a funk and many Americans pulling back on spending, the rich are again buying designer clothing, luxury cars and about anything that catches their fancy. Luxury goods stores, which fared much worse than other retailers in the recession, are more than recovering -- they are zooming. Many high-end businesses are even able to mark up, rather than discount, items to attract customers who equate quality with price.

Mama said there'd be days like this, but she didn't say that such a day would come so soon for ''Baby It's You!'' That Broadway jukebox musical, about the Scepter Records founder Florence Greenberg and her discovery of the girl group the Shirelles, will play its final performance on Sept. 4, its press representatives said on Wednesday. Though the show featured a cast including Beth Leavel, a Tony Award-winner for ''The Drowsy Chaperone,'' and a book by Floyd Mutrux and Colin Escott, the writers of ''Million Dollar Quartet,'' ''Baby It's You!'' did not generate many harmonious reviews when it opened at the Broadhurst Theater in April. Reviewing the musical for The New York Times, Charles Isherwood wrote that it resembled ''one of those PBS pledge-night specials devoted to oldies but goodies.'' Its sole Tony Award nod was for Ms. Leavel, a nominee for lead actress in a musical. At its closing, ''Baby It's You!'' will have played 33 previews and 151 regular performances.

Over the last several weeks, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made a series of unusual fund-raising calls to a handful of wealthy New Yorkers. Would they be willing, he asked, to chip in $250,000 each to save some standardized tests? The state, he told them, had canceled the January administration of the high school Regents exams, endangering the graduation of thousands of city students. Principals were warning of disastrous consequences and more dropouts. To reinstate the exams for next year, the state needed $1.4 million the State Legislature did not provide.

SACERDOTE--Peter Marcello, of New York City and Nantucket, MA died in New York on July 31st peacefully surrounded by his family. He succumbed to the prostate cancer that he had been stalwartly battling for many years. He was 73 years old. Mr. Sacerdote was born October 15, 1937 in Turin, Italy and in 1940 his family moved to the United States. He received a Bachelor's Degree of Electrical Engineering from Cornell University in 1960. He served in the Navy from 1960-1962 as Lieutenant (JG), and graduated as a Baker Scholar from Harvard Business School in 1964. He was married to Bonnie L. Johnson on June 18, 1967 in Bronxville, NY. They were devotedly married for forty-four years. Peter enjoyed a distinguished forty-one year career with Goldman, Sachs & Co., which he joined in 1964 directly from business school. He became a General Partner in 1972 and in 1973 was appointed head of the firm's Private Finance Department. In 1980 he became head of the firm's Corporate Finance Department serving in that role for seven years. In 1987 Peter became Co-Head of the firm's merchant banking activities, and served as Chairman of its Investment Committee. He was also Chairman of both the Firm's Commitments and Credit Committees until he retired as a General Partner in 1990. Peter remained active as a Limited Partner serving as Chairman of Goldman's Principal Investment Area's (PIA) Investment Committee - the group responsible for Goldman's corporate private equity and venture capital investing. He served in this role until his retirement in 2006. Peter was known within the firm for his wisdom and investment acumen as well as for being a great teacher, mentor, and friend to many and always reminding everyone, how important it is to have a sense of humor. In 2006, Peter co-founded Whale Rock Capital Management a long-short technology hedge fund with his son Alexander. Peter served as the firm's Chairman for five years and greatly enjoyed working with his son and helping the firm grow to an eight person operation. Over the years, Mr. Sacerdote served on seven corporate boards but there were two that he had a special affinity for: Qualcomm, Inc. and Franklin Resources, Inc. As a Cornell "double EE," Peter had a strong understanding of technology and appreciated his vantage point at Qualcomm to watch the wireless communications revolution unfold. Peter also particularly enjoyed serving on the Board of Franklin Resources, Inc, a firm his father in law founded in 1947. His philanthropic activities included science, education and the arts. He was respected as an active and effective board member. He was on the Board of Overseers of Weill Cornell Medical School and established the Peter M. Sacerdote Urology Laboratory of Research at New York Hospital. He was an Adjunct Professor at Columbia University Business School where he taught a course in corporate finance. He served on the Board of Duke University's Fuqua Business School and Milton Academy. For two years, he served as President of the Alumni Association at Harvard Business School where he established the Peter M. Sacerdote Prize for Social Entrepreneurship. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He also partnered with his wife Bonnie in supporting a number of cultural institutions, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Nantucket Island where Peter spent the last forty two summers, held a very special place in his heart. He loved the island for its natural beauty, sports, friendships and most of all because it was a great place to spend time with his family. Some of his fondest memories were boating and fishing off the shores of Coatue and Great Point with his children and grandchildren. Peter loved playing golf with his friends on Nantucket, whether on the rolling fairways of the Nantucket Golf Club, where he was a founding member, or at seaside Sankaty Head, for which he had a special love having served as a board member for several years and as the Club's President from 2008-2010. Peter also loved his special times with family and friends at the Nantucket Yacht Club, never more so than his last time there - at a picnic celebration of this years 4th of July. He was also active in the Nantucket philanthropic affairs. He endowed the Annual Nantucket Cottage Hospital Health Fair, enabling free mammograms and prostate screenings for local residents. Peter recognized the paramount importance of preserving the island's open, natural land and devoted much time and expertise as a board member of the Nantucket Conservation Foundation. But at his core, Peter was a family man. He derived the most joy from his children, their spouses and his grandchildren, to whom he will always be an inspiration. He lived his life with dignity, grace, and a wonderfully positive attitude, all of which earned him the respect and admiration of those around him. Peter will be remembered as a man dedicated to his family, friends and the communities in which he was involved. All his friends and colleagues continually commented on his wide ranging intellect, his wit and his truly unique sense of humor. These qualities touched all those around him. Peter is survived by his devoted family including his wife Bonnie, his daughter Alisa Brockelman, his sons Alexander and Laurence, his son-in-law Curt Brockelman, daughter-in-law Annagret Sacerdote and his five grandchildren Curtis Brockelman III, Nina Brockelman, Bridget Brockelman, Kate Sacerdote and Peter Sacerdote. In addition he is survived by his brother George Sacerdote, sister in law Carol Sacerdote and their two nephews David and Michael. His other two nephews are the sons of his older brother Albert who predeceased him. He is also pre deceased by his parents Luciana and Giorgio. A private family burial will be held on Nantucket. A future memorial service will take place in New York City, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in honor of Mr. Peter Sacerdote to Memorial Sloan- Kettering Box 27106, New York, NY 10087 or to The Nantucket Conservation Foundation, P.O. Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554-0013.

''Lysistrata Jones,'' a musical comedy about sex and college basketball that had a well-received production Off Broadway in the spring, will transfer to Broadway and begin performances on Nov. 12 and open on Dec. 14 at the Walter Kerr Theater, the show's producers said on Wednesday. The music and lyrics are by Lewis Flinn and the book is by the playwright Douglas Carter Beane, a three-time Tony Award contender who most recently shared a nomination in June for the book of the musical ''Sister Act.'' The move to Broadway is a big leap: ''Lysistrata Jones'' played this spring in the 99-seat gymnasium of the Judson Memorial Church in Greenwich Village, while the Kerr (while on the small side for musicals) has about 940 seats to sell for each performance. Some Off Broadway shows founder financially in the transition to the much larger Broadway houses; two such musicals last season, ''Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson'' and ''The Scottsboro Boys,'' flopped in their uptown theaters. But Mr. Beane said in an interview on Wednesday that he was optimistic that ''Lysistrata Jones,'' which will cost $6 million to mount, would find a wide audience.

An article on July 26 about urban evolution described the rise of nonnative Oriental bittersweet vines incorrectly. The vines are outcompeting American bittersweet in a 50-mile radius of New York City, research by the Brooklyn Botanic Garden has found; they are not replacing American bittersweet at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

From its beginnings in the United States, Comedy Central has expanded to become a global presence, with channels in countries like Britain, Poland, Israel and New Zealand. A comedy explosion in Brazil, brought on by ''a new generation of humorists out there who are acid, vibrant and clever,'' will see that cable channel make its debut early next year in its largest overseas market (200 million people) and establish its first foothold in Latin America. Álvaro Paes de Barros, the general manager for Viacom in Brazil, who is supervising the opening of Comedy Central there, talked with Larry Rohter about the new generation of Brazilian comedians, cultural gulfs in humor and how to overcome them. Here are excerpts from that conversation: Q. Do American styles of humor automatically translate to a society like Brazil?

Updated, 1:49 p.m. | A supervisor at a state-run psychiatric center on Staten Island surrendered to the police on Wednesday to face homicide charges in the death of a 27-year-old man who was asphyxiated while being restrained last December, the authorities said. The supervisor, Erik Stanley, pleaded not guilty at his arraignment on Wednesday on charges of criminally negligent homicide and endangering the welfare of an incompetent or physically disabled person for the death of Jawara Henry, 27, the Staten Island district attorney's office said.

The actress Lauren Ambrose, best known as the rebellious Claire Fisher in the HBO series ''Six Feet Under,'' was not an obvious first choice for the Barbra Streisand role in the Broadway-bound revival of the musical ''Funny Girl.'' But a combination of acting skill, comic timing, singing talent - including the high belt that is critical for well-known numbers like ''Don't Rain on My Parade'' - and a ''quirky, surprising fearlessness'' (in the words of the director Bartlett Sher) helped win Ms. Ambrose the role, the revival's producers said on Wednesday. Ms. Ambrose, 33, will star as the comedian and actress Fanny Brice in the revival, which is scheduled for a tryout run at the Ahmanson Theater in Los Angeles from Jan. 15 to Feb. 26, 2012, before an anticipated move to New York in the spring. It would be the first production of ''Funny Girl'' on Broadway since the Streisand-led original, which ran from 1964 to 1967 and led to a 1968 film version for which Ms. Streisand won a best-actress Academy Award.

8 P.M. (Planet Green) DETROIT IN OVERDRIVE Planet Green teams up with General Motors for a three-part program to examine how this city, which once dominated automotive production, is working to rebuild from a devastating economic decline. Part 1 follows creative types like Joe Faris, who moved back home to Detroit from New York to establish Motor City Denim, a fashion line incorporating elements like seat belts and rivets. The items are made in a retrofitted factory that manufactured protective covers for auto-industry robots for more than 30 years. Then there's Badass Beer, which the Grammy-winning rapper Kid Rock devised to bolster employment in his hometown, and First Robotics, an after-school program founded by Dean Kamen, the inventor of the Segway PT, to pique the interest of high school students. Part 2, at 9, explores the significance of the arts in Detroit, including an installation by Tyree Guyton (above) focusing on the city's homeless and the Sphinx Organization, which introduces classical music to Latino and black children. And Part 3, at 10, visits with those spearheading local food campaigns and highlights the efforts of Veronika Scott, a fourth-year student at the College for Creative Studies who has designed a heat-capturing coat that turns into a sleeping bag. It is made for the homeless and by the homeless, and has become part of a broader effort to provide housing, food and jobs. 4:30 P.M. (HBO Signature) GREENBERG (2010) In what A. O. Scott of The New York Times called Noah Baumbach's ''funniest and saddest movie'' so far, ''and also the riskiest,'' Ben Stiller plays Roger Greenberg, a 40-year-old former musician who, after a mental breakdown, house-sits in the large Los Angeles home of his vacationing brother. Greta Gerwig portrays Florence Marr, the brother's 25-year-old assistant and Roger's on-again, off-again love interest in his quest to recapture his youth. ''Mr. Stiller, suppressing his well-honed sketch comedian's urge to wink at the audience, turns Roger into a walking challenge to the Hollywood axiom that a movie's protagonist must be likable,'' Mr. Scott wrote. Only at the end does Mr. Baumbach reveal that the film has been ''a romantic comedy all along,'' he said. ''And suddenly a movie about a man who is defiantly difficult to like becomes very hard not to love.'' (Above, Mr. Stiller with Bree Larson, left, and Juno Temple.)

FORER--David, May 6, 1919 - August 1, 2011. Husband of Margery Bregman for sixty three years. Father of David B. and Kathy, father-in-law of Mimi, grandfather of David W., Chessa and Katie. A man of integrity, strength and compassion. We are blessed to be left with the standard of his character and the memory of his loyal, loving person. He taught us so much, especially how to see. We will always remain deeply grateful for David Forer's life. The family will receive friends Thursday, August 4, 5:30-7:pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

“Big Brother” on CBS claimed the top spot for total viewers in prime time among programs on the broadcast networks Thursday night, and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, with 7.3 million viewers tuning in according to Nielsen. After the contestants voted to evict another member of the “Big Brother” household, it was announced that a new twist would be added to the shows’ long-in-the-tooth format.  Fans can now go to CBS.com and vote for a previously evicted resident, and the person with the most votes will get the chance to return to the show. The reality program carried CBS to an overall ratings victory as well, averaging around 6.3 million total viewers for the night. ABC came in second, averaging just under 5.5 million viewers thanks to its reality competitions, “Wipeout” (6.6 million viewers) and “Expedition Impossible.” (4.8 million).

First quarter sales had fallen by about 6.41 percent from the year-earlier period.

To put it in layman’s terms, NewVillager is a pop band that plays art galleries. Its debut album comes out Aug. 16 on IAMSOUND Records.

The job numbers every month come from two different surveys, which sometimes point in different directions. The establishment survey questions employers, and produces one headline number. This month it concluded that, seasonally adjusted, the economy added 117,000 jobs in July. The household survey asks people if they are working, and is used to calculate the unemployment rate.

“A World On Fire” by Amanda Foreman makes its debut at No. 10. Ms. Foreman, the acclaimed historian, sheds light on the vast involvement that Britain had in the American Civil War; the fruits of her research shocked her: finding that countless British writers, students, actors and others sympathized with the feudal South. “The Storm Of War” by Andrew Roberts debuts at No. 13. A British historian, Roberts ponders that if the Axis had strategized and made better decisions, they possibly could have won World War II. And the final debut is “The Triple Agent” by Joby Warrick at No. 14. This is the first comprehensive account of the C.I.A. blunder that allowed a Qaeda mole, Humam al-Balawi, a Jordanian pediatrician turned spy, to detonate a custom-made vest of explosives that took the lives of nine intelligence operatives at a C.I.A. base in Afghanistan.

CHENEY, Wash. — A beautiful, difficult three-day ride through the Palouse region of eastern Washington has left me leg-weary and sun-baked, and reminded of how bicycle touring lets you experience the country in intensely felt geographical segments. I made it here, a college town (Eastern Washington University) just south of Spokane, and it feels like a pivot; next I head east, toward Idaho, Montana and the Rockies.

When Toyota and Tesla Motors announced an agreement last year to collaborate on electric versions of the RAV4 compact S.U.V., there was much speculation that the battery car would be built at the 5.5-million-square-foot Nummi plant in California that Tesla bought in 2010. Have you ever e-mailed a bunch of photos to your family? Or written an e-mail to all of your best friends trying to plan a trip? Or have you done the same thing on Facebook, trying to carry on a discussion in a message to a dozen recipients? Facebook has a fix for that – Facebook Groups – explicitly designed to let a small set of people communicate with one another either in public, or in private. Groups are meant to replace mailing lists for people planning weddings, parties or team events.

This week Andy Warhol would have been 83 years old. As an artist who immortalized mass-produced commercial products, Warhol ruffled the feathers of the fine art establishment with his cheerfully banal connoisseurship. Gore Vidal once said Warhol was a genius with the IQ of a moron. In that, Warhol reminds me of the reclusive simpleton Chauncey Gardener, the character in Jerzy Kosinski’s “Being There” lauded for uttering Zen-like nuggets of wisdom when, in fact, like the quotable Warhol, he was a mere precursor to Forrest Gump.

Prince Language has been spinning house music for a really long time,” says Hanratty of the D.J. whose remix work for acclaimed artists like LCD Soundsystem, the Rapture and MGMT put him on the map as one of New York City’s most in-demand remixers in dance music. “His is a near-encyclopedic knowledge of both hip-hop and house.” Language, who hails from Chicago and now calls Manhattan’s Alphabet City home, worked on Twin Shadow‘s debut album, “Forget,” and is currently at bat on a remix for Light Asylum, as well as his own record.
