SACERDOTE--Peter Marcello, of New York City and Nantucket, MA died in New York on July 31st peacefully surrounded by his family. He succumbed to the prostate cancer that he had been stalwartly battling for many years. He was 73 years old. Mr. Sacerdote was born October 15, 1937 in Turin, Italy and in 1940 his family moved to the United States. He received a Bachelor's Degree of Electrical Engineering from Cornell University in 1960. He served in the Navy from 1960-1962 as Lieutenant (JG), and graduated as a Baker Scholar from Harvard Business School in 1964. He was married to Bonnie L. Johnson on June 18, 1967 in Bronxville, NY. They were devotedly married for forty-four years. Peter enjoyed a distinguished forty-one year career with Goldman, Sachs & Co., which he joined in 1964 directly from business school. He became a General Partner in 1972 and in 1973 was appointed head of the firm's Private Finance Department. In 1980 he became head of the firm's Corporate Finance Department serving in that role for seven years. In 1987 Peter became Co-Head of the firm's merchant banking activities, and served as Chairman of its Investment Committee. He was also Chairman of both the Firm's Commitments and Credit Committees until he retired as a General Partner in 1990. Peter remained active as a Limited Partner serving as Chairman of Goldman's Principal Investment Area's (PIA) Investment Committee - the group responsible for Goldman's corporate private equity and venture capital investing. He served in this role until his retirement in 2006. Peter was known within the firm for his wisdom and investment acumen as well as for being a great teacher, mentor, and friend to many and always reminding everyone, how important it is to have a sense of humor. In 2006, Peter co-founded Whale Rock Capital Management a long-short technology hedge fund with his son Alexander. Peter served as the firm's Chairman for five years and greatly enjoyed working with his son and helping the firm grow to an eight person operation. Over the years, Mr. Sacerdote served on seven corporate boards but there were two that he had a special affinity for: Qualcomm, Inc. and Franklin Resources, Inc. As a Cornell "double EE," Peter had a strong understanding of technology and appreciated his vantage point at Qualcomm to watch the wireless communications revolution unfold. Peter also particularly enjoyed serving on the Board of Franklin Resources, Inc, a firm his father in law founded in 1947. His philanthropic activities included science, education and the arts. He was respected as an active and effective board member. He was on the Board of Overseers of Weill Cornell Medical School and established the Peter M. Sacerdote Urology Laboratory of Research at New York Hospital. He was an Adjunct Professor at Columbia University Business School where he taught a course in corporate finance. He served on the Board of Duke University's Fuqua Business School and Milton Academy. For two years, he served as President of the Alumni Association at Harvard Business School where he established the Peter M. Sacerdote Prize for Social Entrepreneurship. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He also partnered with his wife Bonnie in supporting a number of cultural institutions, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Nantucket Island where Peter spent the last forty two summers, held a very special place in his heart. He loved the island for its natural beauty, sports, friendships and most of all because it was a great place to spend time with his family. Some of his fondest memories were boating and fishing off the shores of Coatue and Great Point with his children and grandchildren. Peter loved playing golf with his friends on Nantucket, whether on the rolling fairways of the Nantucket Golf Club, where he was a founding member, or at seaside Sankaty Head, for which he had a special love having served as a board member for several years and as the Club's President from 2008-2010. Peter also loved his special times with family and friends at the Nantucket Yacht Club, never more so than his last time there - at a picnic celebration of this years 4th of July. He was also active in the Nantucket philanthropic affairs. He endowed the Annual Nantucket Cottage Hospital Health Fair, enabling free mammograms and prostate screenings for local residents. Peter recognized the paramount importance of preserving the island's open, natural land and devoted much time and expertise as a board member of the Nantucket Conservation Foundation. But at his core, Peter was a family man. He derived the most joy from his children, their spouses and his grandchildren, to whom he will always be an inspiration. He lived his life with dignity, grace, and a wonderfully positive attitude, all of which earned him the respect and admiration of those around him. Peter will be remembered as a man dedicated to his family, friends and the communities in which he was involved. All his friends and colleagues continually commented on his wide ranging intellect, his wit and his truly unique sense of humor. These qualities touched all those around him. Peter is survived by his devoted family including his wife Bonnie, his daughter Alisa Brockelman, his sons Alexander and Laurence, his son-in-law Curt Brockelman, daughter-in-law Annagret Sacerdote and his five grandchildren Curtis Brockelman III, Nina Brockelman, Bridget Brockelman, Kate Sacerdote and Peter Sacerdote. In addition he is survived by his brother George Sacerdote, sister in law Carol Sacerdote and their two nephews David and Michael. His other two nephews Dean and Bruce Sacerdote are the sons of his older brother Albert who predeceased him. He is also pre deceased by his parents Luciana and Giorgio. A private family burial will be held on Nantucket. A future memorial service will take place in New York City, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in honor of Mr. Peter Sacerdote to Memorial Sloan- Kettering Box 27106, New York, NY 10087 or to The Nantucket Conservation Foundation, P.O. Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554-0013.

GOLDMAN--Priscilla (Perky) Dilks. Beloved wife, mother and grandmother. Priscilla died on July 19, at White Plains Hospital, of pneumonia. Priscilla was born in Richmond, IN, September 29, 1928. She graduated from Indiana University, where she was a member of the Delta Delta Delta sorority, a life long source of friendship. She worked for the USIS in Helsinki, Finland after graduating. She later moved to Washington, DC, where she met Richard Goldman. They were married there on April 23, 1960. Richard passed away in 2004. She was an active volunteer all of her life, most recently at White Plains Public Library and Meals on Wheels. She is survived by daughter Sally Goldman, son Robert Goldman, daughter-in-law Pamela Goldman, and grandchildren Elana and Arthur Goldman. Memorial service Sunday, August 7, 11am at Summerfield Suites Hotel, White Plains, NY.

The Deal Professor column on Wednesday, about the career paths of Enron directors after the energy company collapsed in 2001, misstated the year that one former director, Ken L. Harrison, retired as chief executive of the Portland General Electric Company. It was 2000, not last year.

For documentary fans, this year's Toronto International Film Festival will bring a variety of new films from familiar names. The festival said today that new work from Werner Herzog, Nick Broomfield, Morgan Spurlock, Frederick Wiseman, Alex Gibney and Wim Wenders will screen, many as world premieres. Films profiling the artist Gerhard Richter (by Corinna Belz), the hockey player Chris Nilan (by Mr. Gibney) and the nude dancers of Paris's Crazy Horse club (by Mr. Wiseman) are part of the lineup, but the documentary portrait that could spark the most discussion is ''Sarah Palin - You Betcha!,'' a look by Mr. Broomfield and Joan Churchill into the life of the former Alaska governor through interviews with friends, family and colleagues.

An article on Saturday about the denial of visas to a Little League team from Uganda, the first team from Africa to qualify for the Little League World Series, misspelled an acronym for a Japanese organization that provides baseball equipment to developing countries. It is JICA -- not JIGA -- and it stands for Japanese International Cooperation Agency.

ROTENBERG--Morris, passed away on August 3, 2011, beloved and much devoted husband of Anne Rotenberg, member of Central Synagogue and Temple Emanu-El for many years. Funeral to be held on Friday, August 5, 2011 at 11am at Plaza Community Jewish Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY between 90th and 91st St; Anne will be sitting Shiva at their family home at 70-31 108th St. Forest Hills, NY, apartment 5H on Sunday and Monday, August 7th and 8th, from 1pm-6pm.

An article in some editions on Wednesday about the death of a bus driver whose body was not discovered at the Port Authority Bus Terminal for several hours misstated the bus route, using information from the Amalgamated Transit Union, that he drove on the day he died. His route to Midtown Manhattan was from Cresskill, N.J., not from Secaucus, N.J.

VARIS--Agnes. With deepest sorrow, the board, staff and artists of Jazz at Lincoln Center mourn the loss of our beloved board member, Agnes Varis. Agnes grew up with the sounds of jazz in her childhood home and was a true believer in its ability to lift people's souls and teach them important lessons about democracy and respect. As a member of Jazz at Lincoln Center's board, Agnes' extraordinary leadership and generosity made it possible for our organization to realize so many of its artistic dreams. In addition, Agnes played a significant role in the development of Jazz at Lincoln Center's home, Frederick P. Rose Hall. In 2010, Jazz at Lincoln Center was once again privileged to name our recording studio in honor of Agnes and her late husband, Karl Leichtman. Agnes was a tireless champion of accessibility both in the arts, as well as in the pharmaceutical field and she will be long and fondly remembered by the many people and institutions whose lives she enriched through her tremendous spirit, intellect and generosity. Lisa Schiff, Chairman Wynton Marsalis, Artistic Director Gordon J. Davis, Founding Chairman Adrian Ellis, Executive Director

A picture caption on Thursday with an article about a recent increase in the sale of luxury goods misidentified the brand of shoes that a shopper, Lissette Gutierrez, planned to try on at Bergdorf Goodman in Manhattan. The $1,495 shoes are Christian Louboutin, not Louis Vuitton. And the article referred incorrectly at one point to the president and chief executive of Neiman Marcus Group, who commented on the trend in luxury goods. The executive, Karen W. Katz, is a woman.

THE 'GENIUS' ARGUMENT Henry R. Silverman, below, the prominent New York financier, who is in the middle of a legal battle with his soon-to-be former wife, believes that he deserves most of the family fortune, which he acknowledged in court papers to be about $450 million. To buttress his case, he asked the court to consider expert testimony from three psychologists about his ''innate intellectual talents'' and ''unique personal traits.'' But a New York Supreme Court justice, Laura E. Drager, rejected Mr. Silverman's argument. PETER LATTMAN

Jerry Lewis's appearance on the Muscular Dystrophy Association's annual Labor Day telethon has been scrapped, the organization said Wednesday night. The announcement came a few weeks before the telethon, which Mr. Lewis has hosted since 1966. In May Mr. Lewis said he was retiring from the show, a television staple, but he had planned to appear on it this year. Now that's not happening, according to R. Rodney Howell, the chairman of the Muscular Dystrophy Association's board. Mr. Howell also said in a statement that Mr. Lewis had been ''released'' from his position as national chairman of the association, but did not explain why. Representatives for Mr. Lewis did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

SCHINDLER--Robin, after a brief battle with cancer, on August 4, 2011. Established social worker, psychotherapist and teacher in NYC. Much loved by family, friends and colleagues. Memorial Service: Sunday, August 7, 2pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

HIDALGO--Aladin, died of his illnesses on August 3, 2011. An unpublished poet, one of his works is Death: An end, a beginning, tears of sorrow cascade into a pool of joy, a conduit into light, memories become hope, shackles removed, the spirit soars, materiality transforms into an exuberance of bliss, earth overpowered by ecstasy, the finite morphs into infiniti, uniqueness of being joins the totality of the universe, death dies. By Aladin Hidalgo.

TEZE--Jacques Gilles Yves, 84, beloved by family and friends, recently passed away in Miami. A native of Ambrieres, France, and a resident of Key Biscayne since 1994, his career in international real estate development included such notable projects as the Tour Montparnesse (Paris); Hotel Cosmos (Moscow); Lafayette Place (Boston); 1080 Madison Avenue (New York City); and Checkpoint Charlie (Berlin). A graduate engineer (Zurich Polytechnikum), he first worked for the railroads, then established a real estate company in Paris. He came to the United States in 1970 as Chairman and President of U.I.I.- Sefrei, later creating the Teze Development Company in Manhattan. In Miami, he worked with I.M.Pei on the CenTrust building and with Constructa, a French real estate development company. He was a principal in international investment and merchant banking ventures. He is survived by Nancy Herstand, his companion of 20 years; his sisters Monique Bouygues, Catherine Delafon, and Marie-Blandine Delafon-Roth; his brothers Henri-Pierre Teze and Rene Teze, their spouses and descendants; those of his deceased siblings; and his step-daughter Vicky Fabry and her sons Gregory, Stephen, and Benjamin.

MOORE--David E. Born June 10, 1923 in Bar Harbor, Maine, the son of William Scoville Moore and Edith Pulitzer Moore; died at home in Rye, New York on August 2, 2011, after a short illness. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Katherine Cromwell Moore; his sons Richard, David, Jr., and Timothy; their wives Barbara, Leni, and Debby; seven grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. His daughter Kate predeceased him. A graduate of St. Marks School and Harvard College, he served as a lieutenant in the 70th Armored Infantry Battalion, 20th Armored Division in Europe during WWII. After his marriage to Katherine in 1948, he worked with the Marshall Plan in London and as Executive Officer of the mission to Portugal in Lisbon. Following their return to the United States, they settled in Rye in 1951. As a grandson of newspaper publisher Joseph Pulitzer, and with journalism in his blood, he soon went to work as a reporter, first at Greenwich Life, a new weekly paper in Greenwich, Connecticut, and then at the Port Chester Daily Item, where he covered sports, police, and local government. In 1961, he founded the Harrison Independent, a weekly newspaper serving that Westchester community. Three years later, he acquired a countywide weekly, renamed it the Independent Herald of Westchester, and changed its focus from social to business news. He then merged it with the Westchester Business Journal and soon thereafter launched the Connecticut Business Journal. He remained editor-in-chief of the latter two publications until 1987. In a further publishing venture, he founded Northeast International Business magazine in 1987, which he later expanded to International Business magazine. In 1979, he was the first journalist to receive the Service to Exporters Award from the Connecticut-Rhode Island District Export Council. In 1980, the U.S. Department of Commerce presented the Connecticut Business Journal with the prestigious President's E Award, in recognition of its contribution to increasing U.S. trade and investment abroad. He served as Chairman of the Connecticut and Rhode Island District Export Council from 1982-1995. He was a director and officer of other trade groups, including WestConn International Trade Association, the largest such organization in New England, and the Westchester World Trade Council. He also served as a director and member of the executive committee of the Pulitzer Publishing Company for many years. Always willing to give of his time and energy, his local civic activities included serving as a Rye City Democratic Committee district leader, a director and treasurer of the Westchester Urban League, a trustee of Rye Country Day School, founder and first chairman of the Rye Art Center, a member of the board of directors of the Westchester Council for the Arts, and board chairman and director of the Westchester-based social service agency FIRST. Other volunteer work included Business Leaders for Sensible Priorities, Port Chester Hope House, and Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry. He also served on the boards of New York Community Media Alliance, Westchester Community College Foundation, Port Chester Carver Center, and Doolittle Lake Company, and was a founding trustee of the Pulitzer Center for Investigative Journalism. Throughout his life, he pursued his passionate interests in freedom of the press and in international economic development, which latter he considered the hope of the world. His wide-ranging interests also included international travel, political history, tennis, the outdoors and painting. He was much loved and will be sorely missed by both family and friends. A memorial service is planned for Friday, September 16 at 11am at Christ's Church, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Westchester Community College Foundation Scholarship Fund, Hartford Hall, 75 Grasslands Road, Valhalla, NY 10595, or Port Chester Carver Center, 400 Westchester Avenue, Port Chester, NY 10573.

VARIS--Agnes. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of one of our most generous and passionate Board members, Agnes Varis. Dedicated to making opera available to as many people as possible, Dr. Varis and her husband, Karl Leichtman, funded the Met's enormously popular Rush Tickets and Open Rehearsals programs. She was particularly committed to helping students and senior citizens gain access to Met performances through her sponsorships. Dr. Varis and her husband supported contemporary American works, underwriting the Met premiere productions of Philip Glass's Satyagraha and John Adams's Doctor Atomic. They also endowed the annual Beverly Sills Artist Award to help talented young singers at the beginning of their careers. We will sorely miss the unique gifts she brought to our Board as a Managing Director: her strong leadership, uncompromising beliefs and devotion to the arts, and her earthy humor which enlivened so many meetings and events. We offer our sincerest condolences to her family, friends, and many admirers. Ann Ziff, Chairman William C. Morris, President Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera Association

(NBC) FRIENDS WITH BENEFITS Brian Grazer (''A Beautiful Mind,'' ''Arrested Development'') is an executive producer of this new half-hour comedy about a group of singles in their 20s navigating the dating world. Ryan Hansen (above with Danneel Ackles) plays Ben, in search of the perfect woman; Ms. Ackles is Sara, Ben's best friend and a doctor looking to settle down with a nice guy. And Zach Cregger is their buddy Aaron, a tech whiz who can't understand why Sara and Ben just don't get together. Meanwhile the ladykiller Julian (Andre Holland) and the free-spirited Riley (Jessica Lucas) have their own issues. The series begins as Ben makes Sara his plus-one for his sister's wedding, leading her to wonder if they're becoming a little too intimate. At 8:30 they decide to give up the benefits part of their relationship when Sara starts dating a colleague. 6 P.M. Joan Cusack plays the tightly wound principal who loosens the grip on her inner Stevie Nicks.

LONGHUI COUNTY, China -- Many parents and grandparents in this mountainous region of terraced rice and sweet potato fields have long known to grab their babies and find the nearest hiding place whenever family planning officials show up. Too many infants, they say, have been snatched by officials, never to be seen again. But Yuan Xinquan was caught by surprise one December morning in 2005. Then a new father at the age of 19, Mr. Yuan was holding his 52-day-old daughter at a bus stop when a half-dozen men sprang from a white government van and demanded his marriage certificate.

KEYES--Elizabeth Dix, born October 17, 1914, died August 3, 2011 at Pennswood Village, Newtown, PA. Beloved wife of Fenton Keyes (1915-1999), mother of Charles Fenton Keyes of Silver Spring, MD and Janet Keyes O'Connell of Larchmont, NY, mother-in-law of Marilyn Rauber and Ryan O'Connell, and devoted grandmother of Elizabeth and Kevin O'Connell and Phoebe and Ben Keyes. LIbba was proud of her Vassar degree and her service at the National Planning Association during WWII and her subsequent career as a stock broker and banker. An avid genealogist, she produced ten volumes of family history and memoirs. She was a frequent traveler, superb chef, gardener, hostess and loving mother; we will miss her joie de vivre and far-ranging interests. Private burial. Donations in her memory may be made to Planned Parenthood Association of Bucks County, 610 Louis Drive, Warminster, PA 18974. To share your fondest memory of Elizabeth, please visit www.lifecelebration.com

BEHREND--Louise. The Juilliard School mourns the passing of Louise Behrend, a distinguished member of the Juilliard faculty from 1943 to 2009 who taught in the Pre-College Division, Evening Division, Summer School, and Regular College Division. An innovative teacher and educational administrator, Louise built the School for Strings into a highly distinguished institution. The British actor Julian Ovenden, whose powerful tenor and leading-man looks positioned him as a star attraction in the new Off Broadway musical ''Death Takes a Holiday,'' has departed the Roundabout Theater Company production and will be replaced by an understudy, a Roundabout spokesman announced on Wednesday night. In a statement, the spokesman said Mr. Ovenden was leaving because of laryngitis. The 35-year-old actor, who played the title character of the grim reaper in the darkly comic musical, has been mostly out since July 19, including missing the opening night performance and festivities on July 21. Mr. Ovenden returned last weekend and completed two performances; he began the show on Tuesday night as well, but was replaced by Kevin Earley midway through Act I.

Jessie Mueller, a rising star in Chicago musical theater, will get a notably big break this fall when she makes her Broadway debut as the love interest opposite Harry Connick Jr., in the provocative re-conception of the 1965 musical ''On a Clear Day You Can See Forever.'' The revival's producers on Thursday announced the casting of both Ms. Mueller and the actor David Turner, who will play the third key role in the production: David Gamble, a gay florist who seeks out a psychiatrist (Mr. Connick) to quit smoking - and who becomes, under hypnosis, a possible former self, a 1940s jazz singer named Melinda Wells (Ms. Mueller).

Marilyn Monroe will make an unexpected appearance at the New York Film Festival in the form of Michelle Williams, who portrays the cinematic bombshell in ''My Week With Marilyn,'' a biographical feature that will be presented as the festival's Centerpiece Gala selection, its organizers said on Thursday. Directed by Simon Curtis, ''My Week With Marilyn'' chronicles Monroe during the making of the movie ''The Prince and the Showgirl,'' as a young assistant (played by Eddie Redmayne) shows the actress a different side of life. In addition to Ms. Williams, the Academy Award-nominated star of ''Blue Valentine'' and ''Brokeback Mountain,'' its cast features Kenneth Branagh as Laurence Olivier and Dougray Scott as Arthur Miller. It will have its world premiere at the New York Film Festival on Oct. 9 at Alice Tully Hall.

After years of mergers and takeovers, Kraft Foods is undertaking its biggest deal yet: breaking itself apart. The food giant said on Thursday that it planned to split into two businesses. Kraft will spin off its North American grocery business - home to familiar brands like Velveeta, Kraft macaroni & cheese and Oscar Mayer meats - to its shareholders. It will hold onto its global snacks business, with brands like Oreos, Cadbury and Trident.

What began as a weak day in the stock markets ended in the worst rout in more than two years, as investors dumped stocks amid anxiety that both Europe and the United States were failing to fix deepening economic problems. With a steep decline of around 5 percent in the United States on Thursday, stocks have now fallen nearly 11 percent in two weeks. Markets have been plunging as investors sought safer havens for their money -- including Treasury bonds, which some had been avoiding during the debate over extending the nation's debt ceiling.

It’s a sweet drug that plays with fire. A wasteland — forest of ruins or paved-over jungle depending on whether wakefulness or sleep tips the scales. An old city where the shadows still hold a trace of vanished occupants, where detailed buildings, patiently reconquered  by nature, suddenly still are there, sand castles. Through the dreamer’s kaleidoscope where the absence of desire is taken as reality, birds slash through the twilight, cypress trees dive into the pool, stars sparkle in the sea, clouds take on shapes, water lilies bloom in the sky, plans become flexible, the limit to how far things can go relaxes, thought dances, light is lit by shade, opposites are juxtaposed, merge and become linked in a prelude to beauty: reverie is contemplation’s prehistory, the education of the gaze by the eyes of the soul.

FRONT PAGE An article on Friday about the worst day for the stock market in two years misstated, in some copies, the interest rate for the 10-year Treasury bond. The rate dropped to 2.41 percent, not 2.64 percent, recording the biggest one day fall since March 2009.

The On Basketball column on Monday, about N.B.A. players who are considering playing for teams in Europe during the lockout, misstated the year that the former Knick Charles Oakley made an observation during the previous N.B.A. lockout. It was in 1998, not 2008.

Delois Barrett Campbell, whose subtle phrasing and silvery soprano helped define the sound of the Barrett Sisters, a prominent Chicago gospel trio featured in the 1982 documentary ''Say Amen, Somebody,'' died on Tuesday in Chicago. She was 85. The cause was a pulmonary embolism, her daughter Mary Campbell said.

As stocks swing violently, a chill is beginning to settle on the initial public offering market. A small number of companies have already retreated on their offering plans. WageWorks, an employee benefits provider, pushed its offering, originally scheduled for Friday, to next week and dropped its target price range by as much as 43 percent. Two real estate investment trusts, Orchid Island Capital and Eola Property Trust, have withdrawn their filings. And Old Mutual, a big South African insurance company, said on Friday that it was now unlikely to go public in the United States before the end of next year because of market conditions.

The free-agent tight end Kevin Boss agreed to a four-year deal with the Oakland Raiders on Friday morning. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Boss was third on the Giants in receiving yards (531) and fifth in receptions (35) last season. In four seasons with the Giants, he appeared in 58 games and started in 45 of them.

WEISCOPF--Helen M. (nee Synnott) on August 4, 2011. Beloved wife of the late Clarence. Devoted mother of the Rev. Daniel and Dennis. Also, survived by many nieces, nephews and other relatives. Reposing at Denis S. O'Connor Funeral Home, 91-05 Beach Channel Drive, Rockaway Beach, NY. Funeral Mass, Monday, 10am at St. Camillus Church. Interment: Woodlawn Cemetery. Visiting: Sunday, 2-5pm and 7-10pm.

9 P.M. (Starz) HOW DO YOU KNOW (2010) Reese Witherspoon taps into her intimidating side to play Lisa, a 31-year-old softball star whose world-class aspirations have been dealt a huge blow. Owen Wilson, above with Ms. Witherspoon, is Matty, the major-league pitcher whose spell she falls under, and who thinks he may be ready to give commitment a try. Then George (Paul Rudd) enters Lisa's life, first as a dud of a blind date and then as a friend whose father-cum-boss, Charles (Jack Nicholson), isn't all that unhappy about letting his son take the fall for his own financial misdeeds. Now Lisa needs to decide. Writing in The New York Times, Manohla Dargis said that this romantic comedy from James L. Brooks was ''so wan and disconnected to anything that feels like real life or, just as good, a screwball interpretation of it, that it's hard to know what Mr. Brooks was really after, other than passing the time with some talented movie people.'' Curiously, she added, Ms. Witherspoon, Mr. Rudd and Mr. Wilson were ''outshone by a pair of character actors -- Kathryn Hahn, who plays George's secretary, Annie, and Lenny Venito, as her boyfriend -- who, in an overworked, overwritten hospital scene, show you what love looks like simply by, surprise, good acting.'' 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: LUCILLE BALL An all-day tribute to Ball, the glamorous blond Goldwyn showgirl turned carrot-top comedian, begins with ''Du Barry Was a Lady'' (1943), Roy Del Ruth's musical about Louis Blore (Red Skelton), a nightclub coatroom attendant who dreams that he's Louis XV and that the star he idolizes, May Daly (Ball) -- who claims to be interested only in rich men -- is his lover. Gene Kelly plays the club M.C., Alec Howe, Louis's rival for May's affections. In ''The Long, Long Trailer'' (1954), at 2:30 p.m., Ball and her real-life husband, Desi Arnaz, above, portray newlyweds who take to the road in an oversize motor home. And in ''Stage Door'' (1937), at 8, Ball is a New York City actress, alongside Ginger Rogers, Eve Arden and Ann Miller, in a boarding house where a society beauty (Katharine Hepburn) has come to fulfill her Broadway dreams.

If those who give out the Oscars are looking for laughs, action and the occasional outrage from their annual awards show, they are on the right track. The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced that Brett Ratner, a filmmaker known for directing the raucous ''Rush Hour'' series and for producing ''Horrible Bosses,'' will join Don Mischer in producing the next Oscar show, which ABC will broadcast on Feb. 26. Last year's ceremony, below, produced by Mr. Mischer and Bruce Cohen, had soft ratings and was widely criticized for a lackluster performance by one of its hosts, James Franco, onstage below with Anne Hathaway. If energy is the issue, Mr. Ratner should be able to provide a fix. He is known as a film aficionado and an ambitious filmmaker who is developing a new version of ''Snow White'' for Relativity Media, and has dozens of projects in development. Mr. Ratner recently directed ''Tower Heist.'' That action picture, due out on Nov. 4 from Universal Pictures, has uncertain Oscar prospects, but counts Ben Stiller, Eddie Murphy, Matthew Broderick and Gabourey Sidibe among its stars.

Who can we count on when our society is threatened? If we can't depend on them, who can we depend on? JIM LETTEN, the United States attorney for Louisiana's Eastern District, after the conviction of five current and former New Orleans police officers in the shooting of six unarmed civilians after Hurricane Katrina.[A3]
8:00 p.m. | Updated The Denver business community was rocked Friday by an insider trading case that touched prominent businessmen in the city.

''Big Brother'' on CBS claimed the top spot among the broadcast networks on Thursday night in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old demographic, with 7.3 million people tuning in, according to Nielsen. After the contestants voted to evict another member of the household, it was announced that a new twist would be added to the shows' long-in-the-tooth format. Fans can now go to CBS.com and vote for a previously evicted houseguest, and the person with the most votes will get a chance to return to the show. The reality program carried CBS to an overall ratings victory as well, as the network averaged around 6.3 million total viewers for the night. ABC came in second, averaging just under 5.5 million viewers, thanks to its reality competitions, ''Wipeout'' (6.6 million viewers) and ''Expedition Impossible'' (4.8 million).

Paul Maringelli stepped into Apartment 1G and walked into an empty bedroom that was stifling hot. ''Yup, this is probably the room Bix died in,'' he said. He meant the great jazz cornetist Bix Beiderbecke, who died in 43-30 46th Street in Sunnyside, Queens, on Aug. 6, 1931 - 80 years ago Saturday - at age 28 of pneumonia, though his alcoholism was said to have been a factor.

A documentary that examines the influence of American rock 'n' roll on the Soviet Union's collapse and a traveling exhibition about the King James Bible, below, are among the 249 recipients of $40 million in grants from the National Endowment for the Humanities. The documentary, awarded $550,000, is being directed by Jim Brown and will detail how the music, initially banned by the Kremlin, became so popular that it fueled resentment toward the authorities and contributed to the creation of a youth movement. (Above, Stas Namin, a Soviet military cadet, in the documentary.) Digital humanities, a discipline that barely existed a decade ago, has been winning additional financing. This year the endowment's Office of Digital Humanities, created in 2009, awarded 32 start-up grants, all $50,000 or less. The winning projects include a conference to assist speakers of endangered languages in digital preservation efforts and an educational computer game to teach middle schoolers about American Indian earthworks. Bruce Ray Smith of the University of Southern California and Katherine Rowe of Bryn Mawr College received $50,000 to develop a portable electronic application: Mobile Shakespeare Scripts. Actors and directors will be able to customize digitized scripts to include commentary and production history. The plan is for the American Shakespeare Center in Staunton, Va., to prepare and rehearse one of its 2012-13 productions using iPads loaded with the script and commentary from Cambridge University Press.

VINCIARELLI--Lauretta, died peacefully at home in New York on August 3 after a long struggle with cancer. She is survived by Peter, her husband, Anthony, her step-son, Donatella, her sister, and Giulio, her brother. Trained as an architect at La Sapienza, but a watercolorist by vocation, her works on paper reside in private collections and among the holding of prominent institutions, include the Museum of Modern Art in New York, The National Gallery in Washington, DC and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art. Noted for luminous qualities of color and light, her depictions of imagined spaces open up a world of enclosed rooms, sweeping landscapes, watery materiality and atmospheric ephemerality. As the title of a monograph on her work suggests the paintings are not architecture exactly, but evidence that it exists. Also a devoted educator, Lauretta taught design studio in architecture for many years at Columbia University, City College and Pratt University, among other institutions. A funeral service will be held at St. Anthonys at 10:30am on Monday.

BOSTON - Fresh off a strong performance against the reeling Chicago White Sox on Thursday, Ivan Nova went through his normal day-after routine for a starting pitcher because, for now, that is what he remains. As Nova answered questions about his status before the Yankees' game against the Boston Red Sox on Friday he wore a big smile on his face, if only because he was still with the team. The Yankees postponed any decisions that could have sent Nova back to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes Barre, deciding instead to keep six starters and then figure out what to do after this weekend's series in Boston. Facing three games in hitter-friendly Fenway Park against a team that can wear out pitchers, the Yankees decided they needed as many arms as possible.

An obituary on July 19 about John Toll, the former president of Stony Brook University, referred incorrectly to the reasons students occupied an administration building in May 1968. Although students raised a variety of concerns, including relations between the university and the local police, overcrowding in makeshift dorms was not at issue (though it had been the subject of other demonstrations on campus).

LONDON - Never let it be said that the pig is not a lady. Yes, the title character of ''Betty Blue Eyes,'' the slyly winning new musical at the Ivor Novello Theater, is irrefutably porcine. She emits odors that cause everyone around her to gag, and you do need to watch where you step after she's been in the room. Yet this over-size porker has a shy, persuasive charm that can only be described as genteel. The same may be said of the show in which she appears. Based on the 1984 film ''A Private Function,'' directed by Malcolm Mowbray and written by Alan Bennett, ''Betty Blue Eyes'' is a sweet paradox of a show. It's a reticent crowd pleaser, a big, well-groomed musical that never seems to be courting a standing ovation. Hustling for applause, after all, is not seemly in a crisis economy, when we all need to work as one, make do and, whenever required, do without. This show - need I add? - does not take place in the present.

OBITUARIES An obituary on Wednesday about Dr. Baruj Benacerraf, an immunologist who received a Nobel Prize in medicine in 1980, misidentified the university where he had a fellowship in immunology in 1947. He was at Columbia University -- not New York University, where he later taught.

Relations between Maria de los Santos and the landlord of her railroad apartment in Bushwick, Brooklyn, soured after she filed a complaint in 2007 over lack of heat. But they worsened, she said, after she discovered she had been overcharged in rent and appealed to the state housing agency for help. Ms. de los Santos said the agency did not process her complaint for 18 months and, according to the agency, she has yet to be paid the $10,000 that the landlord owes her. All the while, she said, her landlord took advantage of the delay to harass her.

WEEKEND A headline on Friday with an article about the departure of Kevin Murphy, a vocal coach, from an arts organization in New York misidentified the organization. It is New York City Opera, not City Ballet. The article also misstated the year Mr. Murphy joined City Opera. It was 2008, not 2007. And the article referred imprecisely to some of Mr. Murphy's duties in his new post, at the Indiana University School of Music, where he will be a professor. He will oversee opera studies within the school's vocal program, not the entire vocal program.

BAINBRIDGE ISLAND, Wash. -- Frank Kitamoto was only 2 when he and his family -- and more than 270 others of Japanese ancestry -- were forcibly removed from this forested island and sent to an internment camp after Japan bombed Pearl Harbor in World War II. Mr. Kitamoto, now 72, said he spent many of his younger years in a severe identity crisis, ashamed of his Japanese heritage and wishing he were white. Other young men went so far as to have plastic surgery to disguise their Japanese features. Some committed suicide. ''As a kid, I thought this was the land of equality and freedom, and so this couldn't be happening because of discrimination,'' Mr. Kitamoto, who became a dentist, said the other day in his office, where one wall is covered with photos from that era. ''So I thought it was because there was something wrong with me, that I was a bad person.''

WIENER--Barbara. The Jewish Federation of Rockland County mourns the passing of Barbara Wiener, a life trustee and past president of the board of directors. Barbara found her work with the Federation on behalf of the local and global Jewish communities to be particularly rewarding and meaningful, having been involved since the earliest days of the organization. The funeral will take place Sunday at 10:00am at Temple Beth Torah, 330 North Highland Ave. (Rt. 9W), Upper Nyack. We offer our condolences to the Wiener family on their unfortunate loss. Barbara's passing will leave a void for the Federation and for the many organizations about which she cared. She is survived by her husband, Shelly, daughter Hillary, sons Jonathan and Jared and eight grandchildren. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Federation held a special place in Barbara's heart. The family is establishing a memorial fund and asks that donations be made to the Jewish Federation of Rockland County in her memory. Call: 845-362-4200 or visit our website at www.jewishrockland.org

BEIRUT, Lebanon -- Syria's state news media broadcast stark images of the destruction in the besieged city of Hama for the first time on Friday, showing burned buildings, makeshift barricades and deserted streets strewn with rubble in footage that appeared designed to show that government forces had put down a rebellion in the city. The images were unmistakably Hama, Syria's fourth-largest city and a focal point of the five-month-old uprising that has left President Bashar al-Assad's leadership isolated and weakened. They suggested the military had retaken control of a city that had briefly wrested itself from four decades of authoritarian rule by the Assad family and enjoyed an unprecedented measure of freedom.

In a change to her father's plans, Elisabeth Murdoch will not be nominated this year to the board of the News Corporation, a member of the board said Friday. The News Corporation is scrambling to contain the damage from a British hacking scandal that has inspired shareholder complaints about the company's corporate governance. Two of Rupert Murdoch's six children, Lachlan and James, sit on the board of the News Corporation alongside him. When Mr. Murdoch acquired Ms. Murdoch's company, the Shine Group, in February for $674 million, he said that he expected her to join them.

After finding the stern of an 18th-century sailing vessel in landfill where the new World Trade Center is being constructed, what could be better? Finding the bow - or at least enough to gain a clearer picture of the length of the vessel and how it was constructed; all of which might help solve the mystery of what it was doing anchored off Lower Manhattan in the first place. The most intriguing theory now in circulation is that the vessel may have been used around the time of the Revolutionary War as a troop carrier of some sort. ''That ties in really neatly with the British military button found between the frames,'' said Warren Riess of the Darling Marine Center at the University of Maine.

Because of an editing error, a film review on Friday about a movie that looks at human trafficking in postwar Bosnia misstated the title at one point. As the review correctly noted elsewhere, it is ''The Whistleblower,'' not ''The Whistleblower: Sex Trafficking, Military Contractors, and One Woman's Fight for Justice.'' (That is the title of a book by Kathryn Bolkovac, whose experiences as a United Nations peacekeeping officer in Bosnia are depicted in the film.) The review also referred incorrectly to the movie as a ''Canadian film.'' While the director is Canadian, the film is a Canadian-German co-production.

Now that gay marriage is legal in New York, legally wed couples will be subject to new state tax rules, which affect everything from income and sales taxes to estate planning. While New York recognized same-sex unions performed elsewhere before the state started issuing marriage licenses of its own last month, that recognition did not extend to tax matters. Now it does.
SCHINDLER--Robin. Manhattan Institute for Psychoanalysis mourns the loss of our dear colleague, teacher and friend. She will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies go out to her family.

The showdown over increasing the federal debt limit got me thinking about the power of compound interest. It's always been one of the most powerful forces in the financial universe. And in the case of the debt ceiling, it appears that compound interest has the potential to become a crushing enemy. Some people fear that the United States will lose its AAA credit-rating or even default temporarily, potentially increasing how much it costs the government to borrow money. According to the Congressional Budget Office, ''...a 4-percentage-point across-the-board increase in interest rates would raise federal interest payments next year by about $100 billion; if those higher rates persisted, net interest costs in 2015 would be nearly double the roughly $460 billion that the C.B.O. currently projects for that year.''

It could have been worse. Just a few days ago, it looked as if any bill to raise the debt ceiling would get rid of subsidized federal student loans. This is the feature that allows undergraduates and graduate students who qualify to pay no interest on their student loans while they are still enrolled more than half-time in their studies.

ROTENBERG--Morris. We note with sorrow the passing of Morris Rotenberg and extend our condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein and President Kenneth Heitner, Central Synagogue of New York City

A fan at the Lollapalooza music festival at Grant Park in Chicago rode across the crowd on Friday during the performance of Foster the People, one of more than 130 acts to play in the three-day event, which ends on Sunday.

Little more than a year ago, most Americans did not know enough about the Tea Party to have an opinion. Now, more people have opinions, and they are hardly positive. The percentage of people with an unfavorable view of the Tea Party in a New York Times/CBS News Poll this week was higher than it has been since the first time the question was asked, in April 2010. Forty percent of those polled this week characterized their view as ''not favorable,'' compared with 18 percent in the first poll.
International ITALY MIGHT HAVE TO CUT ITS VACATION SHORT

A dance review on Friday about ''The Male Dancer by Balanchine,'' an event in the Vail International Dance Festival featuring performers from New York City Ballet, misidentified a dancer who performed an excerpt from ''Stars and Stripes'' with Tiler Peck. The male role was danced by Daniel Ulbricht -- not by Joaquin De Luz, who also performed in the program. The review also carried an erroneous dateline. The site of the event, the Vilar Performing Arts Center, is in Beaver Creek, Colo., not Vail itself.

SPORTS The Sports of The Times column on Friday, about the return of wide receiver Plaxico Burress to the National Football League with the New York Jets, misstated the number of seasons quarterback Mark Sanchez has played in the N.F.L. He is starting his third season, all with the Jets, not his fourth.

The progressive rock band Coheed and Cambria announced on Friday that it had parted ways with its bassist, Michael Todd, three weeks after he was arrested on charges of robbing a pharmacy in Massachusetts to obtain prescription painkillers. The band posted a statement on its Web site saying the group ''will be continuing our journey without bassist Michael Todd.'' The statement added that it was ''a mutual decision.'' Mr. Todd, 30, left, was arrested in Mansfield, Mass., on July 10, hours before the band was to open for Soundgarden. The band went on without him that night, and a replacement bassist was hired to finish the tour. Court officials in Attleboro, Mass., said Mr. Todd had been released from the county jail and was scheduled to appear in court next week for a hearing. He faces felony charges of armed robbery and drug possession. Through a publicist, the other band members -- Claudio Sanchez, Travis Stever and Chris Pennie -- declined to comment about the decision beyond the statement on the Web site. Mr. Todd did not respond to a message left on Friday. Formed in the mid-1990s in Nyack, N.Y., Coheed and Cambria came to national attention in 2002 and has released five studio albums since then, revolving around a sci-fi story line known as the Amory Wars. The statement said that they were writing and recording songs for a new album, and that Wes Styles, who replaced Mr. Todd during several live performances after the arrest, would continue to play bass for a series of shows in South America and Mexico.

ZETZEL--Susanna, died August 4 at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. Daughter of the late Bernard and Elizabeth Stambler, survived by her husband James Zetzel and her brother Peter Stambler of Philadelphia.

THE ARTS A report in the ''Arts, Briefly'' column on Wednesday about a festival dedicated to Philip Glass at the Park Avenue Armory next February, using information from a publicist, referred incorrectly to the planned performance of Mr. Glass's ''Another Look at Harmony.'' The work was played at Carnegie Hall in 1978; the performance at the Armory will not be its first in New York.

A cancer patient underwent the Hipec treatment, a controversial process that involves surgery to remove visible tumors in the abdomen, followed by the dousing of the abdominal cavity in a hot chemotherapy bath.
WASHINGTON — Here is the bad news forPresident Obama and incumbents in both parties: it can get worse — and stay that way for a long time.
A look at a wet and wild day in sports.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y. — Teaching professionals and well-traveled players see all kinds of golf swings, good and bad. But perhaps no one bears witness to more golfers’ mistakes than caddies at private clubs.

NEWPORT, R.I. — Since the beginning of the Newport Jazz Festival on Sunday it has been raining, sometimes hard and loud and overwhelming, sometimes a thick harborside mist. The main stage, where there is no tent for the audience, has it the hardest. Maybe 150 hardy people are out there right now watching James Farm, the co-operative quartet with the saxophonist Joshua Redman, the pianist Aaron Parks, the bassist Matt Penman and the drummer Eric Harland. They’re playing way back from the lip of the stage to avoid getting wet, huddling closer than they would at a small club. They’re sounding good–strolling, right now, through a minor ballad.Hiromi is back for round two on a smaller stage with her trio, wowing them with amiable virtuosity. Earlier, John Hollenbeck’s 19-piece big band– including bass saxophone, vibraphone and two singers– played a great set, including songs by Ornette Coleman, Jimmy Webb and Imogen Heap and a version of the traditional “I’m a Man of Constant Sorrow,” with a solo by the tenor saxophonist Tony Malaby that came in chapters, getting destabilized and righting itself, using a few notes of the melody or, or of Hollenbeck’s strong arrangement, to start a new section. It takes at least a half-hour to start to understand this band’s range, from sci-fi to pastoral, loopy to dead serious. It’s come a long way over the last 10 years.

Copa América, which was played in Argentina last month, marked the debut of the vanishing spray in an international tournament for national teams. This technological innovation consists of a can with white spray that allows referees to mark the place where the ball ,as well as the defensive wall,should be located on free kicks. ARDEN--Eugene, PhD. Born in New York City, June 25, 1923, died at home in Boca Raton on July 28, 2011. In his 88 years, Gene touched so many lives with his kindness, generosity of spirit, and all-round decency. He was the consummate gentleman - erudite without conceit, commanding but tolerant. His academic career spanned 45 years culminating at retirement as Vice Chancellor of Academic Affairs at the University of Michigan, Dearborn Campus. Gene was devoted and loving and beloved by his bereft wife, Sandra, his children Stacey Koltonow and Dr. Jonathan Arden (wife Ronni), his grandchildren Benjamin, Becky, and Rachel Arden and Matthew Koltonow. He also leaves nephew Dr. Martin Reish, cousins Mina and Milton Pascaner, Judith and Norman Green, and many friends and colleagues. There never was a finer man; the heavens have a new star in the firmament.

An article in the special Education Life section on July 24 about a degree's return on investment misstated the program cost for a master's of social work at Hunter College. It is $20,440, not $34,000. The article also misstated the cost of Cornell's veterinary medicine program. At the 2010 rate of $27,700 a year ($41,700 for nonresidents), the four-year program would cost $110,800 ($166,800 for nonresidents), not $85,000 ($128,250 for nonresidents).

FORTUNOFF--Lenore. Died peacefully on August 6 after a valiant 22 year struggle with cancer. Devoted wife of almost sixty beautiful years to Murray, Beloved mother of Sara (Robbie), David and Naomi. Adoring Bubby to Joshua, Rachel and Rebekah. Loving sister to Robert (Andrea). She will be greatly missed in the home and in the community for all the philanthropic endeavors she has undertaken including fundraising for many Jewish Woman's organizations and putting her artistic talents to use by sewing, knitting and quilting teddy bears and blankets for children's foundations.

SPORTS An article on Saturday about the National Football League's proposed new program for testing its players for human growth hormone inaccurately described crucial aspects of the program. A corrective article appears on Page 1, SportsSunday.

Beginning in September, Ginia Bellafante will write the Big City column, covering a broad range of subjects pertaining to life in New York. In conjunction with that, she will host the Big City Book Club, an online club featuring classic and obscure novels and nonfiction works with the city as a central character. In commemoration of 9/11, the club will get under way on Sept. 6 with a discussion of ''Let the Great World Spin'' by Colum McCann. The novel, winner of the 2009 National Book Award, hinges on Philippe Petit's 1974 high-wire walk between the World Trade Center towers.
Clinton $259,000 325 West 45th Street, The Whitby

BEHREND--Louise. The School for Strings mourns the passing of its Founder/Director, Louise Behrend. A distinguished, influential and visionary pedagogue and violinist, Miss Behrend dedicated much of her life to disseminating educational ideas of Dr. Shinichi Suzuki. By founding The School for Strings in 1971, Miss Behrend created an outlet for training future Suzuki teachers and an oasis for nurturing young children in the art of music. Miss Behrend's love of the violin, contagious enthusiasm for music and teaching are at the heart of the legacy she leaves behind at The School for Strings. We are fortunate to inherit her spirit and to be entrusted with her vision, so deeply affected by the work of Dr. Suzuki. Donations in her name can be made to The School for Strings, 419 West 54th Street, NYC, 10019. Sheila Keats, President Alexander Yudkovsky, Executive Director

From the less-is-more department: A perfectly ripe, local summer tomato eaten with a drizzle of olive oil, a sprinkle of salt or nothing at all has become a bit of a culinary cliché. Your superior appreciation of the superior tomato relies on a distinct lack of meddling. I get this. For those of us who grew up eating mealy, pink winter tomatoes harvested hundreds or thousands of miles away, this handling was a revelation.

IN some New York neighborhoods, business after dark still takes on an altogether noirish tone, even though violent crime has fallen citywide by nearly 30 percent over the past decade. At night, the handshakes and fist-bumps are gone, the cheerful banter between clerks and customers replaced by strained conversations conducted through plexiglass. For store owners and overnight clerks, transaction windows in varying styles and degrees of security are an essential safeguard; for customers in persistently dangerous neighborhoods, they are a way of life, a reminder that progress takes time. ''It's just everywhere,'' Charlie Colon, the owner of two Harlem pawnshops, said of the city's transaction windows, as the sky over Frederick Douglass Boulevard turned a steely gray. ''I almost compare it to the taxicabs: If you have one they can't get to you; if you don't have one you get gotten.''

OLESEN--Walter Lawrence, died surrounded by family in Oakland, CA on July 24. Born in 1925, Wally graduated from Columbia High in Maplewood, NJ. He received two Bronze Stars for his service in the army during WWII. After graduating from Williams College in 1949, Wally married artist Candace deVries. During his 30 years in advertising, Wally was twice named Ad Man of the Year and subsequently appointed Dean of the Newhouse School at Syracuse U. Also a professional musician, Wally played piano and clarinet until his final days. Wally is survived by two children, John Olesen of Oakland, CA and Robin Olesen of Berkeley, CA; three grandchildren, Walker, Theo and Ivy Olesen; his partner in later life, Gayle Bishop; and countless friends from his 12-step fellowship, which gave him a second chance at life beginning in 1982.

PECK--Edgar Wallace Jr.,of Atlantic Beach, FL., formerly of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL., and Rye, New York died on July 31, 2011 at the age of 77. He was active in the family business, Peck & Peck, Inc. as General Merchandise Manager. Later, he was President and then Chairman of Estate Properties, Inc., a family investment concern. He was a graduate of the Choate School and Yale University. He was predeceased by his parents, Edgar Wallace Peck and Dorothy Dunham Peck, and his first wife Kathleen Hope Cron. He is survived by his wife, Amelia Joy Peck of Atlantic Beach, FL; his sister Margaret Blosser of Aiken, SC; his children, Edgar W. Peck III of Millington, NJ, Dorothy Voorhees of Katonah, NY, Virginia O'Connor of Monroe, CT, and Frederick D. Peck of Willington, CT.; and five grandchildren. A Memorial Service was held at 11:00am, Monday, August 1, 2011 in Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home of Jacksonville Beach. Interment will be held in Greenwood Cemetery of Rye, New York. Please visit our online Tribute at www.quinn-shalz.com. Services under the direction and care of Quinn-Shalz, A Family Funeral Home, Jacksonville Beach, FL.

SUMMER'S heat has many of us running for cover. Here, cool portable cotton Sombrillas from the Melbourne, Australia, company Hollie & Harrie are a delightful alternative to unwieldy stick-in-the-sand umbrellas. Designed by the longtime friends Skye Hollingsworth and Claire Harris, the cheerful beach tents fold up to roughly the size of a yoga mat and come with a clever matching carrying case. Clean lines, 95 percent UV protection and three pitch-perfect summer colors (Moroccan blue, French stripe and a sunny yellow) ensure that our last days of summer are stylish and sunburn-free. $195. Go to hollieandharrie.com.au. LILY MIESMER

MARCUS--Elliott M.,M.D., 78, of Boston, MA and Key Biscayne, FL on July 25. Emeritus Professor of Neurology at UMass Medical School and former Tufts Medical School Professor. Co-authored four neuroscience textbooks. Founding President, Mass. Neurologic Association. Neurology Chair at St. Vincent's Hospital/Fallon Clinic. Epilepsy researcher, educator. Husband of Dr. R. Nuran Turksoy-Marcus. Father of Dr. Erin N. Marcus. Life Celebration at Tufts Goddard Chapel, Noon, September 17. Donations to: UMass Elliott Marcus Lecture Fund, 508-856-6515.

SCHINDLER--Robin, after a brief battle with cancer, on August 4, 2011. Established social worker, psychotherapist and teacher in NYC. Much loved by family, friends and colleagues. Memorial Service: Sunday, August 7, 2pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

Millerton, N.Y. FROM the venerable general store his grandparents opened in 1919, where you can get hunting knives, cigars, worms, khaki pants and copies of Vogue, Phil Terni has watched Dutchess County's passing parade for most of his 68 years.

MAGAZINE An essay on July 31 about News of the World misspelled the name of the city in Italy where the writer, Paul McNamara, stayed while traveling from off the coast of Libya back to the newspaper's offices in London in July. And a correction in this space last weekend gave another incorrect spelling. The city is Taranto -- not Torrento or Sorrento.

An article last Sunday about a new analysis of the decisions by United States immigration court judges in defensive political asylum cases misstated the number of applicants who filed for such asylum in the 2010 fiscal year, according to the Executive Office of Immigration Review. It is about 33,000, not about 19,500, which is the estimated number of cases that were either granted or denied. The article also misspelled the name of the town that Emilio Gutiérrez, a Mexican journalist, fled. It is Ascensión, not Ascensción.

KORNBLAU--Gerald, American Folk Art dealer and photographer, has died at the age of 82 at his home after a long illness. Mr. Kornblau's love for American Folk Art was evident as he frequented flea markets throughout the country and in his displays at the Winter Antiques Show until his retirement. He is survived by his children Stephanie, Erika and Seth, four grand children whom he adored, and his brother Seymour.

In his job as an analyst for ESPN, Barry Larkin travels the baseball map, landing in a different spot every Sunday night. Two weeks ago he found himself in Cincinnati, his hometown, where he starred at shortstop for the Reds. He said he was touched by the fans who cheered him on the set. ''The support and the love the fans gave me,'' Larkin said, ''it was incredible.''

JetBlue's All You Can Jet pass attracted a loyal following, and when the program wasn't offered this year, fans expressed their disappointment on blogs and Twitter. The airline now has a new program, BluePass, allowing an unlimited number of flights out of its hubs in Boston or Long Beach, Calif., over a three-month period, for one flat rate. There are three options: Boston All ($1,999, plus taxes and fees); Boston Select ($1,499); and Long Beach Select ($1,299). Flights can be booked for dates between Aug. 22 and Nov. 22, and scheduled up to 90 minutes before departure.

COLLINS--Harriet Smith, of Somers, NY, died July 29th at the age of 86. She will be remembered for her humor, generosity and love of nature. The widow of Robert S. Collins, she is survived by her children, Sarah Collins of New York City and John Collins of Oregon; a granddaughter, Rachel; and two great-grandchildren, Neiko and Rayna. A private graveside Memorial Service will be held at Fair Ridge Cemetery in Chappaqua, NY on Friday, August 12. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to any of Harriet's favorite charities: The World Wildlife Fund or The New York Chapter of The Salvation Army. Services by Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY.

Marshall Faulk, who was inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday, said he was happy to see the lockout end, if only so he could return to his job as an analyst on the NFL Network and avoid losing another Madden NFL video game to his son. ''My son is a teenager now,'' said Faulk, who is featured on the cover of the game's Hall of Fame Edition. ''And he's playing high school football. Before, he would never stand a chance. Not anymore. I can't beat him. And he even knows how to talk football now - Cover 1, Cover 2 - from playing Madden.''

METROPOLITAN An article about beekeeping in some editions last Sunday misstated the number of bees that can be purchased for about $80. That price, or slightly more, is the typical payment for a three-pound package that contains about 10,000 bees, not 200.
A caption last Sunday with the What I Wore column, about Michael Wolff, misstated the location of the picture. It was taken at Mr. Wolff's home, not at his office.
International ATOMIC BOMB SURVIVORS

WHAT does an up-and-coming restaurateur wear to work every day? For Tuan Bui, an owner of An Choi, the Lower East Side hot spot, who meets vendors, entertains clients, serves tables and helps in the kitchen, ''having one style or uniform is the most practical way,'' he said. This translates into dropped-crotch pants for comfort, dark colors to conceal spills and shoes with rubber soles. ''It's a physical job, so what I wear needs to meet those demands.'' This unstructured knit blazer is as durable and easy to move in as a sweater, but looks swell when the stylists, models and other pho-fanatics come in for dinner. Shades of Grey by Micah Cohen jacket, $150. Go to bloomingdales.com. Robert Geller Seconds sweat pants, $292, and T-shirt, $104. Go to robertgeller.com. Sacai cable knit shorts, $920. Available at Union in Los Angeles. Call (323) 549-6950. Black Sheep & Prodigal Sons necklace, price on request. Go to occulter.org. JASON RIDER

FOR the first installment of Off the Shelf, a feature in T: The Times Style Magazine that asks tastemakers about the books that are inspiring them now, Gillian Schwartz, the founder of the design studio Schwartz & Sons, picked ''Adhocism: The Case for Improvisation'' (Doubleday) by Charles Jencks and Nathan Silver. Bought at High Valley Books in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, about five years ago, the book is an amusing ode to a design method that was as subversive as it was sustainable when it was published in the early 1970s. ''It's about hodgepodging,'' Ms. Schwartz said. About patching the future onto the past instead of bulldozing it. JANE HERMAN

A Russian acquaintance of mine who grew up in Brooklyn told me that her father microwaved his orange juice. Her grandmother also used to heat ice cream in a saucepan on the stove. She remembers once asking her grandmother why it was even called ''ice'' cream, when by all rights it should be called warm or hot cream. ''Things have all kinds of crazy names,'' her grandmother snapped. ''How should I know?'' As the daughter of émigrés from Ukraine, I was raised on room-temperature beverages and always associated ice with a raft of great American stuff other kids were allowed to have but I wasn't: puppies, sheet cake, fun. My own grandmother would cringe from a glass of ice water as if it were a syringe of Ebola virus. I have no idea what disease she associated with the consumption of cold liquids. Pneumonia? Athlete's foot? Chlamydia?

ENRIONE--Robert Ugo Bob. February 5, 1947 June 28, 2011. Robert Ugo Bob Enrione, a veteran of the United States Navy, an Emmy award-winning video journalist, and a longtime resident of Tarrytown, NY, died suddenly on June 28, 2011, while he and his wife were visiting family in Virginia. He was 64 years old. Born on February 5, 1947, in Astoria, Queens, Mr. Enrione was the son of the late Hugo and Ermina Enrione. A 1964 graduate of Bryant High School, Mr. Enrione earned a Bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from City College in 1974. During the Vietnam War, Mr. Enrione served in the United States Navy as a Petty Officer -- Machinist's Mate. Stationed in Vietnam, he was awarded the Silver Star, as well as numerous other decorations. Bob worked for ABC News and CBS News as a videotape editor from the mid 70's through his retirement in 2010. Most notably, Bob worked for the CBS Evening News and 60 Minutes and sports. He was also a frequent commentator on political, social, and economic topics on blogs and online journals. In the mid-1990's Bob shared responsibilities with his wife, Jackie, on their local newspaper, West Side Beat. They covered neighborhood politics up through the Washington Beltway. A gourmet cook, Bob is immortalized in his Chef Hugo column providing unique, easy-to-cook recipes for Manhattanites in their traditional closet-size kitchens. The couple was married October 26, 1996. Mayor Giulilani performed the nuptials. Mr. Enrione was an amateur naval historian of enormous skill and considerable reputation. A contributor to Sea Classics and Naval History magazines, Bob's encyclopedic knowledge of naval warfare ranged from the operational intricacies of sloops and brigs-of-war, to the strategic and tactical nuances of the great naval battles of the French Revolutionary and Napoleonic wars, and the War of 1812. At the time of his passing, Bob was working on a monumental historical novel concerning life at sea during the Nelsonian period. He was also a long-time member of the U.S. Naval Institute, and an informal researcher for the renowned novelist, Dewey Lambdin. Bob was also a very talented visual artist, and his sketches of schooners, sloops, brigs, and ship-of-the-line from the great age of sail enlivened several publications and serve as special keepsakes for his family and friends. He leaves his loving wife of 15 years, Jacqueline Wolf-Enrione, as well as numerous close cousins and friends. Bob had many good friends from all walks of life from medical lab technicians to media moguls and five star generals. Those of us whose lives he touched are richer for having known him. Enrione's HMS Indefatigable 251947 shines on. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that a donation be made in Bob's name to the Naval Institute, 291 Wood Rd, Annapolis, MD 21402, attn: Carol Parkinson. A memorial service will be announced.

STACK--Joan Murphy, of Lambertville, NJ and Doylestown, PA, a native of Stamford, CT. Noted Bucks County radio talk show host of the Joan Stack Show, a daily half hour interview done live from Conti's Cross Keys Inn on WBUX Doylestown for over 20 years. Guests ranged from James Michener and Nathan Lane to George Nakashima and Gloria Steinheim. Former Chair of American Women in Radio and Television/Philadelphia Chapter. Graduate Low Heywood School in Stamford. Survived by her sons actors/producers/writers Patrick and Timothy (wife Jano) and daughter Nina (partner Bob Gould); granddaughters Murphy, Emma and Winnie and grandson Doyle. Memorial celebration to be held on October 8th in Lambertville. Donations to the Passage Theatre Company, Trenton, NJ or to Compassion and Choices in Denver, CO, advocating end of life choices.

SACERDOTE--Peter Marcello, of New York City and Nantucket, MA died in New York on July 31st peacefully surrounded by his family. He succumbed to the prostate cancer that he had been stalwartly battling for many years. He was 73 years old. Mr. Sacerdote was born October 15, 1937 in Turin, Italy and in 1940 his family moved to the United States. He received a Bachelor's Degree of Electrical Engineering from Cornell University in 1960. He served in the Navy from 1960-1962 as Lieutenant (JG), and graduated as a Baker Scholar from Harvard Business School in 1964. He was married to Bonnie L. Johnson on June 18, 1967 in Bronxville, NY. They were devotedly married for forty-four years. Peter enjoyed a distinguished forty-one year career with Goldman, Sachs & Co., which he joined in 1964 directly from business school. He became a General Partner in 1972 and in 1973 was appointed head of the firm's Private Finance Department. In 1980 he became head of the firm's Corporate Finance Department serving in that role for seven years. In 1987 Peter became Co-Head of the firm's merchant banking activities, and served as Chairman of its Investment Committee. He was also Chairman of both the Firm's Commitments and Credit Committees until he retired as a General Partner in 1990. Peter remained active as a Limited Partner serving as Chairman of Goldman's Principal Investment Area's (PIA) Investment Committee - the group responsible for Goldman's corporate private equity and venture capital investing. He served in this role until his retirement in 2006. Peter was known within the firm for his wisdom and investment acumen as well as for being a great teacher, mentor, and friend to many and always reminding everyone, how important it is to have a sense of humor. In 2006, Peter co-founded Whale Rock Capital Management a long-short technology hedge fund with his son Alexander. Peter served as the firm's Chairman for five years and greatly enjoyed working with his son and helping the firm grow to an eight person operation. Over the years, Mr. Sacerdote served on seven corporate boards but there were two that he had a special affinity for: Qualcomm, Inc. and Franklin Resources, Inc. As a Cornell "double EE," Peter had a strong understanding of technology and appreciated his vantage point at Qualcomm to watch the wireless communications revolution unfold. Peter also particularly enjoyed serving on the Board of Franklin Resources, Inc, a firm his father in law founded in 1947. His philanthropic activities included science, education and the arts. He was respected as an active and effective board member. He was on the Board of Overseers of Weill Cornell Medical School and established the Peter M. Sacerdote Urology Laboratory of Research at New York Hospital. He was an Adjunct Professor at Columbia University Business School where he taught a course in corporate finance. He served on the Board of Duke University's Fuqua Business School and Milton Academy. For two years, he served as President of the Alumni Association at Harvard Business School where he established the Peter M. Sacerdote Prize for Social Entrepreneurship. He was a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He also partnered with his wife Bonnie in supporting a number of cultural institutions, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Nantucket Island where Peter spent the last forty two summers, held a very special place in his heart. He loved the island for its natural beauty, sports, friendships and most of all because it was a great place to spend time with his family. Some of his fondest memories were boating and fishing off the shores of Coatue and Great Point with his children and grandchildren. Peter loved playing golf with his friends on Nantucket, whether on the rolling fairways of the Nantucket Golf Club, where he was a founding member, or at seaside Sankaty Head, for which he had a special love having served as a board member for several years and as the Club's President from 2008-2010. Peter also loved his special times with family and friends at the Nantucket Yacht Club, never more so than his last time there - at a picnic celebration of this years 4th of July. He was also active in the Nantucket philanthropic affairs. He endowed the Annual Nantucket Cottage Hospital Health Fair, enabling free mammograms and prostate screenings for local residents. Peter recognized the paramount importance of preserving the island's open, natural land and devoted much time and expertise as a board member of the Nantucket Conservation Foundation. But at his core, Peter was a family man. He derived the most joy from his children, their spouses and his grandchildren, to whom he will always be an inspiration. He lived his life with dignity, grace, and a wonderfully positive attitude, all of which earned him the respect and admiration of those around him. Peter will be remembered as a man dedicated to his family, friends and the communities in which he was involved. All his friends and colleagues continually commented on his wide ranging intellect, his wit and his truly unique sense of humor. These qualities touched all those around him. Peter is survived by his devoted family including his wife Bonnie, his daughter Alisa Brockelman, his sons Alexander and Laurence, his son-in-law Curt Brockelman, daughter-in-law Annagret Sacerdote and his five grandchildren Curtis Brockelman III, Nina Brockelman, Bridget Brockelman, Kate Sacerdote and Peter Sacerdote. In addition he is survived by his brother George Sacerdote, sister in law Carol Sacerdote and their two nephews David and Michael. His other two nephews Dean and Bruce Sacerdote are the sons of his older brother Albert who predeceased him. He is also pre deceased by his parents Luciana and Giorgio. A private family burial will be held on Nantucket. A future memorial service will take place in New York City, date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in honor of Mr. Peter Sacerdote to Memorial Sloan- Kettering Box 27106, New York, NY 10087 or to The Nantucket Conservation Foundation, P.O. Box 13, Nantucket, MA 02554-0013.

The Fair Game column last Sunday, about a proposed regulation regarding the sale of mortgage securities, misstated one attribute of what various regulators have defined as safe home loans. In such loans, borrowers' monthly housing debt payments -- not their total housing debts -- do not exceed 28 percent of their monthly income. And the borrowers' total monthly debt payments -- not their total debts -- do not exceed 36 percent of monthly income.

KELSON--Leonard N. Beloved father of Andrea, Judith and Suzanne. Adored father-in-law of Chris and Jon. Cherished grandfather of Jack, Nora, and Liliana. Admired uncle of Andrew and dear brother-in-law of Marian. Predeceased by the love of his life, wife Selma (Lurie). Born in Brooklyn, Len lived in Brentwood, LI and Manhattan. He was a guidance counselor at Amityville High School and a sports official in Suffolk County. Donations can be made in his memory to Brooklyn College.

ZETZEL--Susanna, died August 4 at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. Daughter of the late Bernard and Elizabeth Stambler, survived by her husband James Zetzel and her brother Peter Stambler of Philadelphia.

A review last Sunday about three classical CDs of hymns and other Americana referred incorrectly to the content of all three. They do indeed share one song, the hymn ''Wondrous Love.'' It is not the case that there is no overlapping material among the three CDs.

Entering July, Braves second baseman Dan Uggla was having the worst season of his career. But on July 5, he began a hitting streak that reached 27 games on Saturday. It has increased his average 44 points, and it needed it: his .173 average was the lowest ever for a player beginning a single-season streak of 25 or more games (among players with more than 20 at-bats before the streak began; Uggla had 318).
FRUGAL TRAVELER Seth Kugel talks about that first-day panic when arriving in a new city -- and how it can be both the bane and the salvation of a frugal traveler.

TRAVERSE CITY, in the fertile northwest corner of Michigan, at the mouth of the Grand Traverse Bay, has long been called the ''Cherry Capital of the World'' (airborne visitors to the city arrive at the Cherry Capital Airport). In recent years, Traverse City has also turned into the gateway to a booming Michigan wine industry that specializes in cool-climate varietals. The city's downtown, only blocks from where the Boardman River empties into the bay, offers plenty of opportunities to shop for cherry products and wine. But the growing culinary and arts scenes show there's more to the region than orchards and vines.DAN PACKEL
