7 P.M. (NBC) THE ROAD BACK In this special edition of ''Dateline NBC,'' Tom Brokaw follows three families -- American, Iraqi and Iraqi-American -- through the war in Iraq, starting in 2002, before the United States invaded that country and removed Saddam Hussein from power, and up to the present, as the United States prepares to withdraw its military forces. In his report Mr. Brokaw reveals what happened to the families and asks whether the war was worth it. ''Nobody wants to go to war, nobody,'' says Staff Sgt. Charles Weaver (above with his wife, Dawn, and Mr. Brokaw) of the Second Brigade, Third Infantry Division, in Iraq. ''But if you have to do it, you do whatever you have to do.'' Dr. El Rabei, the patriarch of an Iraqi family, counters, ''I would rather be dead than see American troops in the streets of Iraq and Baghdad.'' 10 A.M. (ABC) THIS WEEK WITH CHRISTIANE AMANPOUR Ms. Amanpour interviews Robert S. Ford, the American ambassador to Syria, about the uprising in the country and its effect on the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad.

INTERNATIONAL An article last Sunday about NATO airstrikes aimed at Libya's state television transmission dishes in Tripoli misidentified the international agreement authorizing such air strikes that expires in September. It is NATO's own agreement on the use of force in the Libya conflict -- not a United Nations resolution that authorized the use of force, which has no time limit.

BOSTON - Curtis Granderson tapped on his cellphone in the Yankees' clubhouse Saturday after a 10-4 loss to the Boston Red Sox. He had received two text messages from old friends, asking if he knew that deer-antler spray was supposedly a form of human growth hormone. Deer-antler spray?

An article last Sunday about the New 42nd Street Studios, which has 14 rehearsal spaces and a theater, misstated the name of the theater that specializes in plays for children and families. It is the New Victory Theater, not the New Victory Theater for Children.

PROUT--Evelyn Betts, of Manchester, VT, died after a brief illness July 29, 2011 at the age of 91. Born June 14, 1920, Evelyn Gloria Ohman grew up in Brooklyn, NY and graduated from Smith College in 1941. She married Allan Whitney Betts in 1945 and settled in Oyster Bay, LI, raising three children. After her husband retired, they spent summers in Manchester, VT and winters in Jupiter Island, FL. Evie loved playing golf and Bridge with her many friends and spent many happy hours at her easel painting, her little dog Scooter by her side. After the death of her beloved husband Allan in 1986, she remarried to William W. Prout in 1990, her close companion until her death this week. Evelyn is predeceased by her husband of 41 years, Allan W. Betts and sister Dorothy Ericsson. She is survived by her sister Anne Wood of Rutland, VT, her three children Roland Betts of NYC, Nancy Betts of San Francisco and Alison DeWitt of Weston, MA. She is also survived by her husband of 21 years William W. Prout, her daughter-in-law Lois Betts, her son-in-law Robert DeWitt, and her five grandchildren, Margaret and Jessica Betts, and Zachary, Andrew and Brooke DeWitt. Evie will be remembered and cherished for her beautiful smile, her easy-going nature, her sense of humor, and her kind heart. She was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, sister and friend, loved by many people. A memorial service will be held later in the fall in Manchester, VT.

Spring Break in Italy? Head to Rome Our family is planning a trip to Italy for 7 to 10 days during spring break in March 2012. We have two teenage boys (ages 16 and 18). Our interest is more historical than religious. Could you suggest reasonable ''must sees'' while allowing for a little down time? And could you please suggest the best mode of travel? Carrie Bearse, Barnstable, Mass.

A news analysis on July 31 about conservatives' approach to debt incorrectly described Harry S. Truman's political career. As vice president, he succeeded to the presidency in 1945 on the death of Franklin D. Roosevelt. He was elected president in 1948, not re-elected.

It's a sweet drug that plays with fire. A wasteland -- forest of ruins or paved-over jungle depending on whether wakefulness or sleep tips the scales. An old city where the shadows still hold a trace of vanished occupants, where detailed buildings, patiently reconquered by nature, suddenly still are there, sand castles. Through the dreamer's kaleidoscope where the absence of desire is taken as reality, birds slash through the twilight, cypress trees dive into the pool, stars sparkle in the sea, clouds take on shapes, water lilies bloom in the sky, plans become flexible, the limit to how far things can go relaxes, thought dances, light is lit by shade, opposites are juxtaposed, merge and become linked in a prelude to beauty: reverie is contemplation's prehistory, the education of the gaze by the eyes of the soul. Suddenly, the world before concepts.
The hardest part is that just to stay in the game, I have to scrutinize my every thought, every attitude, every emotion, everything, and ask, 'Is this real?' JOE HOLT,

SAX--Dr. Sheldon D.,passed away quietly and with dignity on August 6, 2011. He was born in Altoona, PA. The son of the late Dr. Leon and Stella Sax. He was an Eagle Scout and served in the US Army. He earned his medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania, was board certified in general surgery and was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons. He began his career as a Staff Surgeon at the Manhattan VA Hospital, where he later became the Assistant Chief of Surgery, before entering private practice. He was on the staffs of Booth Memorial Hospital NYHQ and Flushing Hospital and Medical Center. He was a Clinical Assistant Professor of Surgery at NYU School of Medicine. He later worked for the Department of Health for the State of New York. He was a member of the AMA, The Medical Society of the State of New York, The Medical Society of the County of Queens and The American College of Surgeons. He served as a delegate to MSSNY, was past president of the MSCQ, chairman of the Applicants Committee of the ACS for the Brooklyn/ Long Island chapter and past president of the Queensboro Surgical Society. He is survived by his devoted wife, Mary Lou, a daughter and son-in-law, Susan and Brian O'Grady of Savoy, MA, a son, David Sax of Flushing, NY, grandchildren Caitlin and Molly O'Grady and Alex and Megan Sax, a sister and brother-in-law, Laryn and Dr. Moses Finder of Pittsburgh, PA. He was predeceased by a daughter, Mary Beth. His former wife, Francis survives. His Funeral will take place on Monday, August 8, at 1:30pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Burial will follow in Flushing Cemetery.

Google dipped its toes into the world of travel in July when it announced a new Web-based tool, Hotel Finder, while Orbitz expanded its presence with Orbitz-Hotels. Hotel Finder (google.com/hotelfinder), limited to the United States, displays search results on a list or a map. What's distinctive is that it lets users define their own search parameters by superimposing an outline on the map. For a hotel search in New York City you could, say, set the outline to show hotels below 14th Street. Once you have found a hotel, Google lets you know if you are getting a deal by comparing that day's rate with the hotel's normal rate.

If you thought the N.F.L. lockout was tough as a fan, imagine being a head coach. These men are accustomed to 20-hour workdays and sleeping in cots at team headquarters. They are not the kind of people who kick back with Angry Birds for an hour. Down time is not something they handle well.

Dakar, Senegal, June 30, 2011 President Obama's fame has reached some faraway places. I was traveling in Senegal, from Dakar to Lac Rose, and I found his image in many small-town barbershops along the way. I very much liked the way this Senegalese artist represented him, including the earring. I asked Ibrahim, my taxi driver, why he thought these places used Obama's image. He smiled and said, ''Because he is one of us.'' GRACE FREDRIKSON, BRUSSELS
An article last Sunday about the filming of the TV reality series ''Jersey Shore'' in Florence, Italy, misspelled the name of a museum in that city. It is the Uffizi, not Uffizzi.

RIDDER--Constance Meach, of Pebble Beach, California and Kona, Hawaii died at home on August 5th, 2011 of intestinal cancer. Born in Charlotte, Michigan on January 16th, 1941 Connie was raised in Traverse City, Michigan where she was Central US Ski Champion in 1957. She met P. Anthony Ridder, her husband of 50 years, at college at the University of Michigan, where they were married during their junior year. While raising her family in Saratoga, California she completed her undergraduate studies at Stanford University and earned a law degree at Santa Clara University. Following her graduation in 1986 she was an associate and then a partner at Holland & Knight in Miami, Florida where she and Tony moved when he became President of the newspaper division and then CEO of Knight - Ridder Inc. After returning to California in 1998, Connie continued her civic activities including serving as a trustee of The Garden Club of America, Carmel, California and President of Filoli Estate and Gardens, in Woodside, California, a property of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Connie was longtime head of the Ladies Golf Committee at the Cypress Point Club. She is survived by her husband, Tony Ridder, her daughters, Katie Ridder of New York, Linda Walker of Seattle, Susie Ridder of Seattle, her son Par Ridder of Winnetka, Illinois and her 12 grandchildren. Contributions, in lieu of flowers, to Filoli, www.filoli.org/support-us.

THURSDAY on ''Morning Joe,'' Mika Brzezinski lamented how buyers of $1,500 shoes were ''shameless.'' She pointed to the front-page article in The New York Times about buoyant luxury-goods spending in a weak economy. Before the co-host Joe Scarborough teased her off the soapbox, Ms. Brzezinski unloaded some indignation. Her aim was off, though. Sensible people might agree that it's shameful to spend that kind of money (and more) for shoes or an article of clothing, but the wealthy and young people with decent-enough jobs have been doing that for months, as retail numbers indicate.

Consumers Union, the publisher of Consumer Reports, sends out a news release each month summarizing the automotive evaluations of the coming month's issue. Rarely does the release generate significant attention, let alone a media scrum, but on Monday a preview of the magazine's September issue contained a bombshell: the 2012 Honda Civic LX sedan scored so poorly during testing that the car did not make the magazine's Recommended list. Previous versions of the Civic were Consumer Reports' highest rated small sedans and were named Top Picks in five of the last 10 years. Under the magazine's methodology, the previous generation Civic EX sedan (a 2006 model) scored ''a very good 78.''

Just two days after signing a four-year contract with the Giants, cornerback Prince Amukamara, the team's first round pick in the N.F.L. draft, broke his left foot in practice Saturday night. Amukamara, the 19th player taken in April's draft, has a fractured fifth metatarsal. He will require surgery and is out indefinitely.

The Phillies' Cliff Lee twirled his fifth shutout of the season on Thursday when he blanked the Giants, 3-0. Lee has the most shutouts in a season since 2005, when Dontrelle Willis had five for Florida. No pitcher has recorded more shutouts in a season since Randy Johnson, who had six shutouts in 1998 (two for the Seattle Mariners and four for the Houston Astros). Lee also has seven games with at least 10 strikeouts, the most in the major leagues, yet at week's end his 2.96 earned run average ranked just 10th in the National League. The reason? When Lee is bad, he makes it count. Three times this season, Lee has allowed six earned runs in a game -- the same total he allowed in Game 1 of the World Series for Texas last October.

WHICH came first: the bicycle helmet or the fashion hood? And does it matter? On the resort runways, we saw hats resembling head protection at Givenchy and Balenciaga, and in bike lanes across town, helmet heads are now the norm. Let's call it out: once-dorky headgear has become a status symbol. ''Helmets really haven't been cool until now,'' said the Tucker designer Gaby Basora, who recently collaborated with the cycle aficionados Trek and Bontrager on a leopard-print version. ''I wore it just last week, and I was stopped literally more than a dozen times by women asking me where to get their own.'' So maybe it takes Givenchy's close-to-the-skull velvet cap (above) to wrap our heads around Bern's brimmed helmet (about $70; go to bernunlimited.com). Or maybe, when fashion intervenes, our options become a lot more interesting. CHELSEA ZALOPANY

DISPROVING all those spurious, borderline-offensive images of Teutonic style (typically involving lederhosen or jackboots), there's ''German Fashion Design'' (Distanz, $68), a half-century survey of one of the more easily overlooked fashion scenes in Europe. The dual-language book dutifully catalogs German fashion contributions in the realms of skiwear (Bogner), exquisitely cut office wear (Jil Sander) and great cheekbones (Claudia Schiffer). It begins in the late 1940s, when the German clothing industry, like much of the country, was still devastated by World War II. (It didn't help matters that the prewar German clothiers were mostly Jewish; the ones who survived emigrated to Seventh Avenue or thereabouts.) Meanwhile, a few visionaries like Heinz Oestergaard and Uli Richter dared to trade the apron dresses and tied-up head scarves worn by Berlin's ''rubble women'' for a more relaxed twist on Gallic chic. Mr. Oestergaard was eventually stymied by the Berlin Wall, but Mr. Richter, whose 1959 fashions are pictured below, flourished in West Germany. His clothes were sold in Bloomingdale's, and he became the first of many German designers to appear in French Vogue. STEPHEN HEYMAN

A 25-FOOT-WIDE Upper East Side town house that underwent a two-year gut renovation was the highest sale of the week, at $15.4 million, city property records show.The town house, which has four bedrooms and 10,200 square feet of space, according to Sotheby's, was listed for $19 million last September. At 162 East 92nd Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, it went into contract in June, according to Streeteasy.com. It last sold in 2007 for $6.3 million, when it was configured as three apartments, according to property records.The sellers, Christopher B. O'Malley and Wendy Flanagan, also renovated and sold a town house at 26 East 73rd Street; they bought it for $6.5 million in 1999 and sold it for $18 million in 2007. The buyer of the 92nd Street house was listed under a limited liability company. Big Ticket includes closed deals from the previous week, ending Wednesday.

Alan Mulally, the Ford Motor Company president and chief executive, took his pitch for the electric car to late-night television just after midnight on Thursday, with an appearance on ''The Late Show With David Letterman'' on CBS. Introduced by his uncharacteristically effusive host as a ''hero'' and the man ''responsible for rescuing the Ford Motor Company from the brink of bankruptcy,'' Mr. Mulally took his seat with a smile and a wave to the audience and, beyond it, the country Mr. Mulally hoped to sell on the Focus Electric, a purely electric compact car due in showrooms in 2012.

The penthouse at the Metal Shutter Houses, a condominium designed by the architect Shigeru Ban and located at an epicenter of modern architecture, on 19th Street in West Chelsea, was snapped up immediately after it went on the market in 2007. That was not unusual during the real estate boom. Many apartments, particularly those in buildings designed by celebrity architects, were sold sight unseen. To the left of the Ban building is a condo by Annabelle Selldorf; across the street is one by Jean Nouvel; and Frank Gehry's IAC building is so close one could almost touch it from the terraces.

An article on July 10 about the Teen Art Gallery exhibition at the New York Open Center in Manhattan and its teenage curators misspelled the surname of a 17-year-old sculptor whose work is in the show. She is Sin Yi Lau, not Yau.

I SIT here, in a suburb of Detroit, writing books by hand on yellow unlined pads with a view from my desk that offers distractions: Disney creatures on the patio, squirrels that come up for a handout and go nuts when I offer pistachios. Once I looked up from my work and a coyote was staring at me from the hedge a dozen feet away, though not with much interest. The squirrels know he's there and stay hidden and the coyote wanders off, hoping to find a little dog in another yard. Several times I've seen a hawk, claws wrapped around the limb of an apple tree, waiting for prey who somehow know better than to reveal themselves. Distractions are good when I'm stuck in whatever it is I'm writing or have reached the point of overwriting. The hawk flies off, the squirrels begin to venture out, cautious at first, and I return to the yellow pad, my mind cleared of unnecessary words. The last in a series on what writers from around the world see from their windows.

Holly Golightly as portrayed by Audrey Hepburn and her imagery, created by the Paris designer Hubert de Givenchy for the film that opened 50 years ago, are having their moment with a new generation this summer. Last month on several occasions, groups paused on their way to work for breakfast by the Tiffany front door, before the store opened. Echoes of Ms. Hepburn's boat necks are reappearing. One group, at about 8:15 a.m., included not only Holly but her film boyfriend, a Paul Varjak lookalike. On another morning, there was Mr. Yunioshi, Holly's neighbor, passing in a large Asian hat and a man's summer kimono. One wondered what Holly would look like today. Judging from passers-by, she would still be dressed in black or perhaps a dazzling red Adrian evening dress. Or a vintage 1950s Norman Norell, top, third from left. There were even some Japanese women in long kid gloves waiting for Tiffany's to open to attend a breakfast inside, left center. Top right, a mannequin and a photo of Holly in the iconic dress as seen in the 1982 Fashion Institute of Technology retrospective of Mr. Givenchy's work, and the designer greeting Ms. Hepburn at the show's opening.

While the Mets might go all season without using their ace, Johan Santana, the Washington Nationals could get theirs back before the end of September. Santana was shut down last week with fatigue in his surgically repaired left shoulder, but Stephen Strasburg is on course in his recovery from reconstructive elbow surgery. Strasburg, 23, underwent the operation last Sept. 3. He has been throwing off a mound for more than two months, and will begin his rehabilitation assignment on Sunday with Class A Hagerstown (Md.). With a 30-day maximum for a rehabilitation assignment, Strasburg could be pitching for the Nationals by mid-September.

OLSON--Martha, who lived in both New York City and Southampton, died peacefully at her New York home surrounded by friends on July 30, 2011 after a long illness. Martha was a proud achiever and built a distinguished career in public relations. She and two partners started a PR firm in St. Louis that was so successful it was acquired by Farley Manning in New York, where she became a Sr. Vice President. She later joined Hill & Knowlton, rising to Sr. Vice President before her retirement. During the course of her career, Martha advised such powerful clients as the Principality of Monaco, Mexico's Department of Tourism (supervising the launch of Cancun), the Virgin Islands, Anheuser-Busch, E. I. du Pont de Nemours, Pet Milk and Chevron Chemical. Her hands-on style and creative ideas earned her major industry awards, including the Prisms Award presented by the Los Angeles chapter of the Public Relations Society of America in 1980, and two years later, she was one of the first women in the country to win the Silver Anvil Award, the highest honor given by the PRSA. Martha Annette Olson was born in Ft. Stockton, Texas on Christmas day 1920, the daughter of Auburn Elizabeth Bransford and John Nels Olson, a Swedish immigrant. She spent her formative years in Parsons, Kansas before moving to St. Louis and finally to New York. In an interview with the St. Louis Post-Dispatch in January 1958 regarding her public relations success, Martha said, "Speed somehow always seems to have been part of my life." Indeed she loved life in the fast lane, whether driving one of her low-slung sports convertibles, flying a single-engine plane as a 19-year-old student pilot and later becoming an airport traffic controller, or much later riding her horse, Dusty, in the Hamptons. Martha is survived by her sister and brother-in-law Jean and Joseph Stevens of Montecito, CA and her brother and sister-in-law Jack and Alice Olson of the National Forest north of Tucson, AZ. She is also survived by her close friends and real estate partners Jody Donohue and Etta Froio, and her beloved Wirehaired Fox Terrier Bentley, named for one of her flashy fast cars she loved to drive. View guestbook online at legacy.com
Art Holland Cotter

LONDON -- Clusters of young men hurled bricks and aimed fireworks at riot police officers before a backdrop of burning cars and buildings early Sunday in north London as what began as a protest turned into an all-out riot. Demonstrators on Saturday evening marched to a police station in the Tottenham area of London to protest the death of Mark Duggan, a 29-year-old father of four who was killed Thursday in what The Guardian newspaper described as a ''shootout'' with officers from the Trident unit of the Metropolitan Police, which investigates gun crime.

WEDECK--David of Teaneck, NJ passed away on July 21st at the age of 85. He is survived by his wife Diane, children Douglas and Andrew, grandchildren Moshe, Sheva, Naama, Benjamin, Eliyahu and daughters-in-law Yael and Mara. Another son Jonathan died in 1973. He was born in Brooklyn, NY. Following a long career as an executive at both NBC and CBS television, at the age of 70, Mr. Wedeck invented the patented technology for, the first screwless, eyeglass frame. Prior to his network positions, he was a VP at the ad agency Benton Bowles. He then co-founded the commercial production company Focus Presentations. Mr. Wedeck was a Jewish soldier stationed in Germany during World War II and then went on to Columbia University where he received an undergraduate degree in Business Management and then a Masters of Science of Business. He attended Townsend Harris High School. Mr. Wedeck was a generous, passionate, honest, funny and intelligent man who until he was ultimately felled by the ravages of Alzheimer's disease, was undaunted in the pursuit of his goals. His loss will be felt by many.

He is familiar with Jets Coach Rex Ryan, linebacker Bart Scott, safety Jim Leonhard and defensive lineman Trevor Pryce, from their shared days with the Ravens.

A picture caption last Sunday with the Local Intelligence column, about reminders of Hollywood that can be found along Hyde Street in the Tenderloin, which was home to many film studios from the 1930s to the 1960s, misspelled the surname of a man at the vaults once used to store films at the former Motion Picture Studio and Laboratory. He is Nick Olivero, not Oliver.

MOSKIN--Marietta D.,83, beloved widow of A. Donald Moskin and mother of James and Linda, died peacefully on August 3, in her home in Manhattan. Born in Vienna, Austria, she came to the United States with her parents in 1946. She earned a BA from Barnard College and an MA in economics from the University of Wisconsin, and worked as an economist for General Motors. Later, she became a prolific children's book author with sixteen books plus short stories and translations. She was a Holocaust survivor, and her book, I Am Rosemarie, was based on her experiences and has been translated into German and Dutch. It is still used in schools in the United States and Europe. She was a member of the Unitarian Church of all Souls for fifty-five years, and served on its board and committees and as editor of its Quarterly Review. Survived by her children, James and Linda. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. A gravesite funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, at 80th St. and Lexington Ave. on Tuesday, September 6, at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the Unitarian Universalist Service Committee, 689 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139 or to Barnard College, Box AS, 3009 Broadway, NY, 10027.

Sitting in the ruins of a Libyan government building in Yafran that had been shattered by violence, Abdul Ghassem recalled his feeling within when he first began to paint murals expressing his disgust for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. That was in early June, soon after the Qaddafi military was driven out of his city. Abdul Ghassem’s paintbrushes moved along the interior walls. As a huge mural took shape, Libya’s longtime leader came to resemble a vampire watching over a world troubled by blood, suffering and fire.

In late July 1861, the noted lithographer John Bachmann published a captivating visual picture of Virginia, offering Northerners a powerful and intuitive way to follow the ongoing conflict. Of course, there were already lots of maps of the Old Dominion. What set this one apart? Perspective: looking westward with the Chesapeake Bay in the foreground, it offered a bird’s eye view, an intuitive but, for many, novel look at the unfolding conflict. His “wide angle lens” approach enabled viewers to follow not just the actual location of the battles, but the terrain of the conflict and a larger sense of the geography of the eastern theater.

For its fall collection of icicle-drop necklaces and pendants, Kora, the L.A.-based, African-made jewelry line, teamed up with glass makers in the Kenyan village of Kitengela. A mere two years old, Kora has dedicated itself to creating “trade not aid” jobs by designing and marketing hand-fashioned pieces made from recycled bone, aluminum, brass, horn and now glass. ”The colors of the glowing green glass are incredible; it’s so unlike animal horn,” says Kora’s co-founder Maxandra Short (above, left). Her partner, Amy Walker, adds, “Glass necklaces still have an organic feel, because every piece is different.” Indeed the latest offerings, like the necklace at right ($220; go to koradesigns.com), are a softer addition to the line’s usually more brawny designs, which in the past have included tribal-inspired manacles and industrial-looking chains. “I think we’re even going to be playing with color in bone,“ Walker says. “Color is our thing now.”

WASHINGTON – There will be far fewer blue polyester jackets seen darting through Capitol Hill. John Boehner, the speaker of the House, and Nancy Pelosi, the minority leader, announced on Monday that they have decided to end the House page program. The decision, based on a cost analysis by an outside consulting firm, was largely driven by costs, and because advances in technology have rendered obsolete some of their tasks, such as taking phone messages.

The man who gave us “Buffalo 66″ (when Cristina Ricci still had breasts) and “The Brown Bunny” (a must for those who like seeing Chloe Sevigny sink to her knees) has announced that his latest, “Promises Written in Water,” will never be screened again. “I do not want my new works to be generated in a market or audience of any kind,” he was quoted as saying in The Guardian. As The Guardian points out, he is in illustrious company. “Promises Written in Water” is  “to take its place in the same sealed vault many miles underground, housing that other movie locked away from prying eyes by its own obsessive mastermind, Jerry Lewis’s “The Day the Clown Cried.” Perhaps, like Lewis, Gallo will end up inducted into the Légion d’Honneur.

Andy Cohen, the Bravo channel executive who doubles as a talk-show host for the network, will soon double — or is that triple? — as an author. Henry Holt and Company said on Monday that it would publish Mr. Cohen’s first book, a memoir about growing up with a love of pop culture and landing a job in the television business, which enabled him to meet many of the stars he admired. The as-yet untitled book will also detail how Mr. Cohen, who is gay, suppressed his sexuality as a boy. It is to be published next summer.

The Canadian government has long fought efforts by politicians and environmentalists in other countries, including the United States, to characterize oil sands production as “dirty oil.” But an analysis quietly released late last month by its environmental agency indicates that the tar-like deposits will become an increasingly significant source of the country’s greenhouse gas emissions by the end of the decade.

The Tribeca Film Festival said on Monday that its 11th annual festival would be held April 18 – 29 in Manhattan. The festival has asked for submissions for narrative and documentary features as well as for short film entries. The Tribeca Film Institute, the year-round nonprofit arts organization, said it would take submissions starting on Monday for its Tribeca All Access program, TFI Documentary Fund, Latin America Media Arts Fund and the TFI Sloan Filmmaker Fund. Starting Sept. 19, submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the 2012 festival will be available on the Tribeca Web site. Submission forms and information regarding eligibility for the film institute programs are available at tribecafilminstitute.org.

SANDPOINT, Idaho — To judge from reader comments on this blog, tweets from those who are following me, e-mails to my New York Times address and inquiries from people I’ve been meeting along the way, the practical aspects of a cross-country bike trip are of real interest. People want solid facts. Not just where did you start and where are you going, but what’s your route, how many hours a day do you ride and when do you think you’ll be finished? How do you do your laundry, how many flat tires have you had, what sort of GPS are you carrying? Then there’s one I’ve been asked three or four times recently: What’s your favorite thing about the trip so far?

It started when my very Parisian friend, staying at my New York apartment, hand-washed her lingerie and neatly hung the coordinating pairs along the shower rod. Bras and panties in tandem styles: frilly florals by Only Hearts, nude sheers from Eres and a hot pink number that could have only been from Agent Provocateur. So French, so chic. I squirmed in my mismatched red cotton briefs and orange satin bra. Why had it never dawned on me to match? “I only started buying sets when I got married,” says the author and Vogue contributing editor Plum Sykes, remembering a pistachio and cream lace combo she fell in love with on the Rue des Saints-Pères in Paris. “Young women today seem to be more aware of the trend for beautiful matching lingerie,” says Cynthia Gabay, Myla’s creative director. “Your underpinnings say as much about you as a person as your choice in clothing or accessories.” My early-20-something self now officially desires grown-up glamour — and one trip to Bergdorf’s later, taps and teddies are joined at the hip.

In trying to marry the prissiness of the Victorians with the sexual revolution of the 1960s, Tabitha Simmons has come out with an English heritage collection that is a hybrid hoot. “Like rockabilly shoes,” the English designer says of her inspirations, “but — more gothic.” The 49 styles are indeed evocative of the British Isles, with a smattering of high-heel brogues, evening sandals with chandelier trim and suede boots that look like they stepped out of “Bedknobs and Broomsticks.” Compared to previous collections, it is slightly more macabre, yet Simmons, now in her fifth season, continues to demonstrate an ability to imbue classic styles with a modern twist. For example, the Edna heel, a reimagined stiletto loafer, “is beetle-crusher when it’s in black and white,” she says, “and then we did a red and leopard version that has an element of Victoriana.” She’s certainly got a bead on the new monarchy. A pair of nude silk slippers looks fit for a duchess or a Park Avenue princess.

The end of summer brings a surge in calls from government clients, mostly from the military, looking to spend remaining dollars in their budgets before the fiscal year ends on Oct. 1. This year is no exception. The surge has started and is most likely to peak at the end of August. Just last week we got calls from the State Department, the Army and the Marines. The person on the phone is generally a low-level officer, responding to a request from a superior for pricing on a large and fancy table. Our bid will be presented to the upper ranks as one of a number of ways to spend their remaining money. Consequently, we sell a much lower percentage of these inquiries than those from private clients. But August is usually a slower month for private business, so we take the time to write proposals anyway.

SCHELLING--William F.,August 3, 2011, of Allendale, NJ, formerly of Tenafly, NJ, cherished father of Patricia Schelling Cellary and her husband Christoper, of Allendale, NJ, devoted grandfather to Brian Christopher and Kevin William Cellary, dearest brother of Lucy Schelling Averill and her husband Professor Dr. Anton W Zimmermann of Atlanta, GA. Beloved husband of the late Martha Louise Turner Schelling and cherished father to the late William F Schelling, Jr. Head of the CBS TV Lighting department in New York City, was at CBS for 40 years, a member of Local 1 IATSE (International Alliance Theatrical Stage Employees) for 63 years. He had the opportunity to travel the world. Bill was responsible for the lighting for political conventions, beauty pageants, sporting events, soap operas and many other significant events. He was a pioneer and innovator in the design of the television lighting industry. A WWII veteran, graduating from RCA Engineering School, a member of Archer United Methodist Church and a member of the Knickerbocker Country Club in Tenafly, NJ for 20 years. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, August 10th at the United Methodist Church, 7 East Allendale Avenue, Allendale, NJ 07401 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Archer United Methodist Endowment Fund 7 East Allendale Avenue, Allendale, NJ 07401 or the ASPCA.

BOSTON - Something about nationally televised night games against the Red Sox seems to evoke lineup issues surrounding Jorge Posada. On May 14, a Saturday night, Posada asked out of the starting lineup when he was written in to bat ninth by Yankees Manager Joe Girardi. But on Sunday night, Posada did not even have the option to ask out. He was already out.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y. - Teaching professionals and well-traveled players see all kinds of golf swings, good and bad. But perhaps no one bears witness to more golfers' mistakes than caddies at private clubs. Hole after hole, round after round - with members, guests and, worst of all, caddies say, participants in corporate outings - they see classic faults repeated over and over.

That might sound like catastrophic thinking after Mr. Obama's nerve-jangling birthday week, during which he got several gag gifts: a near default, a 500-point market drop and the first-ever downgrade of United States debt by a major credit ratings agency.

A division of Warren E. Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is involved in what is now a three-way fight to acquire Transatlantic Holdings, a reinsurance company. Berkshire's National Indemnity is offering $3.25 billion, or $52 a share, Transatlantic confirmed in a statement on Sunday. That is a nearly 15 percent premium to Transatlantic's Friday closing price.

ALBERT--Lawrence, 87, of Sleepy Hollow, NY, on August 7, 2011. Devoted husband of Joan (Jacober), beloved father of Kathi Arnow, Susan Albert and Kenneth Albert, proud grandfather of Benjamin, Daniel, Joel, Jacob, Zachary, and Julian, doting great-grandfather of Liran and Harper, dear brother of Ina LeKachman. Service will be held on Tuesday, August 9th, 1:00pm at Kendal-on-Hudson, 1010 Kendal Way, Sleepy Hollow, NY, followed by internment at Mt. Pleasant Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. TEPLITZ--Benjamin I.,of Tenafly, NJ on August 4, 2011. Beloved husband of Dona E. Teplitz, devoted father to Fran Teplitz, and proud grandfather of Rosa Teplitz Zielinski. In recent years, Ben worked avidly with the Platts Oilgram Price Report, until age 78, an achievement that gave him great satisfaction. Prior to that he worked with American Metal Market (AMM) for more than 20 years. In 1994, Ben shared a first place Chilton Editorial Award for the Best Subject Series of Articles on the Mississippi Floods. AMM colleagues called Ben, who stood 5'5, the little dynamo with a nose for news. Ben may have inherited his passion for reporting from his grandfather and father, newsmen who worked for the Yiddishe Veldt (Jewish World). Ben also worked as an adjunct professor at Coppin State College in Baltimore, MD. He earned his Ph.D in History from Howard University in Washington, DC. Interviewing and delving for the facts came naturally to Ben, as anyone who talked with him would soon discover. As a young man, he served in the army during the Korean War era. Ben loved the pace and diversity of Manhattan and greatly enjoyed the city's theatre, opera, restaurants, and neighborhoods. At home in New Jersey he enjoyed nature walks and cultural events with his wife and tending to his house plants. Ben was born in Philadelphia on November 25, 1932 to the late Israel David and Marion (Malin) Teplitz. His brother, Ralph, passed away in 2008. Survivors include his wife of 48 years, Dona; a daughter, Fran (Mike Zielinski); a grand-daughter, Rosa; and numerous cousins, nieces, and nephews. Ben's smile, sense of humor, generosity, and vitality will always be remembered by his family, friends, and colleagues. A memorial service will be held in the Washington, DC area at a later date. Contributions in Ben's memory may be made to the Tenafly Nature Center, 313 Hudson Ave., Tenafly, NJ 07670.

JOYCE--Francis (Frank) John, of Ann Arbor, Michigan, formerly of Morris Plains, New Jersey, died at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital, Ann Arbor, MI on August 2, 2011. He was 89 years old. Frank was born on June 1, 1922 and raised on a dairy farm in Montgomery, New York. He graduated from Webb Institute in February 1944. He was commissioned as Ensign USNR and coordinated the hull design of the LSM-60 vessel of the Cross Roads project. In 1947, he began his 43 year career with D.K. Ludwig in design, construction, and operation of oil tankers, iron ore and bulk carriers, some of the world's largest in their class at the time. He initiated and coordinated the marine design and overall construction and start-up of a 750 ton-per-day pulp mill constructed in Japan and towed to the Jari River in Brazil. He was Executive Vice President of both National Bulk Carriers and Universe Tankships and President of Harsimus Cove Real Estate. He retired in 1990. In 1978, he received the William Selkirk Owen Award from the Webb Institute in recognition of outstanding achievement and service to the profession and to his alma mater and received an honorary doctorate from the Webb Institute in 1997. He was an active member for many years in the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers (SNAME) and the American Bureau of Shipping (ABS). He is predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Mary Patricia (Pat) Hamill Joyce; brothers John, Richard, Thomas, William, and sister Alice. He is survived by his three children M. Tara Joyce of Oak Park, Illinois; Frank Joyce, Jr. (Katy Van Dusen) of Monteverde, Costa Rica; Patricia Joyce (Steven J. Slack) of Ann Arbor, MI; and grandchildren Helen, Francis, Richard, Connor, and Devin. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends for his kind and gentle manner, his humility, his genuine interest in and compassion for others, his great intellect and his wit. A funeral mass will be held at St. Mary's Abbey in Morristown, New Jersey at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Webb Institute in Glen Cove, New York or Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (LICR) in New York, New York.

8 P.M. (13) BARBRA STREISAND: ONE NIGHT ONLY AT THE VILLAGE VANGUARD On Sept. 26, 2009, Ms. Streisand, below, gave a rare live performance at this Greenwich Village haunt, where she opened for Miles Davis 48 years earlier. Her handpicked audience included Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton, Sarah Jessica Parker and Nicole Kidman. This special, which captures that evening, is being shown before the release, on Aug. 23, of Ms. Streisand's album ''What Matters Most: Barbra Streisand Sings the Lyrics of Alan and Marilyn Bergman.'' In ''The Greatest Duets: It Takes Two,'' at 9:30, Kenny Loggins recalls memorable musical pairings from the 1960s, '70s and '80s, like ''Ain't No Mountain High Enough'' by Marvin Gaye and Tammi Terrell, and ''Don't Go Breaking My Heart'' by Elton John and Kiki Dee. 6 A.M. (TCM) SUMMER UNDER THE STARS: ORSON WELLES In 1939 Welles arrived in Hollywood as a 24-year-old dreamer after having convinced listeners on the East Coast that alien invaders had landed during his radio broadcast of H. G. Wells's ''War of the Worlds.'' For his first feature film, ''Citizen Kane'' (1941), he told the story of a megalomaniacal newspaper mogul who closely resembled William Randolph Hearst -- too closely, it turned out, for the comfort of Hearst, who tried to suppress the project. That movie, considered Welles's masterpiece and what Bosley Crowther, writing in The New York Times, called ''close to being the most sensational film ever made,'' is shown at 10 as part of a prime-time lineup that includes ''The Third Man'' (1949) at 8 and ''Touch of Evil'' (1958) at 12:15 a.m.

CAREY--Governor Hugh Leo (April 11, 1919 August 7, 2011). Life does not cease; it merely changes. The family of the 51st Governor of New York State gathered in their Shelter Island home to surround their beloved father, grandfather and great-grandfather as he made his peaceful journey to eternal life. In seven terms in Congress, he represented the 12th and then 15th Districts from Brooklyn and was elected unanimously to the Ways and Means Committee. A member of the 4 Horsemen, Hugh Carey joined with Ted Kennedy, Pat Moynihan and Tip O'Neill to advocate for a peaceful solution to the conflict in Northern Ireland. Hugh Carey was elected the 51st Governor of New York on November 5, 1974, the first Democrat in sixteen years, and was re-elected in 1978. As Governor he was the architect of the financial plan that averted the bankruptcy of New York City. Upon the conclusion of his time in office, the NY Times hailed him as a Governor for Hard Winters. One of his earliest acts as Governor was signing the historic Willowbrook consent decree, committing New York State to sweeping reforms in the care of the developmentally disabled. He instituted the I Love New York program and founded the Empire State Games. Following the attacks of September 11, 2001, Governor Carey was asked to represent New York State and speak at numerous funerals for fallen firefighters, throughout the five boroughs and surrounding counties. His public legacy was matched by his larger than life personal story. Born in Brooklyn, NY, he was the third of Margaret and Dennis Carey's six sons. The family persevered during the Depression and went on to form the Peerless Oil Company, a business they started as an offshoot of Margaret Collins Carey's barrel business with the great Nellie Bly. The Governor attended St. Augustine's School in Park Slope and graduated from St. John's University and St. John's University Law School. Hugh Carey married the lovely Helen Owen Twohy on February 27, 1947 in The Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral. The Carey's love of family was demonstrated by their parenting of fourteen children: Alexandria, Christopher, Susan, the late Peter and Hugh, Jr., Michael, Donald, Marianne, Nancy, Helen, Bryan, the late Paul, Kevin and Thomas. Mrs. Carey died of cancer in March 1974. Known as much for his wit as his powerful intellect, the Governor was gifted with inimitable Irish charm and a love of song. He was proud to call the legendary Frank Sinatra his friend and adopted New York, New York as his signature song. Channeling Maurice Chevalier, he regaled guests at the many family weddings with his popular rendition of Thank Heaven for Little Girls. His sartorial taste was colorful and impeccable. He found great joy in his 25 grand children and six great-grandchildren. Among his many awards and recognitions, his favorite was an honorary degree in Elan and Joie de Vivre. His larger than life spirit was indomitable; friends and family knew him simply as Huge. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral; St. John's University, or The Paul R. Carey Foundation, 22 Corporate Woods Blvd., Albany, NY 12211. The family wishes to acknowledge the many doctors and caregivers who have been devoted to our father in his final years, bringing a singular life to a dignified and peaceful close, or rather the beginning of his next chapter. Excelsior!

Hugh L. Carey, the governor who helped rescue New York from the brink of financial collapse in the 1970s and tamed a culture of ever-growing spending, died Sunday at his summer home on Shelter Island, N.Y. He was 92. His death was announced by the office of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo. ''Governor Carey led our state during a time of great financial turmoil and pulled us back from the brink of bankruptcy and economic ruin,'' Mr. Cuomo said in the statement.

Jane White, an actress who made her reputation in the 1960s and '70s in Shakespearean and classical Greek drama in New York but who felt hampered by the racial attitudes of casting directors toward light-skinned black performers like herself, died on July 24 at her home in Greenwich Village. She was 88. The cause was cancer, said Joan K. Harris, her friend and executor.

In the end, it was not the opposition of East Hampton, N.Y., locals worried about a Woodstock in their quiet seaside enclave but lackluster ticket sales that doomed the Music to Know Festival on Long Island next weekend. Just six days before the festival was to be held on an unused runway at the East Hampton Airport, the promoters -- Chris Jones, a Montauk hotelier, and his partner, Bill Collage, a screenwriter -- posted an announcement online saying ''the ticket sales were not adequate to allow the event to continue.'' Mr. Jones had lined up an impressive list of indie bands, led by Vampire Weekend and Bright Eyes. He had also overcome significant resistance in the Hamptons, where many residents worried the two-festival meant an invasion of rowdy rock fans that would snarl traffic on the narrow road running from the Shinnecock to Montauk. But the tickets, which were selling for $195 for a two-day pass, didn't move, and the festival did not have major corporate sponsors, with the exception of some support from Bing, the search engine. The passes were priced fairly high for a new festival. By comparison, Bonnaroo, the giant event in Tennessee, cost between $210 and $250 for a four-day pass to see a lineup that includes the biggest names in popular music. One reason for the lack of ticket sales might have been competition from a similar festival at the Shinnecock reservation this weekend, Escape to New York, which went off smoothly.

From its 1,200-square-foot space overlooking 34th Street in Manhattan, Spy Shops offers customized surveillance installations with five-figure price tags for foreign princes, chart-topping rappers, business tycoons and paranoid husbands. Its display cases exhibit an impressive pastiche of long-range listening equipment ($249 and up) and matchbook-sized tracking devices ($650), perfect for concealment in an imitation soda can, which the store also offers. Spy Shops even sells a high-definition video camera embedded in a fake B.M.W. key ($249), which might make Agent 007 - a poster of James Bond hangs on a wall - kvell with delight.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y. - Ron Conboy had played 25 holes - on foot, as always - when he crested a ridge that runs across the fifth fairway here at Sleepy Hollow Country Club. Atop another rise about 200 yards away, the green was silhouetted against the silver-blue waters of the Hudson River. ''You get tired of walking it, but you don't get tired of looking at it,'' Conboy said of Sleepy Hollow, a storied course about 30 miles north of Manhattan, where he has caddied for the past 20 years. ''Up in here, this is just brilliant, a brilliant view.''

HORODAS--Shirley, of New York City died peacefully at home on August 6, 2011, at age 86. She is survived by two children: Eric (Linda) Horodas and Susan (Joel) Goldstein, and two grandchildren, Kevin Horodas and Marc Horodas. She was predeceased in 1995 by her husband of 49 years, Bernard Stuart Horodas. She was the daughter of Maurice S. Handler who built Smart Maid Suit & Co., one of America's leading coat and suit manufacturers during and after WWII. After marrying her beloved husband Bud upon his return from service in the Army Medical Core in the European Theater of Operations in World War II, she completed her education by obtaining a Bachelor's Degree in Anthropology from New York University. She was an avid world traveler, having visited over 30 countries around the world with Bud. She was a patron of the arts, a lifelong subscriber to both the New York Philharmonic and the New York Opera. She was very active in many volunteer causes including Hadassah, but her passion was museum work. In a volunteer capacity, she created the archives at the Katonah Museum, in Katonah, New York. Shirley was a devoted wife and mother, like her father, a loyal supporter of the philanthropies to which she was committed, and all those whose lives she touched will miss her terribly. Memorial services will be held on Wednesday, August 10, 2011 at 11:30AM at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY.

Levi's is adding a hue to its marketing efforts: Facebook blue. The purveyor of all things denim has teamed up with the social media giant on the next phase of its ''Go Forth'' campaign. On Tuesday, Levi's will announce the campaign exclusively on Facebook and will encourage the company's 6.2 million Facebook fans (and, it hopes, their Facebook friends) to support Water.org, a nonprofit organization that supplies clean water to people in the developing world.

Computer-generated primates, yes. Extreme scatological humor? No. That sums up Hollywood's weekend, as ''Rise of the Planet of the Apes'' took in about $54 million at North American theaters and ''The Change-Up,'' an ultra-crude comedy (it opens with a baby defecating in Jason Bateman's mouth), landed with a $13.5 million thud. The strong No. 1 result for ''Rise of the Planet of the Apes,'' which cost 20th Century Fox about $100 million to produce and won mostly rapturous reviews, validates that studio's bet on computerized visual effects; no live apes were used to make the movie. ''The Smurfs'' (Sony Pictures Entertainment) finished second, selling about $21 million in tickets for a two-week total of $76 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office data. ''Cowboys & Aliens'' (Universal Pictures/DreamWorks Studios) limped along third place, taking in an estimated $15.7 million in its second weekend for a total of $67 million.

MOSKIN--Marietta D.,83, beloved widow of A. Donald Moskin and mother of James and Linda, died peacefully on August 3, in her home in Manhattan. Born in Vienna, Austria, she came to the United States with her parents in 1946. She earned a BA from Barnard College and an MA in economics from the University of Wisconsin, and worked as an economist for General Motors. Later, she became a prolific children's book author with sixteen books plus short stories and translations. She was a Holocaust survivor, and her book, I Am Rosemarie, was based on her experiences and has been translated into German and Dutch. It is still used in schools in the United States and Europe. She was a member of the Unitarian Church of all Souls for fifty-five years, and served on its board and committees and as editor of its Quarterly Review. Survived by her children, James and Linda. She will be missed by all who knew and loved her. A gravesite funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, at 80th St. and Lexington Ave. on Tuesday, September 6, at 5:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in her memory to the Unitarian Universalist Service Committee, 689 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MA 02139 or to Barnard College, Box AS, 3009 Broadway, NY, 10027.

SAX--Dr. Sheldon D.,passed away quietly and with dignity on August 6, 2011. He was born in Altoona, PA. The son of the late Dr. Leon and Stella Sax. He was an Eagle Scout and served in the US Army. He earned his medical degree from the University of Pennsylvania, was board certified in general surgery and was a Fellow of the American College of Surgeons. He began his career as a Staff Surgeon at the Manhattan VA Hospital, where he later became the Assistant Chief of Surgery, before entering private practice. He was on the staffs of Booth Memorial Hospital NYHQ and Flushing Hospital and Medical Center. He was a Clinical Assistant Professor of Surgery at NYU School of Medicine. He later worked for the Department of Health for the State of New York. He was a member of the AMA, The Medical Society of the State of New York, The Medical Society of the County of Queens and The American College of Surgeons. He served as a delegate to MSSNY, was past president of the MSCQ, chairman of the Applicants Committee of the ACS for the Brooklyn/ Long Island chapter and past president of the Queensboro Surgical Society. He is survived by his devoted wife, Mary Lou, a daughter and son-in-law, Susan and Brian O'Grady of Savoy, MA, a son, David Sax of Flushing, NY, grandchildren Caitlin and Molly O'Grady and Alex and Megan Sax, a sister and brother-in-law, Laryn and Dr. Moses Finder of Pittsburgh, PA. He was predeceased by a daughter, Mary Beth. His former wife, Francis survives. His Funeral will take place on Monday, August 8, at 1:30pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY. Burial will follow in Flushing Cemetery.

A new Warner Brothers movie had stalled. The story lines for Conan comics had grown plain weird. Related toys and merchandise were a mishmash of designs.

Most media organizations hunger for recognition for their work. But on Friday, a different kind of publication received an award for its coverage: a medical journal. In June, the publication, The Spine Journal, devoted an entire issue to editorials and reports that challenged previous medical studies supporting the safety and effectiveness of Infuse, a bone-growth product sold by Medtronic. The product, a bioengineered material, is used mainly in spinal fusions.

Having successfully extended the Lollapalooza franchise to Chile this year, the founder of the influential alternative rock festival in Chicago has announced that he will start a second sister festival in Brazil next spring. The event, Lollapalooza Brazil, will be held April 7-8 at the Jockey Club de Sao Paulo, a large horse-racing track in one of Latin America's largest cities, festival officials said. Perry Farrell, who founded Lollapalooza 20 years ago, announced his intention to expand to Brazil as the United States festival got under way at Grant Park in Chicago. Mr. Farrell, who is also the flamboyant lead singer in Jane's Addiction, said that Brazilians ''have a very rich history of celebration'' and ''there's no telling what heights that party will reach.'' There may be no telling what height the profits will reach either. The strong response to the first Lollapalooza festival in Santiago, Chile, last April suggests there is an appetite in Latin America for the sort of large festivals that have become profitable over the last decade in the United States. Eminem did extremely well at the same racetrack in November, showing that an English-speaking star from the United States could sell out a 25,000-seat venue in Sao Paolo. The two-day Lollapalooza event will use more of the racetrack and is expected to draw about 60,000 people a day, festival promoters said.

MAYER--Harold C.,Jr. of Manhattan and Orleans, Massuchsetts died in Hyannis, MA on August 6, 2011 at age 87. Known to his friends as Billy, he was born in New York City on January 30, 1924. He was a graduate of Riverdale Country School and Yale University and was a proud supporter of each institution. Billy enjoyed a long career in finance. Throughout his life, he was a passionate fan of Yale Football. Billy was known for his extreme generosity, his quick wit and his joyous spirit. Billy will always be remembered as a devoted and loyal family man. He is survived by his adoring wife of 47 years Joan Arnstein Mayer, his beloved daughters Lucy Mayer Harrop (Mark D. Harrop), Kathy Mayer Braddock (Richard J. Zakin) and Elizabeth Mayer Rappaport (Howard S. Rappaport), his step-sons Stephen Wilder (Sue Wilder), Andrew Wilder (Debra Wilder) and Scott K. Wilder (Elizabeth Abbott), his eight grandchildren Philip Braddock, Charles Braddock, Hilary Rappaport, Mark Rappaport, Bonnie Wilder, Sam Wilder, Scott S. Wilder and Katherine Rose Wilder. In addition, he is survived by his loving sisters Nancy Mayer and Sue Ellen Rittmaster. Donations in memory of Billy may be made to Riverdale Country School, 5250 Fieldston Road, Bronx, NY 10471 and to Congregation Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, New York, NY. The family will be receiving visitors on Tuesday, August 9th between 5:00pm - 7:30 pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1067 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Services Wednesday August 11, 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street.

SINGER--Ernestine (Teeney), 88, died August 4th in Bal Harbour, FL after a brief battle with pancreatic cancer. Loving mother to Diana, sister to Louis (and Barbara) Singer and David (deceased) and Jeannie Singer, aunt and cousin to relatives nationwide. Active throughout her life in the estate jewelry industry as part of the Singer dynasty, she glittered socially and gemologically during her years in San Francisco at Antoinette's Estate Jewelry. Diminutive of stature but radiating a huge life force, she was clever, demanding, funny, fascinating - a memorable woman, truly a woman of valor. Services Tuesday August 9th at the Riverside, 76th and Amsterdam, 11am. Donations to pancreatic cancer research or JDF in lieu of flowers.

VOJTA--Susan H.,born August 15, 1935, died peacefully on August 6, 2011. She is survived by her sons Christopher and Timothy, grandchildren George II, Charles and Grace, and daughters-in-law Deneen and Amber. She was married to George J. Vojta for 53 years until his passing in December 2010. She received her Bachelor of Arts from Pembroke College in Brown University, graduating Phi Beta Kappa, and Masters in Arts from Yale University. She also conducted advanced study in history and Asian art history at Columbia University and Manhattan College. She was a passionate art historian, teacher and leader in the community. Her work experience included Chair of the History Departments at high schools in New Haven, CT, Manila and Singapore as well as Chairman of the Committee for the Tokyo Annual Print Show. Later, she served as a docent for Major Asian art exhibitions at The Asia Society in New York City, Member of the Art Advisory Committee for Brown University, Chairman and Member of the Board for the Maxwell Institute, Chairman of the Friends of the Sarah Lawrence Library. Previously, she had served as Chairman of the Bronxville High School Council, Member of the Board of Family and Community Services, the Bronxville Adult School, the Bronxville Parent Teacher Association and the Adoption Service. She was a beloved mother and grandmother. She will be remembered for her generous and compassionate nature, and the friendships she made and held dear across the entire globe. Memorial services will be held at the Reformed Church in Bronxville on August 13, 2011 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family is asking for donations to the Lawrence Hospital Cancer Center at 55 Palmer Avenue, Bronxville, NY.

Paul Lee, the president of entertainment for ABC, confirmed at a news conference on Sunday that this would be the last season of that network's longtime comedy-drama hit ''Desperate Housewives.'' Mr. Lee called it an ''iconic show'' that ''put the network on the map.'' He added that the network, in conjunction with the show's creator, Marc Cherry, had decided to make the call before the season started to make sure the show ''would have a victory lap.'' Mr. Lee cited the success that ABC had had in making an early announcement that it would end its other hit drama that started around the same time, ''Lost.'' Mr. Cherry said that, having worked in television for 23 years, he was aware of shows ''overstaying their welcome'' with viewers. ''I didn't want that to happen with 'Desperate Housewives,' he said. ''I wanted to go off while it was still a viable show and doing well and was still a force to be reckoned with.''

In Friday’s Fixes column I wrote about organizations that collect usable surplus equipment and supplies from hospitals in the United States and ship it to hospitals that need them in poor countries.   Readers were generally enthusiastic about the environmental and health benefits of this idea, but some offered important cautions. Homira from Wash, D.C. (15) wrote:  “There are a slew of complex issues that make donations of any kind aside from financial  really poor practice for trying to help developing countries. When it comes to medical equipment donations, the consumables necessary to operate many of these machines, such as x-ray film, reagents, etc,  are often not considered prior to the donations; nor is life-cycle costing and maintenance and operational costing and support figured in. Subsequently we see a lot of discarded medical equipment lying around clinics, hospitals and dump sites in low-income countries we work in.”

As our colleagues at Green report, tractor-trailer trucks will have to get 20 percent more miles per gallon by the 2018 model year, under the first-ever fuel economy rules for heavy vehicles, announced Tuesday by President Obama. Fuel economy standards for “light duty” cars and sport-utility vehicles have been in place since 1975. But the new heavy vehicle standards are more complex, tailored to cover everything from garbage trucks, which must get a 10 percent improvement, to pickups and vans that are too big to be covered by the existing rules, which must now make a 15 percent improvement. One of Issawi’s Laws, which I can’t seem to find online, explained the laws of progress or lack thereof. First, the total amount of good and evil in any system remains constant. Second, most things get steadily worse. In particular, people get worse as they grow older, because they become more like themselves. The second proposition does not contradict the first, because some things get much better.

This is not your father’s Hunan restaurant. Uncle Zhou (pronounced Uncle Joe) features the cuisine of Henan, breadbasket of China, especially the province’s well-known wheat noodles. Knife-shaved noodles are brusquely cut from a lump of dough, boiled until wonderfully chewy, and deposited in cool bowls dressed with tomato and egg. Thin, hand-pulled noodles swirl at the bottom of spicy soups; their ribbonlike cousins are great for swabbing the plate. Other are stretched to the fineness of angel hair, baked, then deposited as a crisp thatch atop a whole fish, swimming in a pool of sweet-and-sour sauce. Noodles and fish soak up the sauce; you and your friends soak up the lively atmosphere.

The whitish outline of two boxy skyscrapers rose from the spot where, until Sept. 11, 2001, the World Trade Center stood. An article on Thursday about Italy's severe economic problems paraphrased incorrectly from comments that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi made to Parliament, in which he defended his government's response and rebutted calls for his resignation. Mr. Berlusconi said he was confident measures already contained in a $70 billion austerity package passed by Parliament in July were sufficient to balance Italy's budget by 2014. He did not call for new measures to achieve that goal.

The trader sat quietly behind a wall of eight monitors in a Midtown Manhattan trading room, enshrined in a cockpit of light, as he struggled to complete a trade. His eyes darted from screen to screen, checking prices as he whispered expletives. Volatility engulfed the markets on Monday as investors digested the downgrade of the United States credit rating.

WASHINGTON -- If ever there was a time for contrition in this town, it might be after the events of the last few days: a deeply embarrassing downgrading of the nation's credit rating, poll numbers showing public support for Congress at record lows, topped on Monday with a bracing plunge in the stock market. But it was not to be. Even as the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.6 percent on the heels of a 5.75 percent drop last week, Congressional Republicans and Democrats retreated to their now-familiar positions, each accusing the other side of sparking the economic turmoil as President Obama continued to preach compromise. Even as he tried to calm an increasingly nervous country, there were few reassurances that any consensus on debt-reduction or remedies to spur the stalling economy were on the way.

Mark O. Hatfield, a liberal Republican who challenged his party's positions on the Vietnam War and on a balanced-budget amendment to the Constitution during his 30 years as a senator from Oregon, died on Sunday in Portland, Ore. He was 89. His death was confirmed by Gerry Frank, a longtime aide.

When all was said and done at the close of ''Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty'' on Sunday night, the final attendance count reached 661,509 visitors since the show opened on May 4, making it the eighth biggest show on record at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. (Of course, some of us saw it five or six times, so that helped.) The exhibition broke the attendance record for the Met's Costume Institute a week ago, surpassing the 2008 show ''Superheroes: Fashion and Fantasy,'' which had 576,000. Nearly 80,000 people saw the McQueen show during its final week, as the museum stayed open until midnight for its final two nights.

CAREY--Hugh L. St. John's School of Law mourns the passing of our alumnus, friend, and benefactor Governor Hugh L. Carey '42C, '51L, '67HON. Governor Carey was a dedicated public servant, a tireless advocate for New Yorkers, and a man of deep personal integrity. He was a loyal son of St. John's University and a proud graduate of the School of Law. Throughout his career, he showed a gift for bringing people together to solve difficult problems and to resolve intractable conflicts. At St. John's School of Law, Governor Carey's legacy lives on through "The Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution". Established in 2009 through the generosity of Governor Carey, the Carey Center promotes the value and practice of conflict resolution in the United States and around the world. The Center's programs which train law students, lawyers, and judges in dispute resolution principles will continue to be a fitting tribute to this great lawyer, great problem solver, and great man. The entire School of Law community extends it prayers and deepest sympathy to the Carey family. Michael A. Simons, Dean and John V. Brennan, Professor of Law and Ethics Paul F. Kirgis, Faculty Chair, Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution Elayne E. Greenberg, Director, Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution

Picture a Monday in August: A bad day on Wall Street. Spain in the headlines again. More hot, dry weather in this country. The mayor was complaining that New York was not getting the federal money it should. It was a Monday 75 years ago, the day on which Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia opened the city pool in Red Hook, Brooklyn, the 11th Depression-era pool built by the parks department with money from the federal Works Progress Administration.

VOJTA--Susan H.,born August 15, 1935, died peacefully on August 6, 2011. She is survived by her sons Christopher and Timothy, grandchildren George II, Charles and Grace, and daughters-in-law Deneen and Amber. She was married to George J. Vojta for 53 years until his passing in December 2010. She received her Bachelor of Arts from Pembroke College in Brown University, graduating Phi Beta Kappa, and Masters in Arts from Yale University. She also conducted advanced study in history and Asian art history at Columbia University and Manhattan College. She was a passionate art historian, teacher and leader in the community. Her work experience included Chair of the History Departments at high schools in New Haven, CT, Manila and Singapore as well as Chairman of the Committee for the Tokyo Annual Print Show. Later, she served as a docent for Major Asian art exhibitions at The Asia Society in New York City, Member of the Art Advisory Committee for Brown University, Chairman and Member of the Board for the Maxwell Institute, Chairman of the Friends of the Sarah Lawrence Library. Previously, she had served as Chairman of the Bronxville High School Council, Member of the Board of Family and Community Services, the Bronxville Adult School, the Bronxville Parent Teacher Association and the Adoption Service. She was a beloved mother and grandmother. She will be remembered for her generous and compassionate nature, and the friendships she made and held dear across the entire globe. Memorial services will be held at the Reformed Church in Bronxville on August 13, 2011 at 11am. In lieu of flowers, the family is asking for donations to the Lawrence Hospital Cancer Center at 55 Palmer Avenue, Bronxville, NY.

An article on Sunday about the marketing opportunities for the swimmer Ryan Lochte after he won five gold medals at the world championships last month misstated, in some editions, the given name of the husband of Erika Wright, one of Lochte's managers. He is Johnny Wright, not Tony. The article also misstated, in some editions, part of the name of the swimming and diving facility at Stanford University, where Lochte competed in the United States championships last week. It is the Avery Aquatic Center, not the Avery Athletic Center.

Doctoroff, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

Dr. Bernadine P. Healy, the first woman to lead the National Institutes of Health and the first physician to lead the American Red Cross until she was forced out in a storm of criticism over flawed responses to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, died on Saturday at her home in Gates Mills, Ohio. She was 67. The cause was recurring brain cancer, which she had battled for 13 years, her husband, Dr. Floyd D. Loop, said.

COOPER--Bernard J.,(84) of New York City and Brewster, MA, passed away August 7th at his summer home on Cape Cod surrounded by his loving family. The cause of death was congestive heart failure. Mr. Cooper was a lifelong resident of Manhattan, a graduate of the prestigious Stuyvesant High School and City College of New York. He served in the US Navy during WWII in both the Atlantic and Pacific theatres. He was founder and CEO of Cove, Cooper Lewis, Inc, a New York City Advertising Agency. A runner since high school Bernie ran and completed 13 marathons starting at age 52. He was a member of the Board of Directors of the New York Road Runners, sponsor of the New York City marathon, serving as its Chairman for a number of years. He was instrumental in the formation and development of the New York Road Runners Foundation, which promotes running for fitness for New York City youth. His unique ability to interact with people of all walks of life, his enthusiasm for living, quick wit and genuine interest in each person made him a true friend to so many. Mr. Cooper is survived by his wife of 44 years, Susan Macycove Cooper, his daughter Beth Sherman (Thomas), his son Alan Cooper (Karen) two granddaughters, Jodi Pike (Brett Rosenau), Rena Kramer (Josh), great-granddaughter Bailey, sister Selma Cooper, sister and brother-in-law Alice and Joe Perdue, sister and brother-in-law Charlotte and Leonard Wasserman, many devoted nephews, nieces and friends. His funeral service will be held at 11:00 am on Wednesday, August 10, 2011 at the Doane, Beal & Ames Funeral Home, 729 Rt. 134, S. Dennis, MA, 02660. Burial will follow in Brewster Memorial Cemetery, Brewster. Donations in his memory may be made to the Brewster Ladies Library, the New York Road Runners Foundation, or to a charity of your choice. For directions and on-line guestbook please visit: www.doanebealames.com.

GRUENSTEIN--Elaine, died August 7, 2011 at the age of 79. Cherished wife of the late Walter. Beloved mother of Steven (Lynn), David (Nicole) and Benjamin (Rebecca). GLAZER--Sidney, 93, of Scarsdale, NY, on August 6, loving husband of Jean for almost 70 years; father of Diane (Arthur) Jacobs, Libbi (Alfred) Locascio; grand- father of Jonathan, Meredith (Sal), Joshua and Matthew; great-grandfather of Dylan, Hudson, Harrison, Piper and Savannah. WWII US Navy veteran and founding partner of Toscany Imports Ltd.

CAREY--Hugh L. The Mutual of America Foundation and its Board of Directors offer its deep condolences on the passing of Hugh L. Carey, New York State's 51st Governor. Governor Carey will be long remembered for his deep concern for the welfare of others and his commitment to helping strengthen communities. From 1996 until this year, he served with distinction on the Selection Committee for the Mutual of America Foundation. Governor Carey's wisdom and compassion played a significant role in the selection of award winners for the prestigious Community Partnership Award - which recognizes the important contributions that nonprofit organizations make to the least advantaged members of their communities. Governor Carey was a true leader and a good friend to the Foundation, as well as to the countless organizations and individuals he helped support. Thomas Gilliam Chairman and CEO Theodore Herman Vice Chairman Mutual of America Foundation

An article on Wednesday about an effort to remove the actress Faye Dunaway from a rent-stabilized apartment in Manhattan misstated the name of an architecture firm that designed an apartment for Ms. Dunaway in the Eldorado in the 1960s. At the time, the firm was Gwathmey, Henderson & Siegel -- not Gwathmey Siegel & Associates, its current name.

City students posted modest gains on elementary and middle school statewide tests this year, showing more improvement than students in the state as a whole and in New York State's other large cities, officials said Monday. But test scores in the city and the state remained far below where they were two years ago, when high achievement levels made it seem that an education miracle might be at work. State officials toughened scoring last year after determining that the tests had become too easy to pass.
