The Teen Choice Awards on Fox on Sunday night managed to ensnare its elusive target demographic thanks to squeal-inducing appearances by Taylor Swift, Robert Pattinson and Justin Bieber. The ceremony was the highest rated telecast of the summer for Fox among teenagers. Adults didn't quite follow suit, flocking to somewhat older fare on CBS. ''60 Minutes'' garnered 8.7 million total viewers and ''Big Brother'' had 7.8 million, giving the station another Sunday win in total viewers and in the 18- to 49-year-old segment. On cable, the season finale of the post-apocalyptic drama ''Falling Skies'' on TNT finished with its best numbers since the series premiere on June 19. The show, which was picked up for a second season last month and will return next summer, had 5.6 million total viewers on Sunday.

VARIS--Dr. Agnes. The Hampshire House Board of Directors and Management acknowledge with sorrow the passing our beloved neighbor and resident, Dr. Agnes Varis on July 29, 2011. Dr. Varis served on our Board of Directors for many years, where her business experience and high standards were a great asset. Her philanthropic contributions made a significant impact on the life of New York City. Her courage during her illness was an inspiration to all. She will be missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her family, friends and colleagues.

The attribution for the Quotation of the Day on Saturday, taken from a front-page article about the conviction of five defendants in the shooting of six unarmed civilians after Hurricane Katrina, referred incorrectly to those defendants. As the article correctly noted, the five included ''current and former'' New Orleans police officers -- not ''one former and five current'' officers. (Of the five convicted, two had already left the force; three are on leave without pay, and are facing termination proceedings.)

Kanye West, the multiplatinum-selling rapper, took his notorious self-pity and feelings of persecution to a new level during an onstage rant in England when he said he sometimes feels as hated as Adolf Hitler. ''I walk through the hotel and I walk down the street, and people look at me like I'm (expletive) insane, like I'm Hitler,'' the 34-year-old rapper said at the Big Chill Festival on Saturday night. ''One day the light will shine through and one day people will understand everything I ever did.''

An article last Tuesday about the five American hockey players who will be inducted into the United States Hockey Hall of Fame erroneously attributed a distinction to one of them, Gary Suter. In 1986, as a defenseman for the Calgary Flames, he became the third American -- not the first -- to win the Calder Trophy as the National Hockey League's top rookie. (Frank Brimsek of the Boston Bruins was the first, in 1939.)

The tumult in the stock market has been a boon for The Brokers With Hands on Their Faces Blog. With traders around the world gesticulating in agony as the financial indexes swoon, a Web site is documenting the suffering.

An article on July 25 about cloud computing in Europe misidentified the city that is home to the headquarters of Capgemini, a company that advises businesses on technology matters. It is based in Paris, not London. The article also misstated the job title of Karl Deacon, a Capgemini executive who commented on European impediments to cloud computing. He is chief technology officer for infrastructure services, not for global services.

MEIER--Paul, died peacefully at home on August 7, age 87. Married 63 years to Louise Goldstone Meier, father of Diane (Warren), Karen (Steve), Joan (Jerry); beloved grandfather of Leo, Clara, Anna, Peter, Penina, and cherished uncle. Dear colleague, mentor and friend to many. Visionary biostatistician and Department Chair, University of Chicago and Columbia University. Lover of ideas, music, sailing, and his fellow humans. Memorial service in the fall. Contributions may be sent to VNS Hospice of New York or the Meier Statistics Fellowship, University of Chicago.

FRIEDMANN--A. Edward, 89, devoted husband of Joan, loving father of Mark, Susan and Peter, grandfather of Lucy, Evan and Melanie, and brother of Rose Bresloff died August 8th after a long illness. His strength and courage will live with us forever. Private burial, sitting Shiva 5-8pm at home.

A theater entry in the Listings pages on Friday about the Royal Shakespeare Company's production of ''The Winter's Tale,'' which runs through Sunday at Park Avenue Armory as part of Lincoln Center Festival, misstated the telephone number for tickets. It is (212) 721-6500.

Signaling that it wants to compete directly with Fox News, MSNBC and CNN, Current TV on Monday hired a prominent CNN executive, David Bohrman, and put him in charge of all programming and production. The announcement, effective immediately, came six weeks after the low-rated channel started to rebuild its schedule around Keith Olbermann, who wants to unseat his former employer, MSNBC, as the leading progressive channel on cable.

9 P.M. (TLC) CRAZY ABOUT PIPPA Blame that knockout dress by Sarah Burton for Alexander McQueen. On April 29 viewers might have been forgiven for turning their attention from Kate Middleton as she walked down the aisle of Westminster Abbey toward Prince William to focus instead on the bridesmaid gliding serenely in her wake: her younger sister, Pippa, above. She has since been crowned Britain's most eligible bachelorette, her every move and fashion choice carefully chronicled. This program examines the making of a media phenomenon. An encore presentation of ''Wild About Prince Harry,'' about the popularity of William's younger brother, leads at 8. ''William & Kate: Royal Baby Watch'' follows at 10. 3 P.M. (HBO) ELIZABETH: THE GOLDEN AGE (2007) Cate Blanchett, above, retakes the throne as the Virgin Queen, now 52 and intent on bringing the Spanish Empire to its knees, in Shekhar Kapur's sequel to his more restrained 1998 period drama, ''Elizabeth.'' Abbie Cornish plays Bess Throckmorton, the queen's female pet, and Clive Owen is Walter Raleigh, ''the queen's favorite smoldering slab of man meat,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times, calling the film ''intentionally playful and an inadvertent giggle, an overripe melodrama that's by turns a bodice-ripper, a cloak-and-dagger thriller and a serious-minded historical drama with dubious contemporary overtones.''

INSIDER TRADING WEEK The first week of August appeared to be ''insider trading week,'' as the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department filed three prominent securities fraud cases. The S.E.C. filed civil complaints against William A. Marovitz, the husband of Playboy Enterprises' former chief executive, Christie Hefner, and against a former Major League Baseball player, Douglas V. DeCinces, above. The United States attorney's office in Manhattan filed criminal charges against H. Clayton Peterson, a former director of Mariner Energy, along with his son Drew, over trading in Mariner stock. The cases are interesting because they provide some clues about why the government chooses between pursuing only civil charges or prosecuting defendants criminally as well. PETER J. HENNING

MAYER--Harold C.,Jr. of Manhattan and Orleans, Massuchsetts died in Hyannis, MA on August 6, 2011 at age 87. Known to his friends as Billy, he was born in New York City on January 30, 1924. He was a graduate of Riverdale Country School and Yale University and was a proud supporter of each institution. Billy enjoyed a long career in finance. Throughout his life, he was a passionate fan of Yale Football. Billy was known for his extreme generosity, his quick wit and his joyous spirit. Billy will always be remembered as a devoted and loyal family man. He is survived by his adoring wife of 47 years Joan Arnstein Mayer, his beloved daughters Lucy Mayer Harrop (Mark D. Harrop), Kathy Mayer Braddock (Richard J. Zakin) and Elizabeth Mayer Rappaport (Howard S. Rappaport), his step-sons Stephen Wilder (Sue Wilder), Andrew Wilder (Debra Wilder) and Scott K. Wilder (Elizabeth Abbott), his eight grandchildren Philip Braddock, Charles Braddock, Hilary Rappaport, Mark Rappaport, Bonnie Wilder, Sam Wilder, Scott S. Wilder and Katherine Rose Wilder. In addition, he is survived by his loving sisters Nancy Mayer and Sue Ellen Rittmaster. Donations in memory of Billy may be made to Riverdale Country School, 5250 Fieldston Road, Bronx, NY 10471 and to Congregation Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, New York, NY. The family will be receiving visitors on Tuesday, August 9th between 5:00pm - 7:30 pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1067 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Services Wednesday August 10, 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street.

Michael Cerveris, the Tony Award-winning actor (''Assassins''), will star as Juan Peron in ''Evita,'' a revival of that Tim Rice and Andrew Lloyd Webber musical opening on Broadway in the spring of 2012, the show's producers said on Monday. Mr. Cerveris joins a cast that includes the singer Ricky Martin as Che and the Olivier Award winner Elena Roger in her Broadway debut as Eva. Mr. Cerveris made his Broadway debut in 1993 as the title character in ''The Who's Tommy,'' and his credits include playing John Wilkes Booth in ''Assassins'' and the title character in the 2005 revival ''Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.'' The ''Evita'' at the Marquis Theater is the first new Broadway production of the musical since its Broadway debut in 1979. That version, which won seven Tony Awards, including Best Musical, starred Patti LuPone as Eva Peron, the first lady of Argentina from 1946 until her death in 1952. The score of the new ''Evita'' will include the hits ''Don't Cry for Me Argentina'' as well as ''You Must Love Me,'' which was part of the 1996 film version of the musical starring Madonna as Eva, a former child of the slums who became a champion of the poor and internationally known for her quest for power. That song will be new to the Broadway revival.

Monday's expedition was in Rockaway Inlet, off South Brooklyn, and into Jamaica Bay in Queens.

CAREY--Hugh L. Mutual of America and its Board of Directors, together with its officers and employees, mourn the passing of Hugh L. Carey, New York State's 51st Governor. Governor Carey will best be remembered for providing the strong leadership that helped pull New York City and State out of financial crisis during his term of office from 1975 to 1982. Mutual of America will fondly remember Governor Carey for his generous contributions to our Company, through which he provided vital legal, regulatory and administrative expertise while serving as a consultant from 1996 to 2007. In addition, he also served with distinction for 16 years on the Selection Committee of the Mutual of America Foundation Board. Hugh Carey was a bold and wise leader, a compassionate man and a cherished friend. He will be greatly missed. William J. Flynn Chairman Emeritus Thomas J. Moran Chairman, President and CEO Mutual of America Life Insurance Company

CAREY--Hugh L. The Officers, Governors and Members of the Friars Club deeply mourn the loss of their esteemed member, Hugh L. Carey. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his family.

Andy Cohen, the Bravo channel executive who doubles as a talk-show host for the network, will soon double - or is that triple? - as an author. Henry Holt and Company said on Monday that it would publish Mr. Cohen's first book, a memoir about growing up with a love of pop culture and landing a job in the television business, which enabled him to meet many of the stars he admired. The as-yet untitled book will also detail how Mr. Cohen, who is gay, suppressed his sexuality as a boy. It is to be published next summer. ''I love to write, and I'm thrilled that I get to share stories of my improbable intersections with pop culture that have enriched my life,'' Mr. Cohen said in a statement.

JOYCE--Francis (Frank) John, of Ann Arbor, Michigan, formerly of Morris Plains, New Jersey, died at St. Joseph Mercy Hospital, Ann Arbor, MI on August 2, 2011. He was 89 years old. Frank was born on June 1, 1922 and raised on a dairy farm in Montgomery, New York. He graduated from Webb Institute in February 1944. He was commissioned as Ensign USNR and coordinated the hull design of the LSM-60 vessel of the Cross Roads project. In 1947, he began his 43 year career with D.K. Ludwig in design, construction, and operation of oil tankers, iron ore and bulk carriers, some of the world's largest in their class at the time. He initiated and coordinated the marine design and overall construction and start-up of a 750 ton-per-day pulp mill constructed in Japan and towed to the Jari River in Brazil. He was Executive Vice President of both National Bulk Carriers and Universe Tankships and President of Harsimus Cove Real Estate. He retired in 1990. In 1978, he received the William Selkirk Owen Award from the Webb Institute in recognition of outstanding achievement and service to the profession and to his alma mater and received an honorary doctorate from the Webb Institute in 1997. He was an active member for many years in the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers (SNAME) and the American Bureau of Shipping (ABS). He is predeceased by his wife of 56 years, Mary Patricia (Pat) Hamill Joyce; brothers John, Richard, Thomas, William, and sister Alice. He is survived by his three children M. Tara Joyce of Oak Park, Illinois; Frank Joyce, Jr. (Katy Van Dusen) of Monteverde, Costa Rica; Patricia Joyce (Steven J. Slack) of Ann Arbor, MI; and grandchildren Helen, Francis, Richard, Connor, and Devin. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends for his kind and gentle manner, his humility, his genuine interest in and compassion for others, his great intellect and his wit. A funeral mass will be held at St. Mary's Abbey in Morristown, New Jersey at a later date. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to Webb Institute in Glen Cove, New York or Ludwig Institute for Cancer Research (LICR) in New York, New York.

HEALY--Bernadine. Hunter College High School Alumnae/i Association is deeply saddened by the passing of one of its brightest stars, Dr. Bernadine Healy. Graduating at the top of her class in 1962, Dr. Healy went on to an exceptional career in medicine and public health. In light of her significant achievements, Dr. Healy was awarded Hunter College High School's highest honor, being named a Distinguished Alumna in 1991. She was honored again in 2009 by the HCHSAA at its Annual Spring Gala. Our deepest condolences to her family.

YOKEN--Richard Lewis, 91, beloved husband of Joan Frye Yoken, adored father of Tony, Hollyce and David, wonderful grandfather to Max, Lia, Anna and Hannah, brother to Connie Martinson. Service private. Rutgers, Red Sox, and the U.S. Navy.

CAREY--Hugh. The Board of Directors and Staff of AHRC New York City mourn the passing of Honorable Hugh L. Carey. As Governor of New York State in 1975 one of his first decisions was to stop the defending of the indefensible. He signed the Willowbrook Consent Judgment. This conscience-driven decision was a wonderful beginning. Governor Carey also placed the resources of New York State behind services for people with developmental disabilities, starting the movement that would change the world for them. His tireless efforts and the role he played in our history will be remembered for many years to come.

The Yankees may be one game behind the Boston Red Sox in the American League East standings, but the New York ball club has at least one thing to celebrate: a postage stamp. Next summer, Joe DiMaggio will appear - for the first time - on a United States Postal Service-issued stamp as part of the 2012 Major League Baseball All-Star stamp series. The collection, announced on Monday, will feature three other Hall of Fame baseball players, though only Mr. DiMaggio's name has been released.

HILLYER--Kenneth S. (March 22, 1928 - August 6, 2011), of Viera, Florida and formerly of Garden City, NY and Manhattan, has died of cancer. He is survived by companion Mary Lane Johnson, former wife Joyce, son Bruce (m. Bethany Robinson), daughters Holly and Hope and granddaughter Alexandra. He was predeceased by brother Charles E. and sister Eleanor M. Ken was educated at Berkeley Institute and Poly Prep in Brooklyn, and received a Bachelor's degree from Colgate University in 1948. He took a year of post-graduate study at Colgate, and re-affiliated himself with the class of '49. His career in the insurance industry in New York started at Home Life Insurance Co. in July 1949. He retired as Vice President of Sedgwick James in 1983. Ken lived a life of generosity and service. He served in the US Army from 1950 to 1953, achieving the rank of 1st Lieutenant. He served on the Garden City School Board from 1970-73 (President 71-73). He served Colgate University as class scribe, Reunion Chairman, member of the Alumni Council, member in perpetuity of the President's Club, and member and president of the Planned Giving Committee. His service to Colgate was honored by the award of the Maroon Citation in 1974 and the Distinguished Service Award in 1989. At Colgate he was an officer of Alpha Tau Omega, where he was nicknamed "The Deacon" for his honesty and good character. He also was a member of the Marching and Chowder Club, the Masque and Triangle, and the Lecture Series. In New York, his social memberships included the Union League Club, The Cherry Valley Country Club, and the Garden City Casino. An energetic traveler through Europe, he quaffed art, theater, and history, and made friends everywhere. "He was truly a gentleman--and he played tennis too." A memorial service will be held 4pm Friday, August 12, St. Mark's Episcopal Church, 4 Church St., Cocoa Village, FL, 32922. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Colgate University Class of 1949 Endowment Fund would be appreciated.

For one boisterous decade in the 1960s, the three-story brick house in Park Slope, Brooklyn, on the corner of Second Street and Prospect Park West, was the vibrant epicenter of politics and family life for Hugh L. Carey. His 14 children watched Kennedys go in and out of the gold-carpeted parlor, played table tennis and pool in the basement, slept on the third floor and played sports with their father in Prospect Park. The formal living room hosted christenings and wakes, campaign events and kitchen-cabinet meetings.

I’ve always liked bridges and been a bit phobic about tunnels, particularly those that run under water. So when I read late last year that the Queensboro Bridge was being named after New York’s former mayor, Edward I. Koch, and the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel for Hugh L. Carey, I felt that the former governor was being cheated. After all, the Tappan Zee Bridge, still majestic in its sweep across the Hudson even in its current dilapidated state, was named after Malcolm Wilson, the man Carey defeated for governor in 1974. And Robert F. Kennedy got the Triborough Bridge.

This week’s episode of the Bits: Tech Talk podcast looks at a new smartphone app created by the Federal Bureau of Investigation can help panicky parents get personal details to the authorities. As an F.B.I. spokesman, Paul Bresson, explains on this week’s show, the agency’s very first iPhone app is called Child ID. The free app lets parents compile a miniature mobile database of photos and written descriptions of a child right on the phone — where the information can be quickly pulled up and shared with police should that child ever go missing.

Sleep-disordered breathing, or sleep apnea, is a common condition characterized by repeated awakenings and pauses in breathing during the night. People with the disorder often snore and gasp during sleep, and it has been associated with hypertension, cardiovascular disease and diabetes. Now a new study suggests it may also be associated with mental decline and dementia.

Ignatius G. Rigor, a ocean, ice and climate researcher at the University of Washington, has long been on my go-to list when grappling with studies of sea ice and climate. I sent him my post on new insights about Arctic ice retreats in the last big northern warm period — a 2,500-year “optimum,” ending around 6,000 years ago, when the region was several degrees warmer on average than today. He and I exchanged some thoughts about his scientific and personal reactions to the study and broader trends and I invited him to consolidate them in a “Your Dot” contribution:

With K-pop groups like the Wonder Girls on the ascent - and sitting front row at the Chloé show in Shanghai - it's clear that Korean pop is having a moment. But is there a Korean underground? According to Sean Patrick Maylone, the answer is yes. His Seoul-based booking and promotion agency, SuperColorSuper, has helped to create a South Korean tour circuit for indie bands like Caribou, Das Racist and CocoRosie, blazing a trail not just to Seoul, but also to Busan and Daegu, places the 30-year-old native Californian knew nothing about when he arrived in Korea to teach English four years ago. There’s a spanking new version of “Porgy and Bess” on the way, one that seeks to transform the classic 1935 opera into a commercial Broadway musical. To that end, the director Diane Paulus and the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks have added new scenes, punched up some dialogue, invented biographical details and — most radically — added a more upbeat ending. Such tinkering with the renowned  Gershwin work was bound to draw fire from some quarters, and indeed it has, following the publication of an Arts & Leisure article by Patrick Healy about the production, which stars Audra McDonald and Norm Lewis. It begins performances at the American Repertory Theater next Wednesday in Cambridge, Mass., with plans to transfer to Broadway next winter.

I love fishing, which was one of the ways, growing up in Rhode Island, that I developed my broader passion for the wider living world outside of the human-built one. As a kid paddling around in a dinghy, I could “feel” the otherwise invisible seabed by bouncing my weighted hand line off the bottom. While waiting for a bite fishing for mackerel from a floating dock, I’d stick my head down close to the water and peer at the fascinating assemblage of small shrimp, sea squirts and other creatures growing on the immersed wood and floats.

In indie rock, it’s not so much who you know as who knows you. And all the right people have come to know First Aid Kit, a Swedish folk duo made up of the sisters Johanna (left) and Klara Söderberg. They were discovered by Karin Dreijer Andersson (one half of the Swedish sibling duo the Knife), who released their first EP. They met Conor Oberst on the Monsters of Folk tour in Sweden; he introduced them to the producer of their next album. When First Aid Kit passed through Nashville on their American tour, Jack White invited them to record for his label. Part of a proud folk tradition — they “enjoy singing older songs,” Johanna says — they chose to rework Buffy Sainte-Marie’s “Universal Soldier,” a protest song from the ’60s, whose message “is unfortunately still very relevant today.”

For years the domed structure between the Aya Sofia (Hagia Sophia) and the Blue Mosque was used as a state-run carpet shop. Kilims and halis were strewn every which way across marble navel stones under huge domes that let shafts of light illuminate the structure built in 1556 by the famed architect Sinan to house the baths of Roxelana, known locally as Hurrem. (Hurrem was the slave who became the powerful wife of Sultan Suleiman the Magnificent.) Now, thanks to a $10 million restoration, the marble-clad space is once again a Turkish bath house, with separate facilities for men and women.

If you want a young person to focus intently in school and perform well on tests, should you first send him or her to gym class? That question, which has particular relevance for school districts weighing whether to reduce or ax their physical education programs to save money, motivated a number of stimulating new examinations into the interplay of activity and attention. Some of the experiments studied children; others looked at laboratory rats bred to have an animal version of attention deficit disorder. For both groups, exercise significantly affected their ability to concentrate, although some activities seemed to be better than others at sharpening attention.

Rosemary Harris (''The Royal Family''), Carla Gugino (''Desire Under the Elms'') and Jim Dale (''Threepenny Opera'') will star in the Roundabout Theater Company's production of Athol Fugard's play ''The Road to Mecca,'' the theater announced Tuesday. Gordon Edelstein is directing the production, which will begin previews on Dec. 16 and open on Jan. 17, 2012, on Broadway at the American Airlines Theater. Set in Mr. Fugard's native South Africa, ''The Road to Mecca'' is about an elderly widow named Miss Helen (Ms. Harris) who has spent years turning her home in an isolated village into a work of art. Marius Byleveld, a local pastor (Mr. Dale), wants her to move to an nursing home. But Elsa, a young Cape Town schoolteacher (Ms. Gugino) who has become a friend to Miss Helen, wants her to live her remaining years at home.
CAREY--Hugh. Harris Beach extends its condolences to our colleague, Michael Carey, and the Carey family, on the passing of Governor Hugh L. Carey.
An article on Tuesday about Hugh L. Carey's life in Brooklyn before he became governor referred incorrectly to the street on which his childhood home is located. It is on Rutland Road, not Avenue.

As mayor, Edward I. Koch would often deflect insults by insisting that he was not, among other things, a ''wacko,'' a ''dope'' or a ''punching bag.'' But he now admits that the taunt that stung most was inflicted well before he acquired a politician's thick skin. As a child, he hated being called ''fatso.'' Worse, still, it was true.
THE LONG NIGHT William L. Shirer and 'The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich'

''The Guys,'' one of the first dramatic responses to 9/11, will return for a series of performances to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the terrorist attacks. Sigourney Weaver and Tom Wopat will star in the play, by Anne Nelson, which the Flea Theater will bring back to Lower Manhattan from Sept. 6 to 9. Partly based on Ms. Nelson's own experiences, ''The Guys'' is structured as a dialogue between a New York fire captain (Mr. Wopat) and the editor (Ms. Weaver) helping him to compose eulogies for the men he lost on 9/11. The anniversary performances will be at Goldman Sachs headquarters on West Street for invited guests, and, for fire department families and the public, at the Museum of Jewish Heritage.

Marshall Grant, a bass player who, as an original member of Johnny Cash's band, the Tennessee Two, helped create the group's pulsing ''boom-chicka-boom'' sound, died on Sunday in Jonesboro, Ark. He was 83. His death was confirmed by the Memorial Park Funeral Home and Cemetery in Memphis. Mr. Grant, who lived in Hernando, Miss., was in Jonesboro for the Johnny Cash Festival, an event to raise money to restore Cash's childhood home in Dyess, Ark.

WEISS--Lynne McLean, August 5th, 2011 at her home in Fleetwood, NY. Born February 19, 1928 in Baldwin, NY to Thomas and Madeline McLean, Lynne resided in Brooklyn, NY. She married Paul E. Weiss on April 26, 1958 and they settled in Bronxville, NY. He preceded her in death on June 5, 2011. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Kurt and (Serena) Weiss of New York, NY; her daughter, Karen Weiss of Greenwich, CT; and her German Shepherd, Madge. Her sister, Elaine Fannon, preceded her in death. Lynne graduated from Fordham University in 1950. She was a realtor, an active member of St. Joseph's Church in Bronxville and a Bridge Life Master. Lynne was blessed by an incredible group of neighborhood and bridge friends led by Dr. and Mrs. Robert Gomprecht and the extended Gomprecht family. Private services were held August, 8th. In lieu of gifts, Lynne would want you to take a moment and make a positive difference in someone's life today, as many have done for her in her life.

SACERDOTE--Peter. We mourn the loss of Peter Sacerdote, our exemplary colleague, friend, business and community leader. His unfailing caring and support for HBS and infectious humor will long be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved family. Howard Morgan, Chairman Harvard Business School Club of New York
GREENBERG--Aaron M.,on August 8, 2011. Beloved husband of Rita. Devoted father of Louis Greenberg and Ellen Hodor. Cherished grandfather of Rick, Lisa, Joanna and six great-grandchildren.

An article on Tuesday about the positions of President Obama and Congressional leaders on the recent financial turmoil misstated the amount of mandatory, across-the-board spending cuts called for in the new compromise budget law if Congress does not enact another round of deficit reduction by the end of the year. The automatic cuts, in defense and domestic discretionary programs, could be up to $1.2 trillion, not $1.5 trillion. And a picture caption with the article misidentified, in some copies, the White House room in which President Obama delivered his first comments on the economy after a downgrade of the nation's credit rating. It was the State Dining Room, not the East Room.

Kelli O'Hara, best known for sunny roles in musicals like ''South Pacific'' and ''The Pajama Game,'' is taking on Shakespeare -- and a not-so-sunny role at that. Ms. O'Hara, a three-time Tony nominee, will play the betraying daughter Regan in a new production of ''King Lear'' at the Public Theater, with Sam Waterston (''Law and Order'') in the title role. According to a spokesman for the Public, this will be Ms. O'Hara's first time performing Shakespeare professionally. Among those also added to the cast, the Public announced on Tuesday, are the Tony nominee Arian Moayed (''Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo'') as Edgar; Seth Gilliam as Edmund; and Richard Topol as Albany.

A picture caption on Tuesday with the Frequent Flier column, about the architect Daniel Libeskind, described incorrectly the 2003 World Trade Center design competition that he won. The competition was for master planner, not master architect.

ALTFEDER--Susan. It is with profound sorrow that the Officers, Board of Governors, members and staff of Fresh Meadow Country Club mourn the loss of our member, Susan Altfeder. The Altfeder's have been members for 53 years. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her husband, Ira Altfeder, her daughters, Nancy Altfeder and Judith Fineman (Stanley), her grandchildren and great grandchildren. Roger Blumencranz, President Michael Lamoretti, Secretary

What is that saying about truth being stranger than fiction? An actress who played a killer for a Baltimore drug gang in the HBO series ''The Wire'' pleaded guilty Monday to conspiring to distribute heroin. She was caught on a wiretap in a joint federal-state investigation of a suspected drug gang, The Associated Press reported. Felicia Pearson, 31, pleaded guilty to conspiracy to distribute heroin, a day before her trial was scheduled to begin. Judge Lawrence Fletcher-Hill accepted the plea, suspending a seven-year sentence with credit for time served and ordering three years of supervised probation with provisions for out-of-state travel for work. The plea allows Ms. Pearson, known as Snoop, to continue her acting career, her lawyer Benjamin C. Sutley, said outside the courthouse in Baltimore.

On the Rick Perry front, while he has not yet announced his presidential candidacy, the ''Perry for President'' shadow campaign is thriving. At least seven so-called superPACs - technically independent groups that ran raise and spend unlimited amounts of money in support of a candidate - have been founded so far this year by supporters and former aides, each vying to tap into the large pool of wealthy donors who have supported Mr. Perry's campaigns for governor of Texas over the last decade.

CAREY--Governor Hugh Leo. Family will receive friends on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2:00-4:30pm and 6:30-9:00pm, at Frank E. Campbell 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. The Governor will lie in state on Thursday from 8:00am to 9:15am at The Cathedral of St. Patrick, Lady Chapel, 5th Ave at 51st St. Mass of Christian burial to follow 10:00am Main Altar. Blessing, Thursday afternoon at Our Lady of the Isle R.C. Church, Shelter Island, NY. Interment to follow at Our Lady of the Isle Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to The Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral; St. John's University, or The Paul R. Carey Foundation, 20 Corporate Woods Blvd. Albany, NY 12211.

FRANKFURT -- The European Central Bank has succeeded at least temporarily in pushing down the effective interest rates on Spanish and Italian government debt. But analysts say the bank must still convince investors that it has the stamina to withstand what could be a long struggle against market turmoil. Spanish and Italian bond prices rose and their yields fell on Tuesday after the central bank stepped in for a second day to buy their sovereign debt, part of expanded efforts to prevent the European debt crisis from deepening in two of the largest economies in the euro currency zone.

Federal prosecutors recommended on Tuesday that Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager convicted of running a huge insider trading scheme, be sentenced to as many as 24 and a half years in prison. That term is the maximum established for his crime under nonbinding sentencing guidelines, and prosecutors said it was warranted because Mr. Rajaratnam's ''criminal conduct was brazen, arrogant, harmful and pervasive.''

CAREY--Hugh L. The St. John's University community celebrates the life and mourns the passing of the Honorable Hugh L. Carey patriot, patriarch, man of faith, friend and most accomplished alumnus of this university. A veteran of World War II, leader in the U.S. House of Representatives, and two-term Governor of New York State, he served the public with compassion, competence, and courage. Loving husband of the late Helen, father of 14 and grandfather and great-grandfather many times over, he enriched his family with his boundless love, faith, and wisdom. For almost * of a century, since earning his bachelor's degree in 1942 and graduating from the School of Law in 1951, he has remained an integral part of this university as friend, active alumnus, and generous benefactor. With pride in and gratitude for his accomplishments, St. John's has conferred upon him virtually every honor it has to give, including an honorary doctorate. He evidenced his devotion to alma mater by entrusting St. John's with his legacy of faith-filled service -- the Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution established in the St. John's School of Law in 2009 will remain as a permanent memorial to his vision and values. And the Hugh and Helen Carey Residence Hall on the Queens campus will remind generations of future students of his life and achievements. St. John's extends its prayers and its deepest sympathy to the Carey family in this time of sorrow and joins them in thanking God for the gift of this truly extraordinary man. Peter P. D'Angelo, Chairman, Board of Trustees Rev. Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

DES MOINES - The specter of Gov. Rick Perry of Texas has been hanging over Iowa for weeks, but on Sunday afternoon he will pay his first visit to the state with a speech in Waterloo. Mr. Perry's appearance in Iowa will complete the trinity of early voting states. He is set to visit South Carolina and New Hampshire on Saturday, where he will make clear his intentions to join the Republican presidential race.

Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about a memorial wall on Bainbridge Island, Wash., dedicated to the Japanese-Americans who were exiled from the area in 1942 rendered incorrectly the given name of the architect who designed the wall. He is Johnpaul Jones, not John Paul.

HOOVER--Gilbert C. Jr.,87 of New York City, died Thursday, August 4, 2011, peacefully at home after a long period of failing health. He was born in Washington, DC, on March 14, 1924, son of the late Martha Smith and Rear Admiral Gilbert C. Hoover, After graduating from Brown University's ROTC program in 1945 he served as an Officer in the US Navy. In 1952 he married Mary Bidgood Rand. He and his wife Mary had a love affair with New York City. Throughout their lives they were active in Democratic politics, social justice and environmental causes. An avid reader, he had a long career in the publishing business and enjoyed fishing, painting, drawing and music. He was predeceased by his wife Mary. He is survived by his sisters Katherine Miller of Bloomfield, CT and Ann Wood of Scotch Plains, NJ; his daughter Mallory Smith and son-in-law Philip De Cillis of Port Angeles, WA; his daughter Katharine Lee and son-in-law Jere Truer of Minneapolis, MN; his son Win (Gilbert C. Hoover, IV) and daughter-in-law Elizabeth Quint of Brooklyn, NY; and his grandchildren Emily and Matthew. We will miss you! Private arrangements. In lieu of flowers, donations maybe made to VNSNY Hospice Care at 1250 Broadway, 7th Floor, New York, NY 10001 or the Arts Student League of New York at 215 W. 57th Street, New York, NY 10019.

LONDON -- Switzerland is close to signing sweeping tax treaties with Germany and Britain intended to ensure that assets belonging to citizens of those countries held in Swiss banks will no longer escape tax. The deals are another step in Swiss efforts to clean up the country's image, under pressure from American prosecutors as well as European countries that have been willing to pay for lists of client names that were stolen by bank employees.

An obituary on Monday about Jane White, a light-skinned black actress who complained that she was sometimes asked to lighten her complexion to play certain roles, paraphrased incorrectly from comments by Jane Klain, a friend, who described the time Ms. White wore such makeup during a cab ride. Ms. Klain said that the actress was on her way to audition for ''Once Upon a Mattress'' -- not that she was on her way to a performance of the acclaimed musical. (She went on to originate the role of Queen Aggravain in the musical.)

A report in the Inside Art column on Friday about an exhibition of Damien Hirst paintings at every Gagosian Gallery in the world next year misidentified the British museum where a major retrospective of Mr. Hirst's career will open in April. It is Tate Modern, not Tate Britain.

MAYER--Harold C.,Jr. of Manhattan and Orleans, Massuchsetts died in Hyannis, MA on August 6, 2011 at age 87. Known to his friends as Billy, he was born in New York City on January 30, 1924. He was a graduate of Riverdale Country School and Yale University and was a proud supporter of each institution. Billy enjoyed a long career in finance. Throughout his life, he was a passionate fan of Yale Football. Billy was known for his extreme generosity, his quick wit and his joyous spirit. Billy will always be remembered as a devoted and loyal family man. He is survived by his adoring wife of 47 years Joan Arnstein Mayer, his beloved daughters Lucy Mayer Harrop (Mark D. Harrop), Kathy Mayer Braddock (Richard J. Zakin) and Elizabeth Mayer Rappaport (Howard S. Rappaport), his step-sons Stephen Wilder (Sue Wilder), Andrew Wilder (Debra Wilder) and Scott K. Wilder (Elizabeth Abbott), his eight grandchildren Philip Braddock, Charles Braddock, Hilary Rappaport, Mark Rappaport, Bonnie Wilder, Sam Wilder, Scott S. Wilder and Katherine Rose Wilder. In addition, he is survived by his loving sisters Nancy Mayer and Sue Ellen Rittmaster. Donations in memory of Billy may be made to Riverdale Country School, 5250 Fieldston Road, Bronx, NY 10471 and to Congregation Emanu-El, One East 65th Street, New York, NY. The family will be receiving visitors on Tuesday, August 9th between 5:00pm - 7:30 pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel at 1067 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. Services Wednesday August 10, 10:30am at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65 Street.

Louis C.K., Tracy Morgan, Sarah Silverman, Ricky Gervais, Bill Maher, Wanda Sykes, Russell Peters, Kathy Griffin and Norm Macdonald are among the stars who will go straight for the funny bone around New York City during the eighth annual New York Comedy Festival from Nov. 9 to 13, festival officials will announce Wednesday. The festival is presented in association with Comedy Central, and is produced by Carolines on Broadway, the New York City comedy club. More than 150 comedians will perform at various spots around the city. This year, for the first time, a performance will be held at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Other sites include the Beacon Theater, Carolines on Broadway, Carnegie Hall and the 92nd Street Y.

POSKOSH--Esther Braun, a woman of singular strength, stamina, and courage, longest survivor of nine siblings and four half-siblings, passed away August 8, 2011. She continues to live in the hearts of her grandsons, Brett and Todd, daughter Geri, son-in-law Bill Brehm, and nieces, nephews, and friends.

Table No. 1 from Elaine's, the Upper East Side restaurant that closed in May, will be auctioned on Sept. 20, along with the posters and artwork that lined the restaurant and books and memorabilia from the nearby apartment of its longtime owner, Elaine Kaufman. She died at 81 on Dec. 3 of complications from emphysema. Doyle New York, the auction house that is handling the sale, estimates that Table No. 1 and its four chairs will go for $400 to $600. Also on the block will be the papier-mache carousel horse that was in the window for years (estimated selling price, $200 to $300), copper pots from the kitchen (also estimated at $200 to $300) and the vintage cash register from behind the bar (estimated selling price, $400 to $600).The items being sold will be displayed at Doyle New York, at 175 East 87th Street, on Sept. 17, 18 and 19.

An article on Friday about the Millstone Valley Scenic Byway and other roads where drivers can enjoy the view misidentified the area of Connecticut through which one such road, State Route 169, passes. It is northeastern Connecticut, not northwestern.

CAREY--Hugh L. Governor. The Campo Family honors and cherishes the memory of our late father's dear friend Governor Hugh L. Carey - the man who saved New York. Our loving thoughts and wishes go out to our good friends the Carey Family members.

After two wild quarters - leaping in the first and missing big in the second - the Walt Disney Company returned to its calm and collected ways on Tuesday, reporting profit slightly above Wall Street's predictions. Disney, the world's largest media company, said net income for its fiscal third quarter rose to $1.48 billion, or 77 cents a share. That compares with income of $1.3 billion, or 67 cents a share, in the year-ago quarter. Revenue climbed 7 percent, to $10.68 billion. Analysts had expected income of 73 cents a share.

A music review on Saturday about the final concert in the 4x4 Baroque Music Festival, at St. Peter's Lutheran Church on Lexington Avenue, misstated part of the title of a Bach cantata that was performed. It is ''Weinen, Klagen, Sorgen, Zagen,'' not ''Sagen.'' (The review included a translation of the correct title -- ''Weeping, Lamentation, Worry, Despair.'')

CLAREMON--Ruth, age 89, a resident of Harrison, NY and Tamarac, FL died in White Plains Hospital on August 9, 2011. She is survived by Irving, her devoted husband of 70 years. She was cherished by her children Neil and Ronni (Donald) Lee and grandchildren Amanda (Greg), Andrea, Benjamin, and Brandon (Liza). Also survived by three brothers David, Arnold (Estelle) and Bernard (Phyllis) Spring. Along with Irving, she was a founding member of the JCC of Harrison and Brae Burn Country Club. Among their contributions, Ruth and Irving donated to Albert Einstein College of Medicine, NY Presbyterian, White Plains Hospital, and UJA. Highly respected for her artistry, beauty, intelligence, advice and thoughtfulness, Ruth will be greatly missed by friends and family. Funeral services will be held 11am, Thursday August 11 at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison. Burial will take place in the Spring Mausoleum at Cedar Park Cemetery.

Reversing what it had said just last week, Syfy now says it has canceled ''Eureka,'' a playful science-fiction series that the channel has broadcast since 2006. The final season, its fifth, will have its debut early next year. ''The 2012 episodes are some of the best we've seen, and will bring this great series to a satisfying end,'' the channel said in a statement.

GOLDMAN'S LOSS Goldman Sachs lost money on 15 days in the second quarter, one of the worst trading performances the bank has posted in some time, according to a regulatory filing released on Tuesday. Goldman also reported that trading revenue rose above $100 million on only four days. In the year-earlier period, Goldman lost money on 10 trading days but had 17 days where revenue rose above $100 million. In the first quarter of 2011 it had just one losing trading day. SUSANNE CRAIG

Alec Baldwin is not running for mayor of New York -- yet. First, Mr. Baldwin, a 53-year-old actor and Long Island native, wants to finish his work on his television show, ''30 Rock,'' then go back to school and learn what the job is all about.
Time: About 30 minutes

An article on June 8 about local foods that members of Congress give out in their Washington offices misidentified the Congressional district that includes Homestead, Pa., the home of Eat 'n Park, which makes a cookie given out by Representative Jason Altmire of Pennsylvania. It is the 10th District, not the 4th, Mr. Altmire's district. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail the day the article was published and again on July 20. This correction was delayed because the e-mail went astray at The Times.

When Rupert Murdoch sat down with his board on Tuesday for the first time since a phone hacking scandal overseas plunged his company into turmoil, he was surrounded by a lot of familiar, friendly faces. The meeting, held on the studio lot of 20th Century Fox and timed to coincide with News Corporation's quarterly earnings announcement on Wednesday, included many people with deep and longstanding ties to Mr. Murdoch, his company and his family.

CLAREMON--Ruth. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed founding member, Ruth Claremon. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to her entire family. Michael Barasch, President William Schultz, Secretary

QUIRK--William F. August 3, 1933 - August 1, 2011. Proud son of the late William and Helen (nee Levins) Quirk. A Bronx native, William spent the majority of his life in Parkchester. He attended Fordham Prep High School, Notre Dame University and Notre Dame Law School. He retired from the law firm Bower & Gardner. He is survived by many friends and family. Funeral Mass will be Saturday, August 13, 9:30am in St Helena's Roman Catholic Church, 1315 Olmstead Avenue, Bronx, NY 10462. Burial will immediately follow at Calvary Cemetery in Queens.

Federal prosecutors recommended on Tuesday that Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund manager convicted of running a huge insider trading scheme, be sentenced to as many as 24 and a half years in prison. That term is the maximum established for his crime under nonbinding sentencing guidelines, and prosecutors said it was warranted because Mr. Rajaratnam's ''criminal conduct was brazen, arrogant, harmful and pervasive.''

Times Books will publish the ''definitive account'' of the hacking scandal swirling around Rupert Murdoch and News International, the publisher said on Tuesday, written by Sarah Lyall and Don Van Natta Jr., longtime reporters for The New York Times. The book will be ''a narrative and investigative account of the culture of phone hacking, payoffs, and coziness with police officials and politicians at the News of the World and other media outlets owned by Murdoch's News Corporation,'' according to a statement from Times Books, an imprint of Henry Holt and Company, and will explain ''the genesis of the scandal, how it unfolded, and its ever-widening scope.''

REDWOOD CITY, Calif. -- Even as Wall Street trembles, the market for investing in tech start-ups remains white-hot. Still, some investors are proceeding with extreme caution. Saying they learned their lesson in the dot-com boom and bust, and the 2008 recession, the institutional investors -- pension funds, university endowments and foundations -- that put money in venture capital funds are more selectively choosing the firms in which they invest, doing exhaustive research before handing over money, and in some cases driving hard bargains for more favorable management fees and shares of profits.

CAREY--Hugh L. St. John's School of Law mourns the passing of our alumnus, friend, and benefactor Governor Hugh L. Carey '42C, '51L, '67HON. Governor Carey was a dedicated public servant, a tireless advocate for New Yorkers, and a man of deep personal integrity. He was a loyal son of St. John's University and a proud graduate of the School of Law. Throughout his career, he showed a gift for bringing people together to solve difficult problems and to resolve intractable conflicts. At St. John's School of Law, Governor Carey's legacy lives on through "The Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution". Established in 2009 through the generosity of Governor Carey, the Carey Center promotes the value and practice of conflict resolution in the United States and around the world. The Center's programs which train law students, lawyers, and judges in dispute resolution principles will continue to be a fitting tribute to this great lawyer, great problem solver, and great man. The entire School of Law community extends its prayers and deepest sympathy to the Carey family. Michael A. Simons, Dean and John V. Brennan, Professor of Law and Ethics Paul F. Kirgis, Faculty Chair, Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution Elayne E. Greenberg, Director, Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution

WELLINGTON--Harry H. The New York Law School community mourns the passing of Harry H. Wellington, Professor of Law and Dean Emeritus at New York Law School. Born in 1926 in New Haven, Connecticut, Dean Wellington received his undergraduate degree from the University of Pennsylvania in 1947 and his law degree from Harvard in 1952. Upon graduation from Harvard, he clerked for United States Circuit Judge Calvert Magruder and later for United States Supreme Court Justice Felix Frankfurter. Dean Wellington's academic career began at Stanford Law School where he taught for one year. He then joined the faculty at Yale Law School where he flourished as a scholar and teacher, and where he served as Dean from 1975 to 1985. In 1983, he was named Sterling Professor of Law. In 1992, upon his retirement from Yale, Dean Wellington joined New York Law School as President and Dean. As Dean, Wellington had a major impact on the image and reputation of New York Law School, by putting together and overseeing a first-rate faculty, whose well-established scholarship continues to earn respect and admiration from the legal community. He remained Dean of New York Law School for nine years until 2001, and in 2007, he retired from teaching. He also served on the Law School's Board of Trustees. Dean Wellington was awarded the President's Medal of Honor during the Law School's 2011 Commencement Exercises for his significant contributions to the history of New York Law School. During his distinguished career, Dean Wellington's numerous writings on legal process earned him a reputation as a scholar whose nuance and subtle style, just as in his teaching and lecturing, served to illuminate complex issues and to make them completely comprehensible. The Law School community will remember Dean Wellington's inspiring leadership, unswerving dedication to the rule of law, and devotion to teaching and to the legal profession. We extend our condolences to his wife Sheila and his children and grandchildren. Arthur N. Abbey, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Richard A. Matasar Dean and President

DEMARAY--Barbara L.,died on July 23, 2011 at Somerset Medical Center. Daughter of Howard H. Demaray and Idabelle C. Demaray, she was a member of one of Somerville's, (NJ) oldest families, occupying the home on West Cliff Street that had been purchased by her grandfather, Lyman H. Demaray in 1896. For most of her career Ms. Demaray was a writer, creative director and vice-president of Young & Rubicam, Inc., the international advertising agency. She served her company in its New York offices, as well as in Hollywood, Copenhagen, Mexico City, the Dominican Republic and Toronto. During a two-year leave of absence from Y&R, she joined the staff of The Children's Television Network in the planning and introduction of Sesame Street. She also designed windows using her wonderfully fanciful creations for Lord and Taylor's and for Tiffany's flagship store on Fifth Avenue in New York City. After retiring in 1986 in Toronto, she continued doing some consulting for a few more years, and eventually embraced full retirement. She maintained residences in Toronto and Somerville, enjoying spending time with friends and their families until finally returning to her family home in Somerville, NJ in 2004. She was a member of St. John's Episcopal Church in Somerville. There are no immediate survivors. A memorial service will be held Saturday, August 13 at 10:00am at St John's Episcopal Church, Somerville. Contributions in her memory can be made to The Nature Conservancy.

There's a scene in ''The Help,'' the new movie based on Kathryn Stockett's novel, that cracks open the early-'60s world of strained smiles and gentility that rarely leaps out of this big, ole slab of honey-glazed hokum. It's after hours, and Aibileen, a maid played with determined grace by Viola Davis, is going home. Suddenly the bus stops, and a white man orders the black passengers off, explaining that a black man has been shot -- except that he doesn't say black, Negro or colored. In a pool of dreadful night, Aibileen and a young man trade goodbyes and rush off. And then this sturdy, frightened woman starts running as if her life were in danger, because it's Mississippi, and it is. When she gets to safety, Aibileen learns that the man who has been shot is Medgar Evers, the civil rights activist who was gunned down in Jackson, Miss., on June 12, 1963, in front of his home. His wife and three young children, who were trained to lie on the floor in case of gunfire, found him, and Evers died shortly afterward. Hours before, President John F. Kennedy, spurred on by different national events, including the demonstrations in Birmingham led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., had delivered his landmark speech about civil rights. He said we were facing a ''moral crisis as a country and a people'' and soon introduced legislation that would become the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the same year ''The Help'' rises to its teary, insistently uplifting end.

10 P.M. (Sundance) MY WINNIPEG (2008) In his rumination on what A. O. Scott, writing in The New York Times, called ''the deep and accidental relationship between a specific place and an individual life,'' Guy Maddin pays tribute to his Canadian hometown and its quirks. Among his assertions: that Winnipeg has two taxi companies, one working the major streets, and the other confined to the back alleys; that some streets were named after well-known prostitutes and brothel owners; that horses, fleeing a fire in the 1920s, froze to death in the river, where their icebound heads became props for skaters (above); and that the city fathers used to sponsor an annual treasure hunt in which first prize was a one-way ticket out of town. Are the stories true? ''To be honest, I'd rather not know,'' Mr. Scott said. ''Fact-checking 'My Winnipeg' would be absurd, since the film, which combines archival documentary images with freshly shot, antique-looking passages, is more concerned with lyrical truth than with literal accuracy.'' He added: ''Much as he may dream of taking that one-way rail journey to somewhere else, Mr. Maddin can no more spurn Winnipeg than it can disown him. In a thoughtful, occasionally excitable voice-over he dutifully tries to explain the place -- its riverine topography and wintry climate, its civic traditions and architectural landmarks. But his real point -- and, for admirers of this brilliant and idiosyncratic artist, the true source of the movie's interest -- is that Winnipeg explains him.'' 6 A.M. One thing you learn when you spend a bunch of time on YouTube looking up songs that use the electronic pitch-correction algorithm known as Auto-Tune is that a lot of people really hate Auto-Tune. Which is weird. It’s just a sound — obnoxious in the hands of the untalented, occasionally amazing in the hands of the amazing. Hating it is like hating falsettos, or the accordion. And, O.K., given the current omnipresence of the sound in pop music, it’s like hating the accordion during some strange period of accordion-fascism during which everyone’s paying top dollar to sound like early Los Lobos or Weird Al. Rap and R&B may have run with Auto-Tune more than other genres, but these days you can’t get away from it, even by listening to metal, country or Moroccan music.

In Boston, scientists measuring the city’s greenhouse gas emissions have found what they call a “weekend effect,” a clear drop-off in the amount of carbon dioxide entering the city’s atmosphere on Saturdays and Sundays. In Fresno, researchers have discovered that backyard water use increases with wealth, as does backyard biodiversity. And in Los Angeles, ecologists studying the city’s “ecohydrology” have calculated that planting a million new trees, an idea with fairly universal appeal, would have the drawback of increasing water consumption by 5 percent.

At Les Arts Decoratifs in Paris, the summer crowds have gravitated to the Hussein Chalayan show and the exhibition of highlights from Ralph Lauren’s car collection. I was glad to see both on a recent trip, but I was also lucky to spot a sign for another, less-heralded exhibition at the museum. “Plastique Ludique” (“Playful Plastic”), which runs until Nov. 6, presents the work of the Czech toy designer Libuse Niklova (1934-1981), whose work with plastics, particularly in the 1960s and ’70s, changed the look — and the nature — of toys in her native country. Niklova believed that children should be able to play as creatively as possible, and the development of plastics after World War II offered a helpful tool. Her inflatable buffalo, giraffe and elephant, with their simplified, graphic silhouettes and bright, pop colors, could be used as chairs or pool toys for small children. (The three have been reissued in limited numbers and are for sale at the museum’s shop.) And Niklova’s ingenious use of pleated plastic piping produced animals with accordion-like midsections that squealed when squeezed. In contrast to the Chalayan and Lauren exhibitions, which are about the more expensive pleasures of the material world, “Plastique Ludique” offers a surprising, refreshing look at a more modest — yet no less inventive — endeavor.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has officially canceled plans to loan works by the fashion designer Paul Poiret to Moscow’s Kremlin Museum, as part of the ongoing fallout from a legal dispute that has halted all loans from Russian to American museums. “It’s really a matter of fairness and equity,” the Met’s spokesman, Harold Holzer, said. As long as Russia’s “loan embargo is in place,” Mr. Holzer said, “this museum believes it can no longer lend to Russian museums.” The Met was to lend 35 Poiret works to the show, which is scheduled to open at the Moscow museum on September 6. The cancellation of the loans was first reported by the New York Observer.

Dirk Schoenberger walks into the lobby of the Bowery Hotel wearing Prada’s infamous platform espadrille wingtips — an odd choice considering that Schoenberger is the creative director of the sports style division at Adidas, a company known for its footwear. What he likes about the Pradas, he explains, is “the mix of sharp tailoring and casual leisure.” Having held his post for little over a year, he has pushed Adidas to hybridize in a similar manner. “When I’m in Berlin and I see how the young guys and girls are dressing, none of them are wearing sneakers anymore. So you think, if these are the target consumers, and we are only selling sneakers, well, what are we going to do?” The answer may be found in Adidas SLVR. Priced somewhere between Originals and Y-3 (also under Schoenberger’s purview), the line has been reimagined for fall under his personal design stewardship. “It’s amazing for such a big company to be so open for discussions,” he says. With SLVR, it is a “new approach but still very much in the language of Adidas.”

Like many women nowadays, I shop for my bikinis in the snow and boots in the blistering heat. You could say I’ve adapted. There is a despairing time lapse between when collections are shown (spring in September and fall in February) and when those pieces are sold. (Fall hits stores as early as July, and spring in February.) And thanks to instantaneous gratification sites like Moda Operandi and Gilt Groupe, avid customers can now begin preordering directly from their favorite designers. “I start planning the moment they walk down the runway,” says the designer Margherita Missoni. But some months, like September, linger in a sort of shopping purgatory. The idea of scouring the racks while waiting for sales and holiday items to hit the floor seems outdated. And tired. So while we dally in the off-season, how does one find (and love) things to buy now?
Sell now — ask questions later.

This week on the Billboard charts Adele continues her remarkable run with a 12th week at No. 1, but big competition from Jay-Z and Kanye West is right behind her. Adele's ''21'' (XL/Columbia), the biggest hit of the year, had 76,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan, bringing its total in the United States to 2.9 million. No album has had so many weeks at No. 1 since Santana's ''Supernatural'' in 1999 and 2000. Ever since ''21'' was released in February it has not fallen lower than No. 3 on the chart, and its sales remain extraordinarily steady for a six-month-old title, this week dropping only 7 percent from the week before.

WATERLOO, Iowa -- Ron Paul has none of the bravado of his Republican presidential rivals. At a town hall meeting here on Wednesday afternoon, he spoke for 35 minutes and then promptly apologized. ''Hopefully, I didn't scare you off,'' Mr. Paul, a congressman from Texas, said with a soft voice and a characteristic shrug.

It has been two years since ''New York Noise,'' a beloved public television show devoted to the city's underground rock bands, went off the air. Now an online subsidiary of MTV has hired the producer behind that show, Shirley Braha, to do a half-hour Webcast of indie videos in her humorous and playful style. The new show, ''Weird Vibes,'' will have its debut Thursday on MTV Hive, a spokesman for the site, Kurt Patat, said.

9 P.M. (Starz) SECRETARIAT (2010) Diane Lane, left, portrays Penny Tweedy, the owner of Secretariat, the thoroughbred who, in 1973, became the first Triple Crown champion in 25 years, setting records in the Kentucky Derby and the Belmont Stakes that still stand. John Malkovich is Lucien Laurin, the trainer who came out of retirement shortly before leading Secretariat to victory. ''But the bigger and truer stars of this enjoyable, sometimes accidentally entertaining movie are the five horses that take turns playing Secretariat -- one was used for running, another posed for the cameras -- along with the memory of that original breathtaking beauty,'' Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. ''It's a pleasurable, seductive fantasy partly because, as we have known from the start of cinema, the sight of a running horse is a beautiful thing.'' 6:35 P.M. (Sundance) KEEP EYE ON BALL: THE HASHIM KHAN STORY (2009) Josh Easdon chronicles the life of Mr. Khan, far right with Prince Philip, considered by many to be the greatest squash player of all time, who between 1951 and 1958 won seven British Open titles and became a hero in his home country, Pakistan.

6:02 p.m. | Updated Is the Obama White House planning an October surprise for next year to give the president's re-election campaign a boost? That's the suspicion of Representative Peter T. King, the New York Republican who is chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee. Mr. King has asked the inspectors general of the Defense Department and the Central Intelligence Agency to investigate the administration's cooperation with filmmakers planning a movie based on the Navy Seal raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

PARIS -- With the sense of economic crisis deepening in Europe after the United States debt downgrade, investors have played Who's Next with the shrinking list of nations that still hold the top rating of AAA. And their sights have landed on France. Shares of French financial institutions were hammered Wednesday on the Paris stock exchange on mounting fears that France's own sterling credit rating could be cut, if the cost of cleaning up the European debt crisis weighs on the nation and its banks.

HSBC SALE Capital One Financial agreed on Wednesday to buy the United States credit card business of HSBC Holdings for $2.6 billion in cash and stock, in what will be Capital One's second major deal with a European firm in recent months. The purchase will give Capital One more than $30 billion of credit card loans. The firm agreed in June to buy the American online banking operations of the ING Group of the Netherlands for $9 billion. MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

Disco may have died, gone undercover or been lying in wait along with other 1970s fixtures like oil crises, economic malaise and wide-legged pants. In any case, it is being recalibrated for SiriusXM, the satellite radio broadcaster, which starts a channel called Studio 54 on Monday. Studio 54 Radio will be a round-the-clock blend of dance and disco hits, rare remixes and deep cuts, many from D.J.'s and habitués of Studio 54, the era-defining Manhattan club run by Steve Rubell and Ian Schrager. John Benitez, the producer of early Madonna songs like ''Borderline'' and ''Holiday'' who went from patron to D.J. at the club, will serve as its executive producer.

CAREY--Hugh L. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of Governor Hugh L. Carey, who will be long remembered for his exemplary leadership of New York State and vigorous defense of New York City's fiscal solvency. His support for the 1979 CUNY Financing and Governance Act and for major campus construction projects in all five boroughs were milestones in public higher education investment. His passion for public service, compassion for the less fortunate, and keen wit will be sorely missed. Our deepest condolences are extended to his beloved family. Benno Schmidt, Chair Board of Trustees Matthew Goldstein, Chancellor

An article on Saturday about the anti-government uprising in Syria misstated the relative size of Homs, one of several cities where large demonstrations were held on Friday. It is Syria's third-largest city, not its second-largest. (Aleppo is the second-largest, and Damascus is the largest.)

Q.I have scanned family photos for a reunion that I'd like to put online, but what's the best way to move them all to the Web (and not on Facebook), and how can I keep them private for only relatives to see? A. Scout around for a photo-sharing site that meets your needs in terms of the amount of data you can upload, as well as privacy options. Depending on what Web services you already use, you may have photo-sharing space and not realize it. For example, Hotmail users can take advantage of Microsoft's Windows Live SkyDrive to upload and share photos and Gmail users can easily get started with Google's Picasa Web albums.

A memoir by Auma Obama, a half-sister of President Obama, will be published in the United States in May, St. Martin's Press said on Tuesday. The book was released in Germany last fall with a title that translates as ''Life Always Gets in the Way'' or ''Life Happens.'' Ms. Obama was born in Kenya and first met her younger brother in the 1980s, after which they traveled to Kenya and researched their family history together. She lived in Germany for 16 years and now works in Nairobi for CARE International. ''In this candid and emotional memoir, Auma shares her own story as well as recollections of and experiences with her famous brother,'' said a statement from St. Martin's, part of Macmillan.

'IRVING JANIS'S GROUPTHINK AND THE SANHEDRIN OF ANCIENT ISRAEL' by Eliezer Schnall, a psychologist at Yeshiva University, and his student, Michael Greenberg. Presented at the American Psychological Association convention in Washington on Aug. 7. THE ARGUMENT One of the most influential theories in the behavioral sciences in recent decades is ''groupthink.'' Developed by the psychologist Irving Janis in the early 1970s, that theory describes how a tight-knit, smart and well-informed group can suppress dissent and make disastrous decisions because of the pressure to agree. As examples Janis used the failure to anticipate the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941 and the American escalation of the Vietnam War in the mid-'60s. Mr. Schnall argues that decision making entities in the ancient world may have been aware of the danger of conformist thought and developed methods similar to Janis's recommended preventatives. He examines, in particular, the practices of the Sanhedrin, the judicial and legislative body of ancient Israel.

LESSIN--Robert Howard. Citizen of the World and reluctant but reliable Englewood, NJ taxpayer, died on August 9, 2011 at age 56. Thinker, teacher, and financier, Bob lived his life with a passion for the present and his eyes keenly fixed on the future. He was always original and true to himself. Bob was born in Brooklyn and attended school in Lexington, MA and Ardsley, NY. He was the youngest Eagle Scout in Massachusetts history. Bob graduated in three years from Harvard College (AB '76) having studied economics and applied physics and continued immediately on to Harvard Business School (MBA '78). After graduating, he joined Morgan Stanley as an investment banking associate and became a rising star in its fledging mergers and acquisitions group. In 1980 he married Naida S. Wharton, with whom he had three children, Sam, Daniel, and Kara. He went on to run Smith Barney's investment bank. In 1994 he suffered a stroke; during his recovery, he wrote The Middle Chapters in which he projected social and financial changes stemming from the Internet and other changes in technology. He followed his own advice and left to become a prolific angel investor, founding Dawntreader, a VC fund. He became the Chairman and CEO of Wit Capital, a pioneering investment bank, which he took public and which was later sold to Schwab. He joined Jefferies in 2002 as vice chairman, a position he held until his death. More important to Bob than his resume were his wanderings, both global and intellectual. He skied, biked, kayaked, or walked his way across most of the earth with his second wife Clara Wong at his side (and sometimes with his dogs, Kismet and Chinta, as well). The beaches of Cape Cod, the slopes of Beaver Creek, the shores of Cyprus and the woods of New Jersey were all home to him. He drank in knowledge from every person and place he met and returned deep insights on life and economics back to the community through his friends and his writings. He taught his children his unique life lessons at bedtime, over the dinner table, during games of catch and on long hikes in Flat Rock Brook. Later, nothing made him happier than teaching students at De Le Salle Academy and George Jackson Academy. Teaching, he often remarked, provides the ultimate geometric return on investment, a criteria he broadly embraced. He loved nature; he loved people; and he loved his family. He made lifelong friends everywhere he went, and they will never forget him. His insights and contributions will live on forever. He is survived by his wife Clara, his three children and their mother Naida, his parents Irving and Phyllis Lessin, of Potomac, MD, as well as his brother Larry Lessin, sister-in-law Deborah Lessin and niece and nephew Jessica and Austin. A public memorial service will be held Friday, August 12 at 10am at the Harvard Club, 35 West 44th Street, New York. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made in Bob's memory to George Jackson Academy, 104 St. Marks Place, New York NY 10009. Attn.: David Arnold.

The Sagra Journal article on Friday, about residents in the rural Russian village of Sagra, who had to band together to protect themselves from criminals in the absence of police protection, misspelled the surname of a Russian law school academic who said the police in Russia are corrupt, lazy or politicized, which explains why ''the country is turning into one big Sagra.'' He is Konstantin M. Kiselyov, not Kiseyov.

The showdown reads like a rejected Hollywood script: ninjas and Brooklynites facing off in a battle for toilet supremacy. This month, the lavatories at two local restaurants - Ninja New York in TriBeCa and Habana Outpost in Fort Greene, Brooklyn - were among the 10 nominees for America's Best Restroom, an annual competition sponsored by Cintas, a uniform and bathroom supply company. In past years, water closets in Bryant Park, Radio City Music Hall and the Muse Hotel were also nominated, but never won. Voting opened online last week and runs through Sept. 19.

Bill Parcells was hired by ESPN as an N.F.L. studio analyst on Wednesday. Again. Parcells's roster of coaching and TV jobs is nearly as long as the list of game shows hosted by Wink Martindale. The ex-Giants, ex-Patriots, ex-Jets, ex-Cowboys coach and former executive vice president of the Dolphins has slotted network jobs into his coaching hiatuses since leaving the Giants in 1991.

In early 2010, top officials at the Federal Reserve began to wonder: how would United States banks hold up through the European debt crisis? Investors were fleeing Greece and Ireland, and starting to get nervous about Portugal and Spain, spreading contagion. The conclusion from the stress tests that resulted was heartening to supervisors at the regulator, according to a person who was directly involved in the exercise: American banks didn't have too much exposure to Portugal and Spain, so the contagion would not be a problem.

The photograph of Mr. Rajaratnam leaving federal court with his lawyer was taken by Rick Maiman of Bloomberg News, not by Andrew Gombert of the European Pressphoto Agency.

BOWDEN--William. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William Bowden, associated with The New York Times from October 1, 1967 until retiring on February 1, 1993.

New from Radica, a division of Mattel: Fijit Friends ($50 each, fijitfriends.com, for girls 6-9), a set of four chatty robots that can dance to music, detect voice prompts and hear ''sonic chirp'' codes embedded in videos or sites. Powered by five AA batteries, the 8-inch creature looks like a Pillsbury Dough Boy covered with a rubbery skin that is impossible not to touch. A microphone can hear detect sound codes that trigger jokes or dance moves that Mattel calls ''Sonic Chirps,'' a technology that has been around before, but has been modified in this case by Mattel engineers to interact with external media, like TV commercials, web sites or YouTube videos. A similar concept was tried with Microsoft's Actimates back in 1997, but instead of using high frequencies, you can hear these codes - they sound like high pitched dial tones that can catch the attention of any nearby cat. (Listen for yourself.)

JOHNS CREEK, Ga. -- The Atlanta Athletic Club course for the 93rd P.G.A. Championship this week has a par of 70 and stretches 7,467 yards from the back tees, placing it among the longest championship courses ever on a par-to-yardage ratio. Rory McIlroy, the reigning United States Open champion, was asked Wednesday whether this constituted a long course. He took a short time to answer.

The Iowa State Fair just got its newest, late-breaking attraction - and it's not even on a stick. Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska and Republican vice presidential nominee in 2008, is coming to town.
