A picture on Wednesday with an article about the European Central Bank's purchase of Spanish and Italian bonds carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of Jean-Claude Trichet, president of the central bank, was taken by Hannelore Foerster of Bloomberg News, not by Daniel Ochoa de Olza of The Associated Press.

Based on a Steven Spielberg movie and reuniting much of the creative team that won eight Tonys for ''Hairspray,'' ''Catch Me If You Can'' came to Broadway with everything going for it -- except, as it turned out, audiences. The musical's producers announced on Tuesday that it would close on September 4, after 32 previews and 170 performances. It's a disappointing ending for the long-in-development musical that matched up rising star Aaron Tveit with Tony-winning actor Norbert Leo Butz, and featured music and lyrics by Scott Wittman and Marc Shaiman, book by Terrence McNally, choreography by Jerry Mitchell, and direction by Jack O'Brien.

For hedge funds, just one week can change their entire year. With the stock market shedding billions of dollars in value and uncertainty in Europe stoking fear, some funds are watching their returns sink by double digits while others are shooting the lights out. August, in less than two weeks, has brought a 13 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and roughly 12 percent drop in the Dow Jones industrial average.

A news analysis article on Wednesday about President Obama's handling of the economy paraphrased incompletely from comments by David Rothkopf, a former Clinton administration Commerce Department official, about steps that Mr. Obama should take to fix the economy and budget deficit. While Mr. Rothkopf called for the president to push for politically unpalatable budget cuts to entitlement programs and the military, he also said the president should do so in the context of a ''grand bargain'' in which the cuts would come in exchange for significant job-creating stimulus and increased tax revenues.

Subscribers to New York City Ballet's Fourth Ring Society will be offered a new discount program for the 2011-12 season starting on Aug. 29. The program, called Society NYCB, will be the same as it was last season for the Fourth Ring Society, which was discontinued. There will be a $20 annual membership fee, and tickets will cost $15 (plus a $2 facility fee). They can be purchased by phone or at the box office; the standard ticket service fee of $7 will be waived and tickets will not be available online. In June members of the Fourth Ring Society complained about the ballet's decision to stop selling most of the lower-priced tickets for so-called nosebleed seats. The ballet has said it hopes to consolidate its audience in the orchestra and lower rings for less-than-full performances.

3:50 p.m. | Updated TBS on Wednesday cancelled George Lopez's late-night show, less than a year after the network moved ''Lopez Tonight'' from 11 p.m. to midnight to make room for Conan O'Brien. The decision seemed abrupt; TBS announced Mr. Lopez's show will end after Thursday's edition. But inside Turner Entertainment, which programs TBS, the move has been much discussed in recent months as ratings for Mr. Lopez's show continued to decline.
8:17 p.m. | Updated Groupon has dropped a much-criticized accounting metric after pushback from the Securities and Exchange Commission, according to an amended prospectus filed on Wednesday.

HECHT--Dr. Warren Henry, of Great Neck, NY, died suddenly at home on August 9, 2011. Warren is survived by Gilda, his wife of 52 years and the light of his life; his children, Dr. Helen Hecht (Cathy Brown), Erica Ebbets (Steve), Steven Hecht (Gary Seis) and Maura Hecht (Joanne Burdish); and his grandchildren, Heather Ebbets, Lily Brown and Ryan Brown. Warren was a Captain in the Air Force, received his degree in dentistry from NYU, and practiced for more than 60 years in New York City and Great Neck. He served as a volunteer fireman in the Vigilant Hook and Ladder Company of Great Neck, NY, for more than 40 years and was a life member. He participated in search and rescue during 9/11. Warren lived a unique life and marched to his own drum. He loved life and lived every minute of it to the fullest. He will be missed.

An article on Wednesday about the abrupt end to Diana Nyad's effort to swim from Cuba to Key West, Fla., misspelled the name of the support boat that she boarded. It is the Bellissimo, not the Bellisimo.

Hunter Parrish has found religion -- at least on Broadway. Mr. Parrish, who stars as a hunky troubled teenager on the Showtime series ''Weeds,'' and played a hunky mopey teenager in ''Spring Awakening,'' will next take on the role of Jesus in a revival of ''Godspell,'' its producers announced on Wednesday. The musical opened Off Broadway in 1971 and played for several years, eventually moving to Broadway and spawning the pop hit ''Day by Day.'' The revival is scheduled to begin preview performances at Circle in the Square Theater Oct. 13 and open on Nov. 7. Mr. Parrish is the first member of the cast to be announced.

CAREY--Hugh L. The St. John's University community celebrates the life and mourns the passing of the Honorable Hugh L. Carey patriot, patriarch, man of faith, friend and most accomplished alumnus of this university. A veteran of World War II, leader in the U.S. House of Representatives, and two-term Governor of New York State, he served the public with compassion, competence, and courage. Loving husband of the late Helen, father of 14 and grandfather and great-grandfather many times over, he enriched his family with his boundless love, faith, and wisdom. For almost * of a century, since earning his bachelor's degree in 1942 and graduating from the School of Law in 1951, he has remained an integral part of this university as friend, active alumnus, and generous benefactor. With pride in and gratitude for his accomplishments, St. John's has conferred upon him virtually every honor it has to give, including an honorary doctorate. He evidenced his devotion to alma mater by entrusting St. John's with his legacy of faith-filled service -- the Hugh L. Carey Center for Dispute Resolution established in the St. John's School of Law in 2009 will remain as a permanent memorial to his vision and values. And the Hugh and Helen Carey Residence Hall on the Queens campus will remind generations of future students of his life and achievements. St. John's extends its prayers and its deepest sympathy to the Carey family in this time of sorrow and joins them in thanking God for the gift of this truly extraordinary man. Peter P. D'Angelo, Chairman, Board of Trustees Rev. Donald J. Harrington, C.M., President

A federal Department of Energy panel issued recommendations on Wednesday for improving the safety and environmental impact of drilling in shale formations for natural gas. In a report on the drilling technique known as hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, that is used currently in most oil and gas wells, the seven-member Natural Gas Subcommittee called for better tracking and more careful disposal of the waste that comes up from wells, stricter standards on air pollution and greenhouse gases associated with drilling, and the creation of a federal database so the public can better monitor drilling operations.

SPERRY--Theodore, died peacefully at age 96, in Sarasota on August 6th with Herta (nee Ungar), his devoted wife of 62 years, by his side. A native of Vienna, Theo lived for 60 years in the New York area. He served proudly with the 2nd New Zealand Expeditionary Force in World War II in Egypt, Greece, and Italy. A graduate of NYU, Ted worked with brokerage firm Fahnestock and co-founded electronics company Fifth Dimension in Princeton. Ted was junior tennis champion and ranked number one in men's doubles in Austria, a ranked Eastern senior player, and a senior doubles competitor at Wimbledon. A USTA volunteer official for over 25 years, Theo was rep to the ITF for senior tennis. Ted was an Emeritus Director of the International Tennis Club of the USA. He was predeceased by daughter Claudia (Michael Kalafer) and granddaughter Nikole and is survived also by daughter Diana (the late William Temple), son Tom, sister Ina Ginsburg, grandchildren Scott, Liz, Justin, and Luisa, four great-grandchildren, and nieces and nephews.

CLAREMON--Ruth. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with deep sadness the passing of Ruth Claremon, beloved wife of Irving. Irving and Ruth have been long-standing supporters, deeply committed to philanthropy in Westchester, New York, and Israel. We extend our condolences to Irving, their children, their grandchildren, and the entire family. Jerry W. Levin, President Alisa R. Doctoroff, Chair of the Board, John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

L ISA PERRY, whose kicky shift dresses appear to have time-traveled from the 1960s archives of André Courrèges, has designed a series of dresses using Roy Lichtenstein images. She incorporated three paintings made available by the Roy Lichtenstein Foundation -- ''Spray'' (1962), ''No Thank You!'' (1964) and ''On'' (1962) -- on silk zibeline. With only 33 of each available, at $2,000, some buyers may wear a dress once, then frame it to hang on the wall. ''It's a very inexpensive way to get a piece of Pop Art,'' Ms. Perry said, laughing. ''Well, much less than the paintings.'' Her $75 T-shirts with ''Hot Dog With Mustard'' (1963), ''Compositions I'' (1964), ''Keds'' (1961) and ''On'' (1962) are more price friendly. The collection goes on sale today at Lisa Perry, 976 Madison Avenue; (212) 334-1956. A portion of the proceeds will go to the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, N.Y.

The actor Alec Baldwin has not yet begun running for mayor of New York, but he is already saying things that could alienate the great number of voters who cannot afford expensive neighborhoods. Describing his decision to live on the Upper West Side, one of the city's wealthier neighborhoods, Mr. Baldwin said in an interview this week with The New York Times that it helped him stay in touch with regular people and that it was ''more real'' and ''seems more middle class'' than other neighborhoods and is ''not a little kind of jewel-box, privileged pocket of the city.''

When the character of Fanny Brice speaks her first lines in ''Funny Girl,'' declaring to her reflection in the mirror, ''Hello, gorgeous,'' it registers as funny because she clearly is not pretty. The words are self-deprecating and bittersweet, and while the audience is in on the joke, it immediately embraces Fanny for owning up to her limitations.

B EAN POLE, the largest clothing brand in South Korea, around since 1989, has only today become available in the United States. It's probably no surprise that the preppy label selected Opening Ceremony, the new import mecca, to sell a collection of men's wear designed in collaboration with Kim Jones. Mr. Jones, who designs the Louis Vuitton men's-wear line, created a youthful and slim-cut collection of fashion-forward basics and playful prints. An electric-hue check shirt jacket, $200, is the quirkiest piece; a two-tone pale blue and white button-down shirt, $175, serves as a tweaked solid; and a shrunken blue cardigan with striped trim, $250, is decidedly geek chic. Bean Pole x Kim Jones is at Opening Ceremony, 35 Howard Street; (212) 219-2688; openingceremony.us.

Most of the world's video is now shot on smartphones, but hardly anyone shares their videos widely. That's partly because it takes too many steps and results in too many error messages, but also because many people aren't convinced their hand-shot clips are worthy of the Internet. Viddy is a relatively new free app for iPhone and iPad (and Android later this year) that spices up mundane video clips of 15 seconds or less with video effects and music soundtracks. The app also makes it easy to share those clips on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Tumblr or a blog, as well as send them around via e-mail or SMS. Or you can bypass the social networks and post directly to a personal account page at Viddy.com that anyone can see.

New York classical music audiences are getting to know the Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer, and that, it turns out, is all to the good. Among other recent appearances, Mr. Fischer conducted the Beethoven symphonies at Lincoln Center last year, dividing them between his own Budapest Festival Orchestra, using modern instruments, and the British period-instrument Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment. Wholly unscientific, the experiment showed, more than anything else, what stirring results Mr. Fischer could achieve in standard fare with an excellent orchestra of any type. And just last week he proved his versatility, providing his own direction for two ambitious ''staged concert'' performances of Mozart's opera ''Don Giovanni'' with the Budapest orchestra, which he also conducted, at the Rose Theater as part of Lincoln Center's Mostly Mozart Festival.

The signature red soles on Christian Louboutin high heels, so famous they inspired a song by Jennifer Lopez and made countless cameos on ''Sex and the City,'' could one day show up on shoes sold at Payless. A judge declined on Wednesday to grant a preliminary injunction requested by Christian Louboutin against Yves Saint Laurent, which was accused of trademark infringement for shoes that featured red soles similar to those of Louboutin's. The decision not only cleared the way for Saint Laurent to continue producing its shoes, but also seemed to give coverage to other shoe manufacturers that may want to add a scarlet underpinning to theirs.

KUBIK--Kamil, of Union City, NJ, from February 9, 1930 to August 3, 2011. Defecting from his home country of Czechoslovakia in 1948 when the Communists seized power, he would become known as "Master of Cityscapes", known internationally for his street scenes, cityscapes and magnificent florals, memorializing royal weddings and inaugurations on his canvas pieces. He once said "The most valuable thing I do by being an artist is that I meet many incredible people". Kamil married English-born Prima Ballerina, Joanna W. Bowers in 1955, settling in Australia. Subsequently, they traveled the world, working in Sydney, Canberra, San Francisco, New York, Washington, DC, London, Paris, Germany, and ultimately came to America. They recently celebrated their 56th Wedding Anniversary. He was the official artist for the White House. His work has been chronicled in Business Week and the New York times. Official painter for both the U.S. Open Tennis and Golf championships, he also owned the St. James Gallery on Madison Avenue. He received numerous awards, "New Yorker Of the Year" and "Ellis Island Medal of Honor". His Readers Digest cover in 1972 of the Skating Rink in front of the Plaza was seen by millions. His pastel of Carnegie Hall, the first American poster in China, was presented to the People's Republic by Isaac Stern. He worked with the Ritz-Carlton Hotels, the Greenbrier and the Breakers. His art is included in the private collections of President and Mrs. Laura Bush, Rudolph Giuliani, Prince Rainier of Monaco and Princess Grace, HRH Queen Elizabeth II, Presidents Ford and Johnson and Mr. and Mrs. Charles Scribner. Kamil is survived by his devoted wife of 56 years, Joanna W. Kubik, a sister Irena Egidova, a nephew Kamil Egida and his children, Kamil and Nikolka. Funeral Service on Saturday, 10:00am at Leber Funeral Home, 2000 Kennedy Blvd, Union City, NJ 07087. Interment, Fairview Cemetery, Fairview, NJ. Visitation, Friday 6-8pm at the Funeral Home.

SATURDAY’S PUZZLE — Before anyone accuses me of being a troublemaker, I would like to say that Daniel Okrent is appearing here today as our celebrity guest blogger of his own free will and because he simply loves solving crossword puzzles. His contribution has nothing, and I mean nothing* to do with the fact that TIME Magazine contributor Joel Stein, who appeared here in June (Across Lite, Solution, blog), accused him of being smug or perhaps even too smart for his own good. This is a blog about crossword puzzles, after all, and it would certainly not be appropriate to use this forum to stoke the fires of competitiveness or to provoke two renowned journalists into a public face-off, no matter how much fun I could have doing it.

In an office on Lafayette and East Fourth Streets in the East Village sits Dennis Mykytyn, former hedge fund owner, current record-label owner and, coolest of all for the purposes of this blog, owner of 100 numbers in the 212 area code. He bought them in 2007 for a total of $3,000 when he still had the hedge fund and was moving it from Westchester County to Manhattan. He’s since closed the fund and is using a handful of the numbers for his own purposes and is just sitting on the rest. They are not for sale. Read about him on the Local East Village »

In the first and second installments of our guide to Auto-Tune pop — check them out here and here — we’ve tried to make the case that, when it’s used creatively, Auto-Tune can be a tool for artists, rather than a crutch. But the biggest criticism Auto-Tune’s critics level against it is that it’s the sonic equivalent of plastic surgery or ‘roids, a digital fix that lets lousy singers skip over that whole learning-to-carry-a-tune thing (boring!) and cut straight to pop stardom’s V.I.P. room. And there’s some truth to that — while the listening public’s acceptance of Auto-Tune has undeniably opened up new avenues of expression for rappers and singers, it’s also enabled some of the world’s most annoying famous people to annoy us in new ways. (Note: We mean no disrespect by including Drake here — his Auto-Tune songs are actually pretty great. But he started out as an actor, so technically he belongs in this category. Hopefully the fact that he is a rich, beautiful man will soften the blow.)

Where there’s a solid restaurant, a solid playlist can most likely be found. For this week’s Jam, Sean Hanratty of Santos Party House has chosen Alain Levitt, whohelps run his wife’s Venetian restaurant, Bacaro, in Manhattan’s Chinatown district. “The music is always amazing in there, and the environment and décor is incredible,” saysHanratty, who is a regular at the intimate vento Italian restaurant on Division near Ludlow. “Alain is usually behind the bar smiling and just being wonderful.” Hanratty quickly learned Levitt recently started a “super-high-energy duo, which usually involved costumes” called Bubbles. (Already, Levitt’s synth-pop outfit with the vocalist Jason Grisell has opened up for Florence and the Machine at Central Park Summerstage and played on a boat with Gang Gang Dance.) The band, who says they “just want to make everyone dance,” is hard at work on a new release. “I knew Alain’s playlist would be a super-diverse set, with songs I personally have always gravitated towards,” says Hanratty of the beat maker who hails from California. Check out Bubbles in the basement of Santos tonight.

Call them the ones that got away. Spring 2009: Ann Demeulemeester’s open-toe lace-up heels came down the runway and the quiet, almost suspicious stirring that precedes a full-blown frenzy began. Everyone wanted them. And, why wouldn’t they: hefty heel, combat-boot-like lacing that left just the right amount of skin showing, options in black or brown leather. But despite the hype — countless credits in fashion magazines, followed by colleagues professing how comfortable they were while wearing them with everything from jean shorts to Sunday dresses — I didn’t buy a pair. My reason (aside from the $965 price tag)? I wasn’t going to let myself fall for another of-the-moment shoe.

In Los Angeles, everyone’s a hybrid. Caterer-dancer. Shop girl-singer. Bartender-drama student. Take Justin Kern: model, screenwriter and now fashion designer. Kern and his partner, Stephanie Danan, film producer and fashion designer, have founded Co, a collection of luxurious mega-basics: slip dresses, silk tanks and skirts, L.B.D.’s, skinny leather pants and the kind of big old fancy furs that Margot Tenenbaum would adore. The Royal Tenenbaum, in fact, is the personification of the Co customer — a woman who pictures herself in a variety of cinematic situations. To illuminate this idea, Kern and Danan (far right) collaborated with the actress Élodie Bouchez and the director Thomas Bangalter of Daft Punk on a four-minute film that they describe as a period piece with a sci-fi twist. (The film will have its premiere on T’s Web site during Fashion Week.) “We wanted to give the clothes an identity through the characters that we imagine inhabiting them,” Danan says. Margot, fictional character-muse, are you listening?

We’re singing the praises — in weird high-pitched computer voices, naturally — of Auto-Tune, the much-maligned and increasingly ubiquitous vocal-processing technology that’s become one of the defining sounds of 21st-century pop. Yesterday, we discussed the Auto-Tune pioneer Cher and the now-ex-Auto-Tune-superfan T-Pain, who brought the technology into diva-driven dance music and hip-hop, and Kanye West’s album “808s and Heartbreak,” on which a lovelorn millionaire used Auto-Tune to make people feel as sad for him as they did for Wall-E. Today, a few examples of how rappers, reggae singers, futuristic party-girls, D.J.’s and cartoon rodents have used and abused Auto-Tune in ways undreamt of by its creators. Plus: Ne-Yo gets cranky!

From heat waves to hurricanes, August can be a month for dangerous weather. Smartphone owners have several custom app choices for getting a steady flow of weather-related information, but any phone with a Web browser and Internet connection can also get important storm alerts, forecasts and updates. For example, most of the major weather-focused Web sites offer streamlined versions for mobile users — just point the phone’s browser to sites like m.accuweather.com, m.weather.com or m.weatherbug.com for a quick look at the latest conditions. If you do not want to keep checking an app or site, you can also have the information find you when a storm is coming. Some commercial sites like Weather.com offer free e-mail or text-message alerts, as does the National Weather Service.
